anchors.text: Acquisition refers to the initial learning phase during which the conditioned response is established. Several factors influence the strength and speed of acquisition:
Temporal Contiguity: The CS and US must occur close together in time. The optimal interval varies by response system but is typically 0.5 seconds for many conditioned responses.
Contingency: The CS must reliably predict the US. If the US occurs equally often with and without the CS, conditioning will not occur despite temporal pairing.
CS-US Intensity: Stronger unconditioned stimuli generally produce faster and stronger conditioning.

Delay conditioning is the most effective temporal arrangement for establishing conditioned responses. In this procedure, the CS begins before the US and continues until the US is presented. The CS "overlaps" with the US onset, creating optimal conditions for association formation.

Research consistently demonstrates that delay conditioning produces more robust learning than trace conditioning (where a gap exists between CS offset and US onset) or simultaneous conditioning (where CS and US begin at the same time).

Example: A child is bitten by a dog (US) while at a park. The pain from the bite naturally produces fear (UR). The visual appearance of dogs (CS) was present just before and during the bite. After this single pairing (one-trial learning), the child now experiences fear (CR) when seeing any dog. The temporal relationship - seeing the dog immediately before and during the painful bite - exemplifies delay conditioning producing rapid fear acquisition.

anchors.text: Extinction occurs when the conditioned stimulus is repeatedly presented without the unconditioned stimulus. Over time, the conditioned response weakens and eventually ceases. However, extinction does not erase the original learning; rather, it represents new inhibitory learning that suppresses the conditioned response.

Evidence for this interpretation comes from spontaneous recovery - the reappearance of the extinguished conditioned response after a rest period. When time passes following extinction training, the CR often returns at partial strength when the CS is presented again. This phenomenon demonstrates that extinction does not eliminate the original CS-US association but instead creates a competing inhibitory association.
Additional phenomena supporting the "new learning" view of extinction include:
Renewal: The CR returns when testing occurs in a context different from the extinction context
Reinstatement: The CR returns after unpaired US presentations following extinction
Rapid reacquisition: Reconditioning after extinction occurs faster than original acquisition

The context-dependence of extinction has important implications for exposure therapy. Fear extinguished in a therapist's office may return when the client encounters the feared stimulus in different contexts. Effective treatment should include exposure in multiple contexts to promote generalization of extinction learning.

However, extinction does not erase the original learning; rather, it represents new inhibitory learning that suppresses the conditioned response.
[002] Evidence for this interpretation comes from spontaneous recovery - the reappearance of the extinguished conditioned response after a rest period. When time passes following extinction training, the CR often returns at partial strength when the CS is presented again. This phenomenon demonstrates that extinction does not eliminate the original CS-US association but instead creates a competing inhibitory association.
[003] Additional phenomena supporting the "new learning" view of extinction include:
[004] Renewal: The CR returns when testing occurs in a context different from the extinction context
[005] Reinstatement: The CR returns after unpaired US presentations following extinction
[006] Rapid reacquisition: Reconditioning after extinction occurs faster than original acquisition
[007] The context-dependence of extinction has important implications for exposure therapy. Fear extinguished in a therapist's office may return when the client encounters the feared stimulus in different contexts. Effective treatment should include exposure in multiple contexts to promote generalization of extinction learning.

anchors.text: Stimulus generalization occurs when stimuli similar to the original CS also elicit the conditioned response. The degree of generalization typically follows a gradient - stimuli more similar to the original CS elicit stronger responses than dissimilar stimuli.

Stimulus discrimination is the opposite process - learning to respond differently to stimuli that differ from the original CS. Discrimination training involves reinforcing (pairing with the US) responses to one stimulus (CS+) while not reinforcing responses to similar stimuli (CS-).

Example: Watson and Rayner's famous demonstration with "Little Albert" illustrated both fear conditioning and stimulus generalization. After conditioning fear to a white rat (CS) by pairing it with a loud noise (US), Albert showed fear responses not only to the rat but also to a rabbit, a dog, a fur coat, and even a Santa Claus mask - stimuli that shared the white, furry characteristics of the original CS. This generalization occurred despite these stimuli never being directly paired with the aversive noise.

[003] Example: Watson and Rayner's famous demonstration with "Little Albert" illustrated both fear conditioning and stimulus generalization. After conditioning fear to a white rat (CS) by pairing it with a loud noise (US), Albert showed fear responses not only to the rat but also to a rabbit, a dog, a fur coat, and even a Santa Claus mask - stimuli that shared the white, furry characteristics of the original CS. This generalization occurred despite these stimuli never being directly paired with the aversive noise.

anchors.text: Higher-order conditioning (also called second-order conditioning) occurs when a well-established CS is used to condition a response to a new neutral stimulus, without further US presentations. In this procedure:
First, CS1 is paired with the US until a strong CR is established
Then, a new neutral stimulus (CS2) is paired with CS1
CS2 eventually elicits a CR, despite never being directly paired with the US

Higher-order conditioning is generally weaker than first-order conditioning and is susceptible to extinction. However, it provides a mechanism for explaining how complex associative networks develop and how fears can spread to stimuli never directly associated with trauma.

anchors_text:
[001] Higher-order conditioning (also called second-order conditioning) occurs when a well-established CS is used to condition a response to a new neutral stimulus, without further US presentations. In this procedure:
[002] First, CS1 is paired with the US until a strong CR is established
[003] Then, a new neutral stimulus (CS2) is paired with CS1
[004] CS2 eventually elicits a CR, despite never being directly paired with the US
[005] Higher-order conditioning is generally weaker than first-order conditioning and is susceptible to extinction. However, it provides a mechanism for explaining how complex associative networks develop and how fears can spread to stimuli never directly associated with trauma.

anchors.text: The blocking phenomenon, discovered by Leon Kamin, demonstrated that mere temporal contiguity between CS and US is insufficient for conditioning. In blocking experiments:
CS1 (e.g., a light) is first conditioned to the US
Then, CS1 and a new stimulus CS2 (e.g., a tone) are presented together and paired with the US
When CS2 is tested alone, little or no conditioning is observed

The prior conditioning to CS1 "blocks" new learning to CS2, even though CS2 was paired with the US. This finding led to the influential Rescorla-Wagner model, which proposes that conditioning occurs only when the US is unexpected or surprising.

anchors_text:
[001] The blocking phenomenon, discovered by Leon Kamin, demonstrated that mere temporal contiguity between CS and US is insufficient for conditioning. In blocking experiments:
[002] CS1 (e.g., a light) is first conditioned to the US
[003] Then, CS1 and a new stimulus CS2 (e.g., a tone) are presented together and paired with the US
[004] When CS2 is tested alone, little or no conditioning is observed
[005] The prior conditioning to CS1 "blocks" new learning to CS2, even though CS2 was paired with the US. This finding led to the influential Rescorla-Wagner model, which proposes that conditioning occurs only when the US is unexpected or surprising.

anchors.text: Overshadowing occurs when two stimuli are presented together as a compound CS, and conditioning to the more salient stimulus interferes with conditioning to the less salient stimulus. Unlike blocking, overshadowing occurs with simultaneous conditioning and does not require prior training with one element.

For example, if a bright light and soft tone are presented together before a shock, the more salient bright light may overshadow the tone, resulting in strong conditioning to the light but weak conditioning to the tone. This phenomenon has implications for understanding why some trauma cues become strongly associated with fear while others do not.

[001] Overshadowing occurs when two stimuli are presented together as a compound CS, and conditioning to the more salient stimulus interferes with conditioning to the less salient stimulus. Unlike blocking, overshadowing occurs with simultaneous conditioning and does not require prior training with one element.
[002] For example, if a bright light and soft tone are presented together before a shock, the more salient bright light may overshadow the tone, resulting in strong conditioning to the light but weak conditioning to the tone. This phenomenon has implications for understanding why some trauma cues become strongly associated with fear while others do not.

anchors.text: Pavlov observed that when discrimination training becomes too difficult - when the CS+ and CS- become increasingly similar - animals may develop behavioral disturbances including agitation, aggression, and stereotyped behaviors. He termed this experimental neurosis.

This phenomenon has been considered a model for understanding how chronic stress and unpredictable environments may contribute to anxiety and other psychological disorders. When organisms cannot reliably predict safety versus threat, chronic arousal and maladaptive behaviors may emerge.

section_title: Biological Preparedness and Constraints on Learning

anchors.text: Garcia and Koelling demonstrated that rats easily learn to avoid flavors (but not audiovisual cues) paired with illness, while they easily learn to avoid audiovisual cues (but not flavors) paired with shock. This selective association suggests that organisms are biologically prepared to form certain associations more readily than others.

Taste aversion learning also violates typical temporal contiguity requirements - illness occurring hours after food consumption can still produce strong conditioned aversions. This makes adaptive sense, as food poisoning typically has delayed effects.

[002] Taste aversion learning also violates typical temporal contiguity requirements - illness occurring hours after food consumption can still produce strong conditioned aversions. This makes adaptive sense, as food poisoning typically has delayed effects.

section_title: Biological Preparedness and Constraints on Learning

anchors.text: Seligman's preparedness theory proposes that humans are biologically prepared to rapidly acquire fears of stimuli that posed threats throughout evolutionary history - snakes, spiders, heights, darkness, enclosed spaces, and social scrutiny. These "prepared" fears are:
Acquired more rapidly (sometimes in single trials)
More resistant to extinction
Less affected by cognitive information
More likely to become clinical phobias

In contrast, fears of evolutionarily recent threats (cars, electrical outlets, guns) are relatively rare despite causing more deaths in modern society. This preparedness may explain the non-random distribution of phobias in clinical populations.

anchors.text: While the conditioned response often resembles the unconditioned response, they are not identical. The CR is typically:
Weaker in magnitude than the UR
Longer in latency (slower to begin)
Sometimes different in form (compensatory CRs)

anchors_text:
[001] While the conditioned response often resembles the unconditioned response, they are not identical. The CR is typically:
[002] Weaker in magnitude than the UR
[003] Longer in latency (slower to begin)
[004] Sometimes different in form (compensatory CRs)

anchors.text: In some cases, particularly with drug conditioning, the CR may be opposite in direction to the UR. For example, when morphine (US) is repeatedly administered in a particular environment (CS), the body develops tolerance by producing physiological responses that counteract the drug's effects. These conditioned compensatory responses are triggered by environmental cues associated with drug administration.

This phenomenon has important implications for drug tolerance and overdose. When drugs are administered in novel environments lacking the conditioned compensatory responses, the full drug effect is experienced, potentially leading to overdose at doses that would be tolerated in familiar settings.

Siegel's research explains why many drug overdoses occur when users take their typical dose in unfamiliar environments. The novel context lacks the conditioned cues that normally trigger compensatory responses, resulting in an unexpectedly powerful drug effect. This underscores the importance of contextual factors in substance use treatment.

anchors.text: Developed by Joseph Wolpe, systematic desensitization uses counterconditioning to treat phobias. The procedure involves:
Training the client in relaxation techniques
Constructing a fear hierarchy from least to most anxiety-provoking
Pairing each hierarchy item with relaxation (reciprocal inhibition)
Progressing through the hierarchy until the most feared item can be imagined while relaxed

[004] Pairing each hierarchy item with relaxation (reciprocal inhibition)
[005] Progressing through the hierarchy until the most feared item can be imagined while relaxed

anchors.text: Modern exposure-based treatments emphasize extinction learning rather than counterconditioning. Prolonged exposure to feared stimuli without the feared outcome allows extinction of the fear response. Key principles include:
Exposure must be prolonged enough for fear reduction to occur
Multiple contexts enhance generalization of extinction
Variability in exposure parameters may enhance long-term outcomes
Cognitive changes (expectancy violation) may be more important than within-session fear reduction

anchors.text: The Pearson r is the most commonly used correlation coefficient and is appropriate when both variables are measured on interval or ratio scales and the relationship is linear. The Pearson r measures the degree to which data points fall on a straight line.
Assumptions for Pearson r include:
Both variables are continuous (interval or ratio scale)
The relationship between variables is linear
Both variables are normally distributed (for significance testing)
Homoscedasticity: variance is similar across the range of scores

[002] Assumptions for Pearson r include:
[003] Both variables are continuous (interval or ratio scale)
[004] The relationship between variables is linear
[005] Both variables are normally distributed (for significance testing)
[006] Homoscedasticity: variance is similar across the range of scores

anchors.text: The phi coefficient (φ) is used when both variables are true dichotomies. It is commonly used in 2×2 contingency tables and is related to chi-square statistics.
Both continuous: Pearson r (if linear) or Spearman rho (if non-linear or ordinal)
One continuous, one dichotomous: Point-biserial correlation
Both dichotomous: Phi coefficient
Both ordinal: Spearman rho

anchors.text: The absolute value of the correlation coefficient indicates the strength of the relationship. Cohen provided widely used guidelines for interpreting effect sizes in behavioral sciences:
.10 to .29 — Small (weak)
.30 to .49 — Medium (moderate)
.50 and above — Large (strong)

However, these guidelines should be interpreted in context. In some research areas (e.g., personality psychology), correlations of .30 are considered substantial, while in others (e.g., test-retest reliability), correlations below .80 might be considered inadequate.

anchors_text:
[001] The absolute value of the correlation coefficient indicates the strength of the relationship. Cohen provided widely used guidelines for interpreting effect sizes in behavioral sciences:
[002] .10 to .29 — Small (weak)
[003] .30 to .49 — Medium (moderate)
[004] .50 and above — Large (strong)
[005] However, these guidelines should be interpreted in context. In some research areas (e.g., personality psychology), correlations of .30 are considered substantial, while in others (e.g., test-retest reliability), correlations below .80 might be considered inadequate.

anchors.text: The coefficient of determination (r²) is obtained by squaring the correlation coefficient. It represents the proportion of variance in one variable that is explained by (or shared with) the other variable. This is also referred to as shared variance or common variance.

Example: If the correlation between SAT scores and college GPA is r = .50, then r² = .25. This means that 25% of the variance in college GPA can be explained by SAT scores. Conversely, 75% of the variance in GPA is due to other factors not captured by SAT scores. This interpretation helps put correlation coefficients in practical perspective.

[001] The coefficient of determination (r²) is obtained by squaring the correlation coefficient. It represents the proportion of variance in one variable that is explained by (or shared with) the other variable. This is also referred to as shared variance or common variance.
[002] Example: If the correlation between SAT scores and college GPA is r = .50, then r² = .25. This means that 25% of the variance in college GPA can be explained by SAT scores. Conversely, 75% of the variance in GPA is due to other factors not captured by SAT scores. This interpretation helps put correlation coefficients in practical perspective.

anchors.text: Restriction of range occurs when the variability in one or both variables is limited compared to the full population. This artificial restriction attenuates (reduces) the observed correlation coefficient. When range is restricted, correlations appear weaker than they would be in the unrestricted population.

Example: A company uses a cognitive ability test to select employees, hiring only those who score above the 75th percentile. When later examining the correlation between test scores and job performance among hired employees, they find a modest correlation of r = .20. However, if they could have studied all applicants (unrestricted range), the correlation might be r = .50. The selection process restricted the range of test scores, attenuating the observed validity coefficient.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Relationships in Data: Correlation & Regression > Factors Affecting Correlation > Restriction of Range
anchors_text:
[001] Restriction of range occurs when the variability in one or both variables is limited compared to the full population. This artificial restriction attenuates (reduces) the observed correlation coefficient. When range is restricted, correlations appear weaker than they would be in the unrestricted population.
[002] Example: A company uses a cognitive ability test to select employees, hiring only those who score above the 75th percentile. When later examining the correlation between test scores and job performance among hired employees, they find a modest correlation of r = .20. However, if they could have studied all applicants (unrestricted range), the correlation might be r = .50. The selection process restricted the range of test scores, attenuating the observed validity coefficient.

anchors.text: Heteroscedasticity occurs when the variability of one variable differs across levels of the other variable. For example, the variance in job performance might be larger for people with low test scores than for people with high scores. This violates an assumption of Pearson's r and can affect the accuracy of the correlation coefficient.

Understanding factors that affect correlation is critical for interpreting validity studies. When a test shows lower validity in clinical samples than in research samples, restriction of range may be responsible. Clinicians should consider whether the validation sample is representative of the population they serve.

For example, the variance in job performance might be larger for people with low test scores than for people with high scores. This violates an assumption of Pearson's r and can affect the accuracy of the correlation coefficient.
[002] Understanding factors that affect correlation is critical for interpreting validity studies. When a test shows lower validity in clinical samples than in research samples, restriction of range may be responsible. Clinicians should consider whether the validation sample is representative of the population they serve.

anchors.text: The simple linear regression equation is: Y' = a + bX
Y' (Y-prime): The predicted score on the criterion variable
a: The Y-intercept (the value of Y when X = 0)
b: The slope (regression coefficient) indicating the change in Y for each one-unit change in X
X: The score on the predictor variable
The regression line is the "line of best fit" that minimizes the sum of squared errors (differences between actual and predicted Y values). This is called the least squares criterion.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Relationships in Data: Correlation & Regression > Simple Linear Regression > The Regression Equation
anchors_text:
[001] The simple linear regression equation is: Y' = a + bX
[002] Y' (Y-prime): The predicted score on the criterion variable
[003] a: The Y-intercept (the value of Y when X = 0)
[004] b: The slope (regression coefficient) indicating the change in Y for each one-unit change in X
[005] X: The score on the predictor variable
[006] The regression line is the "line of best fit" that minimizes the sum of squared errors (differences between actual and predicted Y values). This is called the least squares criterion.

anchors.text: The standard error of estimate (SEE) quantifies the average amount of error in predictions made from the regression equation. It represents the standard deviation of the residuals (prediction errors). A smaller SEE indicates more accurate predictions.

The relationship between SEE and correlation is: as r increases, SEE decreases. When r = 1.00 (perfect correlation), SEE = 0 (no prediction error). When r = 0, the SEE equals the standard deviation of the Y variable (knowing X provides no improvement over just guessing the mean of Y).
Predictor Variable (X): The variable used to make predictions; also called the independent variable in regression.
Criterion Variable (Y): The variable being predicted; also called the dependent variable in regression.
Residual: The difference between the actual Y score and the predicted Y score (Y - Y').
SEE: The standard deviation of the residuals; indicates prediction accuracy.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Relationships in Data: Correlation & Regression > Simple Linear Regression > Standard Error of Estimate
anchors_text:
[001] The standard error of estimate (SEE) quantifies the average amount of error in predictions made from the regression equation. It represents the standard deviation of the residuals (prediction errors). A smaller SEE indicates more accurate predictions.
[002] The relationship between SEE and correlation is: as r increases, SEE decreases. When r = 1.00 (perfect correlation), SEE = 0 (no prediction error). When r = 0, the SEE equals the standard deviation of the Y variable (knowing X provides no improvement over just guessing the mean of Y).
[003] Predictor Variable (X): The variable used to make predictions; also called the independent variable in regression.
[004] Criterion Variable (Y): The variable being predicted; also called the dependent variable in regression.
[005] Residual: The difference between the actual Y score and the predicted Y score (Y - Y').
[006] SEE: The standard deviation of the residuals; indicates prediction accuracy.

anchors.text: The multiple correlation coefficient (R) indicates the correlation between the actual criterion scores and the predicted scores from the multiple regression equation. R ranges from 0 to 1.00 (it is always positive because it represents the correlation between actual and predicted values).

R² indicates the proportion of variance in the criterion variable explained by the combination of all predictor variables. R² always increases (or stays the same) when additional predictors are added, even if those predictors have no true relationship with the criterion. For this reason, adjusted R² is often reported, which accounts for the number of predictors and sample size.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Relationships in Data: Correlation & Regression > Multiple Regression > Multiple Correlation Coefficient (R)
anchors_text:
[001] The multiple correlation coefficient (R) indicates the correlation between the actual criterion scores and the predicted scores from the multiple regression equation. R ranges from 0 to 1.00 (it is always positive because it represents the correlation between actual and predicted values).
[002] R² indicates the proportion of variance in the criterion variable explained by the combination of all predictor variables. R² always increases (or stays the same) when additional predictors are added, even if those predictors have no true relationship with the criterion. For this reason, adjusted R² is often reported, which accounts for the number of predictors and sample size.

anchors.text: Incremental validity refers to the additional predictive power provided by adding a new predictor to an existing set of predictors. A predictor has incremental validity if it significantly increases R² beyond what existing predictors already explain. This concept is important in personnel selection and clinical assessment when evaluating whether adding a new test improves prediction.

Example: A researcher examines whether a new anxiety questionnaire adds predictive value for treatment outcomes beyond existing measures. A regression using only the BDI-II yields R² = .30. Adding the new anxiety measure increases R² to .38. The increment of .08 (8% additional variance explained) represents the incremental validity of the new measure. Statistical tests can determine whether this increment is significant.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Relationships in Data: Correlation & Regression > Multiple Regression > Incremental Validity
anchors_text:
[001] Incremental validity refers to the additional predictive power provided by adding a new predictor to an existing set of predictors. A predictor has incremental validity if it significantly increases R² beyond what existing predictors already explain. This concept is important in personnel selection and clinical assessment when evaluating whether adding a new test improves prediction.
[002] Example: A researcher examines whether a new anxiety questionnaire adds predictive value for treatment outcomes beyond existing measures. A regression using only the BDI-II yields R² = .30. Adding the new anxiety measure increases R² to .38. The increment of .08 (8% additional variance explained) represents the incremental validity of the new measure. Statistical tests can determine whether this increment is significant.

anchors.text: Meta-analysis is a quantitative method for systematically combining results from multiple studies to arrive at an overall estimate of an effect. Unlike a narrative literature review, meta-analysis uses statistical techniques to integrate findings, weight studies by quality or sample size, and assess variability across studies. Correlation coefficients can be converted to other effect size metrics and combined to estimate population-level relationships while accounting for sampling error and study artifacts.

The foundation of meta-analysis is the effect size—a standardized measure of the magnitude of an effect that can be compared across studies with different scales and designs. Common effect size metrics include Cohen's d (standardized mean difference), Pearson's r (correlation), and odds ratios (for binary outcomes). Each study's effect size is calculated and then combined into a weighted average, with larger studies typically receiving more weight.

Fixed effects model: Assumes all studies estimate the same underlying true effect size. Differences between studies are attributed solely to sampling error. Appropriate when studies are very similar in design, population, and intervention. Inferences are limited to the specific studies included.

Random effects model: Assumes that true effect sizes vary across studies due to differences in populations, methods, and contexts. Accounts for both within-study sampling error and between-study variability. Generally preferred in psychological research because studies are rarely identical in all respects. Produces wider confidence intervals than fixed effects models.

A forest plot is the standard graphical display of meta-analytic results. Each study is represented by a horizontal line (confidence interval) with a square at the point estimate (the square's size reflects the study's weight). The overall combined estimate is displayed as a diamond at the bottom. Forest plots allow readers to visually assess the consistency and direction of effects across studies.
Heterogeneity refers to variability in effect sizes across studies beyond what would be expected from sampling error alone. Key measures include:
Q statistic: Tests whether observed variability exceeds chance; a significant Q indicates heterogeneity is present

I² statistic: Quantifies the percentage of variability due to true differences between studies rather than sampling error. Values of 25%, 50%, and 75% are considered low, moderate, and high heterogeneity, respectively

When substantial heterogeneity exists, researchers conduct moderator analysis (also called subgroup analysis or meta-regression) to identify variables that explain why effect sizes differ across studies (e.g., type of intervention, participant age, study quality).

Publication bias (also called the "file drawer problem") occurs when studies with statistically significant results are more likely to be published than studies with null findings. This can inflate meta-analytic effect size estimates because non-significant studies are missing from the analysis.

Funnel plot: A scatter plot of effect sizes (x-axis) against study precision or sample size (y-axis). In the absence of bias, the plot should be symmetrical around the mean effect. Asymmetry (missing studies in the lower-left corner) suggests publication bias.

File drawer problem (Rosenthal): Refers to the unknown number of unpublished studies with null findings "sitting in file drawers." Rosenthal's fail-safe N estimates how many null studies would need to exist to reduce the combined effect to non-significance.
Trim and fill method: Statistically estimates and corrects for missing studies in an asymmetric funnel plot

Meta-analyses are considered among the highest levels of evidence in evidence-based practice hierarchies. They inform clinical practice guidelines (e.g., APA treatment guidelines), resolve conflicting findings across individual studies, and provide more precise effect size estimates than any single study. However, the quality of a meta-analysis depends on the quality and representativeness of the included studies—"garbage in, garbage out."

anchors.text: Predictive validity is demonstrated when test scores predict future performance on a criterion measured at a later time. This is the most important type of criterion-related validity for selection decisions, as it addresses the practical question: "How well does this test predict future outcomes?"

Example: An admissions test administered to graduate school applicants is used to predict first-year GPA. A correlation of .45 between admission test scores and subsequent GPA demonstrates predictive validity. The test provides useful information about likely academic performance, though the moderate correlation indicates other factors also influence success.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Predicting Outcomes: Criterion-Related Validity > Predictive and Concurrent Validity > Predictive Validity
anchors_text:
[001] Predictive validity is demonstrated when test scores predict future performance on a criterion measured at a later time. This is the most important type of criterion-related validity for selection decisions, as it addresses the practical question: "How well does this test predict future outcomes?"
[002] Example: An admissions test administered to graduate school applicants is used to predict first-year GPA. A correlation of .45 between admission test scores and subsequent GPA demonstrates predictive validity. The test provides useful information about likely academic performance, though the moderate correlation indicates other factors also influence success.

anchors.text: Concurrent validity is demonstrated when test scores correlate with a criterion measured at approximately the same time. This approach is often used when developing a shorter or more efficient assessment to replace a longer criterion measure, or when establishing that a new test measures the same construct as an established instrument.
Timing — Criterion measured later — Criterion measured simultaneously
Purpose — Forecast future outcomes — Substitute for existing measure
Sample — Applicants/candidates — Current group members
Limitation — Time-consuming, attrition — May not generalize to prediction
Predictive validity is preferred for selection/admissions decisions where forecasting future performance is the goal
Concurrent validity is appropriate when substituting one measure for another, screening, or diagnosis where the criterion is currently observable
Concurrent validity evidence should not be assumed to generalize to predictive contexts without additional investigation

anchors.text: Restriction of range occurs when the variability of scores in the validation sample is less than in the applicant population. This commonly happens in predictive validity studies when only those who score above a cutoff are selected, reducing the range of predictor scores available for validation. Range restriction attenuates the observed validity coefficient.

Example: A company uses a cognitive ability test to select employees, hiring only those who score above the 70th percentile. When validating the test against job performance, only selected employees (those with high scores) are available. The restricted range of test scores reduces the observed validity coefficient. Statistical corrections can estimate what the validity would be in the full applicant population.

This commonly happens in predictive validity studies when only those who score above a cutoff are selected, reducing the range of predictor scores available for validation. [002] Example: A company uses a cognitive ability test to select employees, hiring only those who score above the 70th percentile. When validating the test against job performance, only selected employees (those with high scores) are available. The restricted range of test scores reduces the observed validity coefficient. Statistical corrections can estimate what the validity would be in the full applicant population.

anchors.text: Unreliability in either the predictor or criterion attenuates the validity coefficient. The correction for attenuation formula estimates what validity would be if both measures were perfectly reliable:
rxy(corrected) = rxy / √(rxx × ryy)

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Predicting Outcomes: Criterion-Related Validity > Factors Affecting Validity Coefficients > Unreliability
anchors_text:
[001] Unreliability in either the predictor or criterion attenuates the validity coefficient. The correction for attenuation formula estimates what validity would be if both measures were perfectly reliable:
[002] rxy(corrected) = rxy / √(rxx × ryy)

anchors.text: The base rate is the proportion of people in the population who would succeed on the criterion without selection (or who have the condition being assessed). Base rate affects how much a test can improve upon chance prediction.
Very high base rate (e.g., 90%): Most people succeed; test has little room to improve prediction
Very low base rate (e.g., 10%): Most people fail/don't have condition; predicting "no" is often correct
Moderate base rate (around 50%): Maximum opportunity for test to improve prediction

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Predicting Outcomes: Criterion-Related Validity > Base Rates and Selection Ratios > Base Rate
anchors_text:
[001] The base rate is the proportion of people in the population who would succeed on the criterion without selection (or who have the condition being assessed). Base rate affects how much a test can improve upon chance prediction.
[002] Very high base rate (e.g., 90%): Most people succeed; test has little room to improve prediction
[003] Very low base rate (e.g., 10%): Most people fail/don't have condition; predicting "no" is often correct
[004] Moderate base rate (around 50%): Maximum opportunity for test to improve prediction

anchors.text: The selection ratio is the proportion of applicants who are selected. A lower selection ratio (selecting fewer applicants) allows for selecting only those with the highest scores, potentially improving outcomes but reducing the number selected.

Example: Taylor and Russell developed tables showing the expected success rate given different combinations of validity coefficient, base rate, and selection ratio. These tables demonstrate that even tests with modest validity can substantially improve selection outcomes when base rates are moderate and selection ratios are low.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Predicting Outcomes: Criterion-Related Validity > Base Rates and Selection Ratios > Selection Ratio

[002] Example: Taylor and Russell developed tables showing the expected success rate given different combinations of validity coefficient, base rate, and selection ratio. These tables demonstrate that even tests with modest validity can substantially improve selection outcomes when base rates are moderate and selection ratios are low.

anchors.text: Specificity (also called true negative rate) is the proportion of people without the condition who test negative. It indicates how well the test correctly identifies the absence of the condition.

Example: A depression screening test is administered to 1,000 patients. Of 200 who actually have depression, 180 test positive (sensitivity = 180/200 = 90%). Of 800 without depression, 720 test negative (specificity = 720/800 = 90%). The test correctly identifies 90% of depressed patients and 90% of non-depressed patients.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Predicting Outcomes: Criterion-Related Validity > Sensitivity and Specificity > Specificity
anchors_text:
[001] Specificity (also called true negative rate) is the proportion of people without the condition who test negative. It indicates how well the test correctly identifies the absence of the condition.
[002] Example: A depression screening test is administered to 1,000 patients. Of 200 who actually have depression, 180 test positive (sensitivity = 180/200 = 90%). Of 800 without depression, 720 test negative (specificity = 720/800 = 90%). The test correctly identifies 90% of depressed patients and 90% of non-depressed patients.

anchors.text: While sensitivity and specificity describe test performance, clinicians often need to know: "Given a positive (or negative) test result, what is the probability the person has (or doesn't have) the condition?"
Positive Predictive Value (PPV) is the proportion of positive test results that are true positives:
Negative Predictive Value (NPV) is the proportion of negative test results that are true negatives:
When base rate is low, PPV is low (most positives are false positives) even with good sensitivity/specificity
When base rate is high, NPV is low (most negatives are false negatives)
This is why screening tests in low-prevalence populations often require confirmation testing

[003] Negative Predictive Value (NPV) is the proportion of negative test results that are true negatives:

anchors.text: Treatment selection: Does the test help match patients to effective treatments?
Outcome prediction: Does the test predict who will benefit from intervention?
Progress monitoring: Is the test sensitive to changes during treatment?
Cost-effectiveness: Do the benefits of testing justify the costs?
Does use of this test lead to different clinical decisions than would be made without it?
Do those different decisions result in better patient outcomes?
Is the test feasible to administer in typical clinical settings?
Is the test acceptable to patients and clinicians?

[006] Do those different decisions result in better patient outcomes?
[007] Is the test feasible to administer in typical clinical settings?
[008] Is the test acceptable to patients and clinicians?

anchors.text: Lowering the cutoff score increases sensitivity but decreases specificity (more true positives but also more false positives). Raising the cutoff increases specificity but decreases sensitivity (fewer false positives but also more false negatives).
↑ Sensitivity (more true positives) — ↑ Specificity (more true negatives)
↓ Specificity (more false positives) — ↓ Sensitivity (more false negatives)
Best when missing a case is costly — Best when false alarms are costly

Example: For a suicide risk screening, a lower cutoff is appropriate because the cost of missing someone at risk (false negative) is much greater than the cost of additional evaluation for someone not at risk (false positive). For a highly invasive or stigmatizing diagnosis, a higher cutoff might be preferred to minimize false positives.

[003] ↓ Specificity (more false positives) — ↓ Sensitivity (more false negatives)

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics

anchors.text: The null hypothesis (H₀) states that there is no effect, no difference, or no relationship in the population. It represents the status quo or the assumption of "no change." The null hypothesis is what we attempt to reject through statistical testing.

The alternative hypothesis (H₁ or Hₐ) states that there is an effect, difference, or relationship. It represents what the researcher typically hopes to demonstrate. The alternative hypothesis can be directional (one-tailed) or non-directional (two-tailed).

Example: A researcher wants to test whether a new therapy reduces depression scores compared to a control condition. H₀: There is no difference in depression scores between the therapy and control groups (μ₁ = μ₂) H₁: The therapy group has lower depression scores than the control group (μ₁ < μ₂) — directional/one-tailed H₁: There is a difference in depression scores between groups (μ₁ ≠ μ₂) — non-directional/two-tailed

anchors_text:
[001] The null hypothesis (H₀) states that there is no effect, no difference, or no relationship in the population. It represents the status quo or the assumption of "no change." The null hypothesis is what we attempt to reject through statistical testing.
[002] The alternative hypothesis (H₁ or Hₐ) states that there is an effect, difference, or relationship. It represents what the researcher typically hopes to demonstrate. The alternative hypothesis can be directional (one-tailed) or non-directional (two-tailed).
[003] Example: A researcher wants to test whether a new therapy reduces depression scores compared to a control condition. H₀: There is no difference in depression scores between the therapy and control groups (μ₁ = μ₂) H₁: The therapy group has lower depression scores than the control group (μ₁ < μ₂) — directional/one-tailed H₁: There is a difference in depression scores between groups (μ₁ ≠ μ₂) — non-directional/two-tailed

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics

anchors.text: The p-value is the probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as those observed, assuming the null hypothesis is true. If p ≤ α, the result is considered statistically significant, and we reject the null hypothesis. If p > α, we fail to reject the null hypothesis.

The p-value is NOT the probability that the null hypothesis is true. It is the probability of the data (or more extreme data) given that the null hypothesis is true. This distinction is commonly misunderstood and frequently tested on the EPPP.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics > Hypothesis Testing Framework > p-Values
anchors_text:
[001] The p-value is the probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as those observed, assuming the null hypothesis is true. If p ≤ α, the result is considered statistically significant, and we reject the null hypothesis. If p > α, we fail to reject the null hypothesis.
[002] The p-value is NOT the probability that the null hypothesis is true. It is the probability of the data (or more extreme data) given that the null hypothesis is true. This distinction is commonly misunderstood and frequently tested on the EPPP.

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics
section_title: Type I and Type II Errors

anchors.text: A Type II error occurs when we fail to reject the null hypothesis when it is actually false. This is also called a "false negative" or "beta error." The probability of a Type II error is denoted by β (beta).
Reject H₀ — Type I Error (α) — Correct Decision (Power)
Fail to Reject H₀ — Correct Decision — Type II Error (β)

In clinical contexts, the consequences of Type I and Type II errors differ. A Type I error in treatment research means concluding a treatment works when it doesn't (potentially exposing patients to ineffective treatments). A Type II error means missing a truly effective treatment (denying patients beneficial interventions). Researchers must consider these trade-offs when designing studies.

[002] Reject H₀ — Type I Error (α) — Correct Decision (Power)
[003] Fail to Reject H₀ — Correct Decision — Type II Error (β)
[004] In clinical contexts, the consequences of Type I and Type II errors differ. A Type I error in treatment research means concluding a treatment works when it doesn't (potentially exposing patients to ineffective treatments). A Type II error means missing a truly effective treatment (denying patients beneficial interventions). Researchers must consider these trade-offs when designing studies.

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics

anchors.text: Sample size (n): Larger samples increase power
Effect size: Larger effects are easier to detect
Alpha level: Higher α (e.g., .10 vs .05) increases power but also increases Type I error risk
Variability: Less variability (smaller SD) increases power
One-tailed vs. two-tailed tests: One-tailed tests have more power but only when the direction is correctly specified

[002] Effect size: Larger effects are easier to detect
[003] Alpha level: Higher α (e.g., .10 vs .05) increases power but also increases Type I error risk
[004] Variability: Less variability (smaller SD) increases power
[005] One-tailed vs. two-tailed tests: One-tailed tests have more power but only when the direction is correctly specified

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics

anchors.text: Used to compare means from two different groups (between-subjects design). For example, comparing depression scores between a treatment group and a control group. Assumptions include:
Independent observations
Normally distributed populations (or large samples)
Homogeneity of variance (equal variances in both groups)

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics > t-Tests > Independent Samples t-Test
anchors_text:
[001] Used to compare means from two different groups (between-subjects design). For example, comparing depression scores between a treatment group and a control group. Assumptions include:
[002] Independent observations
[003] Normally distributed populations (or large samples)
[004] Homogeneity of variance (equal variances in both groups)

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics

anchors.text: Used to compare a sample mean to a known or hypothesized population value. For example, testing whether a sample's IQ differs from the population mean of 100.

Example: Scenario: A researcher measures anxiety before and after a relaxation intervention in the same 30 participants. Appropriate test: Paired samples t-test, because the same participants are measured twice (within-subjects design). Scenario: A researcher compares anxiety scores between 30 participants who received treatment and 30 different participants who received placebo. Appropriate test: Independent samples t-test, because different participants are in each group (between-subjects design).

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics > t-Tests > One-Sample t-Test
anchors_text:
[001] Used to compare a sample mean to a known or hypothesized population value. For example, testing whether a sample's IQ differs from the population mean of 100.
[002] Example: Scenario: A researcher measures anxiety before and after a relaxation intervention in the same 30 participants. Appropriate test: Paired samples t-test, because the same participants are measured twice (within-subjects design). Scenario: A researcher compares anxiety scores between 30 participants who received treatment and 30 different participants who received placebo. Appropriate test: Independent samples t-test, because different participants are in each group (between-subjects design).

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics

anchors.text: Used when there are two or more independent variables. A 2×3 factorial ANOVA, for example, examines two IVs—one with 2 levels and one with 3 levels. Factorial ANOVA can detect:
Main effects: The effect of each independent variable separately
Interaction effects: Whether the effect of one IV depends on the level of another IV

An interaction occurs when the effect of one independent variable differs depending on the level of another independent variable. For example, a medication might be more effective for women than for men—the effect of medication (IV1) depends on sex (IV2). Interactions are often depicted as non-parallel lines in a graph of means.

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics

anchors.text: When ANOVA indicates significant differences, post hoc tests are used to determine which specific groups differ. Common post hoc tests include:
Tukey's HSD: Controls familywise error rate; most commonly used
Bonferroni: Conservative; divides α by number of comparisons
Scheffé: Most conservative; appropriate for complex comparisons
Fisher's LSD: Least conservative; does not control familywise error well

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics
section_title: Extensions of ANOVA: ANCOVA, MANOVA, and MANCOVA

anchors.text: ANCOVA combines ANOVA with regression by including one or more covariates—continuous variables that are statistically controlled to reduce error variance and remove the influence of confounding variables. ANCOVA adjusts group means on the DV to account for pre-existing differences on the covariate.
Purpose: Statistically control for confounding variables that cannot be controlled experimentally
Covariate requirement: The covariate must be measured before treatment (pre-treatment) so it is not affected by the independent variable
Effect: Reduces within-group error variance, increasing statistical power
Assumption: Homogeneity of regression slopes—the relationship between the covariate and the DV must be similar across groups

Example: A researcher compares the effectiveness of three therapy approaches on post-treatment anxiety scores. Because groups may differ in pre-treatment anxiety, the researcher uses pre-treatment anxiety as a covariate in an ANCOVA. This statistically adjusts post-treatment means to reflect what they would be if all groups had started with equal pre-treatment anxiety levels.

ANCOVA adjusts group means on the DV to account for pre-existing differences on the covariate.
[002] Purpose: Statistically control for confounding variables that cannot be controlled experimentally
[003] Covariate requirement: The covariate must be measured before treatment (pre-treatment) so it is not affected by the independent variable
[004] Effect: Reduces within-group error variance, increasing statistical power
[005] Assumption: Homogeneity of regression slopes—the relationship between the covariate and the DV must be similar across groups
[006] Example: A researcher compares the effectiveness of three therapy approaches on post-treatment anxiety scores. Because groups may differ in pre-treatment anxiety, the researcher uses pre-treatment anxiety as a covariate in an ANCOVA. This statistically adjusts post-treatment means to reflect what they would be if all groups had started with equal pre-treatment anxiety levels.

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics
section_title: Extensions of ANOVA: ANCOVA, MANOVA, and MANCOVA

anchors.text: MANOVA extends ANOVA to situations with multiple dependent variables measured simultaneously. Rather than running separate ANOVAs for each DV (which inflates Type I error), MANOVA tests whether groups differ on a linear combination of the DVs in a single omnibus test.
Purpose: Compare groups on multiple DVs simultaneously while controlling familywise Type I error rate
Test statistics: Wilks' Lambda (most commonly reported; based on ratio of determinants), Pillai's Trace (most robust to violations of assumptions), Hotelling's Trace, Roy's Largest Root
Assumptions: Multivariate normality, homogeneity of variance-covariance matrices (Box's M test), independence of observations

Follow-up analyses: If the omnibus MANOVA is significant, follow up with discriminant function analysis (preferred, as it accounts for DV intercorrelations) or individual ANOVAs on each DV with Bonferroni correction

Example: A researcher compares two therapy groups on three outcome measures simultaneously: depression, anxiety, and quality of life. Running three separate ANOVAs would inflate the Type I error rate (approximately 1 - .95^3 = .14 rather than .05). MANOVA tests all three DVs in one analysis, maintaining the overall alpha at .05. The researcher reports Wilks' Lambda and, if significant, conducts follow-up analyses to determine which DVs contribute to the group difference.

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics
section_title: Extensions of ANOVA: ANCOVA, MANOVA, and MANCOVA

anchors.text: MANCOVA combines the features of both MANOVA and ANCOVA—it analyzes multiple dependent variables simultaneously while statistically controlling for one or more covariates. This is used when a researcher has both multiple outcome measures and pre-existing differences that need to be adjusted for.
ANCOVA: One DV + need to control for a covariate (e.g., comparing treatment groups on post-test scores while controlling for pre-test)
MANOVA: Multiple DVs + no covariates needed (e.g., comparing treatment groups on depression, anxiety, and functioning simultaneously)
MANCOVA: Multiple DVs + need to control for a covariate (e.g., comparing treatment groups on multiple outcomes while controlling for baseline severity)

Chi-square test of independence: Tests whether two categorical variables are related (using a contingency table)

chapter_title: From Samples to Populations: Inferential Statistics

anchors.text: Partial eta-squared (η²ₚ): Variance explained by one IV while controlling for other IVs; used in factorial ANOVA
Omega-squared (ω²): Less biased estimate of population effect size than η²
Odds ratio: Used with categorical outcomes; commonly reported in logistic regression
r: Correlation coefficient itself is an effect size measure

Clinical significance refers to whether a treatment effect is meaningful in practice. A treatment might produce a statistically significant reduction in symptoms that is too small to matter clinically. Effect sizes, confidence intervals, and measures like the Reliable Change Index (RCI) help determine whether changes are clinically meaningful, not just statistically detectable.

anchors.text: Edward Thorndike's pioneering research with cats in puzzle boxes established the groundwork for operant conditioning. Thorndike observed that cats placed in puzzle boxes gradually learned to escape more quickly over successive trials. He formulated the Law of Effect, stating that responses followed by satisfying consequences are strengthened, while responses followed by annoying consequences are weakened.

B.F. Skinner expanded and refined Thorndike's work, developing the experimental analysis of behavior. Skinner introduced the operant chamber (commonly called the "Skinner box"), which allowed precise control and measurement of behavioral contingencies. His radical behaviorism emphasized the environmental control of behavior and rejected mentalistic explanations.

anchors_text:
[001] Edward Thorndike's pioneering research with cats in puzzle boxes established the groundwork for operant conditioning. Thorndike observed that cats placed in puzzle boxes gradually learned to escape more quickly over successive trials. He formulated the Law of Effect, stating that responses followed by satisfying consequences are strengthened, while responses followed by annoying consequences are weakened.
[002] B.F. Skinner expanded and refined Thorndike's work, developing the experimental analysis of behavior. Skinner introduced the operant chamber (commonly called the "Skinner box"), which allowed precise control and measurement of behavioral contingencies. His radical behaviorism emphasized the environmental control of behavior and rejected mentalistic explanations.

anchors.text: Positive reinforcement occurs when a behavior is followed by the addition of a stimulus that increases the probability of that behavior. The term "positive" refers to the addition (presentation) of something, not to whether it is pleasant. In practice, positive reinforcers are typically stimuli that the organism finds desirable.

Example: A child completes homework and receives praise from parents. The praise (added stimulus) increases the likelihood that the child will complete homework in the future. In a clinical setting, a therapist might use positive reinforcement by providing verbal praise when a client uses a coping skill appropriately during a session.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Shaping Behavior: Operant Conditioning > Reinforcement > Positive Reinforcement
anchors_text:

The term "positive" refers to the addition (presentation) of something, not to whether it is pleasant. In practice, positive reinforcers are typically stimuli that the organism finds desirable.
[002] Example: A child completes homework and receives praise from parents. The praise (added stimulus) increases the likelihood that the child will complete homework in the future. In a clinical setting, a therapist might use positive reinforcement by providing verbal praise when a client uses a coping skill appropriately during a session.

anchors.text: Negative reinforcement occurs when a behavior is followed by the removal of an aversive stimulus, which increases the probability of that behavior. The term "negative" refers to the removal (subtraction) of something, not to punishment. Negative reinforcement still strengthens behavior.

Example: A person with social anxiety leaves a party early (behavior) and experiences relief from anxiety (removal of aversive stimulus). The relief reinforces avoidance behavior, making it more likely to occur in future social situations. This mechanism is central to the maintenance of anxiety disorders and explains why avoidance is so persistent.

[002] Example: A person with social anxiety leaves a party early (behavior) and experiences relief from anxiety (removal of aversive stimulus). The relief reinforces avoidance behavior, making it more likely to occur in future social situations. This mechanism is central to the maintenance of anxiety disorders and explains why avoidance is so persistent.

anchors.text: Primary reinforcers (also called unconditioned reinforcers) are stimuli that are inherently reinforcing without prior learning. These include food, water, warmth, and sexual stimulation - stimuli that satisfy basic biological needs.

Secondary reinforcers (also called conditioned reinforcers) acquire their reinforcing properties through association with primary reinforcers. Money, grades, praise, and tokens are common examples. These reinforcers are powerful in human behavior because they can be exchanged for various primary reinforcers.

Token economies are clinical interventions based on secondary reinforcement. Patients earn tokens (secondary reinforcers) for target behaviors, which can be exchanged for backup reinforcers (items or privileges). Token economies have demonstrated effectiveness in psychiatric hospitals, classrooms, and residential treatment settings.

anchors.text: Negative punishment (also called punishment by removal or response cost) occurs when a behavior is followed by the removal of a desired stimulus, decreasing the probability of that behavior. Examples include time-out from reinforcement, loss of privileges, or having a driver's license suspended.
Increase Behavior — Positive Reinforcement — Negative Reinforcement
Decrease Behavior — Positive Punishment — Negative Punishment

Examples include time-out from reinforcement, loss of privileges, or having a driver's license suspended.
[002] Increase Behavior — Positive Reinforcement — Negative Reinforcement
[003] Decrease Behavior — Positive Punishment — Negative Punishment

anchors.text: Research has identified several limitations of punishment as a behavior change strategy:
Temporary suppression: Punishment often suppresses behavior only temporarily and in the presence of the punishing agent
Emotional side effects: Punishment can produce fear, anxiety, and aggression
Escape and avoidance: The punished individual may learn to escape or avoid the punishing agent rather than change behavior
Modeling aggression: Physical punishment models aggressive behavior for children
Does not teach alternatives: Punishment tells the individual what not to do but does not teach appropriate alternatives

anchors.text: Continuous reinforcement (CRF) occurs when every instance of the target behavior is reinforced. This schedule is optimal for initially establishing a new behavior but produces rapid extinction when reinforcement is discontinued.

Intermittent (partial) reinforcement occurs when only some instances of the behavior are reinforced. Behavior maintained on intermittent schedules is more resistant to extinction because the organism has learned that not every response produces reinforcement.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Shaping Behavior: Operant Conditioning > Schedules of Reinforcement > Continuous vs. Intermittent Reinforcement
anchors_text:
[001] Continuous reinforcement (CRF) occurs when every instance of the target behavior is reinforced. This schedule is optimal for initially establishing a new behavior but produces rapid extinction when reinforcement is discontinued.
[002] Intermittent (partial) reinforcement occurs when only some instances of the behavior are reinforced. Behavior maintained on intermittent schedules is more resistant to extinction because the organism has learned that not every response produces reinforcement.

anchors.text: Reinforcement is delivered after a fixed number of responses. For example, FR-5 means reinforcement occurs after every 5 responses. FR schedules produce high, steady response rates with a brief pause after reinforcement (post-reinforcement pause). Piecework pay is a real-world example.

Reinforcement is delivered after a variable number of responses, averaging to a specified number. VR schedules produce the highest and most consistent response rates with no post-reinforcement pause. Gambling operates on a VR schedule, which explains its highly addictive nature.

Reinforcement is delivered for the first response after a fixed time period has elapsed. FI schedules produce a characteristic "scalloped" pattern - responding is slow immediately after reinforcement and accelerates as the interval ends. Checking the mailbox for an expected delivery is an example.

Reinforcement is delivered for the first response after a variable time period, averaging to a specified duration. VI schedules produce steady, moderate response rates. Checking email or social media operates on a VI schedule.
Ratio schedules produce higher response rates than interval schedules (ratio schedules depend on response rate).
Variable schedules produce more consistent responding and greater resistance to extinction than fixed schedules.
Variable ratio (VR) produces the highest response rate and greatest resistance to extinction.

anchors.text: Shaping, also called the method of successive approximations, is a procedure for teaching new behaviors by reinforcing responses that increasingly resemble the target behavior. The trainer reinforces behaviors that are progressively closer to the desired response while no longer reinforcing earlier approximations.

Shaping is essential when the target behavior does not occur spontaneously in the organism's repertoire. For example, training a pigeon to turn in a complete circle requires first reinforcing any slight head turn, then quarter turns, half turns, and finally complete rotations.

Example: Applied behavior analysis (ABA) uses shaping to develop speech in nonverbal children with autism. A clinician might first reinforce any vocalization, then vocalizations that resemble consonant sounds, then consonant-vowel combinations, and eventually approximations of words. This systematic approach has been highly effective in early intervention programs.

The trainer reinforces behaviors that are progressively closer to the desired response while no longer reinforcing earlier approximations.
[002] Shaping is essential when the target behavior does not occur spontaneously in the organism's repertoire. For example, training a pigeon to turn in a complete circle requires first reinforcing any slight head turn, then quarter turns, half turns, and finally complete rotations.
[003] Example: Applied behavior analysis (ABA) uses shaping to develop speech in nonverbal children with autism. A clinician might first reinforce any vocalization, then vocalizations that resemble consonant sounds, then consonant-vowel combinations, and eventually approximations of words. This systematic approach has been highly effective in early intervention programs.

anchors.text: Chaining is a procedure for teaching complex behaviors that consist of a sequence of simpler responses. Each response in the chain produces a stimulus that serves as both a conditioned reinforcer for the previous response and a discriminative stimulus for the next response.
Forward chaining: Teaching the first step first, then adding subsequent steps. Used when early steps must be mastered before later steps can be attempted.
Backward chaining: Teaching the last step first, then adding preceding steps. Often preferred because the learner always completes the chain and contacts the terminal reinforcer.
Total task presentation: Teaching all steps together with prompts. Useful for simpler chains or more capable learners.

Chaining procedures are commonly used to teach daily living skills (dressing, toothbrushing, handwashing) to individuals with developmental disabilities. Backward chaining is often preferred for these tasks because completing the final step provides natural reinforcement (e.g., clean teeth, dry hands).

anchors.text: A discriminative stimulus (SD) is a stimulus in the presence of which a particular response has been reinforced. Through experience, organisms learn to respond differently in the presence versus absence of the SD. The SD does not elicit the response (as in classical conditioning) but rather sets the occasion for the response by signaling reinforcement availability.

An S-delta (SΔ) is a stimulus that signals reinforcement is not available. Through discrimination training, organisms learn to respond in the presence of the SD and withhold responding in the presence of the SΔ.

Example: A ringing telephone (SD) signals that answering will be reinforced by conversation. The silent telephone (SΔ) signals that picking up the receiver will not produce reinforcement. Similarly, an "open" sign on a store (SD) signals that entering will be reinforced, while a "closed" sign (SΔ) signals it will not.

The SD does not elicit the response (as in classical conditioning) but rather sets the occasion for the response by signaling reinforcement availability.
[002] An S-delta (SΔ) is a stimulus that signals reinforcement is not available. Through discrimination training, organisms learn to respond in the presence of the SD and withhold responding in the presence of the SΔ.
[003] Example: A ringing telephone (SD) signals that answering will be reinforced by conversation. The silent telephone (SΔ) signals that picking up the receiver will not produce reinforcement. Similarly, an "open" sign on a store (SD) signals that entering will be reinforced, while a "closed" sign (SΔ) signals it will not.

anchors.text: The relationship between discriminative stimuli, behavior, and consequences is captured in the three-term contingency (or ABC model):
Antecedent (A): The discriminative stimulus that precedes behavior
Behavior (B): The operant response
Consequence (C): The reinforcement or punishment that follows
This framework is fundamental to functional behavior assessment and the development of behavior intervention plans in clinical and educational settings.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Shaping Behavior: Operant Conditioning > Stimulus Control > The Three-Term Contingency
anchors_text:
[001] The relationship between discriminative stimuli, behavior, and consequences is captured in the three-term contingency (or ABC model):
[002] Antecedent (A): The discriminative stimulus that precedes behavior
[003] Behavior (B): The operant response
[004] Consequence (C): The reinforcement or punishment that follows
[005] This framework is fundamental to functional behavior assessment and the development of behavior intervention plans in clinical and educational settings.

anchors.text: Avoidance learning occurs when an organism learns to perform a behavior that prevents an aversive stimulus from occurring. The avoidance response is made before the aversive stimulus is presented, based on warning signals (discriminative stimuli).
Mowrer's two-factor theory explains avoidance learning through a combination of classical and operant conditioning:
Factor 1 (Classical conditioning): A neutral stimulus becomes a conditioned stimulus (CS) for fear through pairing with an aversive unconditioned stimulus
Factor 2 (Operant conditioning): The avoidance response is negatively reinforced by reduction of the conditioned fear
This theory explains why avoidance behavior is so resistant to extinction - the organism never remains in the presence of the feared stimulus long enough for extinction to occur.

Two-factor theory provides a behavioral account of anxiety disorder maintenance. Avoidance prevents exposure to feared situations, thereby preventing extinction of conditioned fear. This explains why exposure therapy, which prevents avoidance and allows extinction to occur, is effective for anxiety disorders. The theory also explains why reassurance-seeking and safety behaviors maintain anxiety.

anchors.text: Contingency management interventions provide tangible reinforcers contingent on evidence of desired behavior change (typically verified drug abstinence). These interventions have demonstrated robust efficacy for substance use disorders, particularly stimulant use disorders where pharmacological treatments are limited.

Example: In voucher-based contingency management for cocaine dependence, patients receive vouchers exchangeable for retail goods contingent on cocaine-negative urine specimens. Voucher values typically start low and increase with consecutive negative specimens, with a reset contingency for positive specimens. Meta-analyses demonstrate significant effects on drug abstinence outcomes.

anchors.text: Functional Behavior Assessment (FBA) is a process for identifying the environmental variables that maintain problem behavior. By identifying the function of behavior (what reinforces it), clinicians can develop function-based interventions that address the maintaining contingencies rather than simply suppressing behavior.
Common functions of problem behavior include:
Attention: Behavior maintained by social reinforcement
Escape: Behavior maintained by negative reinforcement (removal of demands)
Access to tangibles: Behavior maintained by access to preferred items or activities
Automatic reinforcement: Behavior maintained by sensory consequences independent of social mediation

rxx = σ²T / σ²X = 1 - (σ²E / σ²X)
A reliability coefficient of .80 means that 80% of the observed score variance is true score variance, while 20% is error variance.

anchors.text: IRT models characterize items using up to three parameters:

Difficulty (b): The ability level at which an examinee has a 50% probability of answering correctly. Higher b values indicate more difficult items. On the ability (theta) scale, b typically ranges from -3 to +3.

Discrimination (a): How well the item differentiates between examinees of different ability levels. Higher a values indicate that the item sharply distinguishes between those just above and just below the difficulty level. Graphically, this is the steepness of the item characteristic curve at the inflection point.

Guessing (c): The probability that an examinee with very low ability will answer correctly (also called the pseudo-guessing parameter). For a four-option multiple-choice item, c is often around .25 but may be lower if distractors are effective.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Consistency of Measurement: Test Reliability > Item Response Theory (IRT) > Item Parameters
anchors_text:
[001] IRT models characterize items using up to three parameters:
[002] Difficulty (b): The ability level at which an examinee has a 50% probability of answering correctly. Higher b values indicate more difficult items. On the ability (theta) scale, b typically ranges from -3 to +3.
[003] Discrimination (a): How well the item differentiates between examinees of different ability levels. Higher a values indicate that the item sharply distinguishes between those just above and just below the difficulty level. Graphically, this is the steepness of the item characteristic curve at the inflection point.
[004] Guessing (c): The probability that an examinee with very low ability will answer correctly (also called the pseudo-guessing parameter). For a four-option multiple-choice item, c is often around .25 but may be lower if distractors are effective.

anchors.text: The Item Characteristic Curve (ICC) is an S-shaped (logistic) curve that plots the probability of a correct response (y-axis) as a function of examinee ability, denoted theta (x-axis). Each item has its own ICC. The curve's position along the theta axis reflects difficulty (b), its steepness reflects discrimination (a), and its lower asymptote reflects guessing (c).

Example: An item with b = 0.0 is of average difficulty (50% correct at average ability). If a = 1.5, the curve is moderately steep, meaning the item differentiates well. If c = 0.20, even very low-ability examinees have a 20% chance of guessing correctly, so the curve never drops below 0.20 on the y-axis.

anchors.text: 1PL (Rasch Model) — Difficulty (b) only — All items assumed equally discriminating; no guessing. Simplest model; emphasizes measurement properties and specific objectivity
2PL — Difficulty (b) + Discrimination (a) — Allows items to vary in discrimination. ICCs can differ in steepness. More realistic for many tests

3PL — Difficulty (b) + Discrimination (a) + Guessing (c) — Accounts for correct guessing on multiple-choice items. Lower asymptote of ICC is above zero. Most commonly used for standardized multiple-choice tests
