anchors.text: Item parameter invariance: Item parameters remain stable across different examinee samples (provided the model fits), enabling items to be calibrated once and used across contexts
Ability estimate invariance: Examinee ability estimates are comparable regardless of which specific items were administered, as long as items come from a calibrated bank
Conditional standard error: IRT provides unique precision estimates at each ability level, rather than a single SEM for all examinees
Flexible test design: Items can be selected to maximize information (precision) at specific ability levels

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Consistency of Measurement: Test Reliability > Item Response Theory (IRT) > Advantages of IRT
anchors_text:
[001] Item parameter invariance: Item parameters remain stable across different examinee samples (provided the model fits), enabling items to be calibrated once and used across contexts
[002] Ability estimate invariance: Examinee ability estimates are comparable regardless of which specific items were administered, as long as items come from a calibrated bank
[003] Conditional standard error: IRT provides unique precision estimates at each ability level, rather than a single SEM for all examinees
[004] Flexible test design: Items can be selected to maximize information (precision) at specific ability levels

anchors.text: Computerized Adaptive Testing (CAT): IRT enables tests that dynamically select items based on the examinee's estimated ability. After each response, the ability estimate is updated and the next item is chosen to provide maximum information at that ability level. CATs are typically shorter yet more precise than fixed-length tests.
Test equating: IRT allows scores from different test forms to be placed on a common scale, ensuring fairness when different examinees take different versions of a test

Differential Item Functioning (DIF): IRT can identify items that function differently across demographic groups (e.g., gender, ethnicity) after controlling for ability, which is essential for detecting item-level bias
Item banking: Calibrated items can be stored in a bank and assembled into multiple test forms with known psychometric properties

The EPPP itself uses IRT-based scoring. Items are calibrated using IRT models, and examinee scores are estimated on a theta scale. This means the EPPP can draw from a large item bank while maintaining score comparability across administrations. The pass/fail decision is based on a theta cutoff rather than a raw percentage correct, which accounts for differences in item difficulty across test forms.

anchors.text: Test-retest reliability (also called temporal stability) assesses the consistency of scores across time. The same test is administered to the same individuals on two occasions, and the correlation between scores indicates stability.
Method: Administer same test twice; correlate scores
Source of error: Time sampling (changes in examinees over time)
Considerations: Interval between testings, memory/practice effects, true changes in the construct
Shorter intervals (days to weeks): Minimize true change but increase practice effects
Longer intervals (months): Reduce practice effects but allow more true change
Stable traits (intelligence, personality): Longer intervals are appropriate
Variable states (mood, anxiety): Very short intervals or alternative methods

anchors_text:
[001] Test-retest reliability (also called temporal stability) assesses the consistency of scores across time. The same test is administered to the same individuals on two occasions, and the correlation between scores indicates stability.
[002] Method: Administer same test twice; correlate scores
[003] Source of error: Time sampling (changes in examinees over time)
[004] Considerations: Interval between testings, memory/practice effects, true changes in the construct
[005] Shorter intervals (days to weeks): Minimize true change but increase practice effects
[006] Longer intervals (months): Reduce practice effects but allow more true change
[007] Stable traits (intelligence, personality): Longer intervals are appropriate
[008] Variable states (mood, anxiety): Very short intervals or alternative methods

anchors.text: Alternate forms reliability assesses consistency across different versions of the same test. Two equivalent forms are administered to the same individuals, and the correlation between forms indicates reliability. This method controls for memory effects and provides evidence of content sampling consistency.

Example: A publisher develops Form A and Form B of an achievement test, each with different items measuring the same content domain. Students take Form A one week and Form B the next. A correlation of .85 between forms indicates good alternate forms reliability, suggesting the two versions measure the same construct consistently.

For forms to be truly parallel, they must have equal means, equal variances, and equal correlations with other measures. In practice, this is difficult to achieve, so most alternate forms are better described as "equivalent" rather than strictly parallel.

This method controls for memory effects and provides evidence of content sampling consistency.
[002] Example: A publisher develops Form A and Form B of an achievement test, each with different items measuring the same content domain. Students take Form A one week and Form B the next. A correlation of .85 between forms indicates good alternate forms reliability, suggesting the two versions measure the same construct consistently.
[003] For forms to be truly parallel, they must have equal means, equal variances, and equal correlations with other measures. In practice, this is difficult to achieve, so most alternate forms are better described as "equivalent" rather than strictly parallel.

anchors.text: Internal consistency assesses the homogeneity of items within a single test administration. It indicates the extent to which items measure the same construct and is the most commonly reported type of reliability.

The test is divided into two halves (typically odd vs. even items), and the correlation between halves is calculated. Because each half is only half as long as the full test, the Spearman-Brown formula is used to estimate the reliability of the full-length test.
rxx = (2 × rhh) / (1 + rhh)
Where rhh is the correlation between the two halves.
For example, if the correlation between halves is .60, the estimated full-test reliability is:

Cronbach's alpha (α) is the most widely used measure of internal consistency. It represents the average of all possible split-half reliabilities and indicates how well items hang together as a set. Alpha is appropriate for items with multiple response options.
Alpha values are interpreted as follows:
≥ .90 — Excellent (individual decision-making)
.70 - .79 — Acceptable (research purposes)
.60 - .69 — Questionable
< .60 — Poor/Unacceptable

The Kuder-Richardson formulas are special cases of Cronbach's alpha for dichotomously scored items (correct/incorrect). KR-20 is used when item difficulties vary, while KR-21 assumes equal item difficulties.
May be inappropriately high for speeded tests (items are not independently answered)
Does not assess stability over time
May be artificially inflated by redundant items
Not appropriate for multidimensional tests (should be calculated separately for each subscale)

anchors.text: Inter-rater reliability assesses the consistency of scores assigned by different raters or scorers. This is essential for tests involving subjective judgment, such as essay tests, behavioral observations, projective tests, and structured interviews.
Percent agreement: Simple but does not account for chance agreement
Cohen's kappa (κ): Corrects for chance agreement; used for categorical ratings
Intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC): Used for continuous ratings; accounts for both agreement and consistency
κ < .20: Poor agreement
κ = .21 - .40: Fair agreement
κ = .41 - .60: Moderate agreement
κ = .61 - .80: Substantial agreement
κ > .80: Almost perfect agreement

anchors.text: The SEM is used to construct confidence intervals around observed scores. Assuming a normal distribution of errors:
68% confidence interval: Observed score ± 1 SEM
95% confidence interval: Observed score ± 1.96 SEM (approximately ± 2 SEM)
99% confidence interval: Observed score ± 2.58 SEM

If a client obtains an IQ score of 115 with an SEM of 4.5, the 95% confidence interval is approximately 115 ± 9 points, or 106 to 124. Clinicians should report and interpret confidence intervals rather than treating observed scores as exact values. This is especially important when scores fall near clinical cutoffs.

[005] If a client obtains an IQ score of 115 with an SEM of 4.5, the 95% confidence interval is approximately 115 ± 9 points, or 106 to 124. Clinicians should report and interpret confidence intervals rather than treating observed scores as exact values. This is especially important when scores fall near clinical cutoffs.

anchors.text: When comparing two scores (e.g., Verbal IQ vs. Performance IQ, or pretest vs. posttest), the standard error of the difference (SEdiff) is used to determine whether the difference is statistically significant:
A difference is typically considered significant if it exceeds 1.96 × SEdiff (for 95% confidence).

anchors.text: Longer tests are generally more reliable because they sample the content domain more thoroughly. The Spearman-Brown formula can estimate how reliability changes with test length:
rkk = (k × rxx) / [1 + (k - 1) × rxx]
Where k is the factor by which the test length is multiplied.
Example: If a 20-item test has reliability of .70, doubling its length (k = 2) would yield estimated reliability of: (2 × .70) / [1 + (2 - 1) × .70] = 1.40 / 1.70 = .82

[002] rkk = (k × rxx) / [1 + (k - 1) × rxx]
[003] Where k is the factor by which the test length is multiplied.
[004] Example: If a 20-item test has reliability of .70, doubling its length (k = 2) would yield estimated reliability of: (2 × .70) / [1 + (2 - 1) × .70] = 1.40 / 1.70 = .82

anchors.text: Test-taking conditions: Standardized administration enhances reliability
Examinee characteristics: Fatigue, anxiety, and motivation affect consistency
Guessing: Random guessing adds error variance, reducing reliability
Scorer training: Well-trained raters produce more consistent scores

anchors.text: The pretest-posttest control group design includes random assignment of participants to treatment and control groups, with measurements taken before and after treatment. This design allows researchers to assess change over time and control for pre-existing differences between groups.

Example: A researcher randomly assigns 60 patients with depression to either cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or a waitlist control. Both groups complete the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) before and after the 12-week treatment period. The researcher can compare change scores between groups to determine if CBT produces significantly greater improvement than the passage of time alone.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Blueprints for Discovery: Research Designs > True Experimental Designs > Pretest-Posttest Control Group Design
anchors_text:
[001] The pretest-posttest control group design includes random assignment of participants to treatment and control groups, with measurements taken before and after treatment. This design allows researchers to assess change over time and control for pre-existing differences between groups.
[002] Example: A researcher randomly assigns 60 patients with depression to either cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or a waitlist control. Both groups complete the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) before and after the 12-week treatment period. The researcher can compare change scores between groups to determine if CBT produces significantly greater improvement than the passage of time alone.

anchors.text: The Solomon four-group design combines elements of both previous designs, using four groups: two receive pretests (one treatment, one control) and two do not (one treatment, one control). This design allows researchers to detect and control for testing effects and sensitization.
Group 1: Pretest → Treatment → Posttest
Group 2: Pretest → No Treatment → Posttest
Group 3: No Pretest → Treatment → Posttest
Group 4: No Pretest → No Treatment → Posttest

[003] Group 2: Pretest → No Treatment → Posttest
[004] Group 3: No Pretest → Treatment → Posttest
[005] Group 4: No Pretest → No Treatment → Posttest

anchors.text: Factorial designs manipulate two or more independent variables simultaneously, allowing researchers to examine both main effects and interaction effects. A 2 × 2 factorial design, for example, has two independent variables, each with two levels, creating four conditions.

Example: A researcher examines the effects of therapy type (CBT vs. psychodynamic) and medication (present vs. absent) on anxiety symptoms using a 2 × 2 factorial design. This allows examination of: (1) the main effect of therapy type, (2) the main effect of medication, and (3) the interaction between therapy and medication (e.g., whether CBT is particularly effective when combined with medication).

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Blueprints for Discovery: Research Designs > True Experimental Designs > Factorial Designs
anchors_text:
[001] Factorial designs manipulate two or more independent variables simultaneously, allowing researchers to examine both main effects and interaction effects. A 2 × 2 factorial design, for example, has two independent variables, each with two levels, creating four conditions.
[002] Example: A researcher examines the effects of therapy type (CBT vs. psychodynamic) and medication (present vs. absent) on anxiety symptoms using a 2 × 2 factorial design. This allows examination of: (1) the main effect of therapy type, (2) the main effect of medication, and (3) the interaction between therapy and medication (e.g., whether CBT is particularly effective when combined with medication).

anchors.text: The nonequivalent control group design resembles the pretest-posttest control group design but lacks random assignment. Participants are assigned to conditions based on pre-existing group membership (e.g., students in different classrooms). The pretest helps assess initial group equivalence and can be used as a covariate in analysis.

In clinical settings, quasi-experimental designs are often the most feasible option. For example, comparing outcomes between patients who choose medication versus therapy cannot use random assignment ethically if patients have strong preferences. Careful matching and statistical controls can strengthen causal inferences in such studies.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Blueprints for Discovery: Research Designs > Quasi-Experimental Designs > Nonequivalent Control Group Design
anchors_text:
[001] The nonequivalent control group design resembles the pretest-posttest control group design but lacks random assignment. Participants are assigned to conditions based on pre-existing group membership (e.g., students in different classrooms). The pretest helps assess initial group equivalence and can be used as a covariate in analysis.
[002] In clinical settings, quasi-experimental designs are often the most feasible option. For example, comparing outcomes between patients who choose medication versus therapy cannot use random assignment ethically if patients have strong preferences. Careful matching and statistical controls can strengthen causal inferences in such studies.

anchors.text: The interrupted time-series design involves multiple measurements before and after an intervention, allowing researchers to examine trends over time and detect changes associated with the intervention. This design is particularly useful for evaluating policy changes or community-level interventions.

Example: A hospital implements a new suicide prevention protocol and tracks monthly suicide attempts for two years before and two years after implementation. By examining the pattern of data points, researchers can determine whether the intervention was associated with a change in level or trend of suicide attempts.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Blueprints for Discovery: Research Designs > Quasi-Experimental Designs > Interrupted Time-Series Design
anchors_text:
[001] The interrupted time-series design involves multiple measurements before and after an intervention, allowing researchers to examine trends over time and detect changes associated with the intervention. This design is particularly useful for evaluating policy changes or community-level interventions.
[002] Example: A hospital implements a new suicide prevention protocol and tracks monthly suicide attempts for two years before and two years after implementation. By examining the pattern of data points, researchers can determine whether the intervention was associated with a change in level or trend of suicide attempts.

anchors.text: The regression discontinuity design assigns participants to conditions based on a cutoff score on a pretest measure. Those above the cutoff receive one treatment while those below receive another. The design examines whether there is a discontinuity (jump or drop) in the outcome variable at the cutoff point, which would indicate a treatment effect.
This design has stronger internal validity than other quasi-experimental designs because assignment is based on a known, measured variable.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Blueprints for Discovery: Research Designs > Quasi-Experimental Designs > Regression Discontinuity Design
anchors_text:
[001] The regression discontinuity design assigns participants to conditions based on a cutoff score on a pretest measure. Those above the cutoff receive one treatment while those below receive another. The design examines whether there is a discontinuity (jump or drop) in the outcome variable at the cutoff point, which would indicate a treatment effect.
[002] This design has stronger internal validity than other quasi-experimental designs because assignment is based on a known, measured variable.

anchors.text: The ABAB design strengthens causal inference by adding withdrawal and reintroduction phases. The sequence is: baseline (A) → treatment (B) → withdrawal (A) → treatment (B). If behavior improves during treatment phases and deteriorates during withdrawal phases, this provides compelling evidence that the treatment caused the change.

The withdrawal phase tests whether behavior is maintained by the treatment. If improvements persist after treatment withdrawal, the treatment may have produced lasting change—or other factors may be responsible for the improvement. If behavior returns to baseline levels during withdrawal, this strengthens the inference that the treatment was responsible for initial improvement.

ABAB designs may be inappropriate when withdrawal of an effective treatment poses risks to the client (e.g., self-injurious behavior). In such cases, multiple baseline designs provide an ethical alternative that maintains experimental control without requiring treatment withdrawal.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Blueprints for Discovery: Research Designs > Single-Subject (Single-Case) Designs > ABAB (Withdrawal/Reversal) Design
anchors_text:
[001] The ABAB design strengthens causal inference by adding withdrawal and reintroduction phases. The sequence is: baseline (A) → treatment (B) → withdrawal (A) → treatment (B). If behavior improves during treatment phases and deteriorates during withdrawal phases, this provides compelling evidence that the treatment caused the change.
[002] The withdrawal phase tests whether behavior is maintained by the treatment. If improvements persist after treatment withdrawal, the treatment may have produced lasting change—or other factors may be responsible for the improvement. If behavior returns to baseline levels during withdrawal, this strengthens the inference that the treatment was responsible for initial improvement.
[003] ABAB designs may be inappropriate when withdrawal of an effective treatment poses risks to the client (e.g., self-injurious behavior). In such cases, multiple baseline designs provide an ethical alternative that maintains experimental control without requiring treatment withdrawal.

anchors.text: The multiple baseline design introduces treatment at different points in time across multiple baselines. These baselines can be across behaviors (different behaviors in one person), across subjects (same behavior in different people), or across settings (same behavior and person in different environments).

Example: A therapist targets three problem behaviors in a child with autism: hand-flapping, echolalia, and tantrums. After establishing baselines for all three, she implements a token economy first for hand-flapping. Once reduction is observed, she extends the intervention to echolalia, then to tantrums. If each behavior decreases only when the intervention is applied to it, this demonstrates experimental control without requiring withdrawal.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Blueprints for Discovery: Research Designs > Single-Subject (Single-Case) Designs > Multiple Baseline Design
anchors_text:
[001] The multiple baseline design introduces treatment at different points in time across multiple baselines. These baselines can be across behaviors (different behaviors in one person), across subjects (same behavior in different people), or across settings (same behavior and person in different environments).
[002] Example: A therapist targets three problem behaviors in a child with autism: hand-flapping, echolalia, and tantrums. After establishing baselines for all three, she implements a token economy first for hand-flapping. Once reduction is observed, she extends the intervention to echolalia, then to tantrums. If each behavior decreases only when the intervention is applied to it, this demonstrates experimental control without requiring withdrawal.

anchors.text: Cross-sectional designs collect data at a single point in time, comparing different groups (e.g., different age groups) simultaneously. While efficient, they cannot distinguish age effects from cohort effects.
Longitudinal designs follow the same participants over time, allowing researchers to track individual change and development. However, they are expensive, time-consuming, and vulnerable to attrition.

The cohort-sequential design combines cross-sectional and longitudinal approaches by following multiple cohorts over time. This allows researchers to separate age effects, cohort effects, and time-of-measurement effects.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Blueprints for Discovery: Research Designs > Non-Experimental Designs > Cross-Sectional vs. Longitudinal Designs
anchors_text:
[001] Cross-sectional designs collect data at a single point in time, comparing different groups (e.g., different age groups) simultaneously. While efficient, they cannot distinguish age effects from cohort effects.
[002] Longitudinal designs follow the same participants over time, allowing researchers to track individual change and development. However, they are expensive, time-consuming, and vulnerable to attrition.
[003] The cohort-sequential design combines cross-sectional and longitudinal approaches by following multiple cohorts over time. This allows researchers to separate age effects, cohort effects, and time-of-measurement effects.

anchors.text: In within-subjects designs, the same participants experience all conditions. This eliminates individual difference variance and requires fewer participants. However, these designs are vulnerable to order effects, including practice effects, fatigue, and carryover.

Counterbalancing addresses order effects by varying the sequence of conditions across participants. In complete counterbalancing, all possible orders are used equally. In Latin square counterbalancing, a subset of orders is used such that each condition appears equally often in each position.

[002] Counterbalancing addresses order effects by varying the sequence of conditions across participants. In complete counterbalancing, all possible orders are used equally. In Latin square counterbalancing, a subset of orders is used such that each condition appears equally often in each position.

anchors.text: Simple Random — Every member has equal chance of selection — Unbiased representation
Stratified Random — Population divided into strata; random sampling within each — Ensures representation of subgroups
Cluster — Randomly select clusters (e.g., schools), sample all within — Practical for geographically dispersed populations
Systematic — Select every kth member from a list — Simple to implement

anchors.text: Grounded theory aims to generate theory from data rather than testing pre-existing hypotheses. Researchers collect data (typically through interviews and observations), code it systematically, and develop theoretical concepts that are "grounded" in the data. The process involves open coding (identifying initial categories), axial coding (relating categories), and selective coding (integrating into a coherent theory). Data collection and analysis occur simultaneously, and theoretical sampling guides recruitment—new participants are selected to refine emerging theory.

Phenomenology seeks to describe the essence of lived experience as perceived by participants. Researchers conduct in-depth interviews to understand how individuals experience a particular phenomenon (e.g., living with chronic pain, experiencing grief). The analyst identifies themes and structures that capture the core meaning of the experience. The researcher engages in bracketing (also called epoché)—setting aside personal preconceptions to focus on participants' subjective experiences.

Ethnography involves prolonged immersion in a cultural group or community to understand its practices, beliefs, and social dynamics from an insider perspective. The researcher engages in participant observation—simultaneously participating in and observing the culture. Ethnographic studies produce thick description, which captures not just behaviors but their context and meaning.

The case study approach involves in-depth examination of a single case or a small number of cases. A "case" can be an individual, a program, an organization, or an event. Case studies use multiple data sources (interviews, documents, observations) and are valuable for exploring complex phenomena in real-world contexts. They provide rich detail but have limited generalizability.

Narrative analysis examines the stories people tell about their lives and experiences. Researchers analyze how individuals construct meaning through narrative structure, plot, characters, and sequencing. This approach recognizes that people organize their understanding of the world through stories and that narratives reveal identity, culture, and values.

topic_name: Quality and Rigor in Qualitative Research

anchors.text: Coding: The systematic process of labeling and categorizing segments of data (text, observations) to identify patterns and themes. Coding may be descriptive, interpretive, or theoretical
Themes: Recurring patterns of meaning across participants or data sources that capture important aspects of the phenomenon
Saturation: The point at which no new themes or information emerge from additional data collection. Saturation signals that data collection is sufficient
Triangulation: Using multiple data sources, methods, investigators, or theoretical perspectives to corroborate findings and increase credibility
Member checking: Sharing findings or interpretations with participants to verify accuracy and ensure the researcher's account reflects participants' perspectives
Thick description: Richly detailed accounts that include context, meaning, and intention—allowing readers to judge transferability to other settings
Reflexivity: The researcher's ongoing self-examination of how their own background, assumptions, and position may influence the research process and interpretation
Quantitative: Tests hypotheses, measures variables, uses statistics, seeks generalizable findings, large samples
Qualitative: Explores meaning, describes experiences, uses thematic analysis, seeks depth and context, smaller samples

Mixed methods: Combines both approaches in a single study to leverage the strengths of each. Sequential designs use one method to inform the other; concurrent designs collect both types of data simultaneously

anchors.text: Formative evaluation: Conducted during program development and implementation. Its purpose is to improve the program while it is still being shaped. Formative evaluation identifies problems in delivery, monitors progress, and provides feedback for mid-course corrections. Think: "forming" the program.

Summative evaluation: Conducted after program completion (or at the end of a cycle). Its purpose is to judge the overall merit, worth, or effectiveness of the program. Summative evaluation determines whether program goals were achieved and informs decisions about continuation or funding. Think: "summing up" the program.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Blueprints for Discovery: Research Designs > Program Evaluation > Formative vs. Summative Evaluation
anchors_text:
[001] Formative evaluation: Conducted during program development and implementation. Its purpose is to improve the program while it is still being shaped. Formative evaluation identifies problems in delivery, monitors progress, and provides feedback for mid-course corrections. Think: "forming" the program.
[002] Summative evaluation: Conducted after program completion (or at the end of a cycle). Its purpose is to judge the overall merit, worth, or effectiveness of the program. Summative evaluation determines whether program goals were achieved and informs decisions about continuation or funding. Think: "summing up" the program.

anchors.text: A needs assessment is conducted before program design to identify the needs of the target population and determine whether a program is warranted. It answers the question: "What problems exist and what services are needed?" Methods include surveys, interviews, focus groups, and analysis of existing data (e.g., community health statistics).

Process evaluation (also called implementation evaluation) monitors whether the program is being delivered as intended. It assesses implementation fidelity—the degree to which the program follows its designed protocol. Process evaluation answers: "Is the program being carried out as planned? Are participants being reached? Are services being delivered correctly?"

Outcome evaluation measures whether program goals and objectives were achieved. It examines the direct, intended effects of the program on participants. For example, did a smoking cessation program lead to reduced smoking rates among participants? Outcome evaluations typically use pre-post designs or comparison groups.

Impact evaluation examines the broader, long-term effects of a program on the community or population beyond the immediate participants. It assesses whether the program produced lasting change and whether effects generalized beyond the target group. Impact evaluations are more comprehensive than outcome evaluations and often examine unintended consequences as well.

Example: A community mental health agency develops a depression prevention program for at-risk adolescents: Needs assessment: Surveys local schools and clinics to document teen depression rates and identify service gaps Process evaluation: During the program, monitors session attendance, facilitator adherence to the manual, and participant engagement Outcome evaluation: Compares pre- and post-program depression scores to determine if symptoms decreased Impact evaluation: Two years later, examines whether reduced depression translated into improved academic performance, fewer hospitalizations, and lower community-wide teen suicide rates

anchors.text: Empowerment evaluation, developed by David Fetterman, is a participatory approach in which program stakeholders (staff, participants, community members) are trained to conduct their own evaluations. The evaluator serves as a facilitator or coach rather than an external judge. The goal is to build the program's internal capacity for self-evaluation and continuous improvement.
Daniel Stufflebeam's CIPP Model is a comprehensive framework with four components:
Context evaluation: Assesses needs, problems, and opportunities in the program environment to guide planning decisions
Input evaluation: Evaluates resources, strategies, and alternative approaches to guide structuring decisions
Process evaluation: Monitors program implementation to guide implementation decisions
Product evaluation: Measures outcomes and impact to guide recycling (continuation, modification, or termination) decisions

Michael Quinn Patton's utilization-focused evaluation is designed from the outset to be useful to its intended users. Rather than prescribing a specific methodology, this approach begins by identifying the primary intended users and their information needs, then tailors the evaluation design to ensure findings will actually be used for decision-making.
Purpose: Research seeks generalizable knowledge; evaluation informs specific program decisions
Audience: Research targets the scientific community; evaluation targets stakeholders and decision-makers
Design priority: Research emphasizes internal validity; evaluation balances rigor with practical constraints
IRB review: Both may require IRB approval, but program evaluation that is purely for quality improvement (not generalizable) may be exempt

anchors.text: Campbell and Stanley and later Cook and Campbell identified numerous threats to internal validity. These are alternative explanations for observed effects that compete with the interpretation that the IV caused changes in the DV.
History refers to external events occurring during the study that may affect the dependent variable. These events are not part of the treatment but happen between pretest and posttest measurements.

Example: A researcher studies the effect of a new anxiety treatment over 8 weeks. During the study, a major national crisis occurs, elevating anxiety in the population. Any observed changes in anxiety might be due to the treatment, the crisis, or both. The external event (crisis) is a history threat.

Maturation refers to natural changes in participants over time, such as growing older, becoming tired, or gaining experience. These changes occur regardless of treatment and may be mistaken for treatment effects.

Testing (also called practice effects) occurs when taking a pretest affects performance on a posttest. Participants may remember items, become test-wise, or become sensitized to what the researcher is measuring.

Instrumentation refers to changes in the measuring instrument or procedure during the study. This includes observer drift (observers changing their rating criteria over time), equipment calibration changes, or modified administration procedures.

Statistical regression (regression to the mean) occurs when participants are selected based on extreme scores. Extreme scores tend to move toward the mean on retesting due to measurement error, regardless of any treatment effect.

Example: A school identifies students with the lowest reading scores for a remedial program. Even without any intervention, these students would likely score somewhat higher on a second test simply because their extreme scores were partly due to measurement error (bad day, unlucky guesses). Any improvement might be regression, not program effects.

Selection occurs when groups differ systematically before treatment. This is a major threat in non-randomized studies. If the treatment group differs from the comparison group on relevant characteristics, any observed differences could be due to pre-existing differences rather than treatment.

Mortality (or attrition) refers to differential dropout from groups during the study. If participants who drop out differ systematically from those who remain (and if dropout rates differ between groups), results may be biased.
Selection can interact with other threats. Selection-maturation occurs when groups mature at different rates. Selection-history occurs when groups are differentially affected by external events.
Diffusion of Treatment: Control group participants learn about or receive aspects of the treatment.
Compensatory Equalization: Administrators provide extra services to the control group to compensate for not receiving treatment.
Compensatory Rivalry: Control group participants work harder to compete with the treatment group (John Henry effect).
Resentful Demoralization: Control group participants become demoralized and perform worse than they otherwise would.

anchors.text: Population validity: Can results be generalized to other people?
Ecological validity: Can results be generalized to other settings?
Temporal validity: Can results be generalized to other time periods?
Treatment variation validity: Can results be generalized to other versions of the treatment?

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Threats & Safeguards: Research Validity > External Validity > Types of External Validity
anchors_text:
[001] Population validity: Can results be generalized to other people?
[002] Ecological validity: Can results be generalized to other settings?
[003] Temporal validity: Can results be generalized to other time periods?
[004] Treatment variation validity: Can results be generalized to other versions of the treatment?

anchors.text: Results may apply only to the specific type of participants studied. For example, a treatment effective for college students might not work for older adults. Volunteer bias is a common form—volunteers may differ from non-volunteers in motivation or characteristics.

Results from one setting may not generalize to others. Laboratory findings may not translate to real-world contexts. A therapy effective in a university clinic may not work in a community mental health center.
Results may be specific to a particular time period. Findings from decades past may not apply today due to cultural, technological, or social changes.

When applying research findings to practice, clinicians must consider whether results generalize to their specific clients and settings. If a treatment was validated primarily on white, middle-class college students, its effectiveness with diverse clinical populations should be evaluated carefully. Evidence-based practice requires attention to both internal validity (does it work?) and external validity (will it work for my clients?).
Pretesting may sensitize participants to the treatment, and without pretesting, results might differ. The treatment effect may depend on the pretest having occurred.
When participants receive multiple treatments, effects of earlier treatments may persist and influence responses to later treatments. Order effects and carryover effects fall into this category.

anchors.text: Poor or incomplete definition of the constructs being studied leads to operationalizations that miss important aspects of the construct or include irrelevant elements.
Using only one operationalization of a construct. A single measure captures only part of a construct and includes irrelevant variance. Multiple operationalizations provide stronger evidence.

Using only one method of measurement. Shared method variance may inflate relationships. Using multiple methods (e.g., self-report, behavioral observation, physiological measures) provides stronger evidence.
Participants guess what the study is about and alter their behavior accordingly. Demand characteristics lead participants to behave as they think the researcher expects.
Researchers' expectations influence participant behavior or data interpretation. Double-blind procedures control for this threat.

When the operationalization of one construct is confounded with another construct. For example, a treatment that includes both cognitive restructuring and relaxation training confounds these two components.

[004] Participants guess what the study is about and alter their behavior accordingly. Demand characteristics lead participants to behave as they think the researcher expects.

anchors.text: When a study has insufficient power to detect a true effect, the researcher may incorrectly conclude no effect exists (Type II error). Small samples and high variability reduce power.
Using statistical tests when their assumptions are violated (e.g., normality, homogeneity of variance) can lead to inaccurate conclusions.
Conducting multiple statistical tests without correction inflates the probability of Type I errors. "Fishing" for significant results capitalizes on chance.
Unreliable measures attenuate observed relationships. Low reliability in either IV manipulation or DV measurement reduces the ability to detect true effects.
Limited variability in scores attenuates correlations and reduces the ability to detect relationships that exist in the population.

anchors.text: Random assignment: The most powerful control for selection and related threats

Pretesting: Establishes baseline and helps detect selection differences
Matching: Pairing participants on relevant variables
Blinding: Participants and/or researchers unaware of condition
Standardized procedures: Consistent administration controls instrumentation
Follow-up of dropouts: Assess and address attrition bias

anchors.text: Random selection: Sampling from the target population
Heterogeneous samples: Including diverse participants

Random assignment controls internal validity threats by ensuring groups are equivalent. Random selection (from the population to the sample) controls external validity threats by ensuring the sample represents the population. Many students confuse these concepts on the EPPP. Random assignment creates equivalent groups; random selection creates representative samples.

chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity

anchors.text: Content validity refers to the degree to which test items adequately sample the domain of content the test is intended to measure. It is established through logical analysis rather than statistical procedures and is particularly important for achievement tests and job performance assessments.
Domain definition: Clearly specify the content domain to be measured
Test blueprint: Create a table of specifications linking items to content areas
Expert review: Have subject matter experts evaluate item relevance and representativeness
Content validity ratio (CVR): Quantify agreement among experts about item essentiality

Example: A licensing exam for clinical psychologists should sample knowledge across relevant domains: assessment, diagnosis, treatment, ethics, and research methods. If the exam heavily emphasizes one area while neglecting others, it would have poor content validity for measuring overall competence in clinical psychology.

Face validity refers to whether a test appears to measure what it claims to measure, from the perspective of examinees or untrained observers. While not technically a form of validity evidence, face validity can affect examinee motivation, public acceptance, and perceived fairness. A test can have good construct validity but poor face validity, or vice versa.

chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity

anchors.text: This type of evidence examines whether examinees actually engage in the cognitive processes the test intends to measure. Methods include think-aloud protocols, eye-tracking studies, and analysis of response patterns.

If a reading comprehension test is designed to measure inference-making, validity evidence should demonstrate that examinees actually make inferences to answer questions, rather than relying on prior knowledge or test-taking strategies that bypass the intended processes.

[002] If a reading comprehension test is designed to measure inference-making, validity evidence should demonstrate that examinees actually make inferences to answer questions, rather than relying on prior knowledge or test-taking strategies that bypass the intended processes.

chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity

anchors.text: Internal structure evidence examines whether the relationships among test items and components conform to the theoretical structure of the construct. Factor analysis is the primary statistical technique for evaluating internal structure.

Exploratory factor analysis (EFA) identifies the underlying factor structure without prior hypotheses about the number or nature of factors. Confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) tests whether data fit a hypothesized factor structure based on theory.

Example: An anxiety measure theorized to assess three components (cognitive, somatic, behavioral) should show three distinct factors in factor analysis. If items from different subscales load on the same factor, or if a single general factor emerges, the theoretical structure is not supported.

[003] Example: An anxiety measure theorized to assess three components (cognitive, somatic, behavioral) should show three distinct factors in factor analysis. If items from different subscales load on the same factor, or if a single general factor emerges, the theoretical structure is not supported.

chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
topic_name: Evidence Based on Relations to Other Variables

anchors.text: This evidence demonstrates that test scores relate to external variables in ways consistent with the theoretical understanding of the construct. This category includes convergent and discriminant validity evidence, as well as criterion-related validity.

Convergent validity is demonstrated when a test correlates strongly with other measures of the same or similar constructs. High correlations with conceptually related measures support the interpretation that the test measures the intended construct.
Discriminant validity is demonstrated when a test shows low correlations with measures of theoretically unrelated constructs. This evidence supports the distinctiveness of the measured construct.
Convergent validity: High correlations between the same trait measured by different methods (monotrait-heteromethod)
Discriminant validity: Lower correlations between different traits, even when measured by the same method (heterotrait-monomethod)

chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity

anchors.text: Cronbach and Meehl introduced the concept of a nomological network—the theoretical framework specifying the relationships between a construct and other constructs, as well as observable manifestations. Validity evidence supports or challenges elements of this network.

Example: The nomological network for intelligence includes theoretical relationships (intelligence should correlate positively with academic achievement, problem-solving ability, and processing speed) and observable indicators (IQ scores should predict school grades, job performance in complex occupations, and performance on cognitive tasks). Evidence supporting these relationships strengthens construct validity.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity > Construct Validity > The Nomological Network
anchors_text:
[001] Cronbach and Meehl introduced the concept of a nomological network—the theoretical framework specifying the relationships between a construct and other constructs, as well as observable manifestations. Validity evidence supports or challenges elements of this network.
[002] Example: The nomological network for intelligence includes theoretical relationships (intelligence should correlate positively with academic achievement, problem-solving ability, and processing speed) and observable indicators (IQ scores should predict school grades, job performance in complex occupations, and performance on cognitive tasks). Evidence supporting these relationships strengthens construct validity.

chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity

anchors.text: Two major threats can undermine construct validity:
Construct underrepresentation occurs when a test fails to capture important aspects of the construct. The test is too narrow, measuring only part of what it should measure.

Construct-irrelevant variance occurs when test scores are influenced by factors unrelated to the construct. These irrelevant factors can include test anxiety, reading ability on non-reading tests, or cultural bias.
Underrepresentation: Ensure comprehensive sampling of the construct domain; use multiple item formats
Irrelevant variance: Minimize irrelevant difficulty sources; provide accommodations when appropriate; evaluate differential item functioning across groups

[004] Underrepresentation: Ensure comprehensive sampling of the construct domain; use multiple item formats
[005] Irrelevant variance: Minimize irrelevant difficulty sources; provide accommodations when appropriate; evaluate differential item functioning across groups

chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity

anchors.text: Validity generalization studies use meta-analytic techniques to:
Estimate the mean true validity across studies
Determine how much variability remains after correcting for artifacts
Identify moderators that explain remaining variability

Example: Meta-analyses of cognitive ability tests show that their validity for predicting job performance generalizes across jobs and settings, with corrected validity coefficients typically ranging from .50 to .60 for overall job performance. This suggests that cognitive ability is a valid predictor across many employment contexts.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity > Validity Generalization > Meta-Analysis of Validity Coefficients
anchors_text:
[001] Validity generalization studies use meta-analytic techniques to:
[002] Estimate the mean true validity across studies
[003] Determine how much variability remains after correcting for artifacts
[004] Identify moderators that explain remaining variability
[005] Example: Meta-analyses of cognitive ability tests show that their validity for predicting job performance generalizes across jobs and settings, with corrected validity coefficients typically ranging from .50 to .60 for overall job performance. This suggests that cognitive ability is a valid predictor across many employment contexts.

chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity

anchors.text: Predictive bias exists when a test's regression line for predicting a criterion differs across groups. If the same test score predicts different criterion levels for different groups, selection decisions based on the test may be unfair.

Differential item functioning occurs when examinees of equal ability from different groups have different probabilities of answering an item correctly. DIF analysis identifies potentially biased items that may function differently across demographic groups.

Bias is a statistical/psychometric concept referring to systematic measurement error. Fairness is a broader concept encompassing social values and judgments about appropriate test use. A test can be psychometrically unbiased yet still raise fairness concerns if its use produces adverse impact on protected groups.
Compare regression equations across groups (intercepts and slopes)
Conduct DIF analyses to identify problematic items
Examine whether content represents all groups fairly
Consider the consequences of test use for different groups

anchors_text:

[002] Differential item functioning occurs when examinees of equal ability from different groups have different probabilities of answering an item correctly. DIF analysis identifies potentially biased items that may function differently across demographic groups.
[003] Bias is a statistical/psychometric concept referring to systematic measurement error. Fairness is a broader concept encompassing social values and judgments about appropriate test use. A test can be psychometrically unbiased yet still raise fairness concerns if its use produces adverse impact on protected groups.
[004] Compare regression equations across groups (intercepts and slopes)
[005] Conduct DIF analyses to identify problematic items
[006] Examine whether content represents all groups fairly
[007] Consider the consequences of test use for different groups

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: The independent variable (IV) is the variable that is manipulated or selected by the researcher to determine its effect on behavior. The dependent variable (DV) is the measured outcome that is expected to change as a function of the independent variable.

Example: In a study examining the effects of sleep deprivation on memory, the researcher manipulates hours of sleep (IV: 8 hours vs. 4 hours) and measures performance on a memory test (DV). The dependent variable "depends on" the level of the independent variable.

Extraneous variables are variables other than the IV that could potentially influence the DV. When an extraneous variable systematically varies with the IV, it becomes a confounding variable, making it impossible to determine whether the IV or the confound caused changes in the DV.
Random assignment: Distributes individual differences across conditions
Matching: Ensures groups are equivalent on specific variables
Holding constant: Keeps a variable at one level across all conditions
Counterbalancing: Varies order of conditions to control sequence effects
Statistical control: Uses ANCOVA or partial correlation to remove effects

A mediating variable explains the mechanism through which an IV affects a DV. It represents the pathway or process by which the effect occurs. A moderating variable affects the strength or direction of the relationship between an IV and DV—it identifies when or for whom an effect occurs.

Example: Mediator example: Therapy → Increased self-efficacy → Decreased depression. Self-efficacy mediates the relationship between therapy and depression by explaining how therapy works. Moderator example: The effect of therapy on depression is stronger for patients with high motivation (motivation moderates the therapy-depression relationship by explaining when therapy works best).

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: The nominal scale uses numbers only as labels or names for categories. Numbers cannot be meaningfully added, subtracted, or compared in terms of magnitude. Examples include gender (1 = male, 2 = female), diagnostic categories, or political party affiliation.
Appropriate statistics for nominal data include frequency counts, percentages, mode, and chi-square tests.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Variables, Scales & the Language of Data > Scales of Measurement > Nominal Scale
anchors_text:
[001] The nominal scale uses numbers only as labels or names for categories. Numbers cannot be meaningfully added, subtracted, or compared in terms of magnitude. Examples include gender (1 = male, 2 = female), diagnostic categories, or political party affiliation.
[002] Appropriate statistics for nominal data include frequency counts, percentages, mode, and chi-square tests.

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: The ordinal scale ranks observations from lowest to highest but does not specify the distance between ranks. The difference between ranks 1 and 2 may not equal the difference between ranks 2 and 3. Examples include class rank, Likert-type scales, and socioeconomic status categories.
Appropriate statistics include median, percentile ranks, and nonparametric tests (Spearman correlation, Mann-Whitney U).

[002] Appropriate statistics include median, percentile ranks, and nonparametric tests (Spearman correlation, Mann-Whitney U).

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: The interval scale has equal intervals between values but no true zero point. The zero is arbitrary, and ratios are not meaningful. The classic example is temperature in Fahrenheit or Celsius—the difference between 20° and 30° equals the difference between 70° and 80°, but 40° is not "twice as hot" as 20°.
Most psychological tests are treated as interval scales. Appropriate statistics include mean, standard deviation, Pearson correlation, t-tests, and ANOVA.

full_path: Domain 1: Psychometrics & Research Methods > Variables, Scales & the Language of Data > Scales of Measurement > Interval Scale
anchors_text:

The classic example is temperature in Fahrenheit or Celsius—the difference between 20° and 30° equals the difference between 70° and 80°, but 40° is not "twice as hot" as 20°.
[002] Most psychological tests are treated as interval scales. Appropriate statistics include mean, standard deviation, Pearson correlation, t-tests, and ANOVA.

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: The ratio scale has all the properties of the interval scale plus a true zero point representing the absence of the measured attribute. Ratios are meaningful—10 seconds is twice as long as 5 seconds. Examples include reaction time, number of errors, height, and weight.
All statistical procedures are appropriate for ratio data.
Nominal — Categories only — Diagnosis, gender — Mode
Ordinal — Rank order — Class rank, severity ratings — Median
Interval — Equal intervals, no true zero — Temperature, IQ scores — Mean
Ratio — Equal intervals, true zero — Reaction time, height — Mean

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: Central tendency statistics identify the typical or representative score in a distribution.

The mean (M or X̄) is the arithmetic average, calculated by summing all scores and dividing by the number of scores. It uses information from every score but is sensitive to extreme values (outliers). The mean is appropriate for interval and ratio data.

The median (Mdn) is the middle score when data are arranged in order. It is less affected by outliers than the mean and is appropriate for ordinal, interval, and ratio data. In a skewed distribution, the median better represents the typical score.
The mode is the most frequently occurring score. It is the only measure of central tendency appropriate for nominal data. A distribution can be bimodal (two modes) or multimodal (multiple modes).

Use the mean when the distribution is relatively normal and outliers are absent. Use the median when the distribution is skewed or contains outliers (e.g., income data). Use the mode for nominal data or to identify the most common category.

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: Variability statistics describe how spread out scores are in a distribution.
The range is the difference between the highest and lowest scores. It is simple but unstable because it is based on only two scores and is highly sensitive to outliers.

The variance (s² or σ²) is the average of the squared deviations from the mean. Squaring the deviations ensures that positive and negative deviations do not cancel out. Sample variance uses n-1 in the denominator to provide an unbiased estimate of population variance.

The standard deviation (SD or s) is the square root of the variance, returning the measure to the original unit of measurement. It represents the average distance of scores from the mean and is the most commonly used measure of variability.
Variance (sample): s² = Σ(X - M)² / (n - 1)
Standard Deviation: s = √s²
The divisor (n - 1) is called degrees of freedom and provides an unbiased estimate of the population parameter.

Defined by two parameters: mean (μ) and standard deviation (σ)
Approximately 68% of scores fall within ±1 SD of the mean
Approximately 95% of scores fall within ±2 SD of the mean
Approximately 99.7% of scores fall within ±3 SD of the mean
68% of observations fall between M - 1SD and M + 1SD
95% of observations fall between M - 2SD and M + 2SD
99.7% of observations fall between M - 3SD and M + 3SD

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: A z-score (standard score) expresses a raw score in terms of how many standard deviations it falls above or below the mean. Z-scores allow comparison of scores from different distributions by converting them to a common scale.
Where X is the raw score, M is the mean, and SD is the standard deviation.
The z-score distribution always has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

Example: On a test with M = 100 and SD = 15, a score of 130 has a z-score of: z = (130 - 100) / 15 = 30 / 15 = 2.0 This score is 2 standard deviations above the mean, falling at approximately the 98th percentile in a normal distribution.

[002] Where X is the raw score, M is the mean, and SD is the standard deviation.
[003] The z-score distribution always has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.
[004] Example: On a test with M = 100 and SD = 15, a score of 130 has a z-score of: z = (130 - 100) / 15 = 30 / 15 = 2.0 This score is 2 standard deviations above the mean, falling at approximately the 98th percentile in a normal distribution.

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: Z-scores can be linearly transformed to other standard score scales that eliminate negative values and decimals:
IQ (deviation) — 100 — 15 — IQ = 15z + 100
SAT/GRE subtest — 500 — 100 — Score = 100z + 500
Stanine — 5 — 2 — Stanine = 2z + 5

[002] T-score — 50 — 10 — T = 10z + 50
[003] IQ (deviation) — 100 — 15 — IQ = 15z + 100
[004] SAT/GRE subtest — 500 — 100 — Score = 100z + 500
[005] Stanine — 5 — 2 — Stanine = 2z + 5

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: Skewness refers to the asymmetry of a distribution. In a positively skewed distribution, the tail extends toward higher values (right), and the mean is greater than the median. In a negatively skewed distribution, the tail extends toward lower values (left), and the mean is less than the median.

Example: Positive skew: Income distribution (many low-to-moderate incomes, few very high incomes pulling the mean up) Negative skew: Age at death in developed countries (most people live to old age, with some early deaths pulling the mean down)

In a negatively skewed distribution, the tail extends toward lower values (left), and the mean is less than the median.
[002] Example: Positive skew: Income distribution (many low-to-moderate incomes, few very high incomes pulling the mean up) Negative skew: Age at death in developed countries (most people live to old age, with some early deaths pulling the mean down)

chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data

anchors.text: Kurtosis describes the "peakedness" of a distribution and the heaviness of its tails. Leptokurtic distributions are more peaked with heavier tails than normal (positive kurtosis). Platykurtic distributions are flatter with lighter tails (negative kurtosis). Mesokurtic distributions have the same kurtosis as the normal distribution.
Using nonparametric alternatives
Transforming data (log, square root)
Using robust statistical methods
Reporting median instead of mean for skewed data

Platykurtic distributions are flatter with lighter tails (negative kurtosis). Mesokurtic distributions have the same kurtosis as the normal distribution.
[002] Using nonparametric alternatives

anchors.text: Jean Piaget proposed that children actively construct their understanding of the world through a series of qualitatively distinct cognitive stages. Central to his theory are the processes of assimilation (incorporating new experiences into existing schemas) and accommodation (modifying existing schemas to fit new information). The dynamic tension between these processes drives cognitive growth through a process Piaget called equilibration.
A cognitive framework or concept that organizes and interprets information. Schemas change with development, becoming more complex and abstract as the child matures through Piaget's stages.
Sensorimotor — Birth–2 years — Object permanence, goal-directed behavior, mental representation
Preoperational — 2–7 years — Symbolic thought, egocentrism, centration, irreversibility
Concrete Operational — 7–11 years — Conservation, classification, seriation, logical operations on concrete objects
Formal Operational — 11+ years — Abstract reasoning, hypothetical-deductive thinking, propositional thought

Example: A 5-year-old watches as water is poured from a short, wide glass into a tall, narrow glass and says there is now "more water." This illustrates the preoperational child's failure to conserve, driven by centration on a single perceptual dimension (height).
Piaget, J.. The origins of intelligence in children. International Universities Press.

[001] Jean Piaget proposed that children actively construct their understanding of the world through a series of qualitatively distinct cognitive stages. Central to his theory are the processes of assimilation (incorporating new experiences into existing schemas) and accommodation (modifying existing schemas to fit new information). The dynamic tension between these processes drives cognitive growth through a process Piaget called equilibration.
[002] A cognitive framework or concept that organizes and interprets information. Schemas change with development, becoming more complex and abstract as the child matures through Piaget's stages.
[003] Sensorimotor — Birth–2 years — Object permanence, goal-directed behavior, mental representation
[004] Preoperational — 2–7 years — Symbolic thought, egocentrism, centration, irreversibility
[005] Concrete Operational — 7–11 years — Conservation, classification, seriation, logical operations on concrete objects
[006] Formal Operational — 11+ years — Abstract reasoning, hypothetical-deductive thinking, propositional thought
[007] Example: A 5-year-old watches as water is poured from a short, wide glass into a tall, narrow glass and says there is now "more water." This illustrates the preoperational child's failure to conserve, driven by centration on a single perceptual dimension (height).
[008] Piaget, J.. The origins of intelligence in children. International Universities Press.

anchors.text: Lev Vygotsky challenged Piaget's view of the solitary child-as-scientist by emphasizing that cognitive development is fundamentally a social and cultural process. Vygotsky argued that higher mental functions—including logical memory, voluntary attention, and conceptual thinking—originate in social interactions before being internalized by the individual.

The distance between what a learner can do independently and what they can accomplish with the guidance of a more skilled partner. Learning is most effective when instruction targets this zone rather than tasks the child can already perform or those far beyond current capacity.

The process by which a more knowledgeable other (parent, teacher, peer) provides temporary, adjustable support to help a learner master a task within their ZPD. As competence increases, the support is gradually withdrawn.

Vygotsky's ZPD concept has direct implications for educational psychology and intervention planning. Clinicians conducting psychoeducational assessments may distinguish between a child's independent performance level and their assisted performance level, using the gap to guide recommendations for instructional strategies and accommodations.
Vygotsky, L. S.. Mind in society: The development of higher psychological processes. Harvard University Press.

[001] Lev Vygotsky challenged Piaget's view of the solitary child-as-scientist by emphasizing that cognitive development is fundamentally a social and cultural process. Vygotsky argued that higher mental functions—including logical memory, voluntary attention, and conceptual thinking—originate in social interactions before being internalized by the individual.
[002] The distance between what a learner can do independently and what they can accomplish with the guidance of a more skilled partner. Learning is most effective when instruction targets this zone rather than tasks the child can already perform or those far beyond current capacity.
[003] The process by which a more knowledgeable other (parent, teacher, peer) provides temporary, adjustable support to help a learner master a task within their ZPD. As competence increases, the support is gradually withdrawn.
[004] Vygotsky's ZPD concept has direct implications for educational psychology and intervention planning. Clinicians conducting psychoeducational assessments may distinguish between a child's independent performance level and their assisted performance level, using the gap to guide recommendations for instructional strategies and accommodations.
[005] Vygotsky, L. S.. Mind in society: The development of higher psychological processes. Harvard University Press.

anchors.text: Gene-environment interaction (G x E) occurs when the effect of a gene depends on the environment, or vice versa. For example, the short allele of the 5-HTTLPR serotonin transporter gene has been associated with increased risk for depression, but primarily in individuals exposed to significant life stress.

Gene-environment correlation (rGE) occurs when genetic predispositions influence environmental exposure. Three types include: passive rGE (parents provide both genes and environment), evocative rGE (a child's genetically influenced traits elicit particular environmental responses), and active rGE (individuals seek out environments compatible with their genetic tendencies).

The study of heritable changes in gene expression that do not involve alterations to the DNA sequence itself. Epigenetic mechanisms—such as DNA methylation and histone modification—can be influenced by environmental factors including nutrition, stress, and toxin exposure, effectively serving as a molecular bridge between nature and nurture.

Research on early adversity and epigenetics has shown that childhood maltreatment can alter glucocorticoid receptor gene methylation, affecting the stress response system. These findings have profound implications for understanding intergenerational transmission of trauma and the biological mechanisms underlying resilience and vulnerability.
Caspi, A., et al.. Influence of life stress on depression: Moderation by a polymorphism in the 5-HTT gene. Science, 301(5631), 386–389.

For example, the short allele of the 5-HTTLPR serotonin transporter gene has been associated with increased risk for depression, but primarily in individuals exposed to significant life stress.
[002] Gene-environment correlation (rGE) occurs when genetic predispositions influence environmental exposure. Three types include: passive rGE (parents provide both genes and environment), evocative rGE (a child's genetically influenced traits elicit particular environmental responses), and active rGE (individuals seek out environments compatible with their genetic tendencies).
[003] The study of heritable changes in gene expression that do not involve alterations to the DNA sequence itself. Epigenetic mechanisms—such as DNA methylation and histone modification—can be influenced by environmental factors including nutrition, stress, and toxin exposure, effectively serving as a molecular bridge between nature and nurture.
[004] Research on early adversity and epigenetics has shown that childhood maltreatment can alter glucocorticoid receptor gene methylation, affecting the stress response system. These findings have profound implications for understanding intergenerational transmission of trauma and the biological mechanisms underlying resilience and vulnerability.
[005] Caspi, A., et al.. Influence of life stress on depression: Moderation by a polymorphism in the 5-HTT gene. Science, 301(5631), 386–389.

anchors.text: A cross-sectional design compares groups of participants at different ages at a single point in time. This approach is faster and less expensive than longitudinal research but cannot track individual change and is vulnerable to cohort effects—differences between age groups that reflect generational differences in experiences rather than developmental change per se.

A difference between groups in a cross-sectional study that is attributable to the unique historical experiences of each generation rather than to age-related development. For example, differences in technology use between 20-year-olds and 70-year-olds tested today may reflect generational exposure rather than cognitive aging.

anchors_text:
[001] A cross-sectional design compares groups of participants at different ages at a single point in time. This approach is faster and less expensive than longitudinal research but cannot track individual change and is vulnerable to cohort effects—differences between age groups that reflect generational differences in experiences rather than developmental change per se.
[002] A difference between groups in a cross-sectional study that is attributable to the unique historical experiences of each generation rather than to age-related development. For example, differences in technology use between 20-year-olds and 70-year-olds tested today may reflect generational exposure rather than cognitive aging.

anchors.text: Sequential designs (also called cohort-sequential or cross-sequential designs) combine elements of both longitudinal and cross-sectional approaches by studying multiple cohorts over time. This powerful strategy, championed by K. Warner Schaie, allows researchers to separate the effects of age, cohort, and time of measurement.
Longitudinal — Tracks individual change; identifies causal antecedents — Expensive; attrition; practice effects; cohort-specific
Cross-Sectional — Efficient; no attrition; quick results — Cohort effects; cannot measure individual change
Sequential — Separates age, cohort, and time effects — Complex; expensive; still subject to some attrition

Example: A researcher in 1990 begins studying cognitive abilities in groups of 20-, 40-, and 60-year-olds, then retests each group every 10 years. By 2010, she can compare age effects (within-person change), cohort effects (between-group differences at the same age), and time-of-measurement effects. This is a sequential design.
Schaie, K. W.. Intellectual development in adulthood: The Seattle Longitudinal Study. Cambridge University Press.

anchors.text: Pre-attachment phase (birth to 6 weeks): Infant signals (crying, grasping, smiling) are directed at anyone; no specific attachment
Attachment-in-the-making (6 weeks to 6-8 months): Infant begins to show differential responding to familiar caregivers but does not protest separation

Clear-cut attachment (6-8 months to 18-24 months): Specific attachment is evident; separation anxiety and stranger anxiety emerge; the child actively seeks proximity and protests when the attachment figure leaves
Goal-corrected partnership (24 months onward): The child begins to understand the caregiver's goals and motives and can negotiate plans, enabling more flexible attachment behavior

[003] Clear-cut attachment (6-8 months to 18-24 months): Specific attachment is evident; separation anxiety and stranger anxiety emerge; the child actively seeks proximity and protests when the attachment figure leaves
[004] Goal-corrected partnership (24 months onward): The child begins to understand the caregiver's goals and motives and can negotiate plans, enabling more flexible attachment behavior

anchors.text: Harry Harlow's research with rhesus monkeys provided powerful evidence against drive-reduction theory. Infant monkeys separated from their mothers were given a choice between a wire "mother" that provided food and a cloth "mother" that provided no food but was covered in soft terrycloth. The monkeys overwhelmingly preferred the cloth mother, spending most of their time clinging to it and running to it when frightened. This demonstrated that contact comfort, not feeding, was the primary basis of attachment.

Monkeys raised in isolation showed severe and lasting social deficits, including inability to mate, neglect of offspring, and self-injurious behavior -- demonstrating the long-term consequences of attachment deprivation.

anchors.text: Secure: Comfortable with intimacy and interdependence; trusting
Avoidant: Uncomfortable with closeness; values independence; suppresses attachment needs
Anxious-ambivalent: Preoccupied with relationships; fears abandonment; hyperactivates attachment system

anchors.text: Bartholomew proposed a four-category model based on two dimensions: model of self (positive/negative) and model of others (positive/negative):
Positive Model of Self — Secure: Comfortable with intimacy and autonomy — Dismissing: Self-reliant; deactivates attachment; dismisses importance of relationships

Negative Model of Self — Preoccupied: Seeks excessive closeness; hypervigilant to rejection; hyperactivates attachment system — Fearful-avoidant: Desires closeness but fears rejection; both activates and deactivates attachment

anchors.text: The Adult Attachment Interview, developed by Mary Main and colleagues, assesses adults' "state of mind with respect to attachment" through a semi-structured interview about childhood attachment experiences. Classification is based not on what happened but on how coherently and collaboratively the person narrates their attachment history:
Autonomous/Secure (F): Coherent, balanced narrative; values attachment relationships
Dismissing (Ds): Minimizes attachment; idealizes or dismisses parents; brief, incomplete narratives that contradict general positive statements
Preoccupied (E): Entangled with past attachment experiences; angry, confused, or passive narratives; excessive detail
Unresolved/Disorganized (U/d): Lapses in monitoring of reasoning or discourse when discussing loss or trauma (e.g., speaking of a deceased person as if alive)
Robust research demonstrates intergenerational transmission: a parent's AAI classification predicts their infant's Strange Situation classification with approximately 75% accuracy.
