anchors.text: Criterion A: Developmentally inappropriate and excessive fear or anxiety concerning separation from those to whom the individual is attached, as evidenced by at least three of the following: Recurrent excessive distress when anticipating or experiencing separation from home or major attachment figures Persistent and excessive worry about losing major attachment figures or about possible harm to them (e.g., illness, injury, disaster, death) Persistent and excessive worry about experiencing an untoward event (e.g., getting lost, being kidnapped, having an accident) that causes separation from a major attachment figure Persistent reluctance or refusal to go out, away from home, to school, to work, or elsewhere because of fear of separation Persistent and excessive fear of or reluctance about being alone or without major attachment figures at home or in other settings Persistent reluctance or refusal to sleep away from home or to go to sleep without being near a major attachment figure Repeated nightmares involving the theme of separation Repeated complaints of physical symptoms (e.g., headaches, stomachaches, nausea, vomiting) when separation from major attachment figures occurs or is anticipated
Criterion B: The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, lasting at least 4 weeks in children and adolescents and typically 6 months or more in adults.
Criterion C: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, academic, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
Criterion D: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder.

The DSM-5 applies a differential duration threshold: 4 weeks for children and adolescents versus 6 months for adults. This reflects the recognition that brief separation fears are normative in childhood but more clinically significant when persistent in adulthood.

anchors.text: Separation anxiety disorder is the most common anxiety disorder in children under 12, with a prevalence of approximately 4% in children and 1-2% in adults. Onset typically occurs in childhood, though adult-onset cases are increasingly recognized. The disorder tends to fluctuate in severity and may re-emerge during periods of stress.

Somatic complaints, particularly headaches and stomachaches, are a hallmark presentation in children with separation anxiety disorder, especially on school mornings or in anticipation of separation. These physical symptoms often lead to medical evaluation before the anxiety disorder is identified. In adults, separation anxiety frequently manifests as excessive concern about the well-being of children or a spouse and reluctance to be apart from them.

anchors.text: Criterion A: Preoccupation with one or more perceived defects or flaws in physical appearance that are not observable or appear only slight to others.

Criterion B: At some point during the course of the disorder, the individual has performed repetitive behaviors (e.g., mirror checking, excessive grooming, skin picking, reassurance seeking) or mental acts (e.g., comparing his or her appearance with that of others) in response to the appearance concerns.
Criterion C: The preoccupation causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
Criterion D: The appearance preoccupation is not better explained by concerns with body fat or weight in an individual whose symptoms meet diagnostic criteria for an eating disorder.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Anxiety Disorders & OCD > Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) > DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria
anchors_text:
[001] Criterion A: Preoccupation with one or more perceived defects or flaws in physical appearance that are not observable or appear only slight to others.
[002] Criterion B: At some point during the course of the disorder, the individual has performed repetitive behaviors (e.g., mirror checking, excessive grooming, skin picking, reassurance seeking) or mental acts (e.g., comparing his or her appearance with that of others) in response to the appearance concerns.
[003] Criterion C: The preoccupation causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
[004] Criterion D: The appearance preoccupation is not better explained by concerns with body fat or weight in an individual whose symptoms meet diagnostic criteria for an eating disorder.

anchors.text: With muscle dysmorphia: The individual is preoccupied with the idea that his or her body build is too small or insufficiently muscular. This specifier applies even if the individual is also preoccupied with other body areas.
Insight specifier: With good or fair insight, with poor insight, or with absent insight/delusional beliefs.

The repetitive behaviors in BDD are compulsive in nature and functionally analogous to OCD compulsions. Common behaviors include: mirror checking (or mirror avoidance), excessive grooming, skin picking to remove perceived flaws, camouflaging (with makeup, clothing, hats, posture), reassurance seeking about appearance, comparing appearance with others, and excessive exercise (particularly in muscle dysmorphia). These behaviors are time-consuming and difficult to resist or control.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Anxiety Disorders & OCD > Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) > DSM-5 Specifiers
anchors_text:
[001] With muscle dysmorphia: The individual is preoccupied with the idea that his or her body build is too small or insufficiently muscular. This specifier applies even if the individual is also preoccupied with other body areas.
[002] Insight specifier: With good or fair insight, with poor insight, or with absent insight/delusional beliefs.
[003] The repetitive behaviors in BDD are compulsive in nature and functionally analogous to OCD compulsions. Common behaviors include: mirror checking (or mirror avoidance), excessive grooming, skin picking to remove perceived flaws, camouflaging (with makeup, clothing, hats, posture), reassurance seeking about appearance, comparing appearance with others, and excessive exercise (particularly in muscle dysmorphia). These behaviors are time-consuming and difficult to resist or control.

anchors.text: BDD has a point prevalence of approximately 2% in the general population, with higher rates (7-8%) in dermatology and cosmetic surgery settings. Onset is typically during adolescence (mean age 16-17), and the course is usually chronic without treatment. The most common areas of concern involve the skin (e.g., acne, scars, wrinkles), hair (e.g., thinning, excessive body hair), and nose, though any body part can be the focus.

BDD carries a significantly elevated suicide risk, with approximately 80% of individuals reporting lifetime suicidal ideation and 24-28% reporting suicide attempts. Comorbidity is high: approximately 75% of individuals with BDD have comorbid major depressive disorder, and 30-40% have comorbid OCD. Cosmetic procedures rarely improve BDD symptoms and may worsen them. Individuals with absent insight may present with delusional intensity and were historically diagnosed with "delusional disorder, somatic type," but DSM-5 allows the BDD diagnosis regardless of insight level.

anchors_text:
[001] BDD has a point prevalence of approximately 2% in the general population, with higher rates (7-8%) in dermatology and cosmetic surgery settings. Onset is typically during adolescence (mean age 16-17), and the course is usually chronic without treatment. The most common areas of concern involve the skin (e.g., acne, scars, wrinkles), hair (e.g., thinning, excessive body hair), and nose, though any body part can be the focus.
[002] BDD carries a significantly elevated suicide risk, with approximately 80% of individuals reporting lifetime suicidal ideation and 24-28% reporting suicide attempts. Comorbidity is high: approximately 75% of individuals with BDD have comorbid major depressive disorder, and 30-40% have comorbid OCD. Cosmetic procedures rarely improve BDD symptoms and may worsen them. Individuals with absent insight may present with delusional intensity and were historically diagnosed with "delusional disorder, somatic type," but DSM-5 allows the BDD diagnosis regardless of insight level.

anchors.text: Criterion A: Persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions, regardless of their actual value.
Criterion B: This difficulty is due to a perceived need to save the items and to distress associated with discarding them.

Criterion C: The difficulty discarding possessions results in the accumulation of possessions that congest and clutter active living areas and substantially compromises their intended use. If living areas are uncluttered, it is only because of the interventions of third parties (e.g., family members, cleaners, authorities).

Criterion D: The hoarding causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning (including maintaining a safe environment for oneself or others).
Criterion E: The hoarding is not attributable to another medical condition (e.g., brain injury, cerebrovascular disease, Prader-Willi syndrome).
Criterion F: The hoarding is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder.

[003] Criterion C: The difficulty discarding possessions results in the accumulation of possessions that congest and clutter active living areas and substantially compromises their intended use. If living areas are uncluttered, it is only because of the interventions of third parties (e.g., family members, cleaners, authorities).
[004] Criterion D: The hoarding causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning (including maintaining a safe environment for oneself or others).
[005] Criterion E: The hoarding is not attributable to another medical condition (e.g., brain injury, cerebrovascular disease, Prader-Willi syndrome).
[006] Criterion F: The hoarding is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder.

anchors.text: With excessive acquisition: If difficulty discarding possessions is accompanied by excessive acquiring of items that are not needed or for which there is no available space.
Insight specifier: With good or fair insight, with poor insight, or with absent insight/delusional beliefs.

Hoarding in the context of hoarding disorder is ego-syntonic -- individuals value their possessions and experience distress at the thought of discarding them. Hoarding in the context of OCD is ego-dystonic -- the accumulation is driven by obsessions (e.g., fear of contamination preventing disposal, need for symmetry/completeness) and is experienced as unwanted. This distinction is critical for differential diagnosis and treatment planning.

anchors.text: Hoarding disorder has a prevalence of approximately 2-6% in the general population, making it substantially more common than OCD. Symptoms typically emerge in adolescence (ages 11-15), become clinically significant in the mid-20s to 30s, and worsen progressively with age. The disorder is equally prevalent in males and females, though clinical samples are predominantly female. Hoarding disorder is associated with significant health and safety risks, including fire hazards, falls, unsanitary living conditions, and social isolation.

Hoarding disorder is notoriously difficult to treat. Standard OCD treatments (ERP alone) have limited efficacy for hoarding. The most effective approach is CBT with motivational interviewing, which addresses the ambivalence about change, cognitive distortions about possessions (emotional attachment, perceived utility, aesthetic value), and skills deficits in organizing, decision-making, and categorizing. Home-based sessions are more effective than office-only treatment. Neuroimaging studies show distinct patterns from OCD, with abnormal activity in the anterior cingulate cortex and insula during decision-making about possessions.

anchors.text: Criterion A: Recurrent pulling out of one's hair, resulting in hair loss.
Criterion B: Repeated attempts to decrease or stop hair pulling.
Criterion C: The hair pulling causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
Criterion D: The hair pulling or hair loss is not attributable to another medical condition (e.g., a dermatological condition).
Criterion E: The hair pulling is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder (e.g., attempts to improve a perceived defect in appearance in BDD).

Trichotillomania typically involves two styles of pulling: focused pulling (deliberate pulling in response to a negative emotion or urge, with full awareness) and automatic pulling (pulling that occurs outside of awareness, often during sedentary activities such as reading, watching TV, or talking on the phone). Most individuals engage in a mixture of both styles. Note that while the DSM-IV required a rising tension-before and relief-after cycle, the DSM-5 removed this criterion, as research showed many individuals do not experience this pattern.

anchors_text:
[001] Criterion A: Recurrent pulling out of one's hair, resulting in hair loss.
[002] Criterion B: Repeated attempts to decrease or stop hair pulling.
[003] Criterion C: The hair pulling causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
[004] Criterion D: The hair pulling or hair loss is not attributable to another medical condition (e.g., a dermatological condition).
[005] Criterion E: The hair pulling is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder (e.g., attempts to improve a perceived defect in appearance in BDD).
[006] Trichotillomania typically involves two styles of pulling: focused pulling (deliberate pulling in response to a negative emotion or urge, with full awareness) and automatic pulling (pulling that occurs outside of awareness, often during sedentary activities such as reading, watching TV, or talking on the phone). Most individuals engage in a mixture of both styles. Note that while the DSM-IV required a rising tension-before and relief-after cycle, the DSM-5 removed this criterion, as research showed many individuals do not experience this pattern.

anchors.text: Trichotillomania has a prevalence of approximately 1-2% and is significantly more common in females than males (approximately 10:1 ratio in adults). The most common sites of pulling are the scalp, eyebrows, and eyelids, though any body area with hair may be targeted. Onset is most common around puberty (ages 10-13). A subset of individuals engage in trichophagia (eating pulled hair), which can lead to trichobezoars (hairballs) requiring surgical removal -- a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.

Habit reversal training (HRT) is the first-line behavioral treatment for trichotillomania. HRT has three core components: (1) awareness training -- learning to identify pulling urges, triggers, and behaviors in real time; (2) competing response training -- engaging in a physically incompatible behavior (e.g., clenching fists, sitting on hands) when an urge to pull arises; and (3) social support -- enlisting others to provide encouragement and reinforcement. HRT is often embedded within a broader CBT framework. SSRIs have shown inconsistent results for trichotillomania, unlike their efficacy in OCD, and N-acetylcysteine (NAC) has shown some promise as an adjunctive pharmacological agent.

[002] Habit reversal training (HRT) is the first-line behavioral treatment for trichotillomania. HRT has three core components: (1) awareness training -- learning to identify pulling urges, triggers, and behaviors in real time; (2) competing response training -- engaging in a physically incompatible behavior (e.g., clenching fists, sitting on hands) when an urge to pull arises; and (3) social support -- enlisting others to provide encouragement and reinforcement. anchors.text: Criterion A: Recurrent skin picking resulting in skin lesions.
Criterion B: Repeated attempts to decrease or stop skin picking.
Criterion C: The skin picking causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
Criterion D: The skin picking is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., cocaine) or another medical condition (e.g., scabies).

Criterion E: The skin picking is not better explained by symptoms of another mental disorder (e.g., delusions or tactile hallucinations in psychotic disorder, attempts to improve perceived defect in BDD, stereotypies in stereotypic movement disorder, intention to harm oneself in nonsuicidal self-injury).

Like trichotillomania, excoriation disorder involves both focused picking (deliberate, in response to negative emotions or urges) and automatic picking (outside of awareness, during sedentary activities). The picking may target healthy skin, minor skin irregularities (e.g., pimples, calluses, scabs), or lesions from previous picking. Common sites include the face, arms, and hands. Individuals may use fingernails, tweezers, pins, or other implements. A similar tension/relief cycle may be present, though it is not required for diagnosis.

[006] Like trichotillomania, excoriation disorder involves both focused picking (deliberate, in response to negative emotions or urges) and automatic picking (outside of awareness, during sedentary activities). The picking may target healthy skin, minor skin irregularities (e.g., pimples, calluses, scabs), or lesions from previous picking. Common sites include the face, arms, and hands. Individuals may use fingernails, tweezers, pins, or other implements. A similar tension/relief cycle may be present, though it is not required for diagnosis.

anchors.text: Excoriation disorder has a prevalence of approximately 1.4% in the general population and is predominantly diagnosed in females (approximately 75% of cases). Onset can occur at any age but frequently begins in adolescence, often coinciding with or following the onset of acne or other dermatological conditions. The course is typically chronic, with waxing and waning symptom severity. Significant medical complications can include tissue damage, scarring, and infection.

Treatment for excoriation disorder closely parallels that for trichotillomania. Habit reversal training (HRT) combined with CBT is the first-line psychotherapy. The treatment approach includes awareness training to identify triggers and high-risk situations, competing response training to substitute incompatible behaviors, and stimulus control strategies (e.g., covering mirrors, wearing gloves, keeping hands occupied). SSRIs are sometimes used but evidence is mixed. N-acetylcysteine has also shown preliminary efficacy as a glutamate-modulating agent.

Is often touchy or easily annoyed
Is often angry and resentful
Often argues with authority figures or adults
Often actively defies or refuses to comply with requests or rules
Often deliberately annoys others
Often blames others for his or her mistakes or misbehavior
Has been spiteful or vindictive at least twice within the past 6 months

DSM-5 added severity specifiers for ODD: mild (symptoms confined to one setting), moderate (some symptoms in at least two settings), and severe (symptoms in three or more settings). Research suggests the angry/irritable mood dimension of ODD is a stronger predictor of later internalizing disorders (depression, anxiety), while the behavioral dimensions predict later conduct disorder and ASPD.

ODD prevalence is approximately 3.3%, with a male predominance in childhood that equalizes by adolescence. It typically emerges in the preschool years and is usually evident before age 8. ODD often precedes the development of conduct disorder, but the majority of children with ODD do not progress to conduct disorder.

anchors.text: The DSM-5 added the specifier "with limited prosocial emotions" (the callous-unemotional traits specifier). To qualify, the individual must display at least two of the following persistently over at least 12 months and in multiple settings:
Lack of remorse or guilt -- does not feel bad about misbehavior
Callous -- lack of empathy -- disregards others' feelings
Unconcerned about performance -- does not show concern about poor performance at school, work, or other activities
Shallow or deficient affect -- does not express emotions or appears insincere

Example: Children with CD and CU traits show distinct neurobiological features: reduced amygdala reactivity to fearful facial expressions, lower cortisol reactivity to stress, and diminished autonomic arousal. They tend to show proactive (instrumental) aggression rather than reactive aggression, and they respond poorly to punishment-based interventions but may respond to reward-based approaches.

section_title: The Developmental Trajectory to Antisocial Personality Disorder

anchors.text: Temperamental risk factors in infancy (difficult temperament, irritability)
ODD emerging in preschool/early childhood (ages 3-8)
Conduct Disorder, childhood-onset type (before age 10)
ASPD diagnosis at age 18 or older (requires evidence of CD before age 15)

ASPD in DSM-5 requires evidence of conduct disorder with onset before age 15. Approximately 40% of children with childhood-onset CD develop ASPD. Moffitt's developmental taxonomy distinguishes life-course persistent antisocial behavior (beginning in childhood, neuropsychological deficits, poor prognosis) from adolescence-limited antisocial behavior (emerging in teen years, peer-influenced, typically resolves by adulthood).

anchors.text: Genetics: Heritability of antisocial behavior is estimated at 40-60%. CU traits show particularly strong heritability.
Autonomic underarousal: Low resting heart rate is one of the most replicated biological correlates of antisocial behavior in children.
Neurotransmitters: Low serotonin levels associated with impulsive aggression; abnormal dopamine functioning linked to reward sensitivity.
Neuroanatomy: Reduced prefrontal cortex volume and function, reduced amygdala reactivity (particularly in those with CU traits).

[003] Neurotransmitters: Low serotonin levels associated with impulsive aggression; abnormal dopamine functioning linked to reward sensitivity.
[004] Neuroanatomy: Reduced prefrontal cortex volume and function, reduced amygdala reactivity (particularly in those with CU traits).

anchors.text: Patterson's coercion theory: Maladaptive parent-child interaction cycles in which the child learns that escalating aversive behavior is reinforced by parental capitulation, creating a coercive cycle.

Social information processing: Dodge and Crick's model posits that aggressive children show biases in processing social cues, particularly a hostile attribution bias -- the tendency to attribute hostile intent to ambiguous social situations.
Attachment: Disorganized attachment in infancy is associated with increased risk for externalizing behavior problems.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Disruptive & Conduct Disorders > Etiology and Theoretical Models > Psychological and Social Factors
anchors_text:
[001] Patterson's coercion theory: Maladaptive parent-child interaction cycles in which the child learns that escalating aversive behavior is reinforced by parental capitulation, creating a coercive cycle.
[002] Social information processing: Dodge and Crick's model posits that aggressive children show biases in processing social cues, particularly a hostile attribution bias -- the tendency to attribute hostile intent to ambiguous social situations.
[003] Attachment: Disorganized attachment in infancy is associated with increased risk for externalizing behavior problems.

anchors.text: Parent Management Training (PMT): Based on Patterson's coercion theory; teaches parents to use positive reinforcement, effective commands, consistent consequences, and to avoid coercive cycles. PMT has the strongest evidence base for ODD and early-onset CD.
Parent-Child Interaction Therapy (PCIT): For children ages 2-7; uses live coaching (via earpiece) to improve the parent-child relationship and teach effective discipline strategies in real time.
The Incredible Years: Group-based parent training program with additional child and teacher components; reduces conduct problems and increases positive parenting.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Disruptive & Conduct Disorders > Evidence-Based Treatments > Parent-Focused Interventions
anchors_text:
[001] Parent Management Training (PMT): Based on Patterson's coercion theory; teaches parents to use positive reinforcement, effective commands, consistent consequences, and to avoid coercive cycles. PMT has the strongest evidence base for ODD and early-onset CD.
[002] Parent-Child Interaction Therapy (PCIT): For children ages 2-7; uses live coaching (via earpiece) to improve the parent-child relationship and teach effective discipline strategies in real time.
[003] The Incredible Years: Group-based parent training program with additional child and teacher components; reduces conduct problems and increases positive parenting.

anchors.text: Problem-Solving Skills Training (PSST): Teaches cognitive problem-solving steps to reduce aggressive responses to social situations; addresses hostile attribution bias.

Multisystemic Therapy (MST): Intensive, family- and community-based treatment for serious juvenile offenders; addresses multiple systems (family, peer, school, community); reduces recidivism and out-of-home placements.
Functional Family Therapy (FFT): Addresses family communication patterns and relational dynamics; evidence-based for adolescents with conduct problems.

Example: For children with CU traits, standard punishment-based approaches are less effective because these children show reduced sensitivity to punishment cues. Reward-based approaches emphasizing positive reinforcement are recommended instead. Dadds et al. demonstrated that targeting emotion recognition and empathy through parent-mediated interventions can improve outcomes for children with CU traits.

anchors.text: Criterion A: Restriction of energy intake relative to requirements, leading to significantly low body weight in the context of age, sex, developmental trajectory, and physical health
Criterion B: Intense fear of gaining weight or becoming fat, or persistent behavior that interferes with weight gain, even though at a significantly low weight

Criterion C: Disturbance in the way body weight or shape is experienced, undue influence of body weight/shape on self-evaluation, or persistent lack of recognition of the seriousness of the current low body weight

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Eating & Sleep-Wake Disorders > Anorexia Nervosa (AN) > DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria
anchors_text:
[001] Criterion A: Restriction of energy intake relative to requirements, leading to significantly low body weight in the context of age, sex, developmental trajectory, and physical health
[002] Criterion B: Intense fear of gaining weight or becoming fat, or persistent behavior that interferes with weight gain, even though at a significantly low weight
[003] Criterion C: Disturbance in the way body weight or shape is experienced, undue influence of body weight/shape on self-evaluation, or persistent lack of recognition of the seriousness of the current low body weight

anchors.text: Restricting type: Weight loss achieved primarily through dieting, fasting, and/or excessive exercise. No recurrent binge-eating or purging in the past 3 months.
Binge-eating/purging type: Recurrent episodes of binge eating or purging (self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or enemas) during the past 3 months.

DSM-5 made several important changes to AN criteria: (1) removed the specific BMI threshold and the word "refusal" to eat, replacing it with "restriction"; (2) removed the amenorrhea criterion, recognizing that AN occurs in males and post-menopausal women; (3) Criterion B no longer requires explicit acknowledgment of fear of weight gain -- persistent behavior interfering with weight gain suffices.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Eating & Sleep-Wake Disorders > Anorexia Nervosa (AN) > Subtypes

[002] Binge-eating/purging type: Recurrent episodes of binge eating or purging (self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or enemas) during the past 3 months.
[003] DSM-5 made several important changes to AN criteria: (1) removed the specific BMI threshold and the word "refusal" to eat, replacing it with "restriction"; (2) removed the amenorrhea criterion, recognizing that AN occurs in males and post-menopausal women; (3) Criterion B no longer requires explicit acknowledgment of fear of weight gain -- persistent behavior interfering with weight gain suffices.

anchors.text: Recurrent episodes of binge eating (eating a definitively large amount of food in a discrete period with a sense of lack of control)
Recurrent inappropriate compensatory behaviors to prevent weight gain (purging, fasting, excessive exercise)
Both occur at least once per week for 3 months (reduced from twice per week in DSM-IV)
Self-evaluation is unduly influenced by body shape and weight
Does not occur exclusively during episodes of AN

Example: A key differential: AN binge-eating/purging type vs. BN. The distinguishing factor is body weight. If the individual is at a significantly low body weight and meets AN criteria, the diagnosis is AN binge-eating/purging type, even if binge-purge cycles are present. BN is diagnosed when the individual is at or above minimally normal weight. Note that BN no longer has purging/nonpurging subtypes in DSM-5.

Medical complications of BN include dental erosion (from stomach acid), parotid gland enlargement ("chipmunk cheeks"), Russell's sign (calluses on the knuckles from self-induced vomiting), esophageal tears (Mallory-Weiss syndrome), and metabolic alkalosis from purging.

anchors.text: Eating much more rapidly than normal
Eating until feeling uncomfortably full
Eating large amounts when not feeling physically hungry
Eating alone because of embarrassment
Feeling disgusted, depressed, or very guilty afterward

Episodes occur at least once per week for 3 months. Marked distress regarding binge eating is present. BED is the most common eating disorder, with a lifetime prevalence of approximately 2.8%. It is associated with obesity but not all individuals with BED are obese, and not all obese individuals have BED.

[006] Episodes occur at least once per week for 3 months. Marked distress regarding binge eating is present. BED is the most common eating disorder, with a lifetime prevalence of approximately 2.8%. It is associated with obesity but not all individuals with BED are obese, and not all obese individuals have BED.

anchors.text: Pica is defined as the persistent eating of nonnutritive, nonfood substances for a period of at least 1 month. The diagnostic criteria require:
The eating behavior is developmentally inappropriate -- mouthing and ingesting nonfood items is not considered abnormal before approximately age 2
The behavior is not part of a culturally sanctioned or socially normative practice
If the behavior occurs in the context of another mental disorder (e.g., intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorder), it is sufficiently severe to warrant independent clinical attention

Pica is associated with intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), pregnancy, and iron deficiency. Substances commonly ingested include dirt, clay, chalk, paper, soap, cloth, hair, string, and paint chips. Medical complications can be serious and include bowel obstruction, intestinal perforation, lead poisoning (from paint chips), parasitic infections, and dental injury.

[003] The behavior is not part of a culturally sanctioned or socially normative practice

[005] Pica is associated with intellectual disability, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), pregnancy, and iron deficiency. anchors.text: Rumination Disorder involves the repeated regurgitation of food for a period of at least 1 month. Regurgitated food may be re-chewed, re-swallowed, or spit out. The diagnostic criteria require:
The behavior is not attributable to an associated gastrointestinal or other medical condition (e.g., gastroesophageal reflux, pyloric stenosis)
The behavior does not occur exclusively during the course of anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge-eating disorder, or avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID)
If occurring in the context of another mental disorder (e.g., intellectual disability), the symptoms are sufficiently severe to warrant independent clinical attention

Rumination disorder can occur across the lifespan, from infancy through adulthood. In infants, it may present with characteristic straining and arching movements. Treatment typically involves habit reversal training (learning incompatible behaviors such as diaphragmatic breathing after meals) and behavioral interventions. Diaphragmatic breathing -- breathing deeply using the diaphragm to create abdominal pressure that counteracts regurgitation -- has the strongest evidence base for this condition.

Example: Key distinctions: Pica involves eating nonfood substances (not regurgitation) and is not diagnosed before age 2. Rumination disorder involves regurgitation of previously ingested food (not nonfood substances). Both require at least 1 month duration and both can occur across the lifespan but must be distinguished from developmentally normal behaviors and medical conditions.

anchors.text: Genetics: Heritability estimates for AN are approximately 50-80%, among the highest for any psychiatric disorder. BN shows heritability of approximately 55%. Twin studies suggest shared genetic vulnerability across eating disorder diagnoses.

Neurotransmitters: Serotonin dysregulation is implicated in both AN and BN. Individuals with BN show reduced serotonergic activity, which may contribute to impulsivity and binge eating. The efficacy of fluoxetine (the only FDA-approved medication for BN) supports serotonergic involvement.

Neuroendocrine changes: Leptin, ghrelin, and other appetite-regulating hormones are disrupted in eating disorders, though many changes appear to be consequences rather than causes of disordered eating.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Eating & Sleep-Wake Disorders > Etiology of Eating Disorders > Biological Factors
anchors_text:
[001] Genetics: Heritability estimates for AN are approximately 50-80%, among the highest for any psychiatric disorder. BN shows heritability of approximately 55%. Twin studies suggest shared genetic vulnerability across eating disorder diagnoses.
[002] Neurotransmitters: Serotonin dysregulation is implicated in both AN and BN. Individuals with BN show reduced serotonergic activity, which may contribute to impulsivity and binge eating. The efficacy of fluoxetine (the only FDA-approved medication for BN) supports serotonergic involvement.
[003] Neuroendocrine changes: Leptin, ghrelin, and other appetite-regulating hormones are disrupted in eating disorders, though many changes appear to be consequences rather than causes of disordered eating.

anchors.text: Perfectionism and low self-esteem: Perfectionism is a robust risk factor, particularly for AN. The combination of high standards and self-critical evaluation creates vulnerability.

Internalization of the thin ideal: Stice's dual-pathway model proposes that sociocultural pressure for thinness leads to body dissatisfaction, which promotes both dietary restraint (risk for AN) and negative affect (risk for binge eating).

Cognitive rigidity: Individuals with AN show set-shifting difficulties and weak central coherence (tendency to focus on details rather than global picture), which may be trait markers rather than state-dependent features.
Trauma history: Childhood sexual abuse is a nonspecific risk factor, associated with increased rates of BN and BED in particular.

Example: Treatment approaches differ by disorder: CBT-E (enhanced cognitive-behavioral therapy) is the first-line treatment for BN and BED. For AN, family-based treatment (FBT/Maudsley approach) is the best-supported treatment for adolescents, empowering parents to take charge of refeeding. For adults with AN, no single therapy has demonstrated clear superiority, though CBT-E, MANTRA (Maudsley model of anorexia treatment), and specialist supportive clinical management have the most evidence. Fluoxetine at 60 mg/day is effective for BN but medications have limited efficacy for AN.

Fluoxetine at 60 mg/day is effective for BN but medications have limited efficacy for AN.

anchors.text: Insomnia disorder involves dissatisfaction with sleep quantity or quality, associated with difficulty initiating sleep, maintaining sleep, or early morning awakening with inability to return to sleep. The disturbance occurs at least 3 nights per week for at least 3 months, despite adequate opportunity for sleep. It causes clinically significant distress or impairment.

Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is the first-line treatment, more effective than pharmacotherapy in the long term. Key components include stimulus control (bed only for sleep and sex), sleep restriction, sleep hygiene education, cognitive restructuring, and relaxation training. Spielman's 3P model of insomnia identifies predisposing, precipitating, and perpetuating factors.

The disturbance occurs at least 3 nights per week for at least 3 months, despite adequate opportunity for sleep. It causes clinically significant distress or impairment.
[002] Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) is the first-line treatment, more effective than pharmacotherapy in the long term. Key components include stimulus control (bed only for sleep and sex), sleep restriction, sleep hygiene education, cognitive restructuring, and relaxation training. Spielman's 3P model of insomnia identifies predisposing, precipitating, and perpetuating factors.

anchors.text: Narcolepsy involves recurrent periods of irrepressible need to sleep, lapsing into sleep, or napping, occurring at least 3 times per week over the past 3 months, plus at least one of the following:
Cataplexy: Brief episodes of sudden bilateral loss of muscle tone triggered by laughter or joking (most specific symptom)
Hypocretin (orexin) deficiency: CSF hypocretin-1 levels less than 110 pg/mL (the definitive biomarker)
Sleep study findings: REM sleep latency of 15 minutes or less, or MSLT showing mean sleep latency of 8 minutes or less with 2 or more sleep-onset REM periods

Narcolepsy Type 1 (with cataplexy/hypocretin deficiency) is caused by autoimmune destruction of hypocretin-producing neurons in the hypothalamus. Narcolepsy Type 2 is without cataplexy and with normal hypocretin levels.

[003] Hypocretin (orexin) deficiency: CSF hypocretin-1 levels less than 110 pg/mL (the definitive biomarker)
[004] Sleep study findings: REM sleep latency of 15 minutes or less, or MSLT showing mean sleep latency of 8 minutes or less with 2 or more sleep-onset REM periods

anchors.text: Parasomnias are abnormal behavioral, experiential, or physiological events occurring during sleep.
Sleepwalking (somnambulism) — NREM (Stage N3) — Rising from bed and walking; blank stare, difficult to awaken, amnesia for episode
Sleep terrors (night terrors) — NREM (Stage N3) — Abrupt awakening with panicked scream, intense fear, autonomic arousal, amnesia
Nightmare disorder — REM sleep — Extended, dysphoric, well-remembered dreams; full alertness on awakening
REM sleep behavior disorder — REM sleep — Acting out dreams due to loss of normal REM atonia; associated with neurodegenerative disease

Example: Distinguishing sleep terrors from nightmares: Sleep terrors occur during NREM Stage N3 (deep sleep), involve intense autonomic arousal, and the individual is typically amnestic for the episode. Nightmares occur during REM sleep, the individual fully awakens with recall of the dream content, and there is less autonomic arousal. Sleep terrors are most common in children ages 4-12 and typically resolve spontaneously.

[003] Sleep terrors (night terrors) — NREM (Stage N3) — Abrupt awakening with panicked scream, intense fear, autonomic arousal, amnesia
[004] Nightmare disorder — REM sleep — Extended, dysphoric, well-remembered dreams; full alertness on awakening

[006] Example: Distinguishing sleep terrors from nightmares: Sleep terrors occur during NREM Stage N3 (deep sleep), involve intense autonomic arousal, and the individual is typically amnestic for the episode. Nightmares occur during REM sleep, the individual fully awakens with recall of the dream content, and there is less autonomic arousal. Sleep terrors are most common in children ages 4-12 and typically resolve spontaneously.

anchors.text: Delayed sleep-wake phase type: Habitual sleep-wake timing is delayed, usually by 2+ hours, relative to conventional times. Common in adolescents. The individual cannot fall asleep until very late (e.g., 2-6 AM) and has difficulty waking for school or work.
Advanced sleep-wake phase type: Habitual sleep-wake timing is advanced. More common in older adults. Individuals fall asleep and wake very early (e.g., sleep at 6-8 PM, wake at 2-5 AM).
Shift work type: Insomnia and/or excessive sleepiness due to a work schedule that overlaps the usual sleep period.
Jet lag type: Sleepiness and alertness occurring at inappropriate times relative to local time after travel across time zones.
Non-24-hour sleep-wake type: Pattern of sleep-wake cycles not synchronized to the 24-hour environment. Most common in blind individuals lacking light input to the suprachiasmatic nucleus.

The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the hypothalamus is the master circadian pacemaker. It is primarily entrained (synchronized) by light input via the retinohypothalamic tract. Melatonin, produced by the pineal gland under SCN control, promotes sleep onset and is used therapeutically for circadian rhythm disorders. Light therapy (bright light exposure) is the primary treatment for delayed sleep-wake phase disorder and seasonal affective disorder.

anchors_text:
[001] Delayed sleep-wake phase type: Habitual sleep-wake timing is delayed, usually by 2+ hours, relative to conventional times. Common in adolescents. The individual cannot fall asleep until very late (e.g., 2-6 AM) and has difficulty waking for school or work.
[002] Advanced sleep-wake phase type: Habitual sleep-wake timing is advanced. More common in older adults. Individuals fall asleep and wake very early (e.g., sleep at 6-8 PM, wake at 2-5 AM).
[003] Shift work type: Insomnia and/or excessive sleepiness due to a work schedule that overlaps the usual sleep period.
[004] Jet lag type: Sleepiness and alertness occurring at inappropriate times relative to local time after travel across time zones.
[005] Non-24-hour sleep-wake type: Pattern of sleep-wake cycles not synchronized to the 24-hour environment. Most common in blind individuals lacking light input to the suprachiasmatic nucleus.
[006] The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the hypothalamus is the master circadian pacemaker. It is primarily entrained (synchronized) by light input via the retinohypothalamic tract. Melatonin, produced by the pineal gland under SCN control, promotes sleep onset and is used therapeutically for circadian rhythm disorders. Light therapy (bright light exposure) is the primary treatment for delayed sleep-wake phase disorder and seasonal affective disorder.

anchors.text: Five or more of the following symptoms present during the same 2-week period, representing a change from previous functioning. At least one must be (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia):
Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day (in children/adolescents, can be irritable mood)
Anhedonia -- markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all or almost all activities
Significant weight change (more than 5% in a month) or appetite change
Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day
Psychomotor agitation or retardation observable by others
Fatigue or loss of energy
Feelings of worthlessness or excessive/inappropriate guilt
Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
Recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, or a suicide attempt
The mnemonic SIG E CAPS (Sleep, Interest, Guilt, Energy, Concentration, Appetite, Psychomotor changes, Suicidality) is commonly used to remember these criteria.

DSM-5 removed the bereavement exclusion that was present in DSM-IV. Previously, depressive symptoms within 2 months of losing a loved one were excluded from an MDD diagnosis. The DSM-5 now allows MDD to be diagnosed even in the context of bereavement, recognizing that bereavement can trigger a full depressive episode.

anchors.text: Monoamine hypothesis: Depression results from deficits in serotonin (5-HT), norepinephrine (NE), and/or dopamine (DA). Supported by the mechanism of action of SSRIs, SNRIs, and MAOIs.

HPA axis dysregulation: Chronic stress leads to elevated cortisol via the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. Non-suppression on the dexamethasone suppression test is associated with depression, though it lacks diagnostic specificity.
Neuroplasticity model: Reduced brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and hippocampal volume reductions are observed in chronic depression.

[002] HPA axis dysregulation: Chronic stress leads to elevated cortisol via the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. Non-suppression on the dexamethasone suppression test is associated with depression, though it lacks diagnostic specificity.
[003] Neuroplasticity model: Reduced brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and hippocampal volume reductions are observed in chronic depression.

anchors.text: With anxious distress — Feeling tense, restless, difficulty concentrating due to worry, fear of something awful
With melancholic features — Profound anhedonia, worse in morning, early morning awakening, psychomotor changes, excessive guilt
With atypical features — Mood reactivity, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, interpersonal rejection sensitivity, weight gain
With psychotic features — Delusions or hallucinations (mood-congruent or mood-incongruent)
With peripartum onset — Onset during pregnancy or within 4 weeks of delivery
With seasonal pattern — Regular temporal relationship between episode onset and time of year

section_title: Bipolar I and Bipolar II Disorders

anchors.text: Bipolar I disorder requires the occurrence of at least one manic episode. The manic episode may have been preceded by or followed by hypomanic or major depressive episodes, but these are not required for diagnosis. During a manic episode, at least three of the following symptoms are present (four if mood is only irritable):
Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after 3 hours)
More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking
Flight of ideas or subjective experience of racing thoughts
Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation
Excessive involvement in activities with high potential for painful consequences
The mnemonic DIG FAST (Distractibility, Indiscretion/Impulsivity, Grandiosity, Flight of ideas, Activity increase, Sleep deficit, Talkativeness) helps recall mania criteria.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Bipolar & Depressive Disorders > Bipolar I and Bipolar II Disorders > Bipolar I Disorder
anchors_text:
[001] Bipolar I disorder requires the occurrence of at least one manic episode. The manic episode may have been preceded by or followed by hypomanic or major depressive episodes, but these are not required for diagnosis. During a manic episode, at least three of the following symptoms are present (four if mood is only irritable):
[002] Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
[003] Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after 3 hours)
[004] More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking
[005] Flight of ideas or subjective experience of racing thoughts
[006] Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation
[007] Excessive involvement in activities with high potential for painful consequences
[008] The mnemonic DIG FAST (Distractibility, Indiscretion/Impulsivity, Grandiosity, Flight of ideas, Activity increase, Sleep deficit, Talkativeness) helps recall mania criteria.

section_title: Bipolar I and Bipolar II Disorders

anchors.text: Bipolar II disorder requires at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode. Bipolar II is not a "milder" form of Bipolar I -- the depressive episodes are often more chronic and debilitating. If a full manic episode ever occurs, the diagnosis changes to Bipolar I.

Bipolar II is frequently misdiagnosed as MDD because patients typically present during depressive episodes and may not recognize hypomania as pathological. Screening for a history of elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, and increased activity is essential. Antidepressant monotherapy in unrecognized Bipolar II can precipitate a manic switch.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Bipolar & Depressive Disorders > Bipolar I and Bipolar II Disorders > Bipolar II Disorder
anchors_text:
[001] Bipolar II disorder requires at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode. Bipolar II is not a "milder" form of Bipolar I -- the depressive episodes are often more chronic and debilitating. If a full manic episode ever occurs, the diagnosis changes to Bipolar I.
[002] Bipolar II is frequently misdiagnosed as MDD because patients typically present during depressive episodes and may not recognize hypomania as pathological. Screening for a history of elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, and increased activity is essential. Antidepressant monotherapy in unrecognized Bipolar II can precipitate a manic switch.

anchors.text: At least one of the following core affective symptoms must be present:
Marked affective lability (e.g., mood swings, feeling suddenly sad or tearful, increased sensitivity to rejection)
Marked irritability or anger or increased interpersonal conflicts
Marked depressed mood, feelings of hopelessness, or self-deprecating thoughts
Marked anxiety, tension, and/or feelings of being keyed up or on edge
Plus one or more of the following additional symptoms (to reach a total of at least 5):
Decreased interest in usual activities
Subjective difficulty in concentration
Lethargy, easy fatigability, or marked lack of energy
Marked change in appetite, overeating, or specific food cravings
Hypersomnia or insomnia
A sense of being overwhelmed or out of control
Physical symptoms such as breast tenderness or swelling, joint or muscle pain, a sensation of bloating, or weight gain

PMDD diagnosis must be confirmed by prospective daily ratings for at least 2 consecutive symptomatic menstrual cycles. Retrospective self-report alone is insufficient because women often overestimate premenstrual symptom severity when recalling past cycles. This prospective confirmation requirement is unique among DSM-5 diagnoses.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Bipolar & Depressive Disorders > Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder (PMDD) > DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria
anchors_text:
[001] At least one of the following core affective symptoms must be present:
[002] Marked affective lability (e.g., mood swings, feeling suddenly sad or tearful, increased sensitivity to rejection)
[003] Marked irritability or anger or increased interpersonal conflicts
[004] Marked depressed mood, feelings of hopelessness, or self-deprecating thoughts
[005] Marked anxiety, tension, and/or feelings of being keyed up or on edge
[006] Plus one or more of the following additional symptoms (to reach a total of at least 5):
[007] Decreased interest in usual activities
[008] Subjective difficulty in concentration
[009] Lethargy, easy fatigability, or marked lack of energy
[010] Marked change in appetite, overeating, or specific food cravings
[011] Hypersomnia or insomnia
[012] A sense of being overwhelmed or out of control
[013] Physical symptoms such as breast tenderness or swelling, joint or muscle pain, a sensation of bloating, or weight gain
[014] PMDD diagnosis must be confirmed by prospective daily ratings for at least 2 consecutive symptomatic menstrual cycles. Retrospective self-report alone is insufficient because women often overestimate premenstrual symptom severity when recalling past cycles. This prospective confirmation requirement is unique among DSM-5 diagnoses.

anchors.text: SSRIs are the first-line pharmacological treatment for PMDD. Uniquely, SSRIs can be used either continuously (daily throughout the cycle) or only during the luteal phase (the approximately 2 weeks between ovulation and menses onset), with both approaches demonstrating efficacy.
Hormonal treatments (oral contraceptives, GnRH agonists) may be used to suppress ovulation and reduce symptom cycling, particularly when SSRIs are insufficient.

Example: PMDD is a new addition to the depressive disorders chapter in DSM-5. The key features to remember are: (1) symptoms must occur in the final week before menses and remit after onset; (2) at least one of four core affective symptoms is required; (3) prospective daily ratings over 2 cycles are required for confirmation; (4) SSRIs are effective even when used only during the luteal phase.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Bipolar & Depressive Disorders > Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder (PMDD) > Treatment
anchors_text:
[001] SSRIs are the first-line pharmacological treatment for PMDD. Uniquely, SSRIs can be used either continuously (daily throughout the cycle) or only during the luteal phase (the approximately 2 weeks between ovulation and menses onset), with both approaches demonstrating efficacy.
[002] Hormonal treatments (oral contraceptives, GnRH agonists) may be used to suppress ovulation and reduce symptom cycling, particularly when SSRIs are insufficient.
[003] Example: PMDD is a new addition to the depressive disorders chapter in DSM-5. The key features to remember are: (1) symptoms must occur in the final week before menses and remit after onset; (2) at least one of four core affective symptoms is required; (3) prospective daily ratings over 2 cycles are required for confirmation; (4) SSRIs are effective even when used only during the luteal phase.

anchors.text: SSRIs (fluoxetine, sertraline, paroxetine, citalopram, escitalopram): First-line treatment; selectively block serotonin reuptake; generally well tolerated with side effects including sexual dysfunction, GI symptoms, and initial anxiety
SNRIs (venlafaxine, duloxetine, desvenlafaxine): Block both serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake; useful for comorbid pain conditions
TCAs (amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine): Older antidepressants; effective but more side effects (anticholinergic effects, cardiac conduction delays); lethal in overdose
MAOIs (phenelzine, tranylcypromine): Require dietary restrictions (tyramine-free diet to avoid hypertensive crisis); generally reserved for treatment-resistant depression or atypical depression
Atypicals: Bupropion (norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor; no sexual side effects; lowers seizure threshold); mirtazapine (increases appetite, causes sedation)

The black box warning on antidepressants warns of increased suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults (ages 18-24) during initial treatment. This does not mean antidepressants cause suicide -- the risk is that as energy and motivation return before mood improves, the individual may have increased capacity to act on suicidal thoughts. The net benefit of antidepressant treatment for depression far outweighs this risk.

anchors.text: Lithium: The gold standard mood stabilizer; effective for acute mania and maintenance; requires blood level monitoring (therapeutic range 0.6-1.2 mEq/L); risks include thyroid dysfunction, renal impairment, and teratogenicity (Ebstein's anomaly)
Anticonvulsants: Valproate (effective for acute mania and mixed states; teratogenic -- neural tube defects); carbamazepine; lamotrigine (particularly effective for bipolar depression prevention)
Atypical antipsychotics: Quetiapine, olanzapine, aripiprazole, lurasidone are used for acute mania and/or bipolar depression

anchors.text: Previous suicide attempt -- the single strongest predictor of completed suicide
Psychiatric diagnosis -- over 90% of completers had a diagnosable disorder, with depression and substance use being the most common
Hopelessness -- a stronger predictor of suicidal intent than depression severity
Demographic factors: Males complete suicide at approximately 4 times the rate of females; females attempt suicide approximately 3 times as often as males
Access to lethal means, family history of suicide, recent losses, social isolation
Age: Highest rates in adults 45-64 and those 85+

anchors.text: Social connectedness and reasons for living
Effective clinical care for mental and substance use disorders
Restricted access to lethal means
Cultural and religious beliefs that discourage suicide

The Joiner interpersonal theory of suicide identifies three factors necessary for a lethal suicide attempt: thwarted belongingness (feeling disconnected), perceived burdensomeness (feeling like a burden to others), and acquired capability (reduced fear of death through habituation to pain and self-harm).

anchors.text: Predominantly Inattentive — 6+ inattention symptoms (5+ for age 17+) — Difficulty sustaining attention, does not follow through, loses things, easily distracted, forgetful
Predominantly Hyperactive-Impulsive — 6+ hyperactive-impulsive symptoms (5+ for age 17+) — Fidgets, leaves seat, runs/climbs inappropriately, talks excessively, interrupts, difficulty waiting
Combined — Meets criteria for both presentations — Most commonly diagnosed presentation

Symptoms must be present in two or more settings (home, school, work), must be present for at least 6 months, and must interfere with or reduce the quality of functioning. ADHD persists into adulthood in approximately 50-65% of cases, though hyperactive-impulsive symptoms tend to decline more than inattentive symptoms. Executive function deficits (working memory, inhibition, cognitive flexibility) are central to Barkley's model of ADHD.

anchors.text: Genetics: ADHD is highly heritable (approximately 74%). It is polygenic, with dopamine-related genes (DRD4, DAT1) implicated.
Neurobiology: Dysregulation of dopamine and norepinephrine in prefrontal-striatal circuits. Structural imaging shows reduced volume in prefrontal cortex, basal ganglia, and cerebellum.
Environmental risk factors: Prenatal tobacco and alcohol exposure, low birth weight, prematurity, and lead exposure.

[003] Environmental risk factors: Prenatal tobacco and alcohol exposure, low birth weight, prematurity, and lead exposure.

anchors.text: ASD requires deficits in both of the following domains:
Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity (e.g., abnormal social approach, failure of back-and-forth conversation, reduced sharing of interests/emotions)
Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors (e.g., poor eye contact, abnormalities in body language, deficits in understanding/use of gestures)
Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships (e.g., difficulty adjusting behavior to social contexts, difficulty sharing imaginative play, absence of interest in peers)
Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech (echolalia, idiosyncratic phrases)
Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, ritualized patterns
Highly restricted, fixated interests that are abnormal in intensity or focus
Hyper- or hyporeactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of the environment

DSM-IV used a triad (social interaction, communication, restricted behaviors). DSM-5 collapsed this into a dyad: (1) social communication/interaction and (2) restricted/repetitive behaviors. The sensory reactivity criterion (B4) is new. Language delay is no longer part of the ASD criteria but can be noted as a specifier. Importantly, DSM-5 requires specifying severity levels for each domain.

anchors.text: Level 1: "Requiring support" — Without supports, deficits cause noticeable impairments; difficulty initiating interactions; atypical responses — Inflexibility causes significant interference; difficulty switching between activities

Level 2: "Requiring substantial support" — Marked deficits with limited social initiation; reduced or abnormal response to social overtures — Inflexibility/RRBs obvious to casual observer; distress with change; difficulty redirecting

Level 3: "Requiring very substantial support" — Severe deficits; very limited initiation; minimal response to social overtures — Extreme difficulty coping with change; marked distress; great difficulty redirecting

Example: Individuals previously diagnosed with Asperger's disorder under DSM-IV would now typically receive a diagnosis of ASD Level 1 ("requiring support") without accompanying intellectual or language impairment. The DSM-5 includes a note that individuals with well-established DSM-IV diagnoses should be given the ASD diagnosis, and those with marked deficits in social communication but not meeting RRB criteria may be evaluated for Social (Pragmatic) Communication Disorder, a new DSM-5 diagnosis.

anchors.text: Stimulant medications are the first-line pharmacological treatment for ADHD and are effective in approximately 70-80% of cases:
Methylphenidate (Ritalin, Concerta): Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake
Amphetamine salts (Adderall, Vyvanse): Block reuptake and increase release of dopamine and norepinephrine

Non-stimulant options include atomoxetine (Strattera, a norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), guanfacine and clonidine (alpha-2 agonists), and bupropion (off-label). The MTA Study found that medication management was superior to behavioral treatment alone for core ADHD symptoms, while combined treatment was superior for functional outcomes and comorbid conditions.

[002] Methylphenidate (Ritalin, Concerta): Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake
[003] Amphetamine salts (Adderall, Vyvanse): Block reuptake and increase release of dopamine and norepinephrine
[004] Non-stimulant options include atomoxetine (Strattera, a norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), guanfacine and clonidine (alpha-2 agonists), and bupropion (off-label). The MTA Study found that medication management was superior to behavioral treatment alone for core ADHD symptoms, while combined treatment was superior for functional outcomes and comorbid conditions.

anchors.text: Behavioral parent training: Teaching parents contingency management strategies (positive reinforcement, token economies, time-out)
Classroom-based behavioral interventions: Daily report cards, token systems, classroom accommodations (preferential seating, breaks, extended time)
Organizational skills training: Particularly important for the predominantly inattentive presentation
Social skills training: Effectiveness is debated; best when integrated into naturalistic settings

Common misconceptions about ADHD stimulant medications: (1) Stimulants do not cause a "paradoxical" calming effect unique to ADHD -- they enhance focus in most individuals; the difference is that individuals with ADHD show greater behavioral improvement. (2) The "medication holiday" debate: some families choose to stop medication on weekends/summers, but this may affect social functioning and self-esteem. (3) Long-term stimulant use may temporarily slow growth velocity by approximately 1-3 cm, but adult height appears largely unaffected.

anchors.text: With impairment in reading (encompasses what was formerly called dyslexia): word reading accuracy, reading rate/fluency, reading comprehension
With impairment in written expression (encompasses dysgraphia): spelling accuracy, grammar/punctuation, clarity/organization
With impairment in mathematics (encompasses dyscalculia): number sense, math facts, calculation, math reasoning

SLD affects approximately 5-15% of school-age children. It requires academic skills substantially below age expectations, confirmed by both clinical assessment and standardized testing. The DSM-5 does not require an IQ-achievement discrepancy, moving away from the discrepancy model toward a response to intervention (RTI) approach.

anchors.text: Tourette's disorder: Both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics present at some time (not necessarily concurrently). Onset before age 18. Duration more than 1 year. Tics wax and wane.
Persistent (chronic) motor or vocal tic disorder: Single or multiple motor OR vocal tics (not both). Onset before 18. Duration more than 1 year.
Provisional tic disorder: Single or multiple motor and/or vocal tics. Duration less than 1 year since first onset. Onset before 18.

Example: Coprolalia (involuntary utterance of obscene words) is often associated with Tourette's in popular culture, but it actually occurs in only about 10-15% of individuals with Tourette's disorder. The most common initial tics are facial (eye blinking, grimacing). Tourette's is highly comorbid with ADHD (approximately 50%) and OCD (approximately 30%). The CSTC circuit implicated in OCD is also involved in tic disorders.

[003] Provisional tic disorder: Single or multiple motor and/or vocal tics. Duration less than 1 year since first onset. Onset before 18.
[004] Example: Coprolalia (involuntary utterance of obscene words) is often associated with Tourette's in popular culture, but it actually occurs in only about 10-15% of individuals with Tourette's disorder. The most common initial tics are facial (eye blinking, grimacing). Tourette's is highly comorbid with ADHD (approximately 50%) and OCD (approximately 30%). The CSTC circuit implicated in OCD is also involved in tic disorders.

anchors.text: A pervasive pattern of distrust and suspiciousness of others such that their motives are interpreted as malevolent. Features include suspecting exploitation or harm, doubting loyalty of friends, reluctance to confide, reading hidden meanings into benign remarks, bearing grudges, perceiving attacks on character, and recurring suspicions of partner infidelity.

Example: Paranoid PD vs. delusional disorder (persecutory type): In paranoid PD, the suspicions are not of delusional intensity -- they are exaggerated interpretations but not fixed, false beliefs. Paranoid PD vs. paranoid schizophrenia: Paranoid PD lacks hallucinations, disorganized speech, and other psychotic features.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Personality Disorders > Cluster A: Odd or Eccentric > Paranoid Personality Disorder
anchors_text:
[001] A pervasive pattern of distrust and suspiciousness of others such that their motives are interpreted as malevolent. Features include suspecting exploitation or harm, doubting loyalty of friends, reluctance to confide, reading hidden meanings into benign remarks, bearing grudges, perceiving attacks on character, and recurring suspicions of partner infidelity.
[002] Example: Paranoid PD vs. delusional disorder (persecutory type): In paranoid PD, the suspicions are not of delusional intensity -- they are exaggerated interpretations but not fixed, false beliefs. Paranoid PD vs. paranoid schizophrenia: Paranoid PD lacks hallucinations, disorganized speech, and other psychotic features.

anchors.text: A pervasive pattern of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with close relationships, cognitive or perceptual distortions, and eccentricities of behavior. Features include ideas of reference, odd beliefs or magical thinking, unusual perceptual experiences, odd thinking and speech, suspiciousness, inappropriate or constricted affect, odd behavior or appearance, lack of close friends, and excessive social anxiety that does not diminish with familiarity.

Schizotypal PD has the strongest genetic link to schizophrenia and is considered part of the schizophrenia spectrum. It involves quasi-psychotic symptoms (ideas of reference, magical thinking, perceptual distortions) that fall short of true psychosis. In the ICD-10, schizotypal disorder is classified as a psychotic disorder rather than a personality disorder.

[002] Schizotypal PD has the strongest genetic link to schizophrenia and is considered part of the schizophrenia spectrum. It involves quasi-psychotic symptoms (ideas of reference, magical thinking, perceptual distortions) that fall short of true psychosis. In the ICD-10, schizotypal disorder is classified as a psychotic disorder rather than a personality disorder.

section_title: Cluster B: Dramatic, Emotional, or Erratic

anchors.text: A pervasive pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others, occurring since age 15. The individual must be at least 18 years old, and there must be evidence of conduct disorder before age 15.
Failure to conform to social norms with respect to lawful behaviors
Deceitfulness (lying, using aliases, conning for profit/pleasure)
Impulsivity or failure to plan ahead
Irritability and aggressiveness (repeated fights/assaults)
Reckless disregard for safety of self or others
Consistent irresponsibility (work, financial obligations)

Psychopathy (as measured by Hare's PCL-R) is a related but distinct construct. The PCL-R captures two factors: Factor 1 (interpersonal/affective traits: glibness, grandiosity, lack of empathy, shallow affect) and Factor 2 (antisocial lifestyle: impulsivity, irresponsibility, criminal versatility). Most individuals with psychopathy meet criteria for ASPD, but most individuals with ASPD do not meet criteria for psychopathy (approximately 50-80% of inmates meet ASPD criteria, but only about 15-25% score high on the PCL-R).

[007] Consistent irresponsibility (work, financial obligations)
[008] Psychopathy (as measured by Hare's PCL-R) is a related but distinct construct. The PCL-R captures two factors: Factor 1 (interpersonal/affective traits: glibness, grandiosity, lack of empathy, shallow affect) and Factor 2 (antisocial lifestyle: impulsivity, irresponsibility, criminal versatility). Most individuals with psychopathy meet criteria for ASPD, but most individuals with ASPD do not meet criteria for psychopathy (approximately 50-80% of inmates meet ASPD criteria, but only about 15-25% score high on the PCL-R).

section_title: Cluster B: Dramatic, Emotional, or Erratic

anchors.text: A pervasive pattern of instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affects, and marked impulsivity. Five or more of nine criteria are required:
Frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment
Pattern of unstable and intense interpersonal relationships (idealization/devaluation, "splitting")
Identity disturbance: markedly unstable self-image or sense of self
Impulsivity in at least two areas that are potentially self-damaging
Recurrent suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behavior
Affective instability due to marked reactivity of mood
Chronic feelings of emptiness
Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty controlling anger
Transient, stress-related paranoid ideation or severe dissociative symptoms

Linehan's biosocial theory proposes that BPD arises from the transaction between biological vulnerability to emotional dysregulation and an invalidating environment (one that erratically, inappropriately, or negligently responds to private experiences). Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) is the best-supported treatment for BPD and targets emotion regulation, distress tolerance, interpersonal effectiveness, and mindfulness. Kernberg's object relations approach emphasizes splitting as the primary defense mechanism in BPD.

section_title: Cluster B: Dramatic, Emotional, or Erratic

anchors.text: A pervasive pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy. Features include grandiose sense of self-importance, preoccupation with fantasies of success/power/beauty, belief in being special, requiring excessive admiration, sense of entitlement, interpersonal exploitation, lack of empathy, envy of others or belief that others are envious, and arrogant behaviors/attitudes.

Example: Kohut's self psychology conceptualizes narcissistic pathology as resulting from empathic failures by early caregivers (selfobjects), leading to a fragmented self. Treatment involves providing empathic mirroring and idealizing transferences. Kernberg, in contrast, views narcissistic personality as a pathological grandiose self that defends against underlying aggression and envy, requiring confrontation of defenses in treatment.

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Personality Disorders > Cluster B: Dramatic, Emotional, or Erratic > Narcissistic Personality Disorder
anchors_text:
[001] A pervasive pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy. Features include grandiose sense of self-importance, preoccupation with fantasies of success/power/beauty, belief in being special, requiring excessive admiration, sense of entitlement, interpersonal exploitation, lack of empathy, envy of others or belief that others are envious, and arrogant behaviors/attitudes.
[002] Example: Kohut's self psychology conceptualizes narcissistic pathology as resulting from empathic failures by early caregivers (selfobjects), leading to a fragmented self. Treatment involves providing empathic mirroring and idealizing transferences. Kernberg, in contrast, views narcissistic personality as a pathological grandiose self that defends against underlying aggression and envy, requiring confrontation of defenses in treatment.

anchors.text: A pervasive pattern of preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and mental and interpersonal control, at the expense of flexibility, openness, and efficiency. Features include preoccupation with details/rules/order, perfectionism interfering with task completion, excessive devotion to work, over-conscientiousness about morality, inability to discard worn-out objects, reluctance to delegate, miserly spending style, and rigidity/stubbornness.

OCPD involves ego-syntonic traits -- the person's perfectionism and control feel consistent with who they are. OCD involves ego-dystonic obsessions and compulsions -- the person recognizes them as excessive and distressing. OCPD does not involve true obsessions or compulsions. Despite the name similarity, only about 23-32% of individuals with OCD also have OCPD. OCPD is the most prevalent personality disorder in the general population (approximately 3-8%).

section_title: Alternative DSM-5 Model for Personality Disorders (AMPD)
topic_name: Criterion A: Level of Personality Functioning

anchors.text: Assessed using the Level of Personality Functioning Scale (LPFS), which evaluates impairments across four elements:
Identity: Experience of oneself as unique; self-esteem stability; emotional range
Self-direction: Pursuit of goals; self-reflective functioning; internal standards
Empathy: Comprehension of others' experiences; tolerance of differing perspectives
Intimacy: Depth and duration of connection; desire and capacity for closeness

section_title: Alternative DSM-5 Model for Personality Disorders (AMPD)

anchors.text: Organized into five broad trait domains (with 25 trait facets):
Negative Affectivity (vs. Emotional Stability)
Detachment (vs. Extraversion)
Antagonism (vs. Agreeableness)
Disinhibition (vs. Conscientiousness)
Psychoticism (vs. Lucidity)

The AMPD retains six specific personality disorders: antisocial, avoidant, borderline, narcissistic, obsessive-compulsive, and schizotypal. The remaining four (paranoid, schizoid, histrionic, dependent) can be described using Criterion A and B but are not retained as named types.

anchors.text: The overall prevalence of any personality disorder in the general population is estimated at approximately 9-15%. By cluster:
Cluster A: Approximately 5.7% total (paranoid 2.3-4.4%, schizoid 3.1-4.9%, schizotypal 3.3-3.9%)
Cluster B: Approximately 1.5-6% (antisocial 1-4% with higher rates in males, borderline 1.6-5.9%, histrionic 1.8%, narcissistic 0-6.2%)
Cluster C: Approximately 2.4-6% (avoidant 2.4%, dependent 0.5-0.6%, OCPD 2.1-7.9%)

anchors.text: BPD — DBT (Linehan); Mentalization-Based Treatment (MBT; Bateman & Fonagy); Transference-Focused Psychotherapy (TFP; Kernberg); Schema Therapy (Young)
ASPD — Limited evidence; Moral Reconation Therapy in forensic settings; CBT components; medication for comorbid conditions
Avoidant PD — CBT (similar to social anxiety); graduated exposure; social skills training
Cluster A PDs — Limited research; supportive therapy; low-dose antipsychotics for schizotypal PD

Example: Mentalization-Based Treatment (MBT), developed by Bateman and Fonagy, targets the capacity to understand behavior in terms of mental states (thoughts, feelings, intentions). Individuals with BPD show impaired mentalization, particularly under emotional stress, which contributes to interpersonal difficulties. MBT has demonstrated efficacy in reducing self-harm, suicide attempts, and hospitalization in BPD. The concept of mentalization overlaps with but is distinct from theory of mind, empathy, and psychological mindedness.

anchors.text: Delusions are fixed beliefs that are not amenable to change in light of conflicting evidence. Common types include:
Persecutory — Belief that one is being harassed, conspired against, or targeted (most common type)
Referential — Belief that gestures, comments, environmental cues are directed at oneself
Grandiose — Belief of having exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame
Erotomanic — Belief that another person is in love with the individual
Nihilistic — Belief that a major catastrophe will occur or that one does not exist
Somatic — Preoccupation with health/organ function
Thought insertion/withdrawal/broadcasting — Belief that thoughts are being placed in, removed from, or broadcast from one's mind
Delusions of control — Belief that one's body or actions are being controlled by an outside force

anchors.text: The dopamine hypothesis is the oldest and most influential neurochemical model of schizophrenia. It has evolved through several versions:

Original version: Excess dopamine activity causes schizophrenia. Supported by the correlation between antipsychotic efficacy and D2 receptor blockade, and the observation that dopamine agonists (e.g., amphetamines) can induce psychotic symptoms.

Revised version: Mesolimbic dopamine hyperactivity (ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens/limbic system) underlies positive symptoms, while mesocortical dopamine hypoactivity (VTA to prefrontal cortex) underlies negative and cognitive symptoms.

Mesolimbic pathway: Overactivity produces positive symptoms; blocked by antipsychotics to reduce psychosis. Mesocortical pathway: Underactivity produces negative/cognitive symptoms; blocking this pathway worsens these symptoms. Nigrostriatal pathway: Blockade produces extrapyramidal side effects (EPS). Tuberoinfundibular pathway: Blockade increases prolactin (hyperprolactinemia).
