[003] Revised version: Mesolimbic dopamine hyperactivity (ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens/limbic system) underlies positive symptoms, while mesocortical dopamine hypoactivity (VTA to prefrontal cortex) underlies negative and cognitive symptoms.
[004] Mesolimbic pathway: Overactivity produces positive symptoms; blocked by antipsychotics to reduce psychosis. Mesocortical pathway: Underactivity produces negative/cognitive symptoms; blocking this pathway worsens these symptoms. Nigrostriatal pathway: Blockade produces extrapyramidal side effects (EPS). Tuberoinfundibular pathway: Blockade increases prolactin (hyperprolactinemia).

anchors.text: Brief psychotic disorder involves the sudden onset of at least one psychotic symptom (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, or grossly disorganized/catatonic behavior) lasting at least 1 day but less than 1 month, with eventual full return to premorbid functioning. It can be specified as with or without marked stressor(s), or with peripartum onset.

Example: Duration-based differential diagnosis: Brief Psychotic Disorder = 1 day to less than 1 month. Schizophreniform Disorder = 1 month to less than 6 months. Schizophrenia = 6 months or more (including prodromal/residual symptoms, with at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms). This duration hierarchy is a high-frequency EPPP question.

anchors_text:

It can be specified as with or without marked stressor(s), or with peripartum onset.
[002] Example: Duration-based differential diagnosis: Brief Psychotic Disorder = 1 day to less than 1 month. Schizophreniform Disorder = 1 month to less than 6 months. Schizophrenia = 6 months or more (including prodromal/residual symptoms, with at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms). This duration hierarchy is a high-frequency EPPP question.

anchors.text: First-generation (typical) antipsychotics (FGAs: haloperidol, chlorpromazine, fluphenazine) primarily block D2 receptors. They are effective for positive symptoms but can cause significant extrapyramidal side effects (EPS):
Acute dystonia: Sustained muscle contractions (onset hours to days)
Akathisia: Subjective restlessness and need to move (onset days to weeks)
Parkinsonism: Tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia (onset weeks to months)
Tardive dyskinesia: Involuntary repetitive movements, especially orofacial (onset months to years; may be irreversible)
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS): Medical emergency with high fever, muscle rigidity, autonomic instability, altered consciousness; treat with dantrolene and bromocriptine

Second-generation (atypical) antipsychotics (SGAs: clozapine, risperidone, olanzapine, quetiapine, aripiprazole, ziprasidone) have broader receptor profiles (blocking both D2 and 5-HT2A receptors). They have lower EPS risk but greater metabolic side effects (weight gain, diabetes, dyslipidemia).

Clozapine is the only antipsychotic with demonstrated superior efficacy for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and is the only medication proven to reduce suicidality in schizophrenia. However, it carries a risk of agranulocytosis (potentially fatal drop in white blood cells) in approximately 1-2% of patients, requiring regular blood monitoring. Clozapine also has significant metabolic and sedative effects.

anchors.text: Family psychoeducation: Reduces relapse by addressing expressed emotion and improving family coping; one of the most effective psychosocial interventions
Social skills training: Structured behavioral approach to improve interpersonal functioning
Cognitive remediation therapy: Targets cognitive deficits through structured exercises
Assertive community treatment (ACT): Intensive, team-based community support for high-need individuals; reduces hospitalization
Supported employment: Individual placement and support (IPS) model has strong evidence
CBT for psychosis (CBTp): Helps patients evaluate and reframe delusional beliefs; reduces distress

anchors.text: Premorbid phase: Subtle cognitive, motor, and social deficits may be present in childhood
Prodromal phase: Gradual decline in functioning; attenuated psychotic symptoms; social withdrawal; typically lasts months to years
Active (psychotic) phase: Full diagnostic criteria are met; positive symptoms prominent
Residual phase: Active-phase symptoms diminish; negative symptoms and cognitive deficits persist

anchors.text: Late onset — Early onset
Acute onset — Insidious/gradual onset
Female sex — Male sex
Prominent mood symptoms — Prominent negative symptoms
Good premorbid functioning — Poor premorbid functioning
Family history of mood disorders — Family history of schizophrenia
No substance use — Comorbid substance use
Married — Single/never married
Developing country — Developed country (WHO finding)

The "rule of thirds" is a rough prognostic guide: approximately one-third of individuals show significant improvement, one-third show moderate but fluctuating course, and one-third show severe chronic illness. The expressed emotion (EE) literature demonstrates that families high in criticism, hostility, and emotional over-involvement have significantly higher relapse rates, which is the basis for family psychoeducation interventions.

anchors.text: This new DSM-5 diagnosis combined what DSM-IV separated as hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) and female sexual arousal disorder. It requires at least 3 of 6 symptoms: absent/reduced interest in sexual activity, absent/reduced sexual fantasies, reduced/absent initiation and unreceptiveness to partner's attempts, absent/reduced sexual excitement during activity, absent/reduced sexual interest in response to internal or external cues, and absent/reduced genital or nongenital sensations during activity.

Persistently or recurrently deficient or absent sexual/erotic thoughts or fantasies and desire for sexual activity. DSM-5 retained this as a separate diagnosis for males, unlike the combined female diagnosis.

Marked difficulty obtaining an erection, maintaining an erection, or marked decrease in erectile rigidity on at least 75-100% of occasions. This is one of the most common sexual dysfunctions in males, particularly with increasing age.

anchors.text: Marked delay in, marked infrequency of, or absence of orgasm, or markedly reduced intensity of orgasmic sensations on at least 75-100% of occasions.
Marked delay in ejaculation, or marked infrequency or absence of ejaculation during partnered sexual activity on at least 75-100% of occasions.

A persistent or recurrent pattern of ejaculation occurring within approximately 1 minute of vaginal penetration and before the individual wishes it. This can also be applied to nonvaginal sexual activities.

Masters and Johnson's Human Sexual Response Cycle (excitement, plateau, orgasm, resolution) and Kaplan's Triphasic Model (desire, excitement, orgasm) provide the conceptual framework for understanding sexual dysfunctions. DSM-5 moved away from rigid mapping onto these models but they remain foundational for the EPPP. Sensate focus exercises, developed by Masters and Johnson, remain a key behavioral intervention for sexual dysfunctions.

anchors.text: Voyeuristic Disorder — Observing unsuspecting persons undressing/in sexual activity — Must be 18+ years old; prevalence up to 12% in males
Exhibitionistic Disorder — Exposing genitals to unsuspecting persons — May involve desire to surprise, shock, or impress
Frotteuristic Disorder — Touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person — Typically occurs in crowded public settings
Sexual Masochism Disorder — Being humiliated, beaten, or otherwise made to suffer — Specify if with asphyxiophilia (arousal by oxygen deprivation)
Sexual Sadism Disorder — Physical or psychological suffering of another person — Must involve nonconsenting partner or cause distress

Pedophilic Disorder — Sexual activity with prepubescent children (generally 13 or younger) — Individual must be at least 16 and at least 5 years older than the child; specify exclusive/nonexclusive type
Fetishistic Disorder — Nonliving objects or highly specific nongenital body parts — Does not include garments used for cross-dressing
Transvestic Disorder — Cross-dressing — Applies to heterosexual males; specify with fetishism or autogynephilia

Example: A person with a paraphilia (e.g., fetishism) who does not experience distress, impairment, or harm to others would not meet criteria for a paraphilic disorder. The diagnosis requires either personal distress/impairment (Criterion B for some disorders) or acting on urges with nonconsenting persons (Criterion B for voyeuristic, exhibitionistic, frotteuristic, and pedophilic disorders). This distinction reduces pathologizing of atypical but harmless sexual interests.

[008] Transvestic Disorder — Cross-dressing — Applies to heterosexual males; specify with fetishism or autogynephilia
[009] Example: A person with a paraphilia (e.g., fetishism) who does not experience distress, impairment, or harm to others would not meet criteria for a paraphilic disorder. The diagnosis requires either personal distress/impairment (Criterion B for some disorders) or acting on urges with nonconsenting persons (Criterion B for voyeuristic, exhibitionistic, frotteuristic, and pedophilic disorders). This distinction reduces pathologizing of atypical but harmless sexual interests.

section_title: Etiology and Treatment of Sexual Dysfunctions

anchors.text: Sexual dysfunctions arise from the interaction of biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors:

Biological factors: Vascular disease, diabetes, hormonal imbalances (low testosterone, hyperprolactinemia), neurological conditions, medications (SSRIs are the most common medication-related cause, particularly for delayed orgasm and decreased desire), substance use (alcohol, opioids)

Psychological factors: Performance anxiety (spectating, as described by Masters & Johnson), relationship distress, depression, anxiety, history of sexual trauma, negative body image, restrictive sexual attitudes
Sociocultural factors: Cultural and religious prohibitions, inadequate sexual education, gender role expectations

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Sexual Disorders & Gender Dysphoria > Etiology and Treatment of Sexual Dysfunctions > Biopsychosocial Etiology
anchors_text:
[001] Sexual dysfunctions arise from the interaction of biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors:
[002] Biological factors: Vascular disease, diabetes, hormonal imbalances (low testosterone, hyperprolactinemia), neurological conditions, medications (SSRIs are the most common medication-related cause, particularly for delayed orgasm and decreased desire), substance use (alcohol, opioids)
[003] Psychological factors: Performance anxiety (spectating, as described by Masters & Johnson), relationship distress, depression, anxiety, history of sexual trauma, negative body image, restrictive sexual attitudes
[004] Sociocultural factors: Cultural and religious prohibitions, inadequate sexual education, gender role expectations

section_title: Etiology and Treatment of Sexual Dysfunctions

anchors.text: Erectile disorder — PDE-5 inhibitors (sildenafil/Viagra); CBT; couples therapy; sensate focus
Female sexual interest/arousal — CBT; mindfulness-based therapies; hormonal therapy (in some cases); addressing relationship factors
Premature ejaculation — Squeeze technique and stop-start technique (Masters & Johnson/Semans); SSRIs (off-label); topical anesthetics
Female orgasmic disorder — Directed masturbation training; sensate focus; CBT; bibliotherapy
Genito-pelvic pain/penetration — Pelvic floor physical therapy; graduated vaginal dilators; CBT; pain management

Spectating refers to the process whereby an individual monitors and evaluates their own sexual performance during sexual activity, becoming an anxious observer rather than an engaged participant. This self-focused attention creates a negative feedback loop: anxiety impairs sexual response, which increases performance monitoring, which further heightens anxiety. Sensate focus exercises address spectating by redirecting attention to sensory experience and removing performance demands.

section_title: Etiology and Treatment of Sexual Dysfunctions

anchors.text: Treatment approaches for paraphilic disorders include:
Cognitive-behavioral therapy: Cognitive restructuring of distorted thinking, relapse prevention planning, social skills training
Aversion therapy: Pairing paraphilic stimuli with aversive consequences (covert sensitization uses imagined aversive scenes)
Orgasmic reconditioning: Redirecting arousal patterns toward appropriate stimuli

Pharmacotherapy: Antiandrogens (medroxyprogesterone acetate/Depo-Provera, cyproterone acetate) reduce testosterone and sexual drive; SSRIs may reduce paraphilic urges; GnRH agonists (leuprolide) for severe cases ("chemical castration")

anchors.text: Requires at least 2 of 6 criteria over at least 6 months: marked incongruence between experienced/expressed gender and primary/secondary sex characteristics, strong desire to be rid of one's sex characteristics, strong desire for sex characteristics of the other gender, strong desire to be the other gender, strong desire to be treated as the other gender, and strong conviction that one has the typical feelings and reactions of the other gender.

The DSM-5 removal of "disorder" from the diagnostic name reflects the movement to depathologize gender diversity. The diagnosis exists primarily to enable access to medical treatment (hormone therapy, surgical interventions) and is distinct from sexual orientation. Research shows that gender dysphoria in childhood persists into adulthood in approximately 12-27% of cases, but persistence rates are much higher when dysphoria intensifies during adolescence.

[002] The DSM-5 removal of "disorder" from the diagnostic name reflects the movement to depathologize gender diversity. The diagnosis exists primarily to enable access to medical treatment (hormone therapy, surgical interventions) and is distinct from sexual orientation. Research shows that gender dysphoria in childhood persists into adulthood in approximately 12-27% of cases, but persistence rates are much higher when dysphoria intensifies during adolescence.

anchors.text: Accurate assessment of sexual dysfunctions requires consideration of several factors:

Medical conditions: Diabetes, cardiovascular disease, neurological conditions (multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury), endocrine disorders (hypogonadism, thyroid dysfunction), and pelvic conditions must be ruled out

Medication effects: SSRIs (most common medication cause), antihypertensives, antipsychotics, anticonvulsants, and opioids can all impair sexual function. SSRI-induced sexual dysfunction affects 30-70% of patients and involves decreased desire, delayed orgasm, and erectile difficulties
Substance effects: Alcohol acutely impairs arousal and orgasm; chronic use causes hormonal changes. Opioids significantly reduce testosterone and sexual desire

Relationship factors: Partner sexual dysfunction, relationship conflict, and differing desire levels must be assessed. DSM-5 requires that the dysfunction is not better explained by relationship distress or other significant stressors
Cultural factors: Cultural expectations about sexual performance, sexual knowledge, and attitudes toward sexual behavior vary widely and must be considered in assessment

anchors.text: NPT testing measures erections during sleep. Normal NPT in a man with erectile complaints suggests a psychogenic etiology (performance anxiety, depression, relationship issues), while absent NPT suggests an organic cause (vascular, neurological, hormonal). This distinction guides treatment planning -- psychogenic erectile dysfunction responds well to psychotherapy, while organic erectile dysfunction requires medical intervention.

Example: A 45-year-old man reports erectile difficulties with his partner but has morning erections and can achieve erections with masturbation. This pattern is most consistent with situational, psychogenic erectile dysfunction, likely related to performance anxiety or relationship factors. In contrast, a man with no erections in any context (including during sleep) likely has an organic etiology. The lifelong vs. acquired and generalized vs. situational specifiers help guide this differentiation.

anchors.text: Assessment of paraphilic disorders, particularly in forensic contexts, typically includes:
Clinical interview: Detailed sexual history, pattern of urges/fantasies/behaviors, history of offenses

Penile plethysmography (PPG): Measures penile blood flow in response to visual and auditory stimuli; used primarily in forensic assessment of sexual interest patterns (e.g., pedophilic interest). Has reliability and ethical concerns
Viewing time measures: Assess attention allocation to sexual stimuli as an indirect measure of sexual interest
Actuarial risk assessment tools: Static-99R, STABLE-2007, and ACUTE-2007 assess static and dynamic risk factors for sexual recidivism
Psychometric instruments: Multiphasic Sex Inventory, Clarke Sexual History Questionnaire

anchors.text: Tolerance: Need for markedly increased amounts to achieve desired effect, or markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount
Withdrawal: The characteristic withdrawal syndrome for the substance, or the substance is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms

Tolerance and withdrawal are neither necessary nor sufficient for an SUD diagnosis. A person taking prescribed opioids after surgery may develop tolerance and withdrawal but would not necessarily have an SUD. Conversely, a person can meet criteria for SUD (e.g., 2-3 social/behavioral criteria) without exhibiting tolerance or withdrawal. The DSM-5 notes that tolerance and withdrawal criteria should not be counted when substances are taken solely under appropriate medical supervision.

[003] Tolerance and withdrawal are neither necessary nor sufficient for an SUD diagnosis. A person taking prescribed opioids after surgery may develop tolerance and withdrawal but would not necessarily have an SUD. Conversely, a person can meet criteria for SUD (e.g., 2-3 social/behavioral criteria) without exhibiting tolerance or withdrawal. The DSM-5 notes that tolerance and withdrawal criteria should not be counted when substances are taken solely under appropriate medical supervision.

anchors.text: Alcohol withdrawal occurs after cessation or reduction of heavy, prolonged use. Symptoms begin within 6-24 hours after the last drink and can include:
Autonomic hyperactivity: sweating, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure
Insomnia, nausea/vomiting
Psychomotor agitation, anxiety
Transient visual, tactile, or auditory hallucinations or illusions
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures (typically 12-48 hours post-cessation)

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal, occurring in approximately 5% of individuals undergoing withdrawal, typically 48-72 hours after the last drink. Features include profound confusion, vivid hallucinations (often visual -- classically insects or small animals), autonomic instability, agitation, and fever. DTs carry a mortality rate of up to 5% without treatment. Treatment involves benzodiazepines (especially long-acting agents like chlordiazepoxide or diazepam).

anchors.text: Wernicke's encephalopathy: Acute condition caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Classic triad: confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (eye movement abnormalities). A medical emergency requiring IV thiamine.
Korsakoff's syndrome: Chronic condition following untreated Wernicke's. Characterized by severe anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) and confabulation. Often irreversible.
Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders: Leading preventable cause of intellectual disability. Features include facial dysmorphology, growth deficiency, and CNS dysfunction.

anchors_text:
[001] Wernicke's encephalopathy: Acute condition caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Classic triad: confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (eye movement abnormalities). A medical emergency requiring IV thiamine.
[002] Korsakoff's syndrome: Chronic condition following untreated Wernicke's. Characterized by severe anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) and confabulation. Often irreversible.
[003] Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders: Leading preventable cause of intellectual disability. Features include facial dysmorphology, growth deficiency, and CNS dysfunction.

anchors.text: Opioid withdrawal is intensely uncomfortable but generally not life-threatening (unlike alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal). Symptoms emerge within hours of last use and include:
Dysphoric mood, nausea/vomiting, muscle aches
Lacrimation (tearing), rhinorrhea (runny nose)
Pupillary dilation, piloerection ("goosebumps"), sweating
Diarrhea, yawning, fever, insomnia

Example: Pharmacological treatments for opioid use disorder: Methadone (full mu-opioid agonist; reduces cravings and withdrawal; dispensed through certified clinics). Buprenorphine (partial mu-opioid agonist; lower abuse potential than methadone; can be prescribed in office settings; often combined with naloxone as Suboxone). Naltrexone (opioid antagonist; blocks euphoric effects; available as daily oral or monthly injectable [Vivitrol]; requires full detoxification before initiation to avoid precipitated withdrawal).

Naltrexone (opioid antagonist; blocks euphoric effects; available as daily oral or monthly injectable [Vivitrol]; requires full detoxification before initiation to avoid precipitated withdrawal).

anchors.text: The classic presentation of opioid overdose involves a characteristic triad of three signs:
Respiratory depression (slow, shallow, or absent breathing) -- the primary cause of death in opioid overdose
Miosis (pinpoint pupils) -- highly characteristic of opioid toxicity
Decreased consciousness (ranging from sedation to coma)

full_path: Domain 3: Clinical Psychopathology > Substance Use Disorders > Opioid Overdose Management > The Opioid Overdose Triad
anchors_text:
[001] The classic presentation of opioid overdose involves a characteristic triad of three signs:
[002] Respiratory depression (slow, shallow, or absent breathing) -- the primary cause of death in opioid overdose
[003] Miosis (pinpoint pupils) -- highly characteristic of opioid toxicity
[004] Decreased consciousness (ranging from sedation to coma)

anchors.text: Naloxone (brand name Narcan) is a pure opioid antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioid overdose by competitively binding to mu-opioid receptors, displacing the opioid. Key clinical features include:
Onset of action within 2-5 minutes when administered intravenously (slightly longer intranasally or intramuscularly)

Duration of action is 30-90 minutes, which is often shorter than the duration of action of the opioid itself -- therefore, repeated doses may be necessary to prevent recurrence of respiratory depression
Administration can precipitate acute opioid withdrawal in dependent individuals, but this is not life-threatening
Available in intranasal, intramuscular, intravenous, and subcutaneous formulations; widely available without a prescription in many states

Good Samaritan laws have been enacted in most U.S. states to encourage bystanders to call emergency services and administer naloxone during an overdose without fear of legal prosecution for drug-related offenses. These laws are an important public health tool in the opioid epidemic. Psychologists should be familiar with naloxone access and Good Samaritan protections in their jurisdiction.

anchors.text: Alcohol — Potentially fatal (DTs, seizures) — Tremor, seizures, hallucinations, autonomic instability
Benzodiazepines — Potentially fatal (seizures) — Similar to alcohol; anxiety, tremor, seizures
Opioids — Extremely uncomfortable but rarely fatal — Flu-like symptoms, pupil dilation, piloerection
Stimulants (cocaine/amphetamines) — Not typically dangerous — "Crash": depression, fatigue, hypersomnia, increased appetite
Cannabis — Not dangerous — Irritability, sleep difficulty, decreased appetite
Nicotine — Not dangerous — Irritability, anxiety, difficulty concentrating, increased appetite

anchors.text: The mesolimbic dopamine pathway (ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens) is the primary neural circuit involved in reward and reinforcement. All substances of abuse, despite their different mechanisms of action, ultimately increase dopamine transmission in the nucleus accumbens. This "final common pathway" explains why diverse substances can all produce addiction.
Stimulants (cocaine, amphetamines): Directly increase dopamine by blocking reuptake or increasing release
Opioids: Disinhibit dopamine neurons by inhibiting GABAergic interneurons in the VTA
Alcohol: Enhances GABA and inhibits glutamate; also indirectly increases dopamine release
Nicotine: Stimulates nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on dopamine neurons
Cannabis: Activates CB1 receptors, which indirectly modulate dopamine release

All substances of abuse, despite their different mechanisms of action, ultimately increase dopamine transmission in the nucleus accumbens. This "final common pathway" explains why diverse substances can all produce addiction.
[002] Stimulants (cocaine, amphetamines): Directly increase dopamine by blocking reuptake or increasing release
[003] Opioids: Disinhibit dopamine neurons by inhibiting GABAergic interneurons in the VTA
[004] Alcohol: Enhances GABA and inhibits glutamate; also indirectly increases dopamine release
[005] Nicotine: Stimulates nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on dopamine neurons
[006] Cannabis: Activates CB1 receptors, which indirectly modulate dopamine release

anchors.text: With chronic substance use, the brain undergoes neuroadaptation: the reward system becomes downregulated (fewer dopamine receptors, reduced dopamine release), leading to tolerance and a new hedonic set point. Koob's allostatic model proposes that addiction involves a shift from positive reinforcement (seeking pleasure) to negative reinforcement (avoiding withdrawal and dysphoria). The extended amygdala and stress systems (CRF, norepinephrine) become hyperactivated, driving the compulsive drug-seeking characteristic of addiction.

Example: The opponent-process theory explains drug tolerance and withdrawal through opposing emotional processes. The initial positive effect (a-process) triggers a compensatory negative effect (b-process). With repeated use, the b-process strengthens, requiring more substance to achieve the same positive effect (tolerance) and producing a powerful negative state when the substance is absent (withdrawal). This model applies beyond substance use to understanding any habituation to emotional stimuli.

The extended amygdala and stress systems (CRF, norepinephrine) become hyperactivated, driving the compulsive drug-seeking characteristic of addiction.
[002] Example: The opponent-process theory explains drug tolerance and withdrawal through opposing emotional processes. The initial positive effect (a-process) triggers a compensatory negative effect (b-process). With repeated use, the b-process strengthens, requiring more substance to achieve the same positive effect (tolerance) and producing a powerful negative state when the substance is absent (withdrawal). This model applies beyond substance use to understanding any habituation to emotional stimuli.

anchors.text: Persistent and recurrent problematic gambling behavior leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, as indicated by 4 or more of 9 criteria within a 12-month period:
Needs to gamble with increasing amounts of money to achieve the desired excitement (tolerance)
Is restless or irritable when attempting to cut down or stop gambling (withdrawal)
Has made repeated unsuccessful efforts to control, cut back, or stop gambling (loss of control)
Is often preoccupied with gambling (e.g., reliving past gambling experiences, planning the next venture, thinking of ways to obtain money)
Often gambles when feeling distressed (e.g., helpless, guilty, anxious, depressed)
After losing money gambling, often returns another day to get even ("chasing" losses)
Lies to conceal the extent of involvement with gambling
Has jeopardized or lost a significant relationship, job, or educational/career opportunity because of gambling
Relies on others to provide money to relieve desperate financial situations caused by gambling

The diagnostic criteria for gambling disorder closely parallel the 11 SUD criteria, including tolerance (needing more to achieve excitement), withdrawal (restlessness when stopping), loss of control, and continued engagement despite negative consequences. This parallel is deliberate and reflects the shared underlying pathology.

[006] Often gambles when feeling distressed (e.g., helpless, guilty, anxious, depressed)

[011] The diagnostic criteria for gambling disorder closely parallel the 11 SUD criteria, including tolerance (needing more to achieve excitement), withdrawal (restlessness when stopping), loss of control, and continued engagement despite negative consequences. This parallel is deliberate and reflects the shared underlying pathology.

anchors.text: Prevalence of gambling disorder is estimated at 0.4-1% of adults. Males are affected more frequently than females, though the gender gap is narrowing. Gambling disorder has high comorbidity with substance use disorders, mood disorders, and personality disorders (particularly antisocial personality disorder). Severity specifiers follow the SUD model: mild (4-5 criteria), moderate (6-7 criteria), severe (8-9 criteria).

Example: Internet gaming disorder was not included as an official DSM-5 diagnosis but was placed in Section III ("Conditions for Further Study"). Gambling disorder remains the only recognized behavioral addiction in the DSM-5. The decision to include gambling disorder was based on decades of evidence showing that it parallels substance addiction in clinical presentation, comorbidity, neurobiology, physiology, and treatment response.

The decision to include gambling disorder was based on decades of evidence showing that it parallels substance addiction in clinical presentation, comorbidity, neurobiology, physiology, and treatment response.

topic_name: Criterion A: Exposure to Traumatic Event

anchors.text: Exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence through one or more of:
Directly experiencing the traumatic event
Witnessing the event in person as it occurred to others
Learning that the event occurred to a close family member or friend (must be violent or accidental for death)
Experiencing repeated or extreme exposure to aversive details of traumatic events (e.g., first responders; does not include exposure through media unless work-related)

anchors.text: Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories
Recurrent distressing dreams related to the event
Dissociative reactions (flashbacks) where the individual feels or acts as if the event is recurring
Intense or prolonged psychological distress at exposure to cues
Marked physiological reactions to reminders
Avoidance of or efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings
Avoidance of or efforts to avoid external reminders (people, places, activities, situations)
Inability to remember important aspects of the event (dissociative amnesia)
Persistent and exaggerated negative beliefs about oneself, others, or the world
Persistent distorted cognitions about the cause or consequences of the event (self-blame)
Persistent negative emotional state (fear, horror, anger, guilt, shame)
Markedly diminished interest in significant activities
Feelings of detachment or estrangement from others
Persistent inability to experience positive emotions (emotional numbing)
Irritable behavior and angry outbursts
Reckless or self-destructive behavior (new in DSM-5)
Exaggerated startle response
Problems with concentration
Sleep disturbance

Major DSM-5 changes to PTSD: (1) Moved from anxiety disorders to its own chapter. (2) Criterion A was tightened -- subjective response of fear/helplessness/horror was removed. (3) Expanded from 3 to 4 symptom clusters (avoidance and numbing were separated). (4) Added "with dissociative symptoms" specifier (depersonalization or derealization). (5) Added "with delayed expression" specifier (full criteria not met until at least 6 months after the event, though some symptoms may begin immediately). (6) Added reckless/self-destructive behavior and negative cognitions as symptoms.

Duration must be more than 1 month. Prevalence is approximately 6.8% lifetime in the United States, with women approximately twice as likely as men to develop PTSD. The strongest predictor of PTSD development is peritraumatic dissociation -- dissociative experiences during or immediately after the traumatic event.

anchors.text: The death of someone close to the individual must have occurred at least 12 months ago for adults, or at least 6 months ago for children and adolescents. Since the death, the individual has experienced, on more days than not, one or both of:
Intense yearning or longing for the deceased
Preoccupation with thoughts or memories of the deceased (in children/adolescents, preoccupation may focus on the circumstances of the death)
In addition, at least 3 of the following 8 symptoms must be present most days, to a clinically significant degree, since the death:
Identity disruption (e.g., feeling as though part of oneself has died)
Marked sense of disbelief about the death
Avoidance of reminders that the person is dead
Intense emotional pain (e.g., anger, bitterness, sorrow) related to the death
Difficulty reintegrating into one's relationships and activities after the death
Emotional numbness (absence or marked reduction of emotional experience)
Feeling that life is meaningless as a result of the death
Intense loneliness as a result of the death

Normal grief is a natural response to loss that, while painful, typically decreases in intensity over time as the bereaved individual adapts. In prolonged grief disorder, the grief response does not diminish over time and remains at an intensity that causes significant distress and functional impairment well beyond expected norms. The duration and severity must cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

[003] Preoccupation with thoughts or memories of the deceased (in children/adolescents, preoccupation may focus on the circumstances of the death)
[004] In addition, at least 3 of the following 8 symptoms must be present most days, to a clinically significant degree, since the death:
[005] Identity disruption (e.g., feeling as though part of oneself has died)
[006] Marked sense of disbelief about the death
[007] Avoidance of reminders that the person is dead
[008] Intense emotional pain (e.g., anger, bitterness, sorrow) related to the death
[009] Difficulty reintegrating into one's relationships and activities after the death
[010] Emotional numbness (absence or marked reduction of emotional experience)
[011] Feeling that life is meaningless as a result of the death
[012] Intense loneliness as a result of the death
[013] Normal grief is a natural response to loss that, while painful, typically decreases in intensity over time as the bereaved individual adapts. In prolonged grief disorder, the grief response does not diminish over time and remains at an intensity that causes significant distress and functional impairment well beyond expected norms. The duration and severity must cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

anchors.text: Approximately 10% of bereaved individuals develop prolonged grief disorder. Risk factors include close kinship to the deceased (e.g., loss of a spouse or child), sudden or violent death, prior psychiatric history, and insecure attachment style.

The most well-supported treatment is Complicated Grief Treatment (CGT), developed by M. Katherine Shear. CGT is a 16-session protocol that combines elements of interpersonal therapy (IPT) and exposure-based techniques. It includes revisiting the story of the death (imaginal exposure), situational exposure to avoided reminders, and work on restoring functioning and pursuing personal goals. CGT has been shown to be more effective than standard interpersonal psychotherapy for this condition.

PGD is distinct from MDD and PTSD. While grief may include depressive symptoms, PGD is specifically focused on the loss of the deceased and the yearning/preoccupation that follows. The 12-month (adults) and 6-month (children) duration thresholds help ensure the diagnosis is not applied to normal grief. The grief response must also exceed expected social, cultural, and religious norms for the individual's context.

anchors.text: Dissociative Identity Disorder (formerly multiple personality disorder) involves a disruption of identity characterized by two or more distinct personality states or an experience of possession, with marked discontinuity in sense of self and sense of agency. Associated features include:
Recurrent gaps in recall of everyday events, important personal information, and/or traumatic events (beyond ordinary forgetting)
Significant distress or impairment in functioning
Not attributable to broadly accepted cultural or religious practice
Not attributable to substances or another medical condition

DID is controversial. The posttraumatic model views DID as arising from severe childhood trauma (typically severe physical/sexual abuse before age 9), with dissociation serving as a defense mechanism. The sociocognitive model argues that DID is created through therapist suggestion, media influences, and sociocultural expectations, noting that it was rarely diagnosed before the 1980s and that its prevalence increased dramatically after media portrayals. Most research supports an association with childhood trauma, but the debate continues.

[006] DID is controversial. The posttraumatic model views DID as arising from severe childhood trauma (typically severe physical/sexual abuse before age 9), with dissociation serving as a defense mechanism. The sociocognitive model argues that DID is created through therapist suggestion, media influences, and sociocultural expectations, noting that it was rarely diagnosed before the 1980s and that its prevalence increased dramatically after media portrayals. Most research supports an association with childhood trauma, but the debate continues.

anchors.text: Conversion disorder involves one or more symptoms of altered voluntary motor or sensory function, with clinical findings providing evidence of incompatibility between the symptom and recognized neurological or medical conditions. DSM-5 removed the requirement to demonstrate a psychological stressor and renamed it to include "functional neurological symptom disorder."

Example: La belle indifference (a relative lack of concern about the nature or implications of the symptom) was historically associated with conversion disorder, but research has shown it is neither sensitive nor specific for the diagnosis. It should not be used as a reliable diagnostic indicator. Hoover's sign and other clinical tests of internal inconsistency are more useful for establishing the "incompatibility" criterion in DSM-5.

[002] Example: La belle indifference (a relative lack of concern about the nature or implications of the symptom) was historically associated with conversion disorder, but research has shown it is neither sensitive nor specific for the diagnosis. It should not be used as a reliable diagnostic indicator. Hoover's sign and other clinical tests of internal inconsistency are more useful for establishing the "incompatibility" criterion in DSM-5.

anchors.text: Prolonged Exposure (PE): Developed by Foa et al., involves repeated, systematic exposure to trauma-related memories (imaginal exposure) and avoided situations (in vivo exposure). Based on emotional processing theory -- the idea that fear memories must be activated and modified with corrective information. PE has the largest evidence base for PTSD treatment.

Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT): Developed by Resick et al., focuses on identifying and challenging maladaptive beliefs ("stuck points") about the trauma, oneself, and the world. Involves written trauma accounts and cognitive restructuring worksheets.

EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing): Developed by Shapiro, involves processing traumatic memories while simultaneously engaging in bilateral stimulation (typically lateral eye movements). Effective but the mechanism of action remains debated -- the specific role of eye movements is controversial, and some argue the exposure component drives efficacy.

Based on emotional processing theory -- the idea that fear memories must be activated and modified with corrective information. PE has the largest evidence base for PTSD treatment.
[002] Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT): Developed by Resick et al., focuses on identifying and challenging maladaptive beliefs ("stuck points") about the trauma, oneself, and the world. Involves written trauma accounts and cognitive restructuring worksheets.
[003] EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitization and Reprocessing): Developed by Shapiro, involves processing traumatic memories while simultaneously engaging in bilateral stimulation (typically lateral eye movements). Effective but the mechanism of action remains debated -- the specific role of eye movements is controversial, and some argue the exposure component drives efficacy.

anchors.text: SSRIs (sertraline and paroxetine are FDA-approved for PTSD) are the first-line pharmacological treatment
Prazosin (alpha-1 antagonist) has evidence for reducing PTSD-related nightmares
Benzodiazepines are NOT recommended for PTSD -- they can interfere with fear extinction learning and may worsen outcomes

Psychological debriefing (including Critical Incident Stress Debriefing/CISD) -- single-session interventions provided immediately after trauma -- has been shown in multiple studies and meta-analyses to be ineffective and potentially harmful, as it may impede natural recovery processes. Current guidelines recommend against mandatory debriefing. Instead, evidence supports psychological first aid -- a non-intrusive, practical approach focused on safety, calming, self-efficacy, social connectedness, and hope.

anchors.text: ACT targets six interrelated processes arranged in a hexagonal model:
Acceptance -- Willingness to experience unwanted thoughts and feelings without trying to control or eliminate them
Cognitive Defusion -- Reducing the literal impact of thoughts; seeing thoughts as mental events rather than truths (e.g., "I'm having the thought that I'm a failure" rather than "I'm a failure")
Present Moment Awareness -- Mindful contact with the here-and-now
Self-as-Context -- Contacting a transcendent sense of self (the "observing self") distinct from the content of experience
Values -- Clarifying what matters most; chosen life directions that are not goals but ongoing patterns of activity
Committed Action -- Taking concrete steps guided by values, even in the presence of difficult internal experiences

anchors.text: Mindfulness — Core skill; present-moment awareness — "What" skills (observe, describe, participate) and "How" skills (non-judgmentally, one-mindfully, effectively)
Distress Tolerance — Surviving crises without making things worse — TIPP (Temperature, Intense exercise, Paced breathing, Paired muscle relaxation), pros/cons, radical acceptance

Emotion Regulation — Understanding and managing emotions — ABC PLEASE (Accumulate positives, Build mastery, Cope ahead, treat PhysicaL illness, balance Eating, avoid mood-Altering substances, balance Sleep, get Exercise)
Interpersonal Effectiveness — Maintaining self-respect while navigating relationships — DEAR MAN (Describe, Express, Assert, Reinforce, Mindful, Appear confident, Negotiate), GIVE, FAST

anchors.text: Comprehensive DBT includes four modes of treatment:

Individual therapy -- Weekly sessions focusing on the target hierarchy: (1) life-threatening behaviors, (2) therapy-interfering behaviors, (3) quality-of-life-interfering behaviors, (4) skills acquisition
Skills training group -- Weekly 2.5-hour group to learn and practice the four skills modules
Phone coaching -- Brief between-session calls for in-the-moment skills application
Therapist consultation team -- Regular meetings to support therapist motivation and capability

The core dialectic in DBT is the balance between acceptance and change. The therapist simultaneously validates the client's experience (acceptance) while pushing for behavioral change. This balancing act is reflected in specific strategies: validation strategies (acceptance) and problem-solving strategies (change). The synthesis of these opposites drives therapeutic progress.

anchors.text: Irvin Yalom identified four existential givens that form the core of human anxiety:
Death -- Awareness of mortality and the tension between the wish to continue existing and the inevitability of death
Freedom -- The absence of external structure; the terrifying responsibility of being the author of one's own life
Isolation -- Fundamental existential aloneness; no matter how close our relationships, an unbridgeable gap remains
Meaninglessness -- The absence of inherent meaning in the universe; the challenge of creating one's own meaning

Frankl developed logotherapy ("therapy through meaning"), influenced by his experiences in Nazi concentration camps. Frankl proposed that the primary human motivation is a will to meaning, and that an existential vacuum (a sense of meaninglessness) is the source of much psychopathology. His technique of paradoxical intention involves instructing clients to intentionally engage in the feared behavior, thereby breaking the anticipatory anxiety cycle.

anchors.text: Beck and his colleagues identified systematic errors in thinking called cognitive distortions. These are habitual patterns of biased information processing:
All-or-nothing thinking — Viewing situations in only two categories — "If I'm not perfect, I'm a total failure."
Catastrophizing — Predicting the worst possible outcome — "If I make a mistake, I'll be fired and lose everything."
Mind reading — Assuming you know what others think — "She thinks I'm boring."
Overgeneralization — Drawing broad conclusions from a single event — "I failed this test; I'll never pass anything."
Selective abstraction — Focusing on one detail while ignoring the big picture — Dwelling on one critical comment despite many compliments
Magnification/minimization — Inflating negatives or shrinking positives — Magnifying a mistake while minimizing achievements
Personalization — Attributing external events to oneself without basis — "My friend is upset; it must be something I did."
Emotional reasoning — Using feelings as evidence of truth — "I feel like a fraud, so I must be one."

anchors.text: Core techniques in Beck's cognitive therapy include:
Socratic questioning -- Guided discovery through a series of questions that help the client examine evidence for and against their beliefs
Thought records -- Structured worksheets documenting the situation, automatic thought, emotion, evidence for/against, and alternative balanced thought
Behavioral experiments -- Testing predictions derived from dysfunctional beliefs in real-world situations
Activity scheduling -- Planning and monitoring daily activities to combat avoidance and increase mastery/pleasure
Downward arrow technique -- Probing beneath automatic thoughts to uncover intermediate and core beliefs

Example: Situation: Gave a presentation at work. Automatic Thought: "Everyone thought I was terrible." Emotion: Anxiety (85%). Evidence For: One person was on their phone. Evidence Against: Several people asked good questions; boss said "nice job." Balanced Thought: "Most people seemed engaged. One person being distracted doesn't mean I was terrible." Emotion after: Anxiety (35%).

[001] Core techniques in Beck's cognitive therapy include:
[002] Socratic questioning -- Guided discovery through a series of questions that help the client examine evidence for and against their beliefs
[003] Thought records -- Structured worksheets documenting the situation, automatic thought, emotion, evidence for/against, and alternative balanced thought
[004] Behavioral experiments -- Testing predictions derived from dysfunctional beliefs in real-world situations
[005] Activity scheduling -- Planning and monitoring daily activities to combat avoidance and increase mastery/pleasure
[006] Downward arrow technique -- Probing beneath automatic thoughts to uncover intermediate and core beliefs
[007] Example: Situation: Gave a presentation at work. Automatic Thought: "Everyone thought I was terrible." Emotion: Anxiety (85%). Evidence For: One person was on their phone. Evidence Against: Several people asked good questions; boss said "nice job." Balanced Thought: "Most people seemed engaged. One person being distracted doesn't mean I was terrible." Emotion after: Anxiety (35%).

anchors.text: Ellis identified several categories of irrational beliefs characterized by rigid, absolutistic demands (musts, shoulds, oughts):
Demandingness -- "I absolutely must perform well and win approval" / "Others must treat me fairly" / "Conditions must be comfortable"
Awfulizing -- "It's awful, horrible, and terrible when things don't go my way"
Low frustration tolerance (LFT) -- "I can't stand it" or "I can't bear this discomfort"
Global rating -- Condemning the total self, others, or life based on single instances

While both are cognitive approaches, there are important differences. Ellis is more directive and confrontational, actively disputing irrational beliefs. Beck uses Socratic questioning and guided discovery. Ellis focuses on irrational beliefs (musts/shoulds); Beck focuses on automatic thoughts, intermediate beliefs, and schemas. Ellis's approach is more philosophical; Beck's is more empirical and research-driven. Both are considered founders of the cognitive-behavioral tradition.

anchors.text: Conceptualization phase -- Educating the client about stress and its effects; identifying stressors and current coping strategies; establishing a collaborative relationship
Skills acquisition and rehearsal phase -- Teaching coping skills (relaxation, cognitive restructuring, self-instructional training, problem-solving); practicing skills through imagery and role-play
Application and follow-through phase -- Gradually applying skills to increasingly stressful situations; booster sessions for maintenance

Meichenbaum also developed self-instructional training (SIT), originally for impulsive children. The client learns to guide their own behavior through internal speech. The sequence follows Vygotsky's developmental model: (1) an adult model performs the task while talking aloud, (2) the child performs the task with the adult's verbal guidance, (3) the child performs while talking aloud to themselves, (4) the child whispers instructions, and (5) the child uses covert (internal) self-instructions. This approach bridges behavioral and cognitive interventions.

anchors.text: Problem orientation -- Recognizing problems as normal and solvable; adopting an optimistic, rational approach rather than an avoidant or impulsive one
Problem definition and formulation -- Clearly defining the problem in specific, concrete terms; identifying goals
Generation of alternatives -- Brainstorming multiple possible solutions without evaluating them (quantity over quality initially)
Decision making -- Evaluating each alternative based on feasibility and likely consequences; selecting the best option
Solution implementation and verification -- Carrying out the chosen solution, monitoring the results, and adjusting if necessary

anchors.text: Relaxation training -- The client is taught progressive muscle relaxation (PMR), originally developed by Edmund Jacobson. The client learns to systematically tense and release muscle groups, achieving a state of deep physical relaxation.

Construction of an anxiety hierarchy -- The client and therapist collaboratively create a graded list of anxiety-provoking situations related to the feared stimulus, ranked from least to most anxiety-provoking using Subjective Units of Distress (SUDs) on a 0-100 scale.

Pairing relaxation with hierarchy items -- Beginning with the lowest item, the client imagines the scene while maintaining relaxation. Only when anxiety is no longer evoked at one level does the client progress to the next. If anxiety emerges, the client returns to relaxation before attempting the item again.

Example: SUD 10: Looking at a photo of a small puppy. SUD 25: Seeing a dog on a leash across the street. SUD 40: Being in the same room as a small, calm dog on a leash. SUD 55: Standing 5 feet from a medium-sized dog. SUD 70: A dog walking past within arm's reach. SUD 85: Touching a calm dog briefly. SUD 100: A large unfamiliar dog approaching off-leash.

anchors.text: During flooding, the client's anxiety rises dramatically. However, because the feared catastrophic outcome does not occur and because the autonomic nervous system cannot sustain peak arousal indefinitely, anxiety eventually habituates. This process, called within-session habituation, is followed by between-session habituation across multiple sessions. The key requirement is that the client remain in the anxiety-provoking situation long enough for the anxiety to diminish -- premature escape can actually reinforce the fear through negative reinforcement.

Flooding carries a risk of sensitization -- if the exposure session is terminated before habituation occurs, the anxiety may actually increase. This makes flooding potentially iatrogenic if not conducted properly. Clients must be fully informed and consent to the procedure, and therapists must ensure sessions are long enough (typically 60-90 minutes) for habituation to occur. Flooding is contraindicated for some clients, including those with serious cardiac conditions or fragile psychological states.

anchors.text: Exposure -- Systematic, prolonged contact with situations, objects, or thoughts that trigger obsessional distress (e.g., touching a "contaminated" doorknob for a person with contamination obsessions)
Response prevention -- Refraining from performing the compulsive behavior that typically follows the obsession (e.g., not washing hands after touching the doorknob)

Exposure alone activates the obsessional anxiety, but without response prevention, the compulsion reduces anxiety through negative reinforcement, maintaining the OCD cycle. Response prevention alone does not provide sufficient exposure to trigger and extinguish the conditioned anxiety. Together, they allow the anxiety to habituate without the maladaptive compulsive relief, breaking the obsession-compulsion cycle.

anchors.text: Chemical aversion — Pairing the target stimulus with a nausea-inducing agent (e.g., emetine, Antabuse/disulfiram) — Alcohol use disorder -- drinking paired with vomiting
Electrical aversion — Pairing the target stimulus with mild electric shock — Historically used for various unwanted behaviors

Covert sensitization — Imagining the target behavior paired with imagined aversive consequences — Clients imagine engaging in the behavior followed by nausea, embarrassment, or other aversive outcomes

Developed by Joseph Cautela, covert sensitization is a purely imaginal form of aversion therapy. The client imagines approaching the target behavior (e.g., reaching for a drink) and then vividly imagines an aversive consequence (e.g., becoming violently ill). Relief is imagined when the client turns away from the behavior. This is considered more ethically acceptable than physical aversion methods and is entirely "covert" (occurring in the imagination).

anchors.text: Stimulus control -- Modifying the environment to alter the cues that trigger maladaptive behavior (e.g., only eating at the dining table to reduce snacking)
Conditioned inhibition -- Presenting the CS without the UCS repeatedly to weaken the conditioned association (basic extinction)

anchors.text: Expectancy violation -- The goal of each exposure trial is to maximally violate the client's specific threat expectancy, not simply to reduce SUDs
Variability -- Conducting exposure across varied stimuli, contexts, durations, and intensities strengthens the inhibitory association and promotes generalization
Deepened extinction -- Combining multiple feared cues during exposure (e.g., exposure to heights AND enclosed spaces together) produces stronger learning
Occasional reinforced extinction -- Intermittently including the feared outcome during exposure may paradoxically strengthen long-term extinction
Removal of safety signals -- Safety behaviors (e.g., carrying a water bottle "in case of panic") should be gradually removed, as they prevent full inhibitory learning

Under the traditional habituation model, successful exposure is marked by within-session and between-session fear reduction. Under the inhibitory learning model, fear reduction during a session is neither necessary nor sufficient for learning. What matters is whether the client's feared prediction was violated. This has shifted clinical practice: therapists now focus on designing exposures that maximally disconfirm threat beliefs, rather than simply waiting for SUDs to decline.

anchors.text: Biofeedback uses electronic instruments to provide real-time information about physiological processes (e.g., muscle tension via EMG, skin temperature, heart rate, EEG brain waves). By observing these signals, clients learn to gain voluntary control over typically automatic physiological functions. Common applications include tension headaches (EMG biofeedback of frontalis muscle), Raynaud's disease (thermal biofeedback), and anxiety disorders. Neurofeedback (EEG biofeedback) has been applied to ADHD, though its evidence base remains debated.

Example: A client with chronic tension headaches is connected to an EMG sensor on the frontalis (forehead) muscle. The machine emits a tone that gets louder as muscle tension increases and quieter as it decreases. Through repeated sessions, the client learns to recognize and reduce excessive muscle tension, eventually gaining the ability to relax the frontalis muscle without the feedback device. This operant learning process (using biofeedback signals as reinforcement) is layered onto classical conditioning-based relaxation.

anchors.text: History taking and treatment planning
Preparation -- Teaching coping skills, establishing safety
Assessment -- Identifying the target memory, negative cognition, desired positive cognition, and baseline SUDs
Desensitization -- Client focuses on the traumatic memory while engaging in bilateral stimulation (typically eye movements, but may include tapping or auditory tones)
Installation -- Strengthening the desired positive cognition
Body scan -- Checking for residual physical tension
Closure -- Returning to equilibrium
Reevaluation -- Assessing treatment effects at the next session

EMDR has generated significant debate. Proponents point to RCT evidence showing it is effective for PTSD (it is listed as an evidence-based treatment by the VA/DoD and WHO). Critics argue that the eye movement component is not the active ingredient -- component analyses suggest that EMDR without the eye movements works equally well, and that the effective component is likely the prolonged exposure to the traumatic memory (i.e., standard extinction/habituation). For the EPPP, know that EMDR is evidence-based for PTSD, but the mechanism of the bilateral stimulation remains debated.

anchors.text: Target behaviors -- Clearly defined, observable behaviors to be increased (e.g., attending group therapy, completing hygiene routines, completing homework)
Tokens -- Generalized conditioned reinforcers (e.g., points, chips, stickers, play money) that bridge the gap between the behavior and the ultimate reward
Backup reinforcers -- The actual desired items or privileges purchased with tokens (e.g., extra free time, snacks, outings)
Exchange rate -- A clear system specifying how many tokens each behavior earns and how many tokens each backup reinforcer costs

Example: On an inpatient psychiatric unit, patients earn tokens for attending group therapy (5 tokens), making their bed (2 tokens), and completing medication rounds on time (3 tokens). Tokens can be exchanged for TV time (10 tokens), a phone call (15 tokens), or an off-unit outing (50 tokens). A posted menu makes the system transparent and predictable.

Token economies are effective because they provide immediate reinforcement for desired behavior and bridge the delay to larger rewards. However, concerns include: (1) difficulty with generalization -- behaviors may not transfer outside the token economy setting; (2) ethical issues regarding the use of reinforcement programs with captive populations; and (3) the need for consistent staff training and implementation fidelity.

anchors.text: A contingency contract (or behavioral contract) is a written agreement between two or more parties specifying: (1) the target behavior, (2) the reinforcement contingencies (rewards for compliance, consequences for non-compliance), and (3) the monitoring method. Contracts are used in family therapy, couples therapy, schools, and substance abuse treatment.

In couples therapy, a quid pro quo contract links one partner's behavior change to the other's ("If you do X, I'll do Y"). A good faith contract provides reinforcement for each partner's behavior change independent of the other's ("If you do X, you earn Y, regardless of what your partner does"). Good faith contracts are generally preferred because they avoid creating a "hostage" dynamic.

anchors.text: Activity monitoring -- Tracking daily activities and associated mood to identify patterns of avoidance and engagement
Activity scheduling -- Systematically planning and engaging in activities that are likely to produce positive reinforcement, even when the person does not feel motivated
Graded task assignment -- Breaking overwhelming tasks into small, manageable steps to build mastery and reduce avoidance
Values-based activation -- Linking activities to the client's personal values to enhance intrinsic motivation

anchors.text: Shaping involves reinforcing successive approximations of a target behavior that is not currently in the individual's repertoire. Rather than waiting for the final behavior to occur, the therapist reinforces behaviors that increasingly resemble the goal.

Example: Teaching a nonverbal child with autism to request items verbally: First, reinforce any vocalization. Then reinforce only sounds approximating the target word. Then reinforce only recognizable words. Then reinforce only complete requests ("I want juice, please"). Each step requires a closer approximation before reinforcement is delivered.

anchors.text: Chaining is used to teach complex behaviors that consist of a sequence of discrete steps. Each step serves as a discriminative stimulus (SD) for the next step and a conditioned reinforcer for the previous step.
Forward chaining — Teaching the first step first; the learner completes step 1, then the therapist assists with the rest — When the first step is easiest or most motivating

Backward chaining — Teaching the last step first; the therapist completes all steps except the last, which the learner does — When the last step is most reinforcing (e.g., eating the food after cooking)
Total task presentation — Teaching all steps simultaneously with prompts at each step — When the learner can approximate the entire sequence

anchors.text: One of the primary challenges with operant interventions is ensuring that behavior changes generalize beyond the training environment. Stokes and Baer identified strategies for promoting generalization:
Train and hope -- Simply implementing the intervention and hoping generalization occurs (least effective)
Train sufficient exemplars -- Practice the skill across multiple settings, people, and stimuli
Use natural reinforcers -- Ensure the behavior contacts natural reinforcement in the environment
Program common stimuli -- Make the training environment resemble the natural environment
Train loosely -- Vary the conditions of training to promote flexible responding
Use indiscriminable contingencies -- Shift from continuous to intermittent reinforcement so the person cannot predict when reinforcement will occur

anchors.text: Michael Lambert estimated the relative contributions to therapy outcome:
Extratherapeutic factors — ~40% — Client variables, life events, social support, fortuitous events -- factors outside therapy
Therapeutic relationship — ~30% — Empathy, warmth, acceptance, therapeutic alliance -- the relationship itself
Expectancy (placebo) — ~15% — The client's hope and expectation that therapy will help
Specific techniques — ~15% — Factors unique to particular therapies (e.g., systematic desensitization, cognitive restructuring)

anchors.text: The Chambless criteria (named after Dianne Chambless, who chaired the original task force) established two levels:

Well-established treatments -- At least two good group-design experiments by different research teams showing superiority to pill/psychological placebo or equivalence to an established treatment, OR a large series of single-case experiments; conducted with treatment manuals; clearly specified population

Probably efficacious treatments -- At least two good experiments showing superiority to a wait-list control, OR one well-designed experiment meeting well-established criteria, OR a small series of single-case experiments

Example: CBT for depression and anxiety disorders. ERP for OCD. Behavioral couples therapy for relationship distress. CBT for bulimia nervosa. Interpersonal therapy for depression. Prolonged exposure for PTSD. These treatments have the strongest evidence bases, supported by multiple RCTs from independent research groups.

The EST approach has been criticized for: (1) overemphasis on manualized treatments at the expense of clinical flexibility; (2) reliance on RCTs that may not generalize to real-world settings; (3) potential exclusion of effective treatments that lack research funding (e.g., psychodynamic, humanistic therapies); (4) treating disorders as discrete entities when comorbidity is the norm; and (5) undervaluing the role of the therapeutic relationship and common factors. The evidence-based practice (EBP) framework was developed partly in response, integrating research evidence with clinical expertise and patient values/preferences.

full_path: Domain 4: Psychotherapy Models & Interventions > Through Evidence > Empirically Supported Treatments (ESTs) > Criteria for EST Designation
anchors_text:
[001] The Chambless criteria (named after Dianne Chambless, who chaired the original task force) established two levels:
[002] Well-established treatments -- At least two good group-design experiments by different research teams showing superiority to pill/psychological placebo or equivalence to an established treatment, OR a large series of single-case experiments; conducted with treatment manuals; clearly specified population
[003] Probably efficacious treatments -- At least two good experiments showing superiority to a wait-list control, OR one well-designed experiment meeting well-established criteria, OR a small series of single-case experiments
[004] Example: CBT for depression and anxiety disorders. ERP for OCD. Behavioral couples therapy for relationship distress. CBT for bulimia nervosa. Interpersonal therapy for depression. Prolonged exposure for PTSD. These treatments have the strongest evidence bases, supported by multiple RCTs from independent research groups.
[005] The EST approach has been criticized for: (1) overemphasis on manualized treatments at the expense of clinical flexibility; (2) reliance on RCTs that may not generalize to real-world settings; (3) potential exclusion of effective treatments that lack research funding (e.g., psychodynamic, humanistic therapies); (4) treating disorders as discrete entities when comorbidity is the norm; and (5) undervaluing the role of the therapeutic relationship and common factors. The evidence-based practice (EBP) framework was developed partly in response, integrating research evidence with clinical expertise and patient values/preferences.

anchors.text: Kenneth Howard and colleagues found a negatively accelerating (log-linear) relationship between number of sessions and improvement:
By session 8: approximately 50% of patients showed measurable improvement
By session 26: approximately 75% showed improvement
By session 52: approximately 85% showed improvement

The curve shows diminishing returns -- the largest gains occur earliest in treatment, with progressively smaller incremental gains per additional session. This has significant implications for managed care and session limits.

anchors.text: Howard also proposed a phase model of psychotherapy outcome with three sequential phases:
Remoralization -- Restoration of hope and subjective well-being (occurs earliest)
Remediation -- Reduction of specific symptoms
Rehabilitation -- Improvement in overall functioning and life patterns (occurs latest)

anchors.text: Mary Lee Smith and Gene Glass conducted the landmark first meta-analysis of psychotherapy outcomes, combining 375 studies. Their key findings:
The average effect size across all therapies was d = 0.85, meaning the average therapy client was better off than 80% of untreated controls
Psychotherapy was clearly effective compared to no treatment
Different types of therapy produced broadly similar effect sizes (supporting the Dodo bird verdict)

anchors.text: Wampold found that specific treatment techniques account for at most 1-8% of outcome variance, while common factors account for substantially more
The allegiance effect -- researchers tend to find superior results for their preferred therapy; when allegiance is controlled, differences between therapies shrink
Therapy is more effective than placebo, which is more effective than no treatment
Individual therapy and group therapy produce broadly comparable outcomes for most conditions

Cohen's d: 0.2 = small, 0.5 = medium, 0.8 = large. The overall effect of psychotherapy (d = 0.80-0.85) is considered a large effect -- comparable to many well-accepted medical interventions. This means the average person receiving therapy is better off than approximately 80% of those who do not receive therapy.

anchors.text: Research consistently shows that there is significant variability in outcomes across therapists, even when delivering the same manualized treatment. Therapist effects account for approximately 5-9% of outcome variance -- comparable to or larger than the effects of specific treatment techniques. Factors associated with more effective therapists include:
Strong facilitative interpersonal skills (empathy, warmth, emotional expressiveness)
Ability to form strong therapeutic alliances across diverse clients
Flexibility in adapting treatment to individual client needs
Engagement in deliberate practice and ongoing professional development

anchors.text: Client characteristics are the single largest predictor of therapy outcome (accounting for roughly 40% of variance per Lambert's model). Key client variables include:
Severity and chronicity -- More severe and chronic disorders generally require longer treatment
Motivation and readiness for change -- Clients in the action stage (Prochaska) tend to benefit more
Social support -- Clients with stronger social networks tend to have better outcomes
Psychological mindedness -- The capacity for self-reflection and insight
Attachment style -- Secure attachment predicts better alliance formation and outcomes

anchors.text: The Institute of Medicine (IOM) proposed an alternative classification that further divides primary prevention:
Universal prevention -- Targets the entire population regardless of risk (e.g., public service announcements about mental health)
Selective prevention -- Targets individuals or groups whose risk is above average (e.g., support groups for children of divorcing parents)
Indicated prevention -- Targets individuals showing early signs or subclinical symptoms (e.g., intervention for students with emerging anxiety symptoms)

Example: A schoolwide social-emotional learning curriculum delivered to all students = primary/universal prevention. Screening all students for depression and referring those who score high = secondary prevention. A cognitive-behavioral group for students already diagnosed with anxiety = tertiary prevention. The EPPP frequently tests the ability to correctly classify interventions into these levels.

topic_name: Four Types of Mental Health Consultation

anchors.text: Client-centered case consultation — The client/case — The consultant assesses the client and provides recommendations to the consultee about the case. Most similar to traditional clinical work. The primary goal is to help the client.

Consultee-centered case consultation — The consultee's difficulty with the case — The focus is on improving the consultee's ability to handle the case. The problem may stem from lack of knowledge, skill, confidence, or objectivity. Most emphasized by Caplan.
Program-centered administrative consultation — A program or organization — The consultant evaluates a specific program or organizational problem and provides recommendations.

Consultee-centered administrative consultation — The consultee's approach to administration — The focus is on improving the consultee's skills in program development, leadership, or organizational management.

full_path: Domain 4: Psychotherapy Models & Interventions > Through Evidence > Caplan's Consultation Model > Four Types of Mental Health Consultation
anchors_text:
[001] Client-centered case consultation — The client/case — The consultant assesses the client and provides recommendations to the consultee about the case. Most similar to traditional clinical work. The primary goal is to help the client.
[002] Consultee-centered case consultation — The consultee's difficulty with the case — The focus is on improving the consultee's ability to handle the case. The problem may stem from lack of knowledge, skill, confidence, or objectivity. Most emphasized by Caplan.
[003] Program-centered administrative consultation — A program or organization — The consultant evaluates a specific program or organizational problem and provides recommendations.
[004] Consultee-centered administrative consultation — The consultee's approach to administration — The focus is on improving the consultee's skills in program development, leadership, or organizational management.

anchors.text: Caplan regarded consultee-centered case consultation as the most unique and important type. He identified four reasons a consultee may have difficulty with a case:
Lack of knowledge -- The consultee doesn't have sufficient information about the client's condition
Lack of skill -- The consultee lacks the technical ability to intervene effectively
Lack of confidence -- The consultee has the knowledge and skill but lacks self-assurance
Lack of objectivity -- The consultee's personal issues interfere with professional judgment (the most complex and interesting problem)

When a consultee lacks objectivity, Caplan attributed this to theme interference -- the consultee unconsciously links the client's situation to an unresolved personal conflict, leading to a "syllogism" such as: "All women who are assertive end up alone and miserable" (connecting the client to the consultee's personal theme). The consultant addresses this through theme interference reduction, which involves demonstrating that the feared outcome is not inevitable -- typically by examining the specifics of the case rather than by directly addressing the consultee's personal issues. The consultant never provides therapy to the consultee.

anchors.text: Prevention over treatment -- Addressing problems before they develop rather than waiting to treat them
Ecological perspective -- Understanding behavior in the context of multiple environmental systems (individual, family, community, society)
Empowerment -- Helping communities and individuals gain control over their lives and circumstances
Social justice -- Advocating for equitable access to resources and addressing systemic inequalities
Respect for diversity -- Valuing cultural differences and adapting interventions to community contexts
Citizen participation -- Involving community members in the design and implementation of programs

anchors.text: Sense of community (McMillan & Chavis) -- Membership, influence, integration and fulfillment of needs, shared emotional connection
Ecological analogy (James Kelly) -- Communities function like ecosystems; interventions must consider interdependence, cycling of resources, adaptation, and succession
Underpopulated settings (Barker) -- Environments with fewer people than needed to fill available roles, leading to increased participation and role versatility

The Community Mental Health Centers Act, signed by President Kennedy, established federally funded community mental health centers (CMHCs). These centers were required to provide five essential services: (1) inpatient care, (2) outpatient care, (3) partial hospitalization, (4) emergency services, and (5) consultation and education. This legislation was a cornerstone of deinstitutionalization -- the movement to shift care from large state hospitals to community-based settings.

anchors.text: Prevention research has increasingly focused on identifying protective factors that buffer individuals against developing psychological disorders, even in the presence of significant risk factors. Key protective factors include:
Individual factors -- High intelligence, easy temperament, positive self-esteem, internal locus of control, effective coping skills
Family factors -- Warm and supportive parenting, family cohesion, stable home environment, at least one caring adult
Community factors -- Strong social support networks, access to quality education, positive school climate, involvement in prosocial organizations

anchors.text: Head Start — Primary/universal — Federal early childhood education program for low-income families; aims to promote school readiness and reduce developmental delays
Perry Preschool Project — Primary/selective — Intensive preschool program for disadvantaged children; long-term follow-up showed reduced crime, higher employment, better educational outcomes
DARE — Primary/universal — Drug Abuse Resistance Education delivered in schools; research consistently shows it is not effective in reducing substance use despite widespread adoption
Triple P — Multi-level (universal to indicated) — Positive Parenting Program using a public health framework with escalating levels of intervention based on need

A critical distinction for the EPPP: primary prevention targets populations before disorder onset and aims to reduce incidence (new cases). Psychotherapy is a form of tertiary prevention that treats existing disorders. Screening programs (e.g., PHQ-9 for depression in primary care) are secondary prevention because they aim for early detection. The EPPP frequently asks examinees to classify interventions into the correct prevention level based on the target population and timing.
