anchors.text: Immediacy -- Respond quickly; delay reduces effectiveness
Short-term focus -- Typically 1-6 sessions; focus on the here and now
Goal: return to pre-crisis functioning -- Not long-term personality change but restoring equilibrium
Active, directive approach -- The therapist is more active and directive than in traditional therapy
Assess lethality -- Evaluate suicide/homicide risk as a first priority

Psychological First Aid (PFA) is the current evidence-informed approach to immediate post-disaster/crisis support. It emphasizes safety, calming, self-efficacy, connectedness, and hope. Critical Incident Stress Debriefing (CISD) -- a structured group intervention conducted within 24-72 hours of a traumatic event -- was once widely used but is no longer recommended. Research (including a Cochrane review) found that CISD does not prevent PTSD and may actually interfere with natural recovery processes.

anchors.text: Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) — Alcohol use disorder — 12-step model; sponsor system; emphasis on spiritual growth and powerlessness over alcohol; the most widely known self-help organization
NAMI — Families of individuals with mental illness — National Alliance on Mental Illness; provides education, advocacy, and family support
Al-Anon / Alateen — Family members of individuals with alcohol problems — Adapted 12-step model for affected family members
DBSA — Depression and bipolar disorders — Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance; peer-led support and psychoeducation

Psychologists can serve as consultants to self-help groups, provide referrals, and collaborate with these organizations. However, it is important to recognize that self-help groups are not a substitute for professional treatment in all cases. Research on AA and 12-step facilitation therapy (TSF) suggests that active involvement in AA is associated with improved abstinence outcomes. The Project MATCH study found TSF to be as effective as CBT and motivational enhancement therapy for alcohol use disorder.

anchors.text: Defense mechanisms are unconscious ego strategies for managing anxiety arising from conflicts between the id, superego, and reality. Key defenses include:
Repression — Pushing threatening material into the unconscious — Having no memory of a traumatic event
Denial — Refusing to acknowledge external reality — An alcoholic insisting they have no drinking problem
Projection — Attributing one's unacceptable feelings to others — "I'm not angry at you -- you're angry at me!"
Displacement — Redirecting impulses toward a safer target — Yelling at your spouse after a conflict with your boss
Reaction formation — Behaving opposite to an unacceptable impulse — Being excessively kind to someone you resent
Rationalization — Creating logical justifications for irrational behavior — "I didn't want that job anyway"
Sublimation — Channeling unacceptable impulses into socially acceptable activities — Aggressive urges expressed through competitive sports
Regression — Returning to an earlier developmental stage — An adult throwing a tantrum under stress
Undoing — Attempting to reverse an unacceptable action or thought — Being excessively generous after having hostile thoughts
Intellectualization — Focusing on abstract/intellectual aspects to avoid emotional content — Discussing the statistics of cancer rather than one's fear of dying

Defenses range from immature/primitive (denial, projection, splitting) to mature (sublimation, humor, suppression). Sublimation is considered the most mature defense. Repression is considered the most fundamental defense -- the cornerstone of all other defenses. For the EPPP, be able to distinguish between similar defenses: projection vs. displacement, repression vs. suppression (suppression is conscious), rationalization vs. intellectualization.

anchors.text: Free association -- The patient says whatever comes to mind without censorship; the "fundamental rule" of psychoanalysis
Dream analysis -- Dreams are the "royal road to the unconscious"; manifest content (surface story) vs. latent content (hidden meaning)
Interpretation -- The analyst offers explanations of the patient's unconscious meanings
Analysis of resistance -- Exploring the patient's opposition to the therapeutic process (e.g., missing sessions, changing topics)
Working through -- Repeated examination of unconscious material to produce lasting change

anchors.text: Klein proposed that infants experience two fundamental positions in relating to the mother:
Paranoid-schizoid position (first few months) -- The infant uses splitting, perceiving the mother as either all-good ("good breast") or all-bad ("bad breast"); characterized by persecutory anxiety
Depressive position (from ~6 months) -- The infant integrates good and bad aspects of the mother into a whole object; experiences guilt and concern for having directed aggression at the loved object

full_path: Domain 4: Psychotherapy Models & Interventions > Through the Unconscious > Object Relations Theory > Melanie Klein
anchors_text:
[001] Klein proposed that infants experience two fundamental positions in relating to the mother:
[002] Paranoid-schizoid position (first few months) -- The infant uses splitting, perceiving the mother as either all-good ("good breast") or all-bad ("bad breast"); characterized by persecutory anxiety
[003] Depressive position (from ~6 months) -- The infant integrates good and bad aspects of the mother into a whole object; experiences guilt and concern for having directed aggression at the loved object

anchors.text: Winnicott introduced several influential concepts:
Good-enough mother -- The caregiver who adequately (not perfectly) meets the infant's needs, gradually allowing manageable frustrations that promote development
Transitional object -- An object (e.g., a blanket, teddy bear) that represents the infant's first "not-me" possession, bridging the space between internal and external reality

True self vs. false self -- The true self emerges when the good-enough mother mirrors the infant's spontaneous gestures; the false self develops as a protective compliance when the mother substitutes her own gestures for the infant's
Holding environment -- The therapist provides a safe, empathic space analogous to the mother's holding of the infant

Example: A client with borderline personality features frequently sees the therapist as either "the best therapist ever" or "completely useless." This splitting reflects a failure to achieve Klein's depressive position -- the inability to integrate good and bad qualities into a coherent whole-object representation. Object relations therapy would help the client develop the capacity for ambivalence (holding contradictory feelings simultaneously).

This splitting reflects a failure to achieve Klein's depressive position -- the inability to integrate good and bad qualities into a coherent whole-object representation. Object relations therapy would help the client develop the capacity for ambivalence (holding contradictory feelings simultaneously).

anchors.text: Otto Kernberg integrated object relations theory with ego psychology, creating a comprehensive framework for understanding personality pathology -- particularly borderline and narcissistic personality organization. Kernberg's central construct is the object relations unit: a mental structure consisting of a self-representation, an object-representation, and the affect linking them. These internalized units, formed through early relational experiences, become the building blocks of personality structure.
Kernberg proposed that personality can be assessed along a structural continuum defined by three criteria: reality testing, identity integration, and predominant defense mechanisms.

Neurotic organization: Intact reality testing, integrated identity (stable and coherent sense of self and others), and reliance on mature/higher-level defenses (repression, rationalization, intellectualization). These individuals experience circumscribed conflicts but maintain a cohesive sense of who they are.

Borderline organization: Reality testing is generally intact but may falter under stress. The hallmark is identity diffusion -- a fragmented, contradictory sense of self and others. Predominant defenses are primitive: splitting, projective identification, idealization, devaluation, and omnipotent control.
Psychotic organization: Impaired reality testing, severe identity diffusion, and reliance on primitive defenses. The individual cannot reliably distinguish internal experience from external reality.

Kernberg developed Transference-Focused Psychotherapy (TFP), a manualized, psychodynamic treatment designed primarily for borderline personality disorder. TFP uses the therapeutic relationship as the primary vehicle of change, with particular emphasis on:

Confrontation -- Drawing the patient's attention to contradictory or split representations as they emerge in the transference (e.g., "Last week I was the best therapist; today I am useless. Can we look at what is happening?")
Interpretation of primitive defenses -- Specifically targeting splitting, projective identification, idealization, and devaluation as they manifest in the here-and-now of the therapeutic relationship
Integration of split self and object representations into more coherent, ambivalent wholes -- moving the patient from the paranoid-schizoid position toward the depressive position

Kernberg and Kohut offer contrasting approaches to narcissistic and borderline pathology, and this distinction is commonly tested on the EPPP. Kernberg views narcissistic and borderline pathology as rooted in aggression and primitive defenses; the therapist actively confronts and interprets defensive operations, particularly splitting and projective identification. Kohut, in contrast, views the same pathology as resulting from empathic failures in development; the therapist provides empathic mirroring and functions as a selfobject, allowing the client to resume arrested development through transmuting internalization. In short: Kernberg confronts defenses; Kohut provides empathic attunement.

anchors.text: Kohut identified three fundamental selfobject needs -- needs for others to serve psychological functions for the self:
Mirroring -- The need to be validated, admired, and recognized ("You are wonderful")
Idealization -- The need to look up to and merge with an admired, powerful other ("You are wonderful and I am part of you")
Twinship/Alter ego -- The need to feel a sense of essential likeness with others ("We are alike")

The therapist functions as an empathic selfobject who provides the mirroring and idealization the client missed in development. Inevitable empathic failures (optimal frustrations) by the therapist, when repaired through empathic understanding, allow the client to develop internal self-soothing capacities through a process called transmuting internalization. The therapist uses empathic immersion (experiencing the world from the client's perspective) as the primary therapeutic stance.

anchors.text: Peter Sifneos — Short-Term Anxiety-Provoking Psychotherapy (STAPP) — Actively confrontational; requires high motivation and specific oedipal focus; provocative interpretation of defenses
Habib Davanloo — Intensive Short-Term Dynamic Psychotherapy (ISTDP) — Actively challenges defenses; uses "trial therapy" for assessment; aims to unlock unconscious feelings
Hans Strupp & Jeffrey Binder — Time-Limited Dynamic Psychotherapy (TLDP) — Focus on the Cyclic Maladaptive Pattern (CMP); 25-30 sessions; emphasizes interpersonal patterns
Lester Luborsky — Supportive-Expressive Therapy — Identifies the Core Conflictual Relationship Theme (CCRT): wish, response from other, response of self

Luborsky's CCRT method identifies recurring relationship patterns across the client's narratives. Each episode is coded for three components: (1) the client's wish or need (e.g., "I want to be accepted"), (2) the response of the other (e.g., "Others reject me"), and (3) the response of the self (e.g., "I feel depressed and withdraw"). The most frequently occurring pattern becomes the therapeutic focus. This method has been widely used in psychotherapy process research.

anchors.text: The miracle question is the hallmark technique of SFBT. The therapist asks: "Suppose tonight, while you are sleeping, a miracle happens and the problem that brought you here is solved. When you wake up tomorrow morning, what will be different that will tell you a miracle has happened?" This question serves multiple functions:
Bypasses the client's sense of hopelessness by creating a vivid vision of a preferred future
Identifies concrete, behavioral goals for therapy in the client's own language
Shifts focus from problem-saturated narratives to solution-oriented thinking
Reveals what the client truly values and wants, rather than simply what they want to eliminate

anchors.text: Scaling questions ask clients to rate their current experience on a scale of 1 to 10. For example: "On a scale of 1 to 10, where 10 means you are handling your anxiety as well as you ever could, where would you say you are today?" Follow-up questions explore what has helped the client reach their current number and what a one-point improvement would look like.

Example: Therapist: "You said you're at a 4 today. What are you doing that has you at a 4 rather than a 1?" Client: "Well, I have been going on walks and calling my sister more." Therapist: "That's impressive. What would be different at a 5?" This questioning identifies existing strengths and generates incremental, achievable goals.

anchors.text: Exception questions explore times when the problem could have occurred but did not: "Tell me about a time recently when you expected the panic to happen but it didn't." These questions highlight client competencies and suggest that solutions are already partially in place.

Coping questions are used when clients feel overwhelmed and cannot identify exceptions: "Given how difficult things have been, how have you managed to keep going?" This validates the client's struggle while simultaneously identifying resilience.

anchors.text: The fundamental micro-skills of MI are captured by the acronym OARS:
Open-ended Questions — Questions that cannot be answered with a simple yes/no — "What concerns do you have about your drinking?"
Affirmations — Statements recognizing client strengths and efforts — "It took a lot of courage to come here today."
Reflections — Statements that mirror or rephrase client speech; simple or complex — "So you're feeling torn between wanting to quit and worrying about losing your social circle."
Summaries — Collecting and linking several client statements together — "Let me make sure I'm following -- you've mentioned health worries, your wife's concerns, and the expense..."

anchors.text: Change talk is any client speech that favors movement toward a target behavior change. It is organized by the mnemonic DARN-CAT:
Desire -- "I want to..." / Ability -- "I could..." / Reasons -- "Because..." / Need -- "I have to..." (Preparatory)
Commitment -- "I will..." / Activation -- "I'm ready to..." / Taking steps -- "I actually did..." (Mobilizing)
Sustain talk is client speech favoring the status quo. The MI therapist does not argue against sustain talk but responds with reflections and explores the ambivalence.

[002] Desire -- "I want to..." / Ability -- "I could..." / Reasons -- "Because..." / Need -- "I have to..." (Preparatory)
[003] Commitment -- "I will..." / Activation -- "I'm ready to..." / Taking steps -- "I actually did..." (Mobilizing)
[004] Sustain talk is client speech favoring the status quo. The MI therapist does not argue against sustain talk but responds with reflections and explores the ambivalence.

anchors.text: MI is closely associated with Prochaska and DiClemente's Transtheoretical Model, which proposes that behavior change unfolds through stages:
Precontemplation -- Not yet considering change; unaware or in denial of the problem
Contemplation -- Aware of the problem but ambivalent; weighing pros and cons
Preparation -- Intending to take action soon; making small preliminary steps
Action -- Actively modifying behavior; requires considerable commitment of time and energy
Maintenance -- Sustaining the change over time; working to prevent relapse

A key principle of MI is to avoid the righting reflex -- the therapist's natural tendency to try to fix the client's problem or persuade them to change. When clinicians argue for change, clients are pushed toward arguing against it (sustain talk). MI posits that the client, not the therapist, should be the one voicing the arguments for change. Rolling with resistance, rather than confronting it, is a core MI strategy.

anchors.text: IPT organizes treatment around one or two of four defined problem areas:
Grief — Complicated bereavement following the death of a significant other — Facilitate mourning process, help establish new relationships and interests
Role Disputes — Conflicts with a significant other due to differing expectations — Identify the dispute, determine the stage (renegotiation, impasse, dissolution), plan strategies
Role Transitions — Difficulty coping with life changes (e.g., divorce, retirement, diagnosis) — Mourn the loss of the old role, develop a positive view of the new role, build mastery
Interpersonal Deficits — Impoverished social networks, chronic loneliness, or poor social skills — Reduce social isolation, enhance social skills, form new relationships

anchors_text:
[001] IPT organizes treatment around one or two of four defined problem areas:
[002] Grief — Complicated bereavement following the death of a significant other — Facilitate mourning process, help establish new relationships and interests
[003] Role Disputes — Conflicts with a significant other due to differing expectations — Identify the dispute, determine the stage (renegotiation, impasse, dissolution), plan strategies
[004] Role Transitions — Difficulty coping with life changes (e.g., divorce, retirement, diagnosis) — Mourn the loss of the old role, develop a positive view of the new role, build mastery
[005] Interpersonal Deficits — Impoverished social networks, chronic loneliness, or poor social skills — Reduce social isolation, enhance social skills, form new relationships

anchors.text: IPT is typically conducted in 12-16 weekly sessions organized into three phases:

Initial Phase (Sessions 1-3): Assess symptoms, conduct an interpersonal inventory (review of significant relationships), identify the primary problem area, assign the "sick role" (legitimizing the patient's need for help), and establish the treatment contract

Middle Phase (Sessions 4-12): Work on the identified problem area using specific strategies; therapist uses techniques such as communication analysis, role playing, and exploring parallels between relationships
Termination Phase (Sessions 13-16): Consolidate gains, anticipate future difficulties, establish the patient's sense of competence, and address feelings about ending therapy

IPT is one of the most well-researched psychotherapies. It has demonstrated efficacy for major depression (comparable to CBT and medication), bulimia nervosa, and is recommended in treatment guidelines by the American Psychiatric Association. The NIMH Treatment of Depression Collaborative Research Program found IPT and CBT were both effective for mild to moderate depression, with IPT showing particular advantages for patients with severe interpersonal difficulties.

anchors.text: Miller and Rollnick organized MI into four overlapping processes that guide the flow of a session:
Engaging -- Establishing a working relationship and mutual trust; the foundation for everything that follows
Focusing -- Developing and maintaining a specific direction for the conversation about change
Evoking -- Eliciting the client's own motivations for change (change talk); the heart of MI
Planning -- Developing commitment to change and formulating a specific plan of action when the client is ready

anchors.text: IPT is unique among psychotherapies in its deliberate use of a medical model. Depression is conceptualized as a medical illness, and the therapist explicitly assigns the patient to a sick role during the initial phase. This serves to: (1) reduce guilt and self-blame; (2) legitimize the need for help; and (3) provide temporary relief from overwhelming role expectations. However, the sick role is time-limited -- a key therapeutic goal is helping the patient gradually resume normal role functioning.

The decisional balance exercise is a technique in which the client explores four quadrants: (1) benefits of the status quo, (2) costs of the status quo, (3) benefits of change, and (4) costs of change. This structured exploration of ambivalence helps the client articulate their own reasons for change without the therapist arguing for it. The decisional balance is particularly useful in the contemplation stage, where the person is actively weighing pros and cons.

anchors.text: Rogers identified three necessary and sufficient conditions that the therapist must provide:
Unconditional positive regard (UPR) -- Accepting the client without judgment or conditions; prizing the client's worth regardless of behavior
Empathic understanding -- Accurately sensing the client's internal frame of reference and communicating this understanding
Congruence (genuineness) -- The therapist is authentic and transparent, without facade; internal experience matches external expression

Rogers believed that the therapeutic relationship itself, characterized by the core conditions, is sufficient for change. The therapist does not direct, interpret, or advise. The primary technique is reflection of feelings -- mirroring back the client's emotional experience to deepen self-understanding. Rogers rejected the term "patient" in favor of "client" and emphasized the egalitarian nature of the therapeutic relationship.

anchors.text: Maslow proposed a five-level pyramid of needs, typically satisfied in order from bottom to top:
Physiological needs -- The most basic survival requirements: food, water, sleep, shelter, warmth, and homeostatic regulation
Safety needs -- Physical security, financial stability, health, protection from danger, predictability and order in one's environment
Belongingness and love needs -- Intimate relationships, friendships, family bonds, social connection, and a sense of community
Esteem needs -- Self-respect, confidence, achievement, mastery, recognition from others, and a sense of competence
Self-actualization -- Realizing one's full potential, pursuing personal growth, creativity, and meaning; becoming "everything one is capable of becoming"

anchors_text:
[001] Maslow proposed a five-level pyramid of needs, typically satisfied in order from bottom to top:
[002] Physiological needs -- The most basic survival requirements: food, water, sleep, shelter, warmth, and homeostatic regulation
[003] Safety needs -- Physical security, financial stability, health, protection from danger, predictability and order in one's environment
[004] Belongingness and love needs -- Intimate relationships, friendships, family bonds, social connection, and a sense of community
[005] Esteem needs -- Self-respect, confidence, achievement, mastery, recognition from others, and a sense of competence
[006] Self-actualization -- Realizing one's full potential, pursuing personal growth, creativity, and meaning; becoming "everything one is capable of becoming"

anchors.text: Maslow distinguished between two categories of motivation:

Deficiency needs (D-needs) -- The first four levels (physiological, safety, belongingness, esteem). These arise from a lack or deficit; when unmet, they produce anxiety and drive behavior aimed at reducing the deficiency. Satisfaction of D-needs reduces motivation related to that level.

Growth needs (B-needs / being needs) -- Self-actualization and, in Maslow's later work, self-transcendence. Unlike D-needs, growth needs are not driven by deficiency but by a desire to grow, expand, and fulfill one's potential. Satisfaction of B-needs does not extinguish motivation -- it intensifies it.

Maslow proposed that lower-level needs are prepotent -- they must be at least partially satisfied before higher-level needs become salient motivators. A person struggling with hunger and physical safety will not be primarily motivated by esteem or self-actualization. However, Maslow acknowledged that the hierarchy is not rigidly fixed: some individuals pursue higher needs despite unmet lower needs (e.g., artists who sacrifice material comfort for creative expression).

[003] Growth needs (B-needs / being needs) -- Self-actualization and, in Maslow's later work, self-transcendence. Unlike D-needs, growth needs are not driven by deficiency but by a desire to grow, expand, and fulfill one's potential. Satisfaction of B-needs does not extinguish motivation -- it intensifies it.
[004] Maslow proposed that lower-level needs are prepotent -- they must be at least partially satisfied before higher-level needs become salient motivators. A person struggling with hunger and physical safety will not be primarily motivated by esteem or self-actualization. However, Maslow acknowledged that the hierarchy is not rigidly fixed: some individuals pursue higher needs despite unmet lower needs (e.g., artists who sacrifice material comfort for creative expression).

anchors.text: Maslow studied individuals he considered self-actualized -- including Abraham Lincoln, Albert Einstein, Eleanor Roosevelt, and others -- through biographical analysis. He identified several characteristics of self-actualized people:
Peak experiences -- Moments of profound joy, wonder, or ecstasy in which the person feels deeply connected, fully alive, and transcendent. Peak experiences are transient but transformative.
Creativity -- A fresh, spontaneous, and non-stereotyped approach to problems and life
Autonomy -- Independence from culture and environment; inner-directed rather than other-directed
Problem-centering -- Focused on problems outside themselves rather than ego-centric; mission-driven
Acceptance -- Acceptance of self, others, and nature without excessive guilt, anxiety, or defensiveness
Democratic character -- Respect for all people regardless of status; comfortable with diversity
Deep interpersonal relationships -- Tend to have a few very close, meaningful relationships rather than many superficial ones
Freshness of appreciation -- Continued capacity to appreciate basic experiences with wonder and awe
Maslow estimated that only approximately 1% of the population fully achieves self-actualization, viewing it as a rare but universally available potential.

Example: In his later writings, Maslow added a level beyond self-actualization: self-transcendence -- the need to connect to something beyond the self, such as altruistic service, spirituality, or identification with a cause greater than one's own existence. This addition is less commonly tested on the EPPP but reflects the evolution of Maslow's thinking and his interest in what he called transpersonal psychology.

anchors.text: Limited empirical support -- The rigid hierarchical ordering has not been consistently supported by research; people often pursue higher needs before lower needs are fully satisfied
Culturally biased -- The hierarchy reflects Western, individualistic values; collectivist cultures may prioritize belongingness and social harmony over individual esteem and autonomy

Methodological concerns -- Maslow's research on self-actualization relied on biographical analysis of subjectively selected individuals, not controlled empirical studies; criteria for selection were not standardized
Vague operationalization -- Concepts like "self-actualization" and "peak experiences" are difficult to define and measure with precision
Gender and cultural selection bias -- Maslow's original sample of self-actualized individuals was predominantly male, Western, and of high socioeconomic status

Both Maslow and Rogers are humanistic theorists who believed in an inherent tendency toward growth. However, their emphases differ in ways commonly tested on the EPPP. Maslow focused on motivation and the hierarchy of needs -- a descriptive model of what drives human behavior at different levels of need fulfillment. Rogers focused on the therapeutic conditions (UPR, empathy, congruence) necessary to facilitate growth and resolve incongruence between self-concept and experience. Maslow was primarily a personality/motivation theorist; Rogers was primarily a psychotherapist who articulated the relational conditions for change.

anchors.text: Here-and-now focus -- Gestalt therapy emphasizes present experience; the therapist redirects past/future talk to the present ("What are you experiencing right now?")

Empty chair technique -- The client speaks to an imagined person (or aspect of self) in an empty chair, then switches seats to role-play the response; used for unfinished business and internal conflicts
Unfinished business -- Unexpressed feelings from the past that interfere with present functioning
Contact and boundary disturbances -- Maladaptive ways of managing the boundary between self and environment (e.g., confluence, introjection, retroflection, deflection)
"I" language -- Encouraging clients to take ownership by saying "I" rather than "it" or "you"

Arnold Beisser articulated a foundational Gestalt principle: the paradoxical theory of change holds that change occurs when one becomes what one is, not when one tries to become what one is not. Full awareness and acceptance of the present state is the prerequisite for change. Rather than striving to be different, the Gestalt approach encourages the client to fully experience and own their current experience -- and it is precisely this deep, non-judgmental awareness that catalyzes organic transformation. This principle underlies the Gestalt emphasis on here-and-now awareness over goal-directed self-improvement.

anchors.text: Subsystems -- Functional units within the family: spousal/marital subsystem, parental subsystem, sibling subsystem. Each has distinct roles and rules.

Boundaries -- Rules defining who participates in a subsystem and how. Range from enmeshed (diffuse, overly permeable boundaries with excessive closeness) to disengaged (rigid boundaries with emotional distance). Healthy families have clear boundaries.
Hierarchy -- The distribution of power and authority; healthy families have parents in a position of authority over children
Coalitions -- Alliances between family members, often across generational lines (e.g., a parent and child aligning against the other parent)

anchors.text: Joining — The therapist accommodates to the family's style to build rapport; entering the family system before attempting to change it
Enactment — Asking family members to interact with each other in session rather than talking to the therapist, so the therapist can observe actual patterns
Boundary making — Strengthening or loosening boundaries between subsystems (e.g., having enmeshed parent-child dyad sit farther apart)
Unbalancing — Deliberately siding with one family member to shift the power structure and disrupt a dysfunctional hierarchy
Restructuring — Actively reorganizing the family's transactional patterns through directives, seating changes, and task assignments

Example: A mother and her 14-year-old daughter are enmeshed -- they share everything, the daughter sleeps in the mother's bed, and the father is disengaged from the family. The structural therapist would work to strengthen the parental subsystem boundary (bringing the parents together as a team), create appropriate distance in the mother-daughter subsystem, and draw the father back into the family. The daughter's presenting problem (e.g., school refusal) is understood as reflecting the dysfunctional structure.

anchors.text: Directives -- The therapist assigns specific tasks for the family to perform between sessions; these may be straightforward or paradoxical

Paradoxical interventions -- Prescribing the symptom or instructing the family to continue the problematic behavior. The rationale: if a symptom is involuntary, prescribing it makes it voluntary (and therefore controllable); if the family resists the directive, they must abandon the symptom
Reframing -- Offering a new interpretation of behavior that changes its meaning (e.g., reframing a teenager's rebellion as "a healthy attempt at independence")
Ordeal therapy -- Assigning a task that is more difficult than the symptom itself, making the symptom less "worth" maintaining

The Mental Research Institute (MRI) in Palo Alto (Watzlawick, Weakland, Fisch) is closely associated with strategic/brief therapy. Their key concept: problems are maintained by the very attempted solutions people use. Therapy focuses on interrupting the cycle of failed solutions. The MRI group also contributed foundational communication theory, including the axiom that "one cannot not communicate."

anchors.text: Differentiation of self -- The ability to maintain one's own sense of self while in emotional contact with others; the capacity to distinguish between thinking and feeling. Low differentiation = emotional fusion with others

Triangulation -- When a two-person relationship becomes stressed, a third person is drawn in to stabilize it (e.g., parents in conflict focus on a child's behavior). Triangles are the basic unit of relationship systems
Nuclear family emotional system -- Four patterns of managing anxiety: marital conflict, dysfunction in one spouse, impairment of one or more children, emotional distance
Multigenerational transmission process -- Emotional patterns and levels of differentiation are transmitted across generations
Emotional cutoff -- Managing unresolved attachment by reducing or cutting off emotional contact with family; appears to resolve the problem but actually increases vulnerability
Genogram -- A multigenerational family diagram used to map family patterns, relationships, and emotional processes across at least three generations

anchors.text: Externalization -- The signature technique of narrative therapy. The problem is linguistically separated from the person's identity, turning it into an external entity that can be examined, resisted, and overcome. Externalization uses language that positions the problem as something that acts upon the person rather than something the person is.

Example: Rather than asking "Why are you so anxious?" a narrative therapist might ask: "When does Anxiety visit you? What tricks does Anxiety use to convince you that you can't cope? Have there been times when you stood up to Anxiety and didn't let it push you around?" This language externalizes the problem (Anxiety) as a separate agent, preserves the client's sense of self as competent, and opens space for identifying moments of agency.

Dominant stories -- The prevailing narratives that organize a person's understanding of themselves and their experience. When dominant stories are problem-saturated (e.g., "I am a failure," "Our family is broken"), they filter out evidence of competence, strength, and positive experience.

Alternative stories (preferred stories) -- New narratives that are more empowering, multidimensional, and reflective of the person's values and hopes. The therapeutic goal is to help clients re-author their lives according to preferred stories.

Unique outcomes -- Exceptions to the dominant problem story -- moments when the person successfully resisted, escaped, or was not influenced by the problem. These are the entry points for constructing alternative narratives. The therapist actively inquires about times when the problem did not dominate.

Re-authoring -- The process of weaving unique outcomes into a coherent new narrative about the person's identity, values, and capabilities. Re-authoring conversations help clients thicken the alternative story by connecting unique outcomes to intentions, values, hopes, and commitments.

Externalization uses language that positions the problem as something that acts upon the person rather than something the person is.

Have there been times when you stood up to Anxiety and didn't let it push you around?" This language externalizes the problem (Anxiety) as a separate agent, preserves the client's sense of self as competent, and opens space for identifying moments of agency.
[003] Dominant stories -- The prevailing narratives that organize a person's understanding of themselves and their experience. When dominant stories are problem-saturated (e.g., "I am a failure," "Our family is broken"), they filter out evidence of competence, strength, and positive experience.
[004] Alternative stories (preferred stories) -- New narratives that are more empowering, multidimensional, and reflective of the person's values and hopes. The therapeutic goal is to help clients re-author their lives according to preferred stories.
[005] Unique outcomes -- Exceptions to the dominant problem story -- moments when the person successfully resisted, escaped, or was not influenced by the problem. These are the entry points for constructing alternative narratives. The therapist actively inquires about times when the problem did not dominate.

anchors.text: Definitional ceremonies / outsider witness practices -- Structured rituals in which an audience (outsider witnesses) listens to the client tell their story, then reflects back what struck them -- without offering interpretations, advice, or judgments. The audience's reflections help thicken the client's preferred story by acknowledging it through multiple perspectives. Drawn from anthropological work on rites of passage.

Therapeutic letters and documents -- White and Epston used letters summarizing sessions, certificates of achievement, and other documents to make therapeutic gains tangible and enduring. These documents serve as external records of the client's preferred story and can be revisited long after therapy ends.

Narrative therapy is deeply influenced by the work of French philosopher Michel Foucault, particularly his analysis of power/knowledge -- the idea that dominant discourses in society (including psychiatric and psychological discourses) shape what is considered "normal" and "pathological." Narrative therapists are attuned to how cultural, institutional, and professional power can produce problem-saturated identities. They adopt a decentered but influential therapeutic stance -- the therapist is curious and facilitative but does not position themselves as the expert on the client's life. The client is always the primary author of their own story.

anchors.text: In family contexts, narrative therapy externalizes problems that the family has internalized as belonging to one member (often the identified patient). By positioning the problem as external to all family members, the entire family can collaborate against it rather than blaming a single individual. Family members are invited to share their own unique outcomes and to serve as witnesses to each other's preferred stories, strengthening new narratives through collective acknowledgment.

Example: A family presents with their 10-year-old son, who has been labeled "the angry kid" at home and school. The narrative therapist externalizes the problem: "It sounds like Anger has been getting a lot of power in your family. When did Anger first start bossing everyone around? Are there times when your family has teamed up and not let Anger take over dinner time?" The family identifies several "Anger-free evenings" (unique outcomes), and together they explore what made those evenings possible -- collaboration that re-authors the family's story from "broken family with an angry child" to "family that sometimes wins against Anger."

anchors.text: Satir emphasized emotional experience and communication patterns. She identified four dysfunctional communication stances people adopt under stress:
Placator -- Agrees with everything to avoid conflict; ignores own needs
Blamer -- Finds fault with others; aggressive and dominating
Super-reasonable (computer) -- Intellectualizes and detaches from feelings
Irrelevant (distracter) -- Changes the subject; uses humor or distraction to deflect

The healthy alternative is the congruent communicator, who expresses feelings directly and honestly while respecting others. Satir used techniques such as family sculpting (having members physically position themselves to represent family dynamics) and family reconstruction.

anchors.text: Irvin Yalom identified 11 therapeutic factors (originally "curative factors") that operate in group therapy:
1 — Instillation of hope — Seeing others improve inspires optimism
2 — Universality — Realizing "I am not alone" -- others share similar struggles
3 — Imparting information — Psychoeducation and advice from therapist and members
4 — Altruism — Helping others enhances one's own self-esteem and sense of purpose
5 — Corrective recapitulation of the primary family group — The group re-creates family dynamics, allowing corrective emotional experiences
6 — Development of socializing techniques — Learning social skills through group interaction
7 — Imitative behavior — Modeling -- observing and imitating adaptive behaviors of others
8 — Interpersonal learning — Gaining insight into one's interpersonal impact through feedback
9 — Group cohesiveness — The sense of belonging and acceptance; the group analog of the therapeutic alliance
10 — Catharsis — Emotional release and expression of feelings in a safe context
11 — Existential factors — Confronting fundamental issues of existence (responsibility, mortality, meaning)

anchors.text: Groups typically progress through predictable stages of development:
Forming (Orientation) -- Members are polite, anxious, dependent on the leader; establishing ground rules; superficial interaction
Storming (Conflict) -- Struggles for dominance, resistance to the leader and to group norms; interpersonal conflicts emerge; members test boundaries
Norming (Cohesion) -- Group identity develops; trust increases; norms are established; members cooperate and support one another
Working (Performing) -- Productive therapeutic work occurs; high cohesion, mutual support, self-disclosure; members give and receive honest feedback
Termination (Adjourning) -- Consolidation of gains; addressing feelings of loss; reviewing accomplishments; planning for continued growth

Research suggests that the most effective group leaders balance emotional stimulation (challenging, confronting) with caring (warmth, support). Leaders who are too confrontational without sufficient caring produce casualties. Leaders must also manage group dynamics such as scapegoating (targeting one member), monopolizing (one member dominating), and subgrouping (cliques forming within the group).

anchors.text: Attitudes are also acquired through modeling. Children adopt the attitudes of parents, peers, and media figures through observation. This mechanism is particularly important in the transmission of prejudice and stereotypes across generations.

Example: When a question asks about attitude formation, consider which learning mechanism is most prominent. Classically conditioned attitudes are often emotional and difficult to change through logic alone. Operantly conditioned attitudes are maintained by their consequences. Observationally learned attitudes may be held without direct personal experience with the attitude object.

anchors.text: Change one of the cognitions: Modify a belief or attitude to make it consistent with the other. ("Smoking isn't actually that dangerous.")
Add new cognitions: Introduce new information that bridges the inconsistency. ("I exercise regularly, which offsets the risks.")
Reduce the importance: Trivialize the inconsistency. ("Life is short -- you have to enjoy it.")

[002] Add new cognitions: Introduce new information that bridges the inconsistency. ("I exercise regularly, which offsets the risks.")
[003] Reduce the importance: Trivialize the inconsistency. ("Life is short -- you have to enjoy it.")

anchors.text: Participants performed a boring task and were then paid either $1 or $20 to tell the next participant the task was enjoyable. Those paid $1 rated the task as more enjoyable than those paid $20. The $1 participants had insufficient justification for lying, creating dissonance that was reduced by changing their attitude toward the task. The $20 participants had sufficient external justification and experienced no dissonance.

After making a difficult choice between two equally attractive alternatives, people increase their liking of the chosen alternative and decrease their liking of the rejected one. This spreading of alternatives effect reduces post-decisional dissonance.

People who undergo a difficult or unpleasant experience to attain a goal tend to value that goal more highly than those who attain it easily. This explains phenomena such as the increased loyalty of fraternity/sorority members who endured severe initiations.

Dissonance can be used therapeutically. Motivational interviewing leverages dissonance by helping clients recognize the discrepancy between their current behavior and their stated values or goals. This dissonance becomes a motivational force for change.

full_path: Domain 5: Social & Cultural Psychology > Attitudes > Cognitive Dissonance Theory > Classic Paradigms
anchors_text:
[001] Participants performed a boring task and were then paid either $1 or $20 to tell the next participant the task was enjoyable. Those paid $1 rated the task as more enjoyable than those paid $20. The $1 participants had insufficient justification for lying, creating dissonance that was reduced by changing their attitude toward the task. The $20 participants had sufficient external justification and experienced no dissonance.
[002] After making a difficult choice between two equally attractive alternatives, people increase their liking of the chosen alternative and decrease their liking of the rejected one. This spreading of alternatives effect reduces post-decisional dissonance.
[003] People who undergo a difficult or unpleasant experience to attain a goal tend to value that goal more highly than those who attain it easily. This explains phenomena such as the increased loyalty of fraternity/sorority members who endured severe initiations.
[004] Dissonance can be used therapeutically. Motivational interviewing leverages dissonance by helping clients recognize the discrepancy between their current behavior and their stated values or goals. This dissonance becomes a motivational force for change.

anchors.text: Mechanism — Aversive arousal from inconsistency — Calm inference from behavior
Applies when — Behavior contradicts strong prior attitudes — Attitudes are weak, ambiguous, or newly formed
Emotional state — Discomfort that motivates attitude change — No discomfort -- simply a rational inference

Research suggests both theories are correct but apply in different circumstances. Dissonance theory better explains attitude change when there is a strong prior attitude that is contradicted by behavior. Self-perception theory better explains attitude formation when there is no strong prior attitude.

A key prediction of self-perception theory: when people receive external rewards for an activity they already enjoy (intrinsically motivated), they may infer that they are doing it for the reward rather than for enjoyment, thereby reducing intrinsic motivation. Lepper, Greene, and Nisbett demonstrated this with children who lost interest in drawing after being given expected rewards for it.

anchors.text: Attitude strength: Strong attitudes (held with certainty, accessible, formed through direct experience) better predict behavior.
Attitude specificity: Specific attitudes predict specific behaviors better than general attitudes predict general behaviors.
Self-awareness: When people are made self-aware (e.g., in front of a mirror), their behavior becomes more consistent with their attitudes.
Low situational pressure: When situational forces are weak, attitudes have greater influence on behavior.
Attitude accessibility: Attitudes that come to mind quickly and easily are better predictors of behavior.

anchors.text: The Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) is the most widely used model for predicting behavior from attitudes. It proposes that behavior is determined by behavioral intention, which is influenced by three factors:
Attitude toward the behavior: One's overall evaluation of performing the behavior (not toward the object in general).
Subjective norms: Perceived social pressure to perform or not perform the behavior -- what important others think one should do.
Perceived behavioral control: One's perception of how easy or difficult it is to perform the behavior. This is similar to Bandura's concept of self-efficacy.

Example: The TPB is a frequently tested model. Remember that it predicts behavioral intention, not behavior directly. Also note that perceived behavioral control can influence behavior directly (not just through intention) when actual control is limited. The TPB is an extension of the earlier Theory of Reasoned Action, which included only attitudes and subjective norms.

anchors.text: Wilson, Lindsey, and Schooler proposed that people can hold different implicit and explicit attitudes toward the same object simultaneously. Explicit attitudes are activated when the person has the motivation and cognitive resources for deliberate processing. Implicit attitudes are activated automatically and may influence behavior when the person is distracted, under time pressure, or lacking motivation to override automatic responses.

Implicit attitudes are measured using reaction-time-based tasks such as the Implicit Association Test, evaluative priming tasks, and the Affect Misattribution Procedure (AMP). These measures assess the strength of associations between concepts and evaluations by measuring response latencies rather than self-reported evaluations.

topic_name: When Do Implicit vs. Explicit Attitudes Predict Behavior?

anchors.text: Explicit attitudes better predict deliberate, controlled behaviors (e.g., voting decisions made after careful thought).
Implicit attitudes better predict spontaneous, uncontrolled behaviors (e.g., nonverbal behavior during interracial interactions, snap judgments).

The MODE model proposes that Motivation and Opportunity serve as Determinants of whether behavior is guided by explicit attitudes (deliberate processing) or implicit attitudes (spontaneous processing).

anchors.text: Fritz Heider's balance theory proposes that people prefer consistency (balance) among their attitudes and relationships. In a triad of a person (P), another person (O), and an attitude object (X), the system is balanced when the product of the three relationships is positive. When the system is imbalanced, there is pressure to restore balance by changing one of the relationships.

Example: If you (P) like your friend (O), and your friend likes a political candidate (X) that you dislike, the triad is imbalanced. To restore balance, you might: (1) change your attitude toward the candidate (come to like X), (2) change your evaluation of your friend (come to dislike O), or (3) decide your friend doesn't really like the candidate (misperceive the O-X relationship).

To restore balance, you might: (1) change your attitude toward the candidate (come to like X), (2) change your evaluation of your friend (come to dislike O), or (3) decide your friend doesn't really like the candidate (misperceive the O-X relationship).

anchors.text: Daniel Katz proposed that attitudes serve different psychological functions, and that attitude change requires addressing the specific function the attitude serves:
Utilitarian function: Attitudes that help maximize rewards and minimize punishments.
Knowledge function: Attitudes that help organize and make sense of the world.
Ego-defensive function: Attitudes that protect self-esteem and defend against internal conflicts.
Value-expressive function: Attitudes that express central values and identity.

Understanding the function an attitude serves is critical for effective intervention. Attempting to change an ego-defensive attitude by presenting rational arguments (targeting the knowledge function) will likely be ineffective. Instead, the clinician must address the underlying anxiety or threat that the attitude defends against. Similarly, cognitive-behavioral approaches to attitude change align with targeting the knowledge and utilitarian functions, while psychodynamic approaches may be better suited to ego-defensive attitudes.

anchors.text: Likert scale: Respondents indicate their level of agreement with a series of statements on a numerical scale (e.g., 1 = Strongly Disagree to 5 = Strongly Agree). The most widely used explicit attitude measure.

Semantic differential scale (Osgood): Respondents rate an object on a series of bipolar adjective pairs (e.g., good-bad, strong-weak, active-passive). Captures evaluative, potency, and activity dimensions of meaning.
Thurstone scale: A set of statements with predetermined scale values. Respondents indicate which statements they agree with, and their attitude score is the average scale value of endorsed items.

Bogus pipeline: Participants are led to believe that a physiological monitoring device can detect their true attitudes, which motivates more honest responding on self-report measures. Used in research on socially sensitive topics like prejudice.

anchors.text: Self-report measures are susceptible to social desirability bias -- the tendency to present oneself in a favorable light. This is especially problematic when measuring attitudes about sensitive topics (prejudice, drug use, sexual behavior). Implicit measures partially address this limitation by assessing attitudes outside conscious control.

Example: Attitudes are among the most tested topics in the social psychology section of the EPPP. Critical topics include: cognitive dissonance (especially the insufficient justification paradigm), the difference between dissonance theory and self-perception theory, the Theory of Planned Behavior and its components, factors affecting attitude-behavior consistency, the distinction between implicit and explicit attitudes, and when each type predicts behavior. Be ready to apply these concepts to clinical vignettes involving motivation for behavior change.

anchors.text: Balance Theory — Heider (1958) — Consistency among triadic relationships (P-O-X)
Congruity Theory — Osgood & Tannenbaum (1955) — Consistency between attitude toward a source and attitude toward the position they advocate
Cognitive Dissonance — Festinger (1957) — Consistency between cognitions, especially after counterattitudinal behavior
Self-Affirmation Theory — Steele (1988) — Proposes that dissonance can be reduced by affirming an unrelated important value rather than changing the inconsistent cognition

Steele's self-affirmation theory is a particularly important alternative to dissonance theory for the EPPP. It proposes that the discomfort of dissonance stems from a threat to overall self-integrity, not from the logical inconsistency itself. Therefore, any affirmation of self-worth -- even in an unrelated domain -- can reduce dissonance without changing the inconsistent cognition. This has been applied to health behavior interventions: having people affirm their values before receiving threatening health information reduces defensive processing.

topic_name: The Role of Affect in Attitudes

anchors.text: Research by Zajonc demonstrated that affective reactions can be independent of and precede cognitive appraisals -- the "affect as information" model. People sometimes evaluate objects based on how they feel ("How do I feel about this?") rather than what they think. This is particularly relevant when cognitive resources are limited. Schwarz and Clore found that people reported greater life satisfaction on sunny days than on rainy days -- their current mood served as information for their evaluative judgment, even though weather is irrelevant to life satisfaction.

Attitudes toward therapy, toward the therapist, and toward the presenting problem all influence treatment outcomes. Research on client expectations shows that positive expectations (attitudes toward the likelihood of therapeutic benefit) predict better outcomes -- a finding consistent with the concept of the placebo effect and the common factors approach to psychotherapy. Understanding attitude formation and change processes helps clinicians build positive treatment expectations and address negative attitudes that may function as barriers to engagement.

McGuire's inoculation theory has been applied in clinical prevention programs. For example, school-based substance abuse prevention programs that expose adolescents to weak peer pressure arguments and help them practice refusal skills are more effective than programs that simply provide information about the dangers of drug use. By "inoculating" students against persuasive peer pressure, these programs build resistance to real-world social influence. This approach has also been applied to anti-smoking campaigns and media literacy interventions.

Relapse prevention in cognitive-behavioral therapy similarly "inoculates" clients by preparing them for anticipated challenges and rehearsing coping responses before the challenges occur. This parallels the inoculation process of exposure to weakened threats followed by practice in resisting them.

anchors.text: Physical and functional proximity is one of the strongest predictors of attraction. People are most likely to form relationships with those they encounter frequently. Festinger, Schachter, and Back's classic study of MIT housing found that residents were most likely to become friends with their next-door neighbors and those they passed frequently in hallways and stairwells.

The mere exposure effect provides a partial explanation: repeated exposure to a stimulus (including a person) tends to increase liking for that stimulus, even in the absence of any interaction. This effect operates below conscious awareness and is one of the most robust findings in social psychology.

This effect operates below conscious awareness and is one of the most robust findings in social psychology.

anchors.text: The similarity-attraction effect demonstrates that we are drawn to people who are similar to us in attitudes, values, interests, personality, and demographic characteristics. Byrne's "bogus stranger" paradigm consistently showed that perceived attitude similarity predicts interpersonal attraction in a linear fashion -- the greater the proportion of similar attitudes, the greater the attraction.

Example: The popular belief that "opposites attract" (complementarity hypothesis) has received minimal empirical support. Research overwhelmingly favors the similarity hypothesis. The one exception involves dominance-submissiveness: some research suggests that dominant and submissive individuals may prefer each other in certain contexts, but even this finding is inconsistent.

The one exception involves dominance-submissiveness: some research suggests that dominant and submissive individuals may prefer each other in certain contexts, but even this finding is inconsistent.

anchors.text: Physical attractiveness is a powerful predictor of initial attraction, particularly in romantic contexts. The halo effect associated with attractiveness leads people to attribute other positive qualities (intelligence, competence, social skills) to physically attractive individuals -- a phenomenon Dion, Berscheid, and Walster described as the "what is beautiful is good" stereotype.

Matching hypothesis: People tend to form relationships with partners who are similar to themselves in physical attractiveness. While people may prefer highly attractive partners, they ultimately select partners at their own level of attractiveness.
Cultural variation: Standards of attractiveness vary across cultures, though some features (e.g., facial symmetry, averageness) show cross-cultural consistency.

Gender differences: Research has consistently found that men place greater emphasis on physical attractiveness when selecting a partner, while women place relatively greater emphasis on status and resources, though both sexes value attractiveness.

anchors.text: The emotional component -- feelings of closeness, connectedness, and bondedness. It includes warmth, sharing, communication, and emotional support. Intimacy tends to increase gradually and may be difficult to detect because it develops slowly.

The motivational component -- physical attraction, sexual desire, and intense emotional arousal. Passion develops quickly but also tends to habituate over time. It is strongly related to physiological arousal.

The cognitive/decision component -- the short-term decision that one loves another person and the long-term decision to maintain that love. Commitment tends to increase gradually and may remain stable even as passion declines.

[003] The cognitive/decision component -- the short-term decision that one loves another person and the long-term decision to maintain that love. Commitment tends to increase gradually and may remain stable even as passion declines.

anchors.text: Liking — Yes — No — No
Infatuated Love — No — Yes — No
Empty Love — No — No — Yes
Romantic Love — Yes — Yes — No
Companionate Love — Yes — No — Yes
Fatuous Love — No — Yes — Yes
Consummate Love — Yes — Yes — Yes

Example: Distinguish companionate love (intimacy + commitment, typical of long-term marriages) from romantic love (intimacy + passion, the "honeymoon" phase). Fatuous love (passion + commitment without intimacy) characterizes whirlwind courtships. Consummate love -- all three components -- is the ideal but hardest to maintain.

anchors.text: Bartholomew and Horowitz expanded the three-category model into four categories based on two dimensions: model of self (positive vs. negative) and model of others (positive vs. negative).
Secure — Positive — Positive — Comfortable with intimacy and autonomy. Trusting, able to depend on others and allow others to depend on them. Associated with the best relationship outcomes.

Preoccupied (Anxious) — Negative — Positive — Desire for extreme closeness and fear of rejection. Overly dependent, jealous, clingy. Self-worth contingent on partner's approval. Corresponds to anxious-ambivalent infant attachment.

Dismissing-Avoidant — Positive — Negative — Compulsive self-reliance. Denial of attachment needs. Emotional distance. View close relationships as unimportant. Corresponds to avoidant infant attachment.

Fearful-Avoidant — Negative — Negative — Desire for intimacy coupled with fear of rejection and distrust. Avoidance of close relationships due to fear of being hurt. Often associated with history of trauma or loss.

Attachment theory has become central to couples therapy approaches such as Emotionally Focused Therapy. Understanding a client's attachment style helps explain patterns of conflict, withdrawal, and emotional reactivity in relationships. In individual therapy, the therapeutic relationship itself can serve as a corrective attachment experience, particularly for clients with insecure attachment styles.

anchors.text: Approximately 60% of adults are classified as securely attached in most Western samples.
Attachment style shows moderate stability from infancy to adulthood but can change in response to significant relationship experiences.
Secure attachment is associated with greater relationship satisfaction, better conflict resolution, and more effective emotion regulation.
Insecure attachment is a risk factor for depression, anxiety, and relationship dysfunction, but it is not destiny -- attachment can be "earned" through positive relationship experiences and therapy.

anchors.text: Equity theory proposes that people are most satisfied when they perceive the ratio of their contributions and benefits to be roughly equal to their partner's ratio. Both over-benefiting and under-benefiting create distress, though under-benefiting produces more dissatisfaction. People in inequitable relationships are motivated to restore equity through behavioral changes (adjusting contributions) or cognitive changes (reappraising contributions).

Social exchange and equity theories are directly relevant to couples therapy. Many relationship conflicts involve perceived inequity -- one partner feels they contribute more or receive less. Gottman's research on marriage emphasizes that stable relationships maintain a ratio of approximately 5:1 positive to negative interactions. Understanding these transactional dynamics helps therapists identify specific patterns that erode relationship satisfaction.

Gottman's research on marriage emphasizes that stable relationships maintain a ratio of approximately 5:1 positive to negative interactions. Understanding these transactional dynamics helps therapists identify specific patterns that erode relationship satisfaction.

anchors.text: John Gottman identified four communication patterns that predict relationship dissolution with high accuracy:
Criticism: Attacking the partner's character rather than addressing a specific behavior. ("You always forget things -- you're so selfish.")
Contempt: Expressions of superiority, disgust, or disrespect (eye-rolling, name-calling, sarcasm). Contempt is the single strongest predictor of divorce.
Defensiveness: Self-protection through counter-complaints or playing the victim rather than accepting responsibility.
Stonewalling: Withdrawing from interaction, shutting down, or refusing to engage. Often a response to emotional flooding.

[003] Contempt: Expressions of superiority, disgust, or disrespect (eye-rolling, name-calling, sarcasm). Contempt is the single strongest predictor of divorce.
[004] Defensiveness: Self-protection through counter-complaints or playing the victim rather than accepting responsibility.
[005] Stonewalling: Withdrawing from interaction, shutting down, or refusing to engage. Often a response to emotional flooding.

topic_name: Duck's Phase Model of Relationship Dissolution

anchors.text: Steve Duck described four phases of relationship breakdown:
Intrapsychic phase: One partner privately broods about dissatisfaction but does not discuss it.
Dyadic phase: The dissatisfied partner confronts the other. Discussion, negotiation, or argument about the relationship occurs.
Social phase: The couple goes public with their problems. Friends and family become involved, often taking sides.
Grave-dressing phase: Each partner constructs a narrative account of the relationship's rise and fall that preserves their self-image.

Example: For attraction and relationships topics, the EPPP often tests: (1) the four determinants of attraction (proximity, similarity, reciprocity, attractiveness), (2) Sternberg's components and types of love, (3) the four attachment styles and their underlying dimensions, and (4) Gottman's "Four Horsemen." Be prepared to apply these concepts to clinical vignettes.

section_title: Evolutionary and Sociocultural Perspectives on Mate Selection

anchors.text: David Buss conducted a landmark cross-cultural study of mate preferences across 37 cultures and found consistent patterns:
Men across cultures placed greater value on physical attractiveness and youth (indicators of fertility and reproductive value).
Women across cultures placed greater value on financial resources, ambition, and social status (indicators of ability to provide for offspring).
Both sexes valued kindness, intelligence, and mutual attraction -- these were consistently the highest-rated traits across all cultures.

Parental investment theory provides the theoretical framework: the sex that invests more in offspring (typically females in mammals) is more selective in mate choice, while the sex that invests less (typically males) competes more intensely for mating opportunities.

[005] Parental investment theory provides the theoretical framework: the sex that invests more in offspring (typically females in mammals) is more selective in mate choice, while the sex that invests less (typically males) competes more intensely for mating opportunities.

section_title: Evolutionary and Sociocultural Perspectives on Mate Selection

anchors.text: Alice Eagly's social role theory provides an alternative explanation for gender differences in mate preferences. This perspective argues that these differences arise not from evolved psychological mechanisms but from the division of labor between men and women in society. As gender roles become more egalitarian, gender differences in mate preferences are expected to diminish -- a prediction that has received some empirical support in more egalitarian societies.

In the famous "bridge study," men who crossed a fear-arousing suspension bridge were more likely to call an attractive female experimenter afterward than men who crossed a sturdy bridge. This demonstrates misattribution of arousal (also known as the excitation transfer effect): physiological arousal from one source (fear) can be misattributed to another source (attraction). This finding connects attraction research to Schachter and Singer's two-factor theory of emotion.

Attraction and relationships questions on the EPPP draw from multiple theoretical perspectives. Be prepared to identify: the four major determinants of attraction, distinguish between Sternberg's seven types of love, map attachment styles onto the two-dimensional model, recognize Gottman's four predictive communication patterns, and understand the theoretical debate between evolutionary and sociocultural explanations for mate preferences. Clinically, attachment theory is the most directly applied framework in therapeutic practice, particularly in Emotionally Focused Therapy.

anchors.text: Self-disclosure follows a norm of reciprocity, particularly in early relationship stages. When one person discloses personal information, the other tends to match the level of disclosure. This reciprocal escalation builds trust and intimacy progressively. In therapy, appropriate therapist self-disclosure can model vulnerability and strengthen the therapeutic alliance, though it must be used judiciously and in the client's interest.

Jourard's research showed that therapist self-disclosure tends to increase client self-disclosure. However, cultural factors significantly moderate the appropriateness and impact of disclosure. Clients from cultures that value emotional restraint may find therapist self-disclosure inappropriate or confusing, while clients from cultures that value relational warmth may view it as a sign of genuine caring and trust.

anchors.text: Loneliness is the subjective experience of perceived social isolation -- a discrepancy between desired and actual social connections. It is distinct from objective social isolation (physically being alone). Research shows that loneliness is associated with increased risk for depression, cardiovascular disease, cognitive decline, and mortality. Cacioppo's evolutionary model of loneliness proposes that loneliness functions as a biological signal (analogous to hunger or thirst) that motivates reconnection with others. However, chronic loneliness creates a self-reinforcing cycle: lonely individuals become hypervigilant to social threats, interpret ambiguous social cues negatively, and withdraw further from social contact.

Robert Weiss distinguished between social loneliness (absence of a social network or sense of community belonging) and emotional loneliness (absence of a close, intimate attachment figure). Different interventions are needed for each type: social loneliness responds to group-based interventions and community integration, while emotional loneliness requires the development of close, confiding relationships. This distinction is clinically important because a person can experience one type without the other.

Interventions for loneliness are most effective when they address maladaptive social cognition (the negative interpretive biases that perpetuate loneliness) rather than simply providing social opportunities. Cognitive-behavioral approaches that target distorted social perceptions have shown the largest effect sizes in meta-analyses.

anchors.text: Perceptual salience: The actor is the "figure" against the "ground" of the situation. We attend to people more than contexts.

Two-stage process: We first make an automatic dispositional attribution, then (if we have the cognitive resources) adjust for situational factors. When cognitively busy or distracted, the adjustment stage is often skipped.
Cultural factors: The FAE is more pronounced in individualistic (Western) cultures. Members of collectivistic cultures attend more to situational factors and show a weaker correspondence bias.

The FAE has implications for clinical judgment. Clinicians may attribute a client's behavior (e.g., missing appointments) to dispositional factors (lack of motivation, resistance) while underestimating situational factors (transportation difficulties, childcare, financial constraints). This bias can lead to inaccurate case conceptualization and damaged therapeutic alliance.

anchors.text: Self-enhancing bias: Taking credit for successes (internal attribution for positive outcomes).
Self-protecting bias: Denying responsibility for failures (external attribution for negative outcomes).

full_path: Domain 5: Social & Cultural Psychology > Attribution Theory > Self-Serving Bias > Components
anchors_text:
[001] Self-enhancing bias: Taking credit for successes (internal attribution for positive outcomes).
[002] Self-protecting bias: Denying responsibility for failures (external attribution for negative outcomes).

anchors.text: The self-serving bias is reduced or reversed in individuals with depression, who tend to show a depressive attributional style -- attributing negative events to internal, stable, and global causes. This pattern was described by Abramson, Seligman, and Teasdale in their reformulated learned helplessness theory and is central to Beck's cognitive model of depression.

Example: The self-serving bias and the fundamental attribution error operate differently. FAE is about how we explain other people's behavior (overemphasizing their dispositions). Self-serving bias is about how we explain our own outcomes (taking credit for success, denying blame for failure). The EPPP may test this distinction directly.

This pattern was described by Abramson, Seligman, and Teasdale in their reformulated learned helplessness theory and is central to Beck's cognitive model of depression.
[002] Example: The self-serving bias and the fundamental attribution error operate differently. FAE is about how we explain other people's behavior (overemphasizing their dispositions). Self-serving bias is about how we explain our own outcomes (taking credit for success, denying blame for failure). The EPPP may test this distinction directly.

anchors.text: Perceptual focus: Actors look outward at the situation; observers look at the actor. This difference in visual perspective produces different causal attributions.

Information asymmetry: Actors have more information about the variability of their own behavior across situations, making them more likely to see situational influences. Observers see only the current behavior and infer stable traits.

Storms tested the perceptual explanation by videotaping a conversation and then showing participants the interaction from the other person's perspective. When actors saw themselves from the observer's point of view, they made more dispositional attributions about their own behavior. When observers saw the situation from the actor's viewpoint, they made more situational attributions. This supports the perceptual salience explanation.

Note: More recent meta-analyses have questioned the robustness of the actor-observer effect, finding it to be smaller and more context-dependent than originally claimed. Nevertheless, it remains a frequently tested concept on the EPPP.

When actors saw themselves from the observer's point of view, they made more dispositional attributions about their own behavior. When observers saw the situation from the actor's viewpoint, they made more situational attributions. This supports the perceptual salience explanation.
[004] Note: More recent meta-analyses have questioned the robustness of the actor-observer effect, finding it to be smaller and more context-dependent than originally claimed. Nevertheless, it remains a frequently tested concept on the EPPP.

anchors.text: Consensus — Do other people behave this way toward the same stimulus? — Everyone laughs at the comedian — Only this person laughs at the comedian
Distinctiveness — Does this person behave this way toward other stimuli? — This person laughs only at this comedian — This person laughs at all comedians
Consistency — Does this person behave this way at other times/situations? — This person always laughs at this comedian — This person laughed only this one time

full_path: Domain 5: Social & Cultural Psychology > Attribution Theory > Kelley's Covariation Model > Three Types of Information
anchors_text:
[001] Consensus — Do other people behave this way toward the same stimulus? — Everyone laughs at the comedian — Only this person laughs at the comedian
[002] Distinctiveness — Does this person behave this way toward other stimuli? — This person laughs only at this comedian — This person laughs at all comedians
[003] Consistency — Does this person behave this way at other times/situations? — This person always laughs at this comedian — This person laughed only this one time

anchors.text: Made when consensus is high, distinctiveness is high, and consistency is high. Example: Everyone laughs at this comedian (high consensus), this person laughs only at this comedian (high distinctiveness), and this person always laughs at this comedian (high consistency). Conclusion: The comedian is genuinely funny (external attribution to the stimulus).

Made when consensus is low, distinctiveness is low, and consistency is high. Example: No one else laughs at this comedian (low consensus), this person laughs at everything (low distinctiveness), and this person always laughs at this comedian (high consistency). Conclusion: This person just laughs easily (internal attribution).
Made when consistency is low. If the behavior occurs only this one time, it is likely attributed to the particular circumstances rather than the person or the stimulus.

Example: Kelley's model is one of the most commonly tested attribution topics. Memorize the pattern: High-High-High = external/stimulus attribution. Low-Low-High = internal/person attribution. Low consistency = circumstance attribution. Practice applying these patterns to scenario questions.

anchors.text: Locus — Internal vs. external cause — Affects self-esteem and pride/shame. Internal attributions for success lead to pride; internal attributions for failure lead to shame.

Stability — Stable (enduring) vs. unstable (temporary) cause — Affects expectations for future performance. Stable attributions for failure (e.g., lack of ability) lead to hopelessness; unstable attributions (e.g., bad luck) preserve hope.
Controllability — Controllable vs. uncontrollable cause — Affects emotions such as guilt (controllable failure) vs. helplessness (uncontrollable failure), and others' sympathy vs. anger.
