anchors.text: Maintenance rehearsal involves simple repetition of information without engaging with its meaning, as when repeating a phone number to keep it in short-term memory. This form of rehearsal produces minimal long-term retention. In contrast, elaborative rehearsal involves connecting new information to existing knowledge, generating examples, and thinking about meaning. Elaborative rehearsal promotes deep processing and robust long-term encoding.

Example: A student who reads the definition of "proactive interference" and then generates her own example of how previously learned Spanish vocabulary interferes with learning French vocabulary is engaging in elaborative rehearsal. A student who simply rereads the definition ten times is engaging in maintenance rehearsal. The first strategy produces far superior retention.

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Learning Processes & Encoding Strategies > Levels of Processing Framework > Elaborative vs. Maintenance Rehearsal
anchors_text:
[001] Maintenance rehearsal involves simple repetition of information without engaging with its meaning, as when repeating a phone number to keep it in short-term memory. This form of rehearsal produces minimal long-term retention. In contrast, elaborative rehearsal involves connecting new information to existing knowledge, generating examples, and thinking about meaning. Elaborative rehearsal promotes deep processing and robust long-term encoding.
[002] Example: A student who reads the definition of "proactive interference" and then generates her own example of how previously learned Spanish vocabulary interferes with learning French vocabulary is engaging in elaborative rehearsal. A student who simply rereads the definition ten times is engaging in maintenance rehearsal. The first strategy produces far superior retention.

anchors.text: State-dependent memory refers to the finding that recall is enhanced when an individual's internal physiological or psychological state at retrieval matches the state during encoding. This has been demonstrated with mood states (mood-dependent memory), pharmacological states, and arousal levels.

State-dependent memory has important implications for psychotherapy. Traumatic memories encoded during high-arousal states may be difficult to access during the calm conditions of a therapy session. Conversely, therapeutic insights gained in session may be harder to retrieve when the patient is in a distressed state outside of therapy. This principle also explains why substance-related memories may be more accessible under the influence of the same substance.

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Learning Processes & Encoding Strategies > Encoding Specificity & Context Effects > State-Dependent Memory
anchors_text:
[001] State-dependent memory refers to the finding that recall is enhanced when an individual's internal physiological or psychological state at retrieval matches the state during encoding. This has been demonstrated with mood states (mood-dependent memory), pharmacological states, and arousal levels.
[002] State-dependent memory has important implications for psychotherapy. Traumatic memories encoded during high-arousal states may be difficult to access during the calm conditions of a therapy session. Conversely, therapeutic insights gained in session may be harder to retrieve when the patient is in a distressed state outside of therapy. This principle also explains why substance-related memories may be more accessible under the influence of the same substance.

anchors.text: The testing effect (also called retrieval practice) is one of the most robust findings in the learning sciences. Practicing retrieval of information — through self-testing, flashcards, or practice questions — produces substantially better long-term retention than restudying the same material for an equivalent amount of time. Roediger and Karpicke demonstrated that students who were tested on material retained it significantly better one week later than students who spent the same time restudying.

Example: For EPPP preparation, the testing effect implies that repeatedly taking practice tests is more effective for long-term learning than repeatedly rereading study materials. Each act of retrieval strengthens the memory trace and makes the information more accessible for future recall, including on exam day.

Practicing retrieval of information — through self-testing, flashcards, or practice questions — produces substantially better long-term retention than restudying the same material for an equivalent amount of time. Roediger and Karpicke demonstrated that students who were tested on material retained it significantly better one week later than students who spent the same time restudying.
[002] Example: For EPPP preparation, the testing effect implies that repeatedly taking practice tests is more effective for long-term learning than repeatedly rereading study materials. Each act of retrieval strengthens the memory trace and makes the information more accessible for future recall, including on exam day.

anchors.text: Mnemonic devices leverage dual coding and elaborative processing to enhance memory. Key techniques tested on the EPPP include:

Method of loci: Associating items to be remembered with specific locations along a familiar mental route. This ancient technique creates vivid spatial-visual associations and is highly effective for ordered recall.

Keyword method: Used for vocabulary learning; the learner creates a concrete image linking the sound of the unfamiliar word to the meaning through an intermediary keyword. Particularly effective for foreign language acquisition.
Pegword method: Items are associated with a pre-memorized sequence of rhyming cue words (e.g., "one is a bun, two is a shoe"). Useful for learning numbered lists.

The transfer-appropriate processing principle states that memory performance depends on the match between the type of processing at encoding and the type of processing required at retrieval. Semantic encoding produces superior performance on meaning-based tests, while phonemic encoding may actually produce better performance on rhyme-recognition tests. This principle refines the levels of processing framework by emphasizing that "deeper" is not always "better" — what matters is the match between encoding and retrieval demands.

[002] Method of loci: Associating items to be remembered with specific locations along a familiar mental route. This ancient technique creates vivid spatial-visual associations and is highly effective for ordered recall.
[003] Keyword method: Used for vocabulary learning; the learner creates a concrete image linking the sound of the unfamiliar word to the meaning through an intermediary keyword. Particularly effective for foreign language acquisition.
[004] Pegword method: Items are associated with a pre-memorized sequence of rhyming cue words (e.g., "one is a bun, two is a shoe"). Useful for learning numbered lists.
[005] The transfer-appropriate processing principle states that memory performance depends on the match between the type of processing at encoding and the type of processing required at retrieval. Semantic encoding produces superior performance on meaning-based tests, while phonemic encoding may actually produce better performance on rhyme-recognition tests. This principle refines the levels of processing framework by emphasizing that "deeper" is not always "better" — what matters is the match between encoding and retrieval demands.

anchors.text: Sensory memory holds a brief, relatively complete record of sensory experience. Two forms are most studied:

Iconic memory (visual): Demonstrated by Sperling's partial-report paradigm, iconic memory holds a nearly complete visual image for approximately 250-500 milliseconds. Sperling showed that participants could report any row of a briefly flashed letter array when cued immediately, but this advantage disappeared after about half a second, indicating rapid decay of the iconic trace.

Echoic memory (auditory): Retains auditory information for approximately 3-4 seconds. This longer duration explains why you can "replay" something someone just said, even if you were not initially attending to it.

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Memory Architecture & Working Memory > The Atkinson-Shiffrin Multi-Store Model > Sensory Memory
anchors_text:
[001] Sensory memory holds a brief, relatively complete record of sensory experience. Two forms are most studied:
[002] Iconic memory (visual): Demonstrated by Sperling's partial-report paradigm, iconic memory holds a nearly complete visual image for approximately 250-500 milliseconds. Sperling showed that participants could report any row of a briefly flashed letter array when cued immediately, but this advantage disappeared after about half a second, indicating rapid decay of the iconic trace.
[003] Echoic memory (auditory): Retains auditory information for approximately 3-4 seconds. This longer duration explains why you can "replay" something someone just said, even if you were not initially attending to it.

anchors.text: Short-term memory holds a limited amount of information in an active, accessible state for approximately 15-30 seconds without rehearsal. George Miller's classic paper established that STM capacity is approximately 7 plus or minus 2 items (the "magical number seven").

Chunking is the process of grouping individual items into larger meaningful units, effectively increasing the amount of information that can be held in short-term memory. For example, the sequence 1-9-4-1-1-7-7-6 contains 8 digits, but chunking it as 1941-1776 (two historical dates) reduces the memory load to 2 chunks. Expertise in a domain facilitates chunking — chess masters perceive meaningful board configurations as single chunks rather than individual piece positions.

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Memory Architecture & Working Memory > The Atkinson-Shiffrin Multi-Store Model > Short-Term Memory (STM)
anchors_text:
[001] Short-term memory holds a limited amount of information in an active, accessible state for approximately 15-30 seconds without rehearsal. George Miller's classic paper established that STM capacity is approximately 7 plus or minus 2 items (the "magical number seven").
[002] Chunking is the process of grouping individual items into larger meaningful units, effectively increasing the amount of information that can be held in short-term memory. For example, the sequence 1-9-4-1-1-7-7-6 contains 8 digits, but chunking it as 1941-1776 (two historical dates) reduces the memory load to 2 chunks. Expertise in a domain facilitates chunking — chess masters perceive meaningful board configurations as single chunks rather than individual piece positions.

anchors.text: The phonological loop consists of a phonological store (which holds speech-based information for 1-2 seconds) and an articulatory rehearsal process (which refreshes the contents through subvocal repetition). Two key phenomena demonstrate the phonological loop's operation:
Phonological similarity effect: Lists of similar-sounding items (B, D, G, T, P) are harder to recall than dissimilar items, because they produce confusable representations in the phonological store.
Word-length effect: Lists of long words are harder to recall than short words, because longer words take more time to rehearse in the articulatory loop.

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Memory Architecture & Working Memory > Baddeley's Working Memory Model > The Phonological Loop
anchors_text:
[001] The phonological loop consists of a phonological store (which holds speech-based information for 1-2 seconds) and an articulatory rehearsal process (which refreshes the contents through subvocal repetition). Two key phenomena demonstrate the phonological loop's operation:
[002] Phonological similarity effect: Lists of similar-sounding items (B, D, G, T, P) are harder to recall than dissimilar items, because they produce confusable representations in the phonological store.
[003] Word-length effect: Lists of long words are harder to recall than short words, because longer words take more time to rehearse in the articulatory loop.

anchors.text: The visuospatial sketchpad maintains and manipulates visual and spatial information. It can be subdivided into a visual cache (which stores visual patterns and colors) and an inner scribe (which processes spatial and movement information). Tasks such as mental rotation, navigating a familiar environment from memory, and solving jigsaw puzzles rely on this component.

Example: The working memory model predicts that two tasks using the same subsystem will interfere with each other more than two tasks using different subsystems. A patient asked to remember a phone number (phonological loop) while counting backward (also phonological loop) will show greater interference than if asked to remember the phone number while tracking a moving object (visuospatial sketchpad). This principle of selective interference is a key prediction tested on the EPPP.

anchors_text:
[001] The visuospatial sketchpad maintains and manipulates visual and spatial information. It can be subdivided into a visual cache (which stores visual patterns and colors) and an inner scribe (which processes spatial and movement information). Tasks such as mental rotation, navigating a familiar environment from memory, and solving jigsaw puzzles rely on this component.
[002] Example: The working memory model predicts that two tasks using the same subsystem will interfere with each other more than two tasks using different subsystems. A patient asked to remember a phone number (phonological loop) while counting backward (also phonological loop) will show greater interference than if asked to remember the phone number while tracking a moving object (visuospatial sketchpad). This principle of selective interference is a key prediction tested on the EPPP.

anchors.text: Declarative (explicit) memory refers to memories that can be consciously recalled and verbally declared. It is further divided into episodic memory (autobiographical events situated in time and place) and semantic memory (general world knowledge and facts). Declarative memory depends critically on the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe structures.

Procedural (implicit) memory refers to knowledge of how to perform skills and procedures (e.g., riding a bicycle, typing). Procedural memories are acquired gradually through practice and are expressed through performance rather than conscious recollection. This system depends on the basal ganglia, cerebellum, and motor cortex rather than the hippocampus.

Endel Tulving proposed that episodic memory stores personally experienced events with contextual details (time, place, associated emotions) and involves "mental time travel." Semantic memory stores general knowledge, facts, concepts, and vocabulary, independent of the personal context in which they were learned. Knowing that Paris is the capital of France (semantic) is distinct from remembering your trip to Paris (episodic). This distinction is critical for understanding amnesia: patients with hippocampal damage may lose the ability to form new episodic memories while retaining the ability to acquire some new semantic knowledge.

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Memory Architecture & Working Memory > Long-Term Memory Taxonomies > Declarative vs. Procedural Memory
anchors_text:
[001] Declarative (explicit) memory refers to memories that can be consciously recalled and verbally declared. It is further divided into episodic memory (autobiographical events situated in time and place) and semantic memory (general world knowledge and facts). Declarative memory depends critically on the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe structures.
[002] Procedural (implicit) memory refers to knowledge of how to perform skills and procedures (e.g., riding a bicycle, typing). Procedural memories are acquired gradually through practice and are expressed through performance rather than conscious recollection. This system depends on the basal ganglia, cerebellum, and motor cortex rather than the hippocampus.
[003] Endel Tulving proposed that episodic memory stores personally experienced events with contextual details (time, place, associated emotions) and involves "mental time travel." Semantic memory stores general knowledge, facts, concepts, and vocabulary, independent of the personal context in which they were learned. Knowing that Paris is the capital of France (semantic) is distinct from remembering your trip to Paris (episodic). This distinction is critical for understanding amnesia: patients with hippocampal damage may lose the ability to form new episodic memories while retaining the ability to acquire some new semantic knowledge.

anchors.text: Priming is a form of implicit memory in which exposure to a stimulus influences the processing of a subsequent stimulus, without conscious awareness. After seeing the word "DOCTOR," a person is faster to recognize "NURSE" because the semantic network has been pre-activated. Priming can be perceptual (based on physical features) or conceptual (based on meaning).

The explicit/implicit distinction has profound clinical implications. Amnesic patients who cannot consciously remember learning a new skill (explicit deficit) may nonetheless show normal skill improvement across practice sessions (intact implicit memory). Patient H.M. could learn new motor skills (mirror drawing) despite having no explicit memory of ever having practiced the task. This dissociation demonstrates that explicit and implicit memory rely on different neural systems.
Episodic (explicit) — Conscious — Hippocampus, medial temporal lobe — Remembering your wedding day
Semantic (explicit) — Conscious — Temporal cortex (independent of hippocampus for well-established knowledge) — Knowing that water boils at 100°C
Procedural (implicit) — Unconscious — Basal ganglia, cerebellum, motor cortex — Riding a bicycle
Priming (implicit) — Unconscious — Neocortex (perceptual and association areas) — Faster word recognition after prior exposure
Classical conditioning (implicit) — Unconscious — Cerebellum (eyeblink); amygdala (fear) — Conditioned emotional response

anchors.text: The levels-of-processing framework proposes that the depth at which information is processed during encoding determines its durability in memory. Deeper processing leads to more elaborate, longer-lasting, and stronger memory traces.

Structural (shallow) processing: Encoding based on physical features of the stimulus, such as the appearance of printed words (e.g., "Is this word in uppercase letters?"). This produces the weakest memory traces.
Phonemic (intermediate) processing: Encoding based on how a stimulus sounds (e.g., "Does this word rhyme with 'train'?"). This produces moderate memory strength.

Semantic (deep) processing: Encoding based on the meaning of information (e.g., "Does this word fit in the sentence: 'The _____ crossed the road'?"). This produces the strongest and most durable memories.

anchors.text: Information related to the self is processed more deeply and remembered better than information about others. Asking "Does this word describe me?" leads to superior recall compared to semantic processing alone.
The process of linking new information to existing knowledge and forming rich associations. The more connections created, the more retrieval routes are available later.

Memory is most effective when the conditions at retrieval match the conditions present at encoding. This principle underlies both context-dependent memory (physical environment) and state-dependent memory (internal physiological or emotional state).

Example: EPPP Application: A student who studies in a quiet room will recall material better when tested in a similar quiet environment. Similarly, material learned while in a particular mood is best recalled in that same mood.

anchors.text: Also called the modal model or multi-store model, this framework proposes three sequential stages of memory processing:
Duration — 0.25-4 seconds — 15-30 seconds (without rehearsal) — Potentially unlimited
Capacity — Large (all sensory input) — 7 +/- 2 items (Miller, 1956) — Essentially unlimited
Encoding — Modality-specific — Primarily acoustic — Primarily semantic
Forgetting — Rapid decay — Decay and displacement — Retrieval failure, interference

The brief retention of sensory information. Iconic memory (visual) lasts approximately 0.5 seconds and was demonstrated by Sperling's partial-report procedure. Echoic memory (auditory) persists for 3-4 seconds.

A limited-capacity store that holds information for brief periods. George Miller established the capacity of STM at 7 plus or minus 2 items. Capacity can be expanded through chunking, the process of grouping individual items into larger meaningful units.

The relatively permanent and essentially limitless storage system. Transfer from STM to LTM is facilitated by rehearsal, elaboration, and meaningful processing. LTM is divided into two major subsystems:
Explicit (declarative) memory: Conscious recollection of facts and events Episodic memory: Personal experiences and events Semantic memory: General knowledge and facts about the world

Implicit (nondeclarative) memory: Memory without conscious awareness Procedural memory: Motor skills and habits (e.g., riding a bicycle) Priming: Facilitated processing of a stimulus due to prior exposure Classical conditioning: Learned associations between stimuli

anchors.text: Baddeley's working memory model replaced the unitary concept of STM with a multicomponent system that actively manipulates information rather than passively holding it:
Central executive: An attentional control system that directs focus, coordinates the subsystems, and manages cognitive resources. It has limited capacity and is modality-free.

Phonological loop: Maintains and rehearses verbal and acoustic information. Consists of a phonological store (the "inner ear") and an articulatory rehearsal process (the "inner voice"). Explains the word-length effect (shorter words are recalled better because they can be rehearsed faster).
Visuospatial sketchpad: Maintains and manipulates visual and spatial information (the "inner eye"). Used in navigation, mental imagery, and spatial reasoning.
Episodic buffer: Integrates information from the phonological loop, visuospatial sketchpad, and long-term memory into unified, coherent episodes. Serves as a limited-capacity temporary store.

Clinical Significance: Working memory deficits are observed in ADHD, schizophrenia, traumatic brain injury, and age-related cognitive decline. Neuroimaging consistently implicates the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in working memory tasks.

anchors.text: Recall: Retrieving information without explicit cues. More demanding than recognition. Free recall (produce items in any order), serial recall (produce items in order), and cued recall (use a hint) are subtypes.
Recognition: Identifying previously encountered information from a set of options. Generally easier than recall because the target item serves as its own retrieval cue.

Relearning (savings method): Ebbinghaus's measure showing that previously learned material is relearned faster, even when conscious recall fails. The difference in learning trials is the "savings score."

[002] Recognition: Identifying previously encountered information from a set of options. Generally easier than recall because the target item serves as its own retrieval cue.
[003] Relearning (savings method): Ebbinghaus's measure showing that previously learned material is relearned faster, even when conscious recall fails. The difference in learning trials is the "savings score."

anchors.text: Effective retrieval depends on the availability and quality of retrieval cues. Tulving's encoding specificity principle states that a cue is effective only if it was encoded with the target information at study.

Example: Example: Godden and Baddeley demonstrated context-dependent memory by having divers learn words either underwater or on land. Recall was significantly better when the retrieval environment matched the learning environment.

anchors.text: Interference theory holds that forgetting occurs because other information competes with or disrupts the target memory:
Proactive interference: Previously learned information interferes with the ability to learn or recall new information. ("Old" disrupts "new.")
Retroactive interference: Newly learned information interferes with the ability to recall previously learned information. ("New" disrupts "old.")

Example: EPPP Example: A student studies Domain 6 material, then studies Domain 7. If the Domain 7 material makes it harder to recall Domain 6 content, that is retroactive interference. If the previously studied Domain 6 content makes Domain 7 harder to learn, that is proactive interference.

[004] Example: EPPP Example: A student studies Domain 6 material, then studies Domain 7. If the Domain 7 material makes it harder to recall Domain 6 content, that is retroactive interference. If the previously studied Domain 6 content makes Domain 7 harder to learn, that is proactive interference.

anchors.text: The inability to form new memories after the onset of amnesia. Patients cannot transfer new information from short-term to long-term storage, yet procedural memory and priming are often preserved.

Case of H.M. (Henry Molaison): Following bilateral medial temporal lobe resection (including the hippocampus) for epilepsy treatment, H.M. developed profound anterograde amnesia. He could not form new declarative memories but retained procedural learning ability, demonstrating the dissociation between explicit and implicit memory systems.

[002] Case of H.M. (Henry Molaison): Following bilateral medial temporal lobe resection (including the hippocampus) for epilepsy treatment, H.M. developed profound anterograde amnesia. He could not form new declarative memories but retained procedural learning ability, demonstrating the dissociation between explicit and implicit memory systems.

anchors.text: Transient global amnesia: Temporary anterograde (and sometimes retrograde) amnesia lasting hours, often in older adults. Cause is unclear but may involve transient ischemia.

Korsakoff's syndrome: Amnesia resulting from thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, typically due to chronic alcoholism. Characterized by severe anterograde amnesia, confabulation, and damage to the mammillary bodies and dorsomedial thalamus.
Dissociative (psychogenic) amnesia: Memory loss for personal information following psychological trauma, without identifiable neurological damage.

Clinical Significance: Korsakoff's syndrome patients produce confabulations -- fabricated memories that fill gaps in recall -- without intent to deceive. This distinguishes the condition from malingering and factitious disorders.

[004] Clinical Significance: Korsakoff's syndrome patients produce confabulations -- fabricated memories that fill gaps in recall -- without intent to deceive. This distinguishes the condition from malingering and factitious disorders.

anchors.text: The lightest stage of sleep, serving as the transition between wakefulness and sleep
Lasts approximately 5-10 minutes
EEG shows theta waves (4-7 Hz), replacing the alpha waves of relaxed wakefulness
Hypnagogic hallucinations (vivid sensory experiences) and hypnic jerks (sudden muscle contractions) may occur
The person can be easily awakened and may not feel they were asleep

anchors.text: Comprises approximately 45-55% of total sleep time in adults

EEG shows theta waves with two distinctive features: sleep spindles (brief 12-14 Hz bursts generated by the thalamus) and K-complexes (large amplitude, sharp negative deflections followed by positive components)
Sleep spindles are believed to play a role in memory consolidation by facilitating the transfer of information from hippocampus to neocortex
Heart rate slows, body temperature decreases, and the threshold for awakening increases

anchors.text: The deepest stage of sleep, also called slow-wave sleep (SWS) or delta sleep
EEG dominated by delta waves (0.5-4 Hz, high amplitude)
Most difficult stage from which to awaken; confusion and disorientation (sleep inertia) occur if awakened
Critical for physical restoration, growth hormone release, and immune function
Predominates in the first third of the night; decreases with age
Parasomnias that occur during SWS include sleepwalking (somnambulism), sleep terrors, and bedwetting (enuresis)

anchors.text: Comprises approximately 20-25% of total sleep time in adults
EEG shows desynchronized, low-amplitude, mixed-frequency activity resembling wakefulness ("paradoxical sleep")
Rapid conjugate eye movements are the defining feature
Muscle atonia (skeletal muscle paralysis) occurs, mediated by glycinergic inhibition from the brainstem, preventing motor enactment of dreams
Vivid, narrative dreaming is most common during REM
Heart rate and respiration become irregular; thermoregulation is impaired
REM periods lengthen across the night; REM predominates in the last third of the night
REM latency (time from sleep onset to first REM period) is normally about 90 minutes; shortened REM latency is a biological marker of major depression

anchors.text: The suprachiasmatic nucleus, located in the anterior hypothalamus above the optic chiasm, is the brain's master biological clock. It receives direct light input from the retina via the retinohypothalamic tract and synchronizes (entrains) internal rhythms to the external light-dark cycle.
SCN neurons have endogenous rhythms of approximately 24.2 hours in humans
Light exposure in the morning advances the clock; light exposure at night delays it
SCN damage abolishes circadian rhythmicity of sleep-wake cycles, hormone release, and body temperature

anchors.text: Melatonin is a hormone produced by the pineal gland under the control of the SCN. It serves as the body's "darkness signal."
Synthesis and release increase with darkness and are suppressed by light (especially blue light)
Promotes sleepiness and lowers core body temperature
Follows a circadian pattern: levels rise in the evening, peak in the middle of the night (approximately 2-4 AM), and decline by morning
Melatonin production decreases with age, which may contribute to age-related sleep changes

anchors.text: Alexander Borbely proposed that sleep is regulated by the interaction of two independent processes:

Process S (homeostatic sleep drive): Builds progressively during wakefulness due to accumulation of adenosine and other sleep-promoting substances. The longer you are awake, the greater the drive to sleep. Dissipates during sleep.
Process C (circadian alerting signal): Driven by the SCN, this signal promotes wakefulness during the day and permits sleep at night, independent of how long you have been awake.

Example: EPPP Application: The two-process model explains why it is possible to feel a "second wind" late at night despite prolonged wakefulness -- the circadian alerting signal transiently overcomes the high homeostatic sleep drive. Caffeine promotes wakefulness by blocking adenosine receptors, counteracting Process S.

[003] Process C (circadian alerting signal): Driven by the SCN, this signal promotes wakefulness during the day and permits sleep at night, independent of how long you have been awake.

anchors.text: NREM slow-wave sleep (SWS) is particularly important for consolidating declarative (explicit) memories -- facts and events:
During SWS, slow oscillations coordinate hippocampal sharp-wave ripples and thalamocortical sleep spindles
This coordinated activity is believed to facilitate the transfer of information from hippocampal to neocortical storage (systems consolidation)
Studies show that enhancing SWS (through transcranial stimulation or acoustic stimulation timed to slow oscillations) improves declarative memory retention

anchors.text: REM sleep appears especially important for consolidating procedural memories (skills, habits) and emotional memories:
REM deprivation impairs performance on procedural learning tasks (e.g., motor sequence learning, visual discrimination)
The high acetylcholine and low norepinephrine levels during REM may facilitate synaptic consolidation and emotional memory processing
Walker and van der Helm proposed that REM sleep "depotentiates" the emotional tone of memories while preserving their informational content -- a form of "overnight therapy"

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Memory & Sleep > Memory Consolidation During Sleep > REM Sleep and Procedural/Emotional Memory
anchors_text:
[001] REM sleep appears especially important for consolidating procedural memories (skills, habits) and emotional memories:
[002] REM deprivation impairs performance on procedural learning tasks (e.g., motor sequence learning, visual discrimination)
[003] The high acetylcholine and low norepinephrine levels during REM may facilitate synaptic consolidation and emotional memory processing
[004] Walker and van der Helm proposed that REM sleep "depotentiates" the emotional tone of memories while preserving their informational content -- a form of "overnight therapy"

anchors.text: Stage N2 sleep spindles are increasingly recognized as markers and mediators of memory consolidation:
Spindle density and amplitude correlate with learning gains and IQ measures
Spindles increase following intensive learning sessions
Pharmacological enhancement of spindles (e.g., with zolpidem) has been shown to improve declarative memory

Clinical Significance: Sleep disruption impairs memory consolidation and is a contributor to cognitive deficits seen in insomnia, sleep apnea, depression, and PTSD. Addressing sleep disturbances is therefore a therapeutic priority. The finding that sleep processes emotional memories has implications for PTSD treatment, as sleep deprivation immediately after trauma has been explored as a potential prevention strategy.

anchors.text: A disorder of excessive daytime sleepiness caused by deficiency of hypocretin (orexin), a neuropeptide produced by the hypothalamus that promotes wakefulness.
Cataplexy: Sudden, brief loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions (pathognomonic for Type 1 narcolepsy)
Sleep paralysis: Temporary inability to move or speak during sleep-wake transitions
Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations: Vivid hallucinations at sleep onset or upon awakening
Sleep-onset REM periods (SOREMPs): REM sleep occurs within 15 minutes of sleep onset, rather than the normal 90-minute latency

[001] A disorder of excessive daytime sleepiness caused by deficiency of hypocretin (orexin), a neuropeptide produced by the hypothalamus that promotes wakefulness.
[002] Cataplexy: Sudden, brief loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions (pathognomonic for Type 1 narcolepsy)
[003] Sleep paralysis: Temporary inability to move or speak during sleep-wake transitions
[004] Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations: Vivid hallucinations at sleep onset or upon awakening
[005] Sleep-onset REM periods (SOREMPs): REM sleep occurs within 15 minutes of sleep onset, rather than the normal 90-minute latency

anchors.text: NREM parasomnias (disorders of arousal): Sleepwalking, sleep terrors, and confusional arousals. Occur during SWS (N3), more common in children, and the person is typically amnestic for the events.

REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD): Loss of normal REM atonia, resulting in the motor enactment of dreams. Occurs predominantly in older males and is a strong predictor of future neurodegenerative disease (Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia).
Nightmare disorder: Recurrent disturbing dreams occurring during REM sleep that cause awakening with full alertness and detailed dream recall.

[002] REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD): Loss of normal REM atonia, resulting in the motor enactment of dreams. Occurs predominantly in older males and is a strong predictor of future neurodegenerative disease (Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia).
[003] Nightmare disorder: Recurrent disturbing dreams occurring during REM sleep that cause awakening with full alertness and detailed dream recall.

anchors.text: Delayed sleep-wake phase disorder: Habitual sleep onset and wake times are delayed by 2+ hours relative to conventional times; common in adolescents
Advanced sleep-wake phase disorder: Habitual sleep onset and wake times are advanced (earlier) by several hours; more common in older adults
Shift work disorder: Insomnia and/or excessive sleepiness due to work schedules that overlap with the normal sleep period
Jet lag disorder: Temporary misalignment between the internal clock and the new time zone

anchors.text: Early stage: Episodic memory impairment (forgetting recent events, repeating questions), word-finding difficulty, misplacing items, mild executive dysfunction. Procedural memory and remote memories are relatively preserved. Patients may show anosognosia (lack of awareness of deficits).

Middle stage: More pronounced memory loss (may not recognize family members), visuospatial disorientation (getting lost), language deterioration (fluent but empty speech), apraxia (difficulty with learned motor sequences), behavioral symptoms (agitation, wandering, sundowning, delusions of theft, paranoia).
Late stage: Severe cognitive decline across all domains, loss of ability to speak, walk, and swallow. Incontinence, bedbound state. Average duration from diagnosis to death is 8-10 years.

The APOE-e4 allele is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset AD: one copy increases risk 3-4 fold; two copies increase risk 12-15 fold. However, APOE-e4 is a risk factor, not a deterministic gene -- not all carriers develop AD, and many AD patients lack the allele. Early-onset AD (before age 65, <5% of cases) has stronger genetic determinism, linked to mutations in APP (amyloid precursor protein, chromosome 21), presenilin 1 (chromosome 14), and presenilin 2 (chromosome 1). The association with chromosome 21 explains the markedly elevated AD risk in Down syndrome (trisomy 21). Other modifiable risk factors include cardiovascular disease, diabetes, low education, social isolation, head injury, and hearing loss.

Example: AD is the prototypical cortical dementia, characterized by amnesia (hippocampal involvement), aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia (the "4 A's"). Subcortical dementias (e.g., Parkinson's disease dementia, Huntington's disease) are characterized by psychomotor slowing, executive dysfunction, personality changes, and movement disorders, with relatively preserved language and recognition memory. Subcortical dementias show retrieval deficits (poor free recall but improved with cues), while cortical dementias show encoding/storage deficits (poor free recall AND cued recall). This distinction is heavily tested on the EPPP.

[002] Middle stage: More pronounced memory loss (may not recognize family members), visuospatial disorientation (getting lost), language deterioration (fluent but empty speech), apraxia (difficulty with learned motor sequences), behavioral symptoms (agitation, wandering, sundowning, delusions of theft, paranoia).
[003] Late stage: Severe cognitive decline across all domains, loss of ability to speak, walk, and swallow. Incontinence, bedbound state. Average duration from diagnosis to death is 8-10 years.
[004] The APOE-e4 allele is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset AD: one copy increases risk 3-4 fold; two copies increase risk 12-15 fold. However, APOE-e4 is a risk factor, not a deterministic gene -- not all carriers develop AD, and many AD patients lack the allele. Early-onset AD (before age 65, <5% of cases) has stronger genetic determinism, linked to mutations in APP (amyloid precursor protein, chromosome 21), presenilin 1 (chromosome 14), and presenilin 2 (chromosome 1). The association with chromosome 21 explains the markedly elevated AD risk in Down syndrome (trisomy 21). Other modifiable risk factors include cardiovascular disease, diabetes, low education, social isolation, head injury, and hearing loss.
[005] Example: AD is the prototypical cortical dementia, characterized by amnesia (hippocampal involvement), aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia (the "4 A's"). Subcortical dementias (e.g., Parkinson's disease dementia, Huntington's disease) are characterized by psychomotor slowing, executive dysfunction, personality changes, and movement disorders, with relatively preserved language and recognition memory. Subcortical dementias show retrieval deficits (poor free recall but improved with cues), while cortical dementias show encoding/storage deficits (poor free recall AND cued recall). This distinction is heavily tested on the EPPP.

anchors.text: Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is the third most common cause of dementia. Lewy bodies are intracellular inclusions composed of alpha-synuclein protein, found diffusely throughout the cortex and brainstem.

The four core clinical features are: (1) Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness (lucid intervals alternating with confused episodes), (2) Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well-formed and detailed (e.g., seeing people, children, or animals that are not there), (3) REM sleep behavior disorder (acting out dreams, which may precede cognitive symptoms by years), and (4) Spontaneous parkinsonism (rigidity, bradykinesia, but tremor is less prominent than in Parkinson's disease). A critically important clinical feature: patients with DLB have severe neuroleptic sensitivity -- conventional antipsychotics can cause life-threatening neuroleptic malignant syndrome or severe worsening. This is a high-yield EPPP fact.

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Neurocognitive Disorders > Lewy Body Disease & Frontotemporal NCD > NCD with Lewy Bodies
anchors_text:
[001] Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) is the third most common cause of dementia. Lewy bodies are intracellular inclusions composed of alpha-synuclein protein, found diffusely throughout the cortex and brainstem.
[002] The four core clinical features are: (1) Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness (lucid intervals alternating with confused episodes), (2) Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well-formed and detailed (e.g., seeing people, children, or animals that are not there), (3) REM sleep behavior disorder (acting out dreams, which may precede cognitive symptoms by years), and (4) Spontaneous parkinsonism (rigidity, bradykinesia, but tremor is less prominent than in Parkinson's disease). A critically important clinical feature: patients with DLB have severe neuroleptic sensitivity -- conventional antipsychotics can cause life-threatening neuroleptic malignant syndrome or severe worsening. This is a high-yield EPPP fact.

anchors.text: Frontotemporal NCD encompasses a group of disorders characterized by progressive degeneration of the frontal and/or temporal lobes. FTD typically has a younger onset than AD (often ages 45-65) and accounts for a significant proportion of early-onset dementias.

Behavioral variant FTD (bvFTD) — Frontal (orbitofrontal, medial frontal) — Early, prominent personality change: disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy, compulsive/ritualistic behaviors, dietary changes (hyperorality, sweet food preference), executive dysfunction. Memory and visuospatial function relatively preserved early on.

Semantic variant PPA — Anterior temporal (usually left) — Progressive loss of word meaning (semantic memory); fluent but empty speech; anomia; surface dyslexia (irregular word reading errors); may lose knowledge of objects and faces.

Nonfluent variant PPA — Left posterior frontal / insular — Effortful, halting speech; agrammatism; speech sound errors (apraxia of speech); relatively preserved word comprehension and object knowledge.

The EPPP frequently tests the distinction between FTD and AD. Key differentiators: FTD has earlier onset (often before 65), personality/behavioral changes precede memory loss, memory and visuospatial skills are relatively preserved early on, and social cognition is disproportionately impaired. AD has later onset, memory impairment is the earliest and most prominent symptom, and personality is relatively preserved until later stages. Approximately 40% of FTD cases have a genetic component, with mutations in MAPT (tau), GRN (progranulin), and C9orf72 genes.

anchors.text: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies attack acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, causing progressive muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. Characteristic features include ptosis (drooping eyelids), diplopia (double vision), difficulty swallowing, and limb weakness. Treatment includes cholinesterase inhibitors (pyridostigmine), immunosuppressants, and thymectomy.

The cerebellum coordinates voluntary movement, balance, and motor learning. Cerebellar damage produces a characteristic syndrome: ataxia (uncoordinated, staggering gait), dysmetria (inability to accurately reach for objects — overshooting or undershooting), intention tremor (worsens as the hand approaches the target — opposite of Parkinson's resting tremor), dysarthria (slurred speech), and nystagmus (involuntary eye movements). Cerebellar signs are ipsilateral to the lesion (unlike cerebral cortex, which is contralateral).

anchors.text: Originate in a localized area of one hemisphere:

Focal aware seizures (formerly "simple partial"): Consciousness is preserved. Symptoms depend on the brain region involved -- motor (jerking), sensory (tingling, visual disturbances), autonomic (nausea, sweating), or psychic (deja vu, fear, hallucinations). An aura is a focal aware seizure that precedes a larger seizure.

Focal impaired awareness seizures (formerly "complex partial"): Consciousness is altered. Most commonly originate in the temporal lobe. Typically feature automatisms (repetitive purposeless movements such as lip smacking, picking at clothes, or wandering). Patients are amnestic for the event.
Focal to bilateral tonic-clonic: Begins focally and then spreads to both hemispheres (secondarily generalized).
Involve both hemispheres from the onset:

Tonic-clonic (formerly "grand mal"): A tonic phase (muscle rigidity, loss of consciousness, possible cry) followed by a clonic phase (rhythmic jerking of all extremities). Postictal confusion and sleepiness follow.

Absence (formerly "petit mal"): Brief (5-30 second) episodes of staring and unresponsiveness, often with subtle motor signs (eye blinking, lip movements). EEG shows characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern. Most common in children and may be mistaken for daydreaming or ADHD.
Myoclonic: Brief, shock-like muscle jerks
Atonic ("drop attacks"): Sudden loss of muscle tone causing falls
Tonic: Sustained muscle stiffening

anchors.text: The most common form of focal epilepsy in adults. Frequently involves the hippocampus and amygdala (mesial temporal sclerosis). Associated with:
Memory impairment (especially if dominant hemisphere is affected)
Interictal personality changes (Geschwind syndrome: hypergraphia, hyperreligiosity, altered sexuality, viscosity)
Psychiatric comorbidities: depression (30-50%), anxiety, and psychosis-like symptoms

Clinical Significance: The Wada test (intracarotid amobarbital procedure) is used before epilepsy surgery to determine hemispheric language dominance and memory lateralization. One hemisphere is anesthetized at a time while language and memory are tested. This information guides surgical decisions to avoid causing language or memory deficits.

[003] Interictal personality changes (Geschwind syndrome: hypergraphia, hyperreligiosity, altered sexuality, viscosity)

[005] Clinical Significance: The Wada test (intracarotid amobarbital procedure) is used before epilepsy surgery to determine hemispheric language dominance and memory lateralization. One hemisphere is anesthetized at a time while language and memory are tested. This information guides surgical decisions to avoid causing language or memory deficits.

anchors.text: Tremor: Resting tremor (4-6 Hz), often described as "pill-rolling." Decreases during intentional movement (in contrast to cerebellar intention tremor).
Rigidity: Increased muscle tone throughout range of motion. "Cogwheel rigidity" (ratchet-like resistance) is characteristic.

Akinesia/Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement (bradykinesia) or difficulty initiating movement (akinesia). Includes reduced facial expressiveness (masked facies), small handwriting (micrographia), and shuffling gait.
Postural instability: Impaired balance and righting reflexes, leading to falls. Typically a later symptom.

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Neurological Disorders > Parkinson's Disease > Cardinal Motor Symptoms (TRAP)
anchors_text:
[001] Tremor: Resting tremor (4-6 Hz), often described as "pill-rolling." Decreases during intentional movement (in contrast to cerebellar intention tremor).
[002] Rigidity: Increased muscle tone throughout range of motion. "Cogwheel rigidity" (ratchet-like resistance) is characteristic.
[003] Akinesia/Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement (bradykinesia) or difficulty initiating movement (akinesia). Includes reduced facial expressiveness (masked facies), small handwriting (micrographia), and shuffling gait.
[004] Postural instability: Impaired balance and righting reflexes, leading to falls. Typically a later symptom.

anchors.text: Depression: Affects 40-50% of PD patients; may precede motor symptoms
Cognitive impairment: Executive dysfunction (frontal-subcortical deficits); approximately 75-80% develop dementia over the disease course
REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD): Often precedes motor diagnosis by years
Autonomic dysfunction: Constipation, orthostatic hypotension, urinary dysfunction
Anosmia: Loss of smell; an early premotor symptom
Psychosis: Visual hallucinations, particularly with advancing disease and dopaminergic medications

[003] REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD): Often precedes motor diagnosis by years
[004] Autonomic dysfunction: Constipation, orthostatic hypotension, urinary dysfunction
[005] Anosmia: Loss of smell; an early premotor symptom
[006] Psychosis: Visual hallucinations, particularly with advancing disease and dopaminergic medications

anchors.text: L-dopa (levodopa): The dopamine precursor that crosses the blood-brain barrier and is converted to dopamine in the brain. Combined with carbidopa (which prevents peripheral conversion). Most effective treatment but associated with motor fluctuations ("wearing off," "on-off" phenomenon) and dyskinesias with long-term use.
Dopamine agonists: Pramipexole, ropinirole (directly stimulate dopamine receptors). Side effects may include impulse control disorders (gambling, hypersexuality, compulsive shopping).
MAO-B inhibitors: Selegiline, rasagiline (prevent dopamine breakdown)
Deep brain stimulation (DBS): Electrodes implanted in the subthalamic nucleus or globus pallidus for medication-refractory symptoms

anchors.text: Mechanism — Blockage of a cerebral artery (thrombus or embolus) — Rupture of a cerebral blood vessel
Subtypes — Thrombotic (clot forms in situ), embolic (clot travels from elsewhere) — Intracerebral hemorrhage, subarachnoid hemorrhage
Acute treatment — tPA (thrombolytic) within 4.5 hours; thrombectomy — Blood pressure control; surgical evacuation if needed
Risk factors — Atrial fibrillation, atherosclerosis, hypertension — Hypertension, aneurysm, AVM, anticoagulant use

anchors.text: Middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke: Most common. Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss (face and arm greater than leg); aphasia if left hemisphere (Broca's, Wernicke's, or global); hemispatial neglect if right hemisphere.
Anterior cerebral artery (ACA) stroke: Contralateral leg weakness greater than arm; personality changes; abulia (loss of will/motivation); urinary incontinence.
Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) stroke: Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia (visual field loss); memory impairment if medial temporal structures are affected.

anchors.text: Loss of consciousness — < 30 minutes — 30 min - 24 hours — > 24 hours
Post-traumatic amnesia — < 24 hours — 1-7 days — > 7 days

anchors.text: Coup injury: Damage at the point of impact
Contrecoup injury: Damage at the opposite side of the brain from the impact, caused by the brain bouncing against the skull
Diffuse axonal injury (DAI): Widespread shearing of axons due to rotational forces; the most common cause of severe TBI disability
Epidural hematoma: Bleeding between skull and dura mater, typically from middle meningeal artery rupture. "Lucid interval" followed by rapid deterioration.
Subdural hematoma: Bleeding between dura and arachnoid, from bridging vein rupture. Can be acute or chronic (common in elderly, alcoholics).

full_path: Domain 7: Biopsychology > Neurological Disorders > Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) > Types of TBI Damage
anchors_text:
[001] Coup injury: Damage at the point of impact
[002] Contrecoup injury: Damage at the opposite side of the brain from the impact, caused by the brain bouncing against the skull
[003] Diffuse axonal injury (DAI): Widespread shearing of axons due to rotational forces; the most common cause of severe TBI disability
[004] Epidural hematoma: Bleeding between skull and dura mater, typically from middle meningeal artery rupture. "Lucid interval" followed by rapid deterioration.
[005] Subdural hematoma: Bleeding between dura and arachnoid, from bridging vein rupture. Can be acute or chronic (common in elderly, alcoholics).

anchors.text: The frontal and temporal lobes are most vulnerable to TBI due to their position against bony skull protrusions:
Executive dysfunction (planning, inhibition, cognitive flexibility)
Memory impairment (anterograde greater than retrograde)
Attention and processing speed deficits
Personality and behavioral changes (disinhibition, irritability, apathy)
Emotional dysregulation (increased risk of depression, anxiety, PTSD)

anchors.text: Depolarization: Voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels open, allowing rapid Na+ influx. The membrane potential rises toward +30 to +40 mV.
Repolarization: Na+ channels inactivate and voltage-gated potassium (K+) channels open, allowing K+ efflux. The membrane potential returns toward resting level.
Hyperpolarization: K+ channels remain open briefly, causing the membrane to overshoot below resting potential (~-80 mV) before returning to -70 mV.

The all-or-none law states that an action potential either fires at full amplitude or does not fire at all — there is no partial action potential. The intensity of a stimulus is coded not by the amplitude of individual action potentials but by the frequency of firing (rate coding) and the number of neurons activated.

anchors_text:
[001] Depolarization: Voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels open, allowing rapid Na+ influx. The membrane potential rises toward +30 to +40 mV.
[002] Repolarization: Na+ channels inactivate and voltage-gated potassium (K+) channels open, allowing K+ efflux. The membrane potential returns toward resting level.
[003] Hyperpolarization: K+ channels remain open briefly, causing the membrane to overshoot below resting potential (~-80 mV) before returning to -70 mV.
[004] The all-or-none law states that an action potential either fires at full amplitude or does not fire at all — there is no partial action potential. The intensity of a stimulus is coded not by the amplitude of individual action potentials but by the frequency of firing (rate coding) and the number of neurons activated.

anchors.text: The absolute refractory period occurs during depolarization and early repolarization, when no stimulus (regardless of intensity) can trigger another action potential. The relative refractory period follows, during which a stronger-than-normal stimulus can trigger an action potential. These periods limit the maximum firing rate and ensure unidirectional propagation of the signal along the axon.

Example: Saltatory conduction refers to the "jumping" of action potentials from one node of Ranvier to the next along myelinated axons. This dramatically increases conduction velocity (up to 120 m/s in large myelinated fibers) compared to continuous conduction in unmyelinated fibers (~1-2 m/s). Demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis disrupt saltatory conduction, slowing or blocking neural transmission.

anchors.text: Twin studies are the cornerstone method of behavioral genetics. They compare concordance rates (or correlations) between monozygotic (MZ, identical) twins, who share 100% of their DNA, and dizygotic (DZ, fraternal) twins, who share approximately 50% of their segregating genes.
If MZ concordance is substantially higher than DZ concordance, genetic factors are implicated
If MZ concordance is similar to DZ concordance, shared environmental factors are more important
If MZ concordance is less than 100%, environmental factors play a role (since MZ twins are genetically identical)
MZ twins reared apart provide the strongest evidence for genetic influence, as any similarity cannot be attributed to shared rearing environment

[003] If MZ concordance is similar to DZ concordance, shared environmental factors are more important

anchors.text: Two distinct processes describe how genes and environments work together:

Gene-environment interaction (GxE): The effect of a gene on a phenotype depends on the environment, and vice versa. The same genotype produces different outcomes in different environments. Classic example: Caspi et al. found that individuals with the short allele of the serotonin transporter gene (5-HTTLPR) were more likely to develop depression following stressful life events than those with the long allele — the genetic vulnerability was only expressed under environmental stress.

Gene-environment correlation (rGE): Genetic factors influence the probability of exposure to certain environments. Three types: Passive rGE: Children passively inherit both genes and environments from their parents (e.g., musically gifted parents both pass on music-related genes and provide a musical home environment) Evocative (reactive) rGE: A person's genetically influenced characteristics evoke particular responses from others (e.g., a genetically temperamental child elicits harsh parenting) Active rGE (niche-picking): Individuals actively select environments that match their genetic predispositions (e.g., an extraverted adolescent seeks out social activities). Active rGE becomes increasingly important with age as individuals gain more autonomy over their environment.

Active rGE becomes increasingly important with age as individuals gain more autonomy over their environment.

anchors.text: Epigenetics refers to changes in gene expression that occur without alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Environmental factors — including stress, nutrition, toxin exposure, early caregiving, and trauma — can add or remove chemical tags (e.g., DNA methylation, histone modification) that turn genes "on" or "off." Critically, some epigenetic changes can be transmitted across generations (transgenerational epigenetic inheritance). Research by Meaney and colleagues demonstrated that rat pups who received more maternal licking and grooming showed epigenetic changes in glucocorticoid receptor genes, resulting in reduced stress reactivity throughout life — providing a biological mechanism by which early experience programs later stress vulnerability.

The following approximate heritability estimates are commonly cited on the EPPP and in board-preparation materials. Remember that these are population-level estimates that vary by study and population:
IQ (general intelligence): h² ~ .50-.80 (heritability increases across development — higher in adults than children, as active rGE becomes stronger)
Schizophrenia: h² ~ .80 (MZ concordance ~48%; DZ concordance ~17%; general population risk ~1%)
Bipolar disorder: h² ~ .85 (among the most heritable psychiatric disorders)
Major depressive disorder: h² ~ .37 (moderate heritability; substantial environmental contribution)
Personality traits (Big Five): h² ~ .40-.60 (remarkably consistent across cultures and measurement methods)
Autism spectrum disorder: h² ~ .80-.90 (very high heritability; MZ concordance far exceeds DZ concordance)
Alcohol use disorder: h² ~ .50-.60 (moderate-to-high genetic contribution)

Example: An exam question might state: "The heritability of intelligence is .70. This means that: (A) 70% of an individual's intelligence is determined by genes, (B) 70% of the variance in intelligence in the population studied is attributable to genetic differences, (C) genes contribute 70% and environment contributes 30% to intelligence, (D) if environment improves, intelligence cannot increase." The correct answer is (B). Choice (A) is the most common error — heritability describes population variance, not individual determination. Choice (D) is incorrect because even highly heritable traits can respond to environmental intervention (e.g., IQ gains from adoption into enriched environments).

section_title: Neural Substrates of Different Memory Systems

anchors.text: Reconsolidation theory proposes that when a consolidated memory is reactivated (retrieved), it temporarily returns to a labile state and must be reconsolidated to persist. During this reconsolidation window, the memory is vulnerable to modification, disruption, or updating. This has clinical implications for treating PTSD — reactivating a traumatic memory during a therapeutic window (e.g., with propranolol administration or extinction training) may allow the emotional component to be weakened during reconsolidation.

Reconsolidation theory has informed trauma therapies that aim to reactivate traumatic memories in safe therapeutic conditions, then introduce new, corrective information during the reconsolidation window. This may update the original memory trace rather than simply creating a competing inhibitory memory (as in standard extinction). The approach is still being researched but represents a promising integration of neuroscience and psychotherapy.

section_title: The Ebbinghaus Forgetting Curve & Interference Theory

anchors.text: Interference theory proposes that forgetting occurs because memories compete with one another during retrieval. Two forms of interference are critical for the EPPP:

Proactive Interference — Previously learned information interferes with the learning or recall of new information — Your old phone number interferes with remembering your new one — "Pro" = forward; old disrupts new

Retroactive Interference — Newly learned information interferes with the recall of previously learned information — Learning your new phone number makes it harder to remember your old one — "Retro" = backward; new disrupts old

Proactive interference increases with age and is a significant contributor to age-related memory complaints. Older adults are particularly susceptible to proactive interference because they have accumulated more competing memories and may have reduced inhibitory control. In neuropsychological testing, proactive interference is assessed through paradigms such as the release-from-PI procedure and is a sensitive indicator of frontal lobe dysfunction.

anchors.text: Signal detection theory provides a framework for understanding how decisions are made under conditions of uncertainty, going beyond simple threshold concepts by acknowledging that detection depends on both the sensitivity of the observer and their response criterion (decision bias).
Respond "Yes" — Hit (correct detection) — False Alarm (Type I error)
Respond "No" — Miss (Type II error) — Correct Rejection

The observer's sensitivity (d-prime) reflects their ability to discriminate signal from noise, independent of response bias. The response criterion (beta) reflects the observer's willingness to say "yes" — a liberal criterion produces more hits but also more false alarms, while a conservative criterion produces fewer false alarms but also more misses. Response criterion shifts depending on the payoff matrix (e.g., a radiologist screening for cancer should adopt a liberal criterion because missing a tumor [miss] is more costly than a false alarm).

Example: Signal detection theory applies directly to clinical decision-making. A psychologist conducting a risk assessment must balance the cost of false positives (incorrectly identifying someone as dangerous, leading to unnecessary restriction) against the cost of false negatives (failing to identify a truly dangerous individual). The base rate of the behavior, the severity of consequences, and the clinician's threshold for action all influence the decision criterion.

anchors.text: Rods (~120 million): Sensitive to low light levels (scotopic vision); located primarily in the periphery; provide black-and-white vision; no color sensitivity; high convergence onto ganglion cells (many rods feed one ganglion cell), producing high sensitivity but low acuity

Cones (~6 million): Function in bright light (photopic vision); concentrated in the fovea (center of the retina); provide color vision and high visual acuity; low convergence (one-to-one mapping in fovea), producing low sensitivity but high acuity

anchors_text:
[001] Rods (~120 million): Sensitive to low light levels (scotopic vision); located primarily in the periphery; provide black-and-white vision; no color sensitivity; high convergence onto ganglion cells (many rods feed one ganglion cell), producing high sensitivity but low acuity
[002] Cones (~6 million): Function in bright light (photopic vision); concentrated in the fovea (center of the retina); provide color vision and high visual acuity; low convergence (one-to-one mapping in fovea), producing low sensitivity but high acuity

anchors.text: The retina contains three types of cones, each maximally sensitive to a different wavelength: short (blue), medium (green), and long (red). All perceived colors result from the combined activation of these three cone types. This theory explains color mixing and certain forms of color blindness (e.g., dichromacy from the absence of one cone type).

Color perception is organized into three opponent channels: red-green, blue-yellow, and black-white. Each channel involves antagonistic neural processing — stimulation of one color inhibits its opponent. This theory explains afterimages (staring at red produces a green afterimage), simultaneous contrast effects, and why certain color combinations (e.g., "reddish-green") are impossible to perceive. Modern understanding holds that trichromatic processing occurs at the retinal level, while opponent processing occurs at the level of retinal ganglion cells and the lateral geniculate nucleus.

anchors.text: Melzack and Wall's gate-control theory proposes that pain signals can be modulated at the spinal cord level by a "gate" in the substantia gelatinosa. Large-diameter (A-beta) fibers carrying touch information can close the gate (inhibiting pain transmission), while small-diameter (C and A-delta) fibers open the gate (facilitating pain). Descending signals from the brain can also close the gate, explaining why attention, expectation, and emotional state influence pain perception. This theory accounts for why rubbing an injury reduces pain and why psychological interventions can modulate pain experience.

Bottom-up processing (data-driven) begins with sensory input and builds up to perception without influence from prior knowledge. Top-down processing (concept-driven) uses prior knowledge, expectations, and context to interpret sensory input. Most perception involves an interaction of both. Top-down processing explains why context allows you to read words with missing letters, why ambiguous stimuli are perceived differently depending on expectations, and why cultural background influences perception.

anchors.text: Two striking phenomena demonstrate the limitations of attention and conscious awareness:

Inattentional blindness: The failure to perceive a clearly visible stimulus when attention is directed elsewhere. In the famous "invisible gorilla" experiment, approximately 50% of observers failed to notice a person in a gorilla suit walking through a basketball game when they were counting passes. This demonstrates that attention, not just visual acuity, is necessary for conscious perception.

Change blindness: The failure to detect large changes in a visual scene when the change coincides with a brief visual disruption (e.g., a flicker, a saccade, or a cut in a film). Change blindness reveals that we do not maintain a detailed, moment-to-moment representation of the entire visual scene — our sense of a complete visual world is, in part, an illusion constructed by the brain.

Attentional deficits are a core feature of many psychological disorders tested on the EPPP. ADHD involves impairments in sustained attention and executive control of attention. Hemispatial neglect following right parietal stroke represents a dramatic failure of spatial attention (Posner's disengage operation). Anxiety disorders involve attentional bias toward threat-related stimuli, which can be measured with the dot-probe task. Understanding the theoretical models of attention provides the conceptual framework for understanding these clinical presentations.

Example: A question might describe a dichotic listening task where a participant shadows (repeats) a message in one ear but still notices their own name in the unattended ear. The best explanation is Treisman's attenuation model (not Broadbent's filter model, which predicts the name would be completely blocked). If the question describes a participant who fails to notice a large, clearly visible stimulus because they were focused on a demanding task, the answer involves inattentional blindness. If the question asks why a simple visual search is fast but a conjunction search is slow, the answer is Feature Integration Theory.

anchors.text: Sleepwalking (somnambulism) and night terrors (sleep terrors) occur during NREM Stage 3 (slow-wave sleep), typically in the first third of the night. During night terrors, the individual may sit up screaming with autonomic arousal (tachycardia, sweating) but has no memory of the event. These parasomnias are most common in children and usually resolve with maturation. They should be distinguished from nightmares, which occur during REM sleep.

REM sleep behavior disorder involves loss of the normal muscle atonia during REM sleep, allowing individuals to physically act out their dreams. RBD is a strong prodromal marker for synucleinopathies — a significant percentage of patients with RBD eventually develop Parkinson's disease or Lewy body dementia. This association is high-yield for the EPPP.

anchors.text: A classic mnemonic for the hypothalamus's primary regulatory functions:
Fighting (aggression): The ventromedial hypothalamus is involved in aggressive behavior
Fleeing (fear responses): Coordinates autonomic fear responses through connections with the amygdala and brainstem

Feeding: The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is the "hunger center" -- stimulation induces eating, and lesions cause aphagia (refusal to eat). The ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH) is the "satiety center" -- stimulation inhibits eating, and lesions cause hyperphagia (overeating) and obesity.
Mating (sexual behavior): Regulates sexual behavior and reproductive functions; the sexually dimorphic nucleus differs in size between males and females

[002] Fighting (aggression): The ventromedial hypothalamus is involved in aggressive behavior
[003] Fleeing (fear responses): Coordinates autonomic fear responses through connections with the amygdala and brainstem

[005] Mating (sexual behavior): Regulates sexual behavior and reproductive functions; the sexually dimorphic nucleus differs in size between males and females

anchors.text: Thermoregulation: Maintains body temperature through sweating, shivering, and vasoconstriction/vasodilation
Circadian rhythms: The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) serves as the master biological clock, entrained by light input from the retina
Endocrine control: Regulates the pituitary gland ("master gland") through releasing and inhibiting hormones. Controls the HPA axis (hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis) for stress responses.
Thirst and water balance: Osmoreceptors detect blood osmolarity changes and trigger thirst and ADH release

Example: EPPP Application: Lesion studies are frequently tested. Remember: lateral hypothalamus lesions produce "lateral leanness" (aphagia/weight loss), while ventromedial hypothalamus lesions produce "ventromedial voluminosity" (hyperphagia/obesity). These mnemonics appear on many EPPP study resources.

[003] Endocrine control: Regulates the pituitary gland ("master gland") through releasing and inhibiting hormones. Controls the HPA axis (hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis) for stress responses.
[004] Thirst and water balance: Osmoreceptors detect blood osmolarity changes and trigger thirst and ADH release
[005] Example: EPPP Application: Lesion studies are frequently tested. Remember: lateral hypothalamus lesions produce "lateral leanness" (aphagia/weight loss), while ventromedial hypothalamus lesions produce "ventromedial voluminosity" (hyperphagia/obesity). These mnemonics appear on many EPPP study resources.

anchors.text: A seahorse-shaped structure in the medial temporal lobe that is essential for the consolidation of new declarative (explicit) memories -- the transfer of information from short-term to long-term storage.
Bilateral hippocampal damage produces severe anterograde amnesia for declarative information (the case of H.M.)
Contains place cells that fire when an animal occupies a specific location, forming cognitive maps for spatial navigation
One of only two brain regions where adult neurogenesis has been confirmed (the other is the olfactory bulb/subventricular zone)
Particularly vulnerable to damage from chronic stress (cortisol is neurotoxic to hippocampal neurons), hypoxia, and Alzheimer's disease

anchors.text: An almond-shaped structure anterior to the hippocampus, the amygdala is the brain's "fear center" and is critical for emotional processing, particularly fear conditioning and threat detection.
Receives rapid, coarse sensory input via a direct pathway from the thalamus (LeDoux's "low road"), enabling fast fear responses before cortical processing is complete
Also receives slower, detailed input from the cortex ("high road") for more nuanced evaluation
Modulates memory consolidation: emotionally arousing events are remembered better because amygdala activation enhances hippocampal encoding
Bilateral damage (Kluver-Bucy syndrome) produces "psychic blindness" -- inability to recognize emotional significance of stimuli, hypersexuality, hyperorality, and flattened affect

anchors.text: The cingulate gyrus wraps around the corpus callosum and is divided into functionally distinct regions:

Anterior cingulate cortex (ACC): Involved in error detection, conflict monitoring, pain perception, and emotional regulation. Active when there is a mismatch between expected and actual outcomes. Plays a role in the emotional experience of pain.

Posterior cingulate cortex (PCC): Part of the default mode network; involved in self-referential processing, autobiographical memory retrieval, and internal mentation. One of the first regions affected in Alzheimer's disease.

anchors.text: Mammillary bodies: Part of the Papez circuit; relay information from the hippocampus to the thalamus. Degeneration occurs in Korsakoff's syndrome (thiamine deficiency) and contributes to anterograde amnesia and confabulation.
Fornix: Major white matter tract connecting the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies and septal nuclei
Septal nuclei: Involved in pleasure, reward, and the inhibition of aggression

anchors.text: Caudate nucleus: Involved in cognitive control of movement, goal-directed behavior, and procedural memory
Putamen: Primary motor component; involved in the initiation and execution of movement. Together with the caudate, forms the striatum (so named for its striped appearance).
Globus pallidus: Output nucleus of the basal ganglia; sends inhibitory signals to the thalamus to regulate motor activity
Subthalamic nucleus: Regulates the globus pallidus; lesions or deep brain stimulation here can reduce Parkinsonian symptoms

Substantia nigra: Located in the midbrain; its pars compacta produces dopamine that is sent to the striatum via the nigrostriatal pathway. Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons here is the primary pathology of Parkinson's disease.

topic_name: Clinical Significance of Basal Ganglia Dysfunction

anchors.text: Parkinson's disease — Loss of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra — Bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, postural instability (hypokinetic)
Huntington's disease — Degeneration of caudate nucleus and putamen (GABAergic neurons) — Chorea (involuntary writhing movements), cognitive decline, psychiatric symptoms (hyperkinetic)
Hemiballismus — Lesion of subthalamic nucleus — Violent flinging movements of contralateral limbs

Clinical Significance: The direct pathway through the basal ganglia facilitates movement (excitatory net effect), while the indirect pathway inhibits movement (inhibitory net effect). Parkinson's disease (too little dopamine) results in difficulty initiating movement. Huntington's disease (loss of inhibitory neurons) results in excessive, uncontrolled movement.

anchors.text: Psychologists must base their assessment opinions on information and techniques sufficient to substantiate their findings. This standard applies across forensic, clinical, educational, and organizational settings. When a personal examination is not possible (e.g., in record review or forensic consultation), the psychologist must clearly state the limitations of the resulting opinion.
Adequate examination means using procedures appropriate to the referral question, the individual being assessed, and the context of the evaluation
If a psychologist cannot conduct a direct examination, they must identify the sources of information used and qualify their conclusions accordingly
Opinions must not extend beyond what the data support

anchors.text: Psychologists must administer, adapt, score, interpret, and use assessment instruments in a manner consistent with the research on and evidence for the instrument's usefulness and proper application. Key provisions include:
Instruments must be used for purposes for which validity evidence exists
When validity or reliability has not been established for a specific population, the psychologist must describe the strengths and limitations of results and interpretation
Assessments must be administered in the standardized manner prescribed in the test manual

anchors.text: Psychologists must obtain informed consent for assessments, except when: (a) testing is mandated by law or regulation, (b) informed consent is implied because testing is a routine educational or organizational activity, or (c) the purpose of testing is to evaluate decisional capacity. Informed consent for assessment should include:
The nature and purpose of the assessment
Fees and billing arrangements
Involvement of third parties (e.g., referring attorneys, insurance companies)
Limits of confidentiality, including who will receive results
The examinee's right to receive an explanation of results (in language reasonably understandable to the person)
