anchors.text: Standard 9.04 distinguishes between test data and test materials. Test data includes raw and scaled scores, client responses, and psychologist notes about client statements and behavior during an examination. Test materials include manuals, instruments, protocols, and test questions.
Psychologists must release test data to the client or other persons identified in a client release, unless substantial harm or misrepresentation is anticipated
In the absence of a client release, psychologists provide test data only when required by law or court order
Test materials are protected by copyright and are generally not released to non-qualified individuals

anchors.text: When interpreting assessment results, psychologists must take into account the purpose of the assessment, various test factors, situational factors, and the test-taking abilities of the person being assessed. Factors that affect interpretation include:
The individual's linguistic and cultural background
Any situational factors (e.g., testing conditions, fatigue, medication)
Disabilities or impairments that may require accommodations
The appropriateness of the norms for the individual being assessed

Method bias arises from differential familiarity with the testing format or medium
Item bias (differential item functioning, or DIF) occurs when members of different groups with the same ability level have different probabilities of endorsing an item

anchors.text: When assessment involves individuals with limited English proficiency, psychologists should ideally use tests validated in the individual's native language. When interpreters are used, the psychologist must:
Ensure the interpreter is trained in psychological assessment contexts
Note the impact of using an interpreter on the standardization of the test
Document any limitations to the conclusions that result from the use of an interpreter

anchors.text: The Specialty Guidelines for Forensic Psychology provide additional ethical guidance for assessment in legal contexts:
The psychologist's primary obligation is to the retaining party (court, attorney), not the examinee
Informed consent is replaced by notification of purpose when the evaluation is court-ordered
Results and reports go to the referring party; the examinee typically does not have unilateral access to the report
Psychologists must clearly identify their role (e.g., evaluator vs. treating clinician) and avoid dual relationships

anchors.text: When assessing minors, informed consent is obtained from the parent or legal guardian, while assent is obtained from the child. Assent means the child agrees to participate in the evaluation with an age-appropriate understanding of what will occur. Special considerations include:
Results may be shared with schools, courts, and other agencies depending on the purpose of the evaluation
The child's developmental level affects which instruments and norms are appropriate
Cultural and linguistic factors may be more pronounced in pediatric populations

anchors.text: The growth of telepsychology has introduced new ethical considerations for assessment practice. The APA Guidelines for the Practice of Telepsychology require psychologists to consider whether remote administration alters standardized procedures, whether test security can be maintained in a remote environment, and whether the test's normative data are applicable to a remotely administered version.
Some tests have validated telehealth administration protocols; others do not
Test publishers have varied in their positions on remote administration
Psychologists must document any modifications to standardized procedures and note potential impacts on validity

anchors.text: Charles Spearman used factor analysis to propose that a single general intelligence factor (g) underlies performance across all cognitive tasks. Spearman's two-factor theory holds that every test measures g plus a task-specific factor (s). Contemporary research consistently shows that g accounts for approximately 40-50% of variance in cognitive test batteries, making it the single most powerful predictor of academic and occupational performance.

A latent construct reflecting general mental ability that influences performance across all cognitive domains. It is extracted as the first unrotated factor in principal components analysis of cognitive test batteries and is highly heritable (h2 approximately 0.50-0.80 in adulthood).

anchors.text: The Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Fourth Edition yields a Full Scale IQ (FSIQ) along with four index scores:
Verbal Comprehension Index (VCI): Similarities, Vocabulary, Information — measures crystallized ability and verbal concept formation
Perceptual Reasoning Index (PRI): Block Design, Matrix Reasoning, Visual Puzzles — assesses fluid reasoning and visual-spatial processing
Working Memory Index (WMI): Digit Span, Arithmetic — taps short-term auditory memory and mental manipulation
Processing Speed Index (PSI): Symbol Search, Coding — measures speed of visual scanning and graphomotor output

All Wechsler IQ and index scores use a metric of M = 100, SD = 15. Subtest scaled scores have M = 10, SD = 3. The Wechsler classification system labels IQ ranges: 130+ = Very Superior, 120-129 = Superior, 110-119 = High Average, 90-109 = Average, 80-89 = Low Average, 70-79 = Borderline, 69 and below = Extremely Low (formerly Intellectual Disability range).

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Intelligence & Cognitive Assessment > Wechsler Intelligence Scales > WAIS-IV (Ages 16-90)
anchors_text:
[001] The Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Fourth Edition yields a Full Scale IQ (FSIQ) along with four index scores:
[002] Verbal Comprehension Index (VCI): Similarities, Vocabulary, Information — measures crystallized ability and verbal concept formation
[003] Perceptual Reasoning Index (PRI): Block Design, Matrix Reasoning, Visual Puzzles — assesses fluid reasoning and visual-spatial processing
[004] Working Memory Index (WMI): Digit Span, Arithmetic — taps short-term auditory memory and mental manipulation
[005] Processing Speed Index (PSI): Symbol Search, Coding — measures speed of visual scanning and graphomotor output
[006] All Wechsler IQ and index scores use a metric of M = 100, SD = 15. Subtest scaled scores have M = 10, SD = 3. The Wechsler classification system labels IQ ranges: 130+ = Very Superior, 120-129 = Superior, 110-119 = High Average, 90-109 = Average, 80-89 = Low Average, 70-79 = Borderline, 69 and below = Extremely Low (formerly Intellectual Disability range).

anchors.text: The Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children, Fifth Edition introduced a five-factor structure by splitting PRI into Visual Spatial Index (VSI) and Fluid Reasoning Index (FRI). The five primary index scores are VCI, VSI, FRI, WMI, and PSI. The WISC-V also provides ancillary index scores such as the Quantitative Reasoning Index, General Ability Index (GAI), and Cognitive Proficiency Index (CPI).

The General Ability Index (GAI) is computed from VCI and PRI/FRI subtests only, excluding Working Memory and Processing Speed. This makes the GAI a useful supplementary score when an examinee has significant processing speed or working memory deficits (e.g., ADHD, traumatic brain injury) that may depress the FSIQ below the level of overall reasoning ability. The Cognitive Proficiency Index (CPI) combines WMI and PSI, capturing the efficiency and automaticity of cognitive processing.

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Intelligence & Cognitive Assessment > Wechsler Intelligence Scales > WISC-V (Ages 6-16)
anchors_text:
[001] The Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children, Fifth Edition introduced a five-factor structure by splitting PRI into Visual Spatial Index (VSI) and Fluid Reasoning Index (FRI). The five primary index scores are VCI, VSI, FRI, WMI, and PSI. The WISC-V also provides ancillary index scores such as the Quantitative Reasoning Index, General Ability Index (GAI), and Cognitive Proficiency Index (CPI).
[002] The General Ability Index (GAI) is computed from VCI and PRI/FRI subtests only, excluding Working Memory and Processing Speed. This makes the GAI a useful supplementary score when an examinee has significant processing speed or working memory deficits (e.g., ADHD, traumatic brain injury) that may depress the FSIQ below the level of overall reasoning ability. The Cognitive Proficiency Index (CPI) combines WMI and PSI, capturing the efficiency and automaticity of cognitive processing.

anchors.text: The Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence, Fourth Edition includes age-appropriate subtests for younger children. For ages 2:6 to 3:11, only three index scores are available (VCI, VSI, WMI). For ages 4:0 to 7:7, the full five-index structure is available. Notable subtests include Bug Search, Picture Memory, and Zoo Locations.

Example: A 35-year-old patient obtains a WAIS-IV VCI of 112, PRI of 98, WMI of 82, and PSI of 79. The 33-point VCI-PSI discrepancy suggests a meaningful cognitive profile with relative weaknesses in processing speed and working memory. This pattern warrants further neuropsychological investigation for possible attentional or processing difficulties.
WAIS-IV — 16-90 years — VCI, PRI, WMI, PSI — M=100, SD=15
WISC-V — 6-16 years — VCI, VSI, FRI, WMI, PSI — M=100, SD=15
WPPSI-IV — 2:6-7:7 years — VCI, VSI, FRI, WMI, PSI — M=100, SD=15

anchors.text: Robert Sternberg proposed that intelligence comprises three aspects: analytical intelligence (academic problem-solving, the type measured by traditional IQ tests), creative intelligence (the ability to deal with novel situations and generate new ideas), and practical intelligence (adaptation to, shaping of, and selection of real-world environments — "street smarts"). Sternberg argued that traditional IQ tests overemphasize analytical intelligence while neglecting creative and practical abilities. His Sternberg Triarchic Abilities Test (STAT) was designed to measure all three components, though it has not achieved widespread clinical adoption.

When comparing IQ scores across Wechsler and SB5 instruments, clinicians must account for the different standard deviations. A Wechsler FSIQ of 85 (1 SD below mean) corresponds roughly to an SB5 FSIQ of 84 (1 SD below mean on that scale). At the tails of the distribution, this discrepancy becomes more meaningful for diagnostic classification.

Sternberg argued that traditional IQ tests overemphasize analytical intelligence while neglecting creative and practical abilities. anchors.text: The Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children, Second Edition offers a unique dual-theoretical framework. Examiners can interpret results using either the Luria neuropsychological model (which yields a Mental Processing Index excluding acquired knowledge) or the CHC model (which yields a Fluid-Crystallized Index including crystallized ability). The Luria model is recommended for linguistically or culturally diverse examinees, as it excludes verbal knowledge from the global score.

The examiner selects the interpretive model before administration based on the referral question and examinee characteristics. The Luria model is preferred when: (1) the examinee is bilingual or English is a second language, (2) cultural background differs significantly from the standardization sample, or (3) the referral question focuses on processing abilities rather than acquired knowledge. The CHC model is preferred when: (1) a comprehensive picture including crystallized ability is needed, (2) the examinee's cultural and linguistic background is well-represented in the norms, or (3) comparison with other CHC-based instruments is desired.

The KABC-II Luria scales include Sequential Processing (Gsm), Simultaneous Processing (Gv), Learning Ability (Glr), and Planning Ability (Gf). Under the CHC interpretation, Knowledge/Gc is added as a fifth scale.

Examiners can interpret results using either the Luria neuropsychological model (which yields a Mental Processing Index excluding acquired knowledge) or the CHC model (which yields a Fluid-Crystallized Index including crystallized ability). The Luria model is recommended for linguistically or culturally diverse examinees, as it excludes verbal knowledge from the global score.
[002] The examiner selects the interpretive model before administration based on the referral question and examinee characteristics. The Luria model is preferred when: (1) the examinee is bilingual or English is a second language, (2) cultural background differs significantly from the standardization sample, or (3) the referral question focuses on processing abilities rather than acquired knowledge. The CHC model is preferred when: (1) a comprehensive picture including crystallized ability is needed, (2) the examinee's cultural and linguistic background is well-represented in the norms, or (3) comparison with other CHC-based instruments is desired.
[003] The KABC-II Luria scales include Sequential Processing (Gsm), Simultaneous Processing (Gv), Learning Ability (Glr), and Planning Ability (Gf). Under the CHC interpretation, Knowledge/Gc is added as a fifth scale.

anchors.text: The WJ-IV Tests of Cognitive Abilities is a comprehensive CHC-based cognitive battery that assesses 7 broad CHC abilities across 18 tests. It provides a General Intellectual Ability (GIA) score as well as cluster scores for Comprehension-Knowledge (Gc), Fluid Reasoning (Gf), Short-Term Working Memory (Gwm), Processing Speed (Gs), Auditory Processing (Ga), Long-Term Retrieval (Glr), and Visual Processing (Gv). The WJ-IV is unique in its comprehensive coverage of CHC factors and its co-norming with the WJ-IV Tests of Achievement, allowing direct comparisons between cognitive abilities and academic achievement.

Example: The co-norming of the WJ-IV cognitive and achievement batteries allows for direct statistical comparison between predicted and actual achievement scores. A significant discrepancy between a child's cognitive ability (e.g., GIA = 105) and reading achievement (e.g., Basic Reading Skills = 78) may contribute to the identification of a specific learning disability, though modern practice emphasizes patterns of strengths and weaknesses (PSW) analysis rather than simple discrepancy models. The PSW approach examines whether specific cognitive weaknesses are consistent with and can account for the specific academic deficits observed.

anchors.text: While not an intelligence test per se, the Vineland-3 is essential in the assessment of intellectual disability. It measures adaptive behavior across four domains: Communication, Daily Living Skills, Socialization, and Motor Skills, yielding an Adaptive Behavior Composite. A diagnosis of intellectual disability requires both significantly subaverage intellectual functioning (IQ approximately 70 or below) and concurrent deficits in adaptive behavior.

The DSM-5 classifies severity of intellectual disability based on adaptive functioning rather than IQ alone: Mild (approximately IQ 55-70), Moderate (approximately IQ 40-55), Severe (approximately IQ 25-40), and Profound (IQ below approximately 25). However, the DSM-5 emphasizes that severity should be determined by the level of support needed across conceptual, social, and practical domains.

anchors.text: Several tests minimize language and cultural demands to provide fairer assessment of diverse populations:
Raven's Progressive Matrices — 5-80+ — Pattern completion; best single measure of g; minimal verbal demands
Leiter International Performance Scale, 3rd Ed. (Leiter-3) — 3-75+ — Completely nonverbal administration and response; no spoken language required
Universal Nonverbal Intelligence Test, 2nd Ed. (UNIT-2) — 5-21 — Uses gestures for instruction; six subtests measuring memory and reasoning
Test of Nonverbal Intelligence, 4th Ed. (TONI-4) — 6-89 — Abstract/figural problem-solving; pointing response only; brief screening measure

No test is truly "culture-free" — even nonverbal tests involve culturally influenced processes such as test-taking familiarity, motivation, and comfort with abstract reasoning tasks. The preferred term is culture-reduced, acknowledging that while verbal and cultural knowledge demands have been minimized, cultural factors can never be entirely eliminated from any assessment context.

section_title: Achievement Testing and Learning Disability Assessment

anchors.text: The identification of specific learning disabilities (SLD) has been guided by several assessment models, each with distinct theoretical and methodological foundations:

The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) defines a specific learning disability as "a disorder in one or more of the basic psychological processes involved in understanding or in using language, spoken or written, which disorder may manifest itself in the imperfect ability to listen, think, speak, read, write, spell, or do mathematical calculations." IDEA specifies that the disability is not primarily the result of visual, hearing, or motor disabilities; intellectual disability; emotional disturbance; cultural disadvantage; environmental deprivation; or limited English proficiency. Achievement must be below the expected level given the individual's age, state-approved grade-level standards, or intellectual development.

IDEA specifies that the disability is not primarily the result of visual, hearing, or motor disabilities; intellectual disability; emotional disturbance; cultural disadvantage; environmental deprivation; or limited English proficiency. Achievement must be below the expected level given the individual's age, state-approved grade-level standards, or intellectual development.

section_title: Achievement Testing and Learning Disability Assessment

anchors.text: The Response to Intervention (RTI) model uses a multi-tiered system of supports to identify and serve students with learning difficulties:
Tier 1: High-quality, evidence-based instruction for all students in the general education classroom, with universal screening to identify at-risk students
Tier 2: Targeted, small-group interventions for students not making adequate progress in Tier 1, with progress monitoring to track response

Tier 3: Intensive, individualized interventions for students who do not respond adequately to Tier 2 supports. Students who fail to respond at Tier 3 may be referred for comprehensive evaluation for special education eligibility

RTI was endorsed by IDEA 2004 as an acceptable alternative to the discrepancy model. Its strengths include early identification and intervention, but critics argue that it does not identify the cognitive processing deficits underlying the learning difficulty and that there is no consensus on what constitutes "adequate response" to intervention.

section_title: Achievement Testing and Learning Disability Assessment
topic_name: Pattern of Strengths and Weaknesses (PSW) Model

anchors.text: The Pattern of Strengths and Weaknesses (PSW) model, also known as the concordance-discordance model, represents a third approach to SLD identification. The PSW model examines whether:
There is a concordance (consistency) between a specific cognitive processing weakness and a specific academic deficit (e.g., weak phonological processing paired with weak reading decoding)
There is a discordance (inconsistency) between the student's overall cognitive ability and the specific area of academic weakness
Cognitive strengths exist in areas unrelated to the academic deficit, ruling out global intellectual deficiency

The PSW model is considered the most theoretically grounded approach, as it directly examines the pattern of cognitive and academic functioning predicted by learning disability theory. It requires comprehensive cognitive and achievement testing and relies on CHC theory to identify the specific cognitive processes underlying academic skills.
Ability-Achievement Discrepancy — IQ-achievement gap — Simple, widely understood — Wait to fail; not empirically validated; disadvantages lower-IQ students
RTI (3-tier model) — Response to evidence-based intervention — Early intervention; prevents over-identification — Does not identify cognitive basis; no consensus on "adequate response"

PSW / Concordance-Discordance — Cognitive-academic profile analysis — Theoretically grounded; identifies specific processing deficits — Complex; requires comprehensive testing; limited consensus on operationalization

Modern best practice in SLD assessment typically integrates elements of multiple models. A thorough evaluation includes comprehensive cognitive testing (to identify processing strengths and weaknesses), achievement testing (to document academic deficits), evidence of inadequate response to intervention (ruling out instructional quality as the primary cause), and consideration of exclusionary factors (intellectual disability, sensory impairment, cultural or linguistic factors, inadequate instruction). Co-normed cognitive-achievement batteries (WJ-IV, WIAT-4/Wechsler scales) provide the strongest statistical foundation for comparing abilities and achievements.

anchors.text: Measurement-Based Care is the practice of using standardized, validated outcome measures at regular intervals to guide treatment decisions. Research consistently demonstrates that MBC improves treatment outcomes, reduces deterioration rates, and helps clinicians identify patients who are not responding to treatment — often before the clinician would notice clinically. Key principles of MBC include:
Routine administration: Measures are given at every session or at regular intervals (e.g., weekly, biweekly), not just at intake and discharge
Real-time feedback: Scores are reviewed immediately to inform the current session's clinical focus
Clinical decision rules: Established thresholds or algorithms guide when to modify, intensify, or change treatment approaches
Patient engagement: Sharing results with patients increases transparency, collaboration, and therapeutic alliance

Michael Lambert's research at Brigham Young University demonstrated that routine outcome monitoring with a signal-alarm system significantly improves therapy outcomes. Using the OQ-45 administered at each session, Lambert's system generates alerts when a patient's trajectory deviates from expected recovery curves — identifying patients who are at risk of treatment failure or deterioration before it becomes clinically obvious. When therapists received these feedback alerts, outcomes improved significantly: deterioration rates were cut in half, and more patients achieved clinically significant change. Lambert's work established that therapists are generally poor at detecting patient deterioration without systematic measurement, tending to overestimate their patients' progress.

Key principles of MBC include:
[002] Routine administration: Measures are given at every session or at regular intervals (e.g., weekly, biweekly), not just at intake and discharge
[003] Real-time feedback: Scores are reviewed immediately to inform the current session's clinical focus
[004] Clinical decision rules: Established thresholds or algorithms guide when to modify, intensify, or change treatment approaches
[005] Patient engagement: Sharing results with patients increases transparency, collaboration, and therapeutic alliance
[006] Michael Lambert's research at Brigham Young University demonstrated that routine outcome monitoring with a signal-alarm system significantly improves therapy outcomes. Using the OQ-45 administered at each session, Lambert's system generates alerts when a patient's trajectory deviates from expected recovery curves — identifying patients who are at risk of treatment failure or deterioration before it becomes clinically obvious. When therapists received these feedback alerts, outcomes improved significantly: deterioration rates were cut in half, and more patients achieved clinically significant change. Lambert's work established that therapists are generally poor at detecting patient deterioration without systematic measurement, tending to overestimate their patients' progress.

anchors.text: The OQ-45 is a 45-item self-report measure designed for repeated administration throughout therapy to track patient progress. It yields a Total Score and three subscale scores:
Symptom Distress (SD): 25 items assessing depression, anxiety, and somatic symptoms — the primary index of intrapsychic distress
Interpersonal Relations (IR): 11 items measuring satisfaction with and functioning in interpersonal relationships
Social Role (SR): 9 items assessing functioning in work, school, and other social roles

The OQ-45 uses a cutoff score of 63 to distinguish between clinical and non-clinical populations and a Reliable Change Index (RCI) of 14 points to determine whether change is statistically meaningful rather than due to measurement error. The combination of crossing the clinical cutoff AND achieving reliable change defines clinically significant change.

[003] Interpersonal Relations (IR): 11 items measuring satisfaction with and functioning in interpersonal relationships
[004] Social Role (SR): 9 items assessing functioning in work, school, and other social roles
[005] The OQ-45 uses a cutoff score of 63 to distinguish between clinical and non-clinical populations and a Reliable Change Index (RCI) of 14 points to determine whether change is statistically meaningful rather than due to measurement error. The combination of crossing the clinical cutoff AND achieving reliable change defines clinically significant change.

anchors.text: The PHQ-9 is a 9-item self-report depression screening and severity measure. Each item corresponds to one of the nine DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Major Depressive Disorder, rated from 0 (not at all) to 3 (nearly every day) over the past two weeks. Total scores range from 0 to 27 with established severity cutoffs:
0-4 — Minimal / None — No treatment indicated
5-9 — Mild — Watchful waiting; repeat at follow-up
10-14 — Moderate — Treatment plan; consider counseling and/or pharmacotherapy
15-19 — Moderately Severe — Active treatment with pharmacotherapy and/or psychotherapy
20-27 — Severe — Immediate initiation of pharmacotherapy; consider referral to specialist

The PHQ-9 is freely available (no copyright cost), making it one of the most widely used outcome measures in primary care, integrated behavioral health, and clinical research. A score of 10 or greater has a sensitivity of 88% and specificity of 88% for detecting Major Depressive Disorder.

anchors.text: The GAD-7 is a 7-item self-report measure assessing the severity of generalized anxiety symptoms over the past two weeks. Items are rated from 0 (not at all) to 3 (nearly every day), with total scores ranging from 0 to 21. Severity cutoffs are:
0-4: Minimal anxiety
5-9: Mild anxiety
10-14: Moderate anxiety
15-21: Severe anxiety

While developed for GAD, the GAD-7 also demonstrates good sensitivity for detecting panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, and PTSD. Like the PHQ-9, it is freely available and widely used as a brief screening and outcome monitoring tool.

anchors.text: The C-SSRS is a structured interview tool for assessing suicidal ideation and behavior. It distinguishes between passive ideation (wishes to be dead), active ideation without plan, active ideation with plan, active ideation with intent, and active ideation with plan and intent, as well as actual attempts, interrupted attempts, aborted attempts, and preparatory behaviors. The C-SSRS has been adopted by the FDA, multiple federal agencies, and numerous health systems as a standard tool for suicide risk assessment. Its structured severity rating helps clinicians make more consistent and defensible risk management decisions.

Example: A therapist treating a patient with comorbid depression and anxiety administers the PHQ-9 and GAD-7 at each session. Over the first four sessions of CBT, the PHQ-9 drops from 18 (moderately severe) to 12 (moderate) and the GAD-7 from 14 (moderate) to 9 (mild), indicating meaningful improvement in both symptom domains. At session 8, the PHQ-9 unexpectedly rises to 16. The therapist uses this feedback to explore recent stressors, discovers a job loss, and adjusts the treatment plan to include behavioral activation targeting the new situational depression. Without routine monitoring, this deterioration might not have been detected until it became clinically obvious weeks later.

The concept of clinically significant change requires two conditions: (1) the patient must cross the threshold from the clinical to the non-clinical distribution (i.e., post-treatment scores fall within the normal range), and (2) the magnitude of change must exceed the Reliable Change Index (RCI), ensuring that the observed change is unlikely due to measurement error alone. The RCI is calculated using the standard error of measurement of the instrument. This dual criterion prevents both overinterpretation of small changes within the clinical range and dismissal of genuine improvement that does not quite reach the non-clinical range.

anchors.text: In vivo — Direct, real-life confrontation with feared stimulus — Specific phobias, social anxiety, agoraphobia
Imaginal — Visualization of the feared scenario in detail — PTSD, GAD worry scenarios, phobias where in vivo is impractical
Interoceptive — Deliberate provocation of feared bodily sensations — Panic disorder (e.g., hyperventilation, spinning, straw breathing)
Virtual reality (VR) — Computer-simulated feared environment — Flying phobia, heights, combat-related PTSD

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > EBT: Anxiety, Trauma & OCD > Exposure-Based Treatments for Anxiety > Types of Exposure
anchors_text:
[001] In vivo — Direct, real-life confrontation with feared stimulus — Specific phobias, social anxiety, agoraphobia
[002] Imaginal — Visualization of the feared scenario in detail — PTSD, GAD worry scenarios, phobias where in vivo is impractical
[003] Interoceptive — Deliberate provocation of feared bodily sensations — Panic disorder (e.g., hyperventilation, spinning, straw breathing)
[004] Virtual reality (VR) — Computer-simulated feared environment — Flying phobia, heights, combat-related PTSD

anchors.text: Systematic desensitization pairs graduated exposure with relaxation training based on the principle of reciprocal inhibition — anxiety and relaxation are mutually incompatible states. The client constructs a fear hierarchy (using SUDS ratings from 0-100) and progresses through it while maintaining a relaxed state. Treatment typically begins with training in progressive muscle relaxation before any exposure begins.

Flooding involves prolonged exposure to the most anxiety-provoking stimulus without the graduated hierarchy, relying on habituation through extended contact with the feared stimulus. Unlike systematic desensitization, flooding does not include relaxation training and begins at high anxiety levels. It is critical that flooding sessions are of sufficient duration to allow anxiety to decrease — premature termination of a flooding session while anxiety is still elevated can actually sensitize the client and increase fear (a process called incubation).

Implosive therapy (Stampfl) is a variant that uses imaginal flooding with psychodynamic content — the therapist describes the feared scenario in exaggerated detail, sometimes incorporating hypothesized unconscious themes. Implosive therapy is rarely used in contemporary practice.

Research comparing graduated and intensive (massed) exposure formats generally shows equivalent outcomes, though intensive formats may produce faster results. The critical variable is that exposure must be of sufficient duration and intensity to promote new learning. Brief exposure sessions that are terminated prematurely (before habituation or expectancy violation occurs) may worsen anxiety. Session duration of at least 60-90 minutes is typically recommended for prolonged exposure exercises.
Expectancy violation: Maximizing the mismatch between expected and actual outcomes during exposure
Deepened extinction: Combining multiple fear cues during a single exposure trial
Variability: Varying exposure parameters (context, duration, intensity) across sessions
Occasional reinforced extinction: Occasionally including the feared outcome during exposure to strengthen new learning
Affect labeling: Verbally labeling the emotional experience during exposure
Retrieval cues: Using cues from the exposure context in everyday life to trigger the inhibitory memory

anchors.text: CBT for panic disorder (Clark, 1986; Barlow & Craske) includes psychoeducation about the nature of panic (the "fear of fear" model), cognitive restructuring of catastrophic misinterpretations of bodily sensations (e.g., "my racing heart means I'm having a heart attack"), interoceptive exposure (deliberately inducing feared sensations), and in vivo exposure to avoided situations. The treatment targets the maintenance cycle in which normal bodily sensations are catastrophically misinterpreted, producing anxiety that intensifies the sensations.

Example: Common exercises include: hyperventilation (30 seconds) to induce dizziness and tingling; breathing through a thin straw to create air hunger; spinning in a chair to produce dizziness; running in place to elevate heart rate; staring at a spot on the wall to induce derealization. Each exercise is designed to provoke the specific bodily sensations the client fears. The client rates the similarity of each exercise to their natural panic symptoms and begins exposure with exercises most closely matching their feared sensations.

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > EBT: Anxiety, Trauma & OCD > Exposure-Based Treatments for Anxiety > CBT for Panic Disorder
anchors_text:
[001] CBT for panic disorder (Clark, 1986; Barlow & Craske) includes psychoeducation about the nature of panic (the "fear of fear" model), cognitive restructuring of catastrophic misinterpretations of bodily sensations (e.g., "my racing heart means I'm having a heart attack"), interoceptive exposure (deliberately inducing feared sensations), and in vivo exposure to avoided situations. The treatment targets the maintenance cycle in which normal bodily sensations are catastrophically misinterpreted, producing anxiety that intensifies the sensations.
[002] Example: Common exercises include: hyperventilation (30 seconds) to induce dizziness and tingling; breathing through a thin straw to create air hunger; spinning in a chair to produce dizziness; running in place to elevate heart rate; staring at a spot on the wall to induce derealization. Each exercise is designed to provoke the specific bodily sensations the client fears. The client rates the similarity of each exercise to their natural panic symptoms and begins exposure with exercises most closely matching their feared sensations.

section_title: Exposure and Response Prevention for OCD

anchors.text: ERP is adapted for different OCD presentations. For checking compulsions, exposure involves resisting the urge to check (locks, stove, alarms) after a single verification. For symmetry/ordering OCD, exposure involves deliberately creating asymmetry and tolerating the resulting distress. For "pure O" (primarily obsessional OCD), imaginal exposure scripts describing the feared scenario are used when behavioral exposure is not feasible. For harm-related obsessions, exposure may involve holding a knife near a loved one while resisting mental rituals. Response prevention targets not only behavioral compulsions but also mental rituals such as mental reviewing, counting, or praying.

SSRIs (particularly fluvoxamine, fluoxetine, sertraline, and paroxetine) and clomipramine (a tricyclic antidepressant with strong serotonergic activity) are first-line pharmacological treatments for OCD. The combination of ERP plus an SSRI is often recommended for moderate-to-severe OCD. However, research suggests that ERP alone produces equivalent or superior long-term outcomes compared to medication alone, with lower relapse rates after treatment discontinuation.

Response prevention targets not only behavioral compulsions but also mental rituals such as mental reviewing, counting, or praying.
[002] SSRIs (particularly fluvoxamine, fluoxetine, sertraline, and paroxetine) and clomipramine (a tricyclic antidepressant with strong serotonergic activity) are first-line pharmacological treatments for OCD. The combination of ERP plus an SSRI is often recommended for moderate-to-severe OCD. anchors.text: Prolonged Exposure is based on Foa's emotional processing theory, which proposes that PTSD involves a pathological fear structure that is activated by trauma-related cues but maintained by avoidance. The fear structure contains stimulus representations, response representations, and meaning representations — successful processing requires activation of the entire fear structure followed by integration of corrective information.

PE consists of four components: (1) psychoeducation about trauma reactions, (2) breathing retraining, (3) imaginal exposure (repeated detailed revisiting of the traumatic memory in session, usually 45-60 minutes, recorded for homework listening), and (4) in vivo exposure to avoided but objectively safe trauma-related situations. PE is typically delivered in 8-15 weekly 90-minute sessions. The imaginal exposure component involves the client narrating the traumatic event in the present tense with eyes closed, repeatedly processing the memory until emotional distress decreases.

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > EBT: Anxiety, Trauma & OCD > Evidence-Based Treatments for PTSD > Prolonged Exposure (PE)
anchors_text:
[001] Prolonged Exposure is based on Foa's emotional processing theory, which proposes that PTSD involves a pathological fear structure that is activated by trauma-related cues but maintained by avoidance. The fear structure contains stimulus representations, response representations, and meaning representations — successful processing requires activation of the entire fear structure followed by integration of corrective information.
[002] PE consists of four components: (1) psychoeducation about trauma reactions, (2) breathing retraining, (3) imaginal exposure (repeated detailed revisiting of the traumatic memory in session, usually 45-60 minutes, recorded for homework listening), and (4) in vivo exposure to avoided but objectively safe trauma-related situations. PE is typically delivered in 8-15 weekly 90-minute sessions. The imaginal exposure component involves the client narrating the traumatic event in the present tense with eyes closed, repeatedly processing the memory until emotional distress decreases.

anchors.text: CPT targets maladaptive trauma-related cognitions — "stuck points" — that maintain PTSD symptoms. Common stuck points involve themes of safety, trust, power/control, esteem, and intimacy. Stuck points may be assimilated (the trauma is distorted to fit pre-existing beliefs, e.g., "it was my fault") or over-accommodated (pre-existing beliefs are distorted to fit the trauma, e.g., "no one can be trusted"). CPT uses Socratic questioning and cognitive worksheets (ABC worksheets, Challenging Beliefs Worksheets) to help clients identify and modify distorted beliefs. CPT can be delivered with or without a written trauma account (CPT vs. CPT-C, the cognitive-only version). Both 12-session individual and group formats are well-supported.
Prolonged Exposure — Foa — Emotional processing via exposure — 8-15 — Avoidance-heavy presentations
CPT — Resick — Modifying trauma-related stuck points — 12 — Guilt, self-blame, cognitive distortions
EMDR — Shapiro — Adaptive information processing — 8-12 — Single-incident trauma
TF-CBT — Cohen et al. — Graduated exposure + caregiver skills — 12-25 — Children/adolescents (ages 3-18)

anchors.text: 1 — History Taking — Identify target memories, current triggers, and future desired behaviors
2 — Preparation — Establish therapeutic relationship; teach self-regulation skills (safe place imagery)
3 — Assessment — Activate target memory; identify image, negative cognition, positive cognition, VOC, emotions, SUDS, body location
4 — Desensitization — Bilateral stimulation while focusing on the target memory; continue until SUDS = 0
5 — Installation — Strengthen the positive cognition (VOC = 7); pair it with the target memory
6 — Body Scan — Identify and process any residual somatic disturbance
7 — Closure — Return client to equilibrium; use self-regulation strategies if needed
8 — Reevaluation — Check treatment effects at next session; identify new targets if needed

While EMDR is listed as an effective treatment for PTSD by multiple guidelines (APA, VA/DoD, WHO), debate continues about whether the bilateral stimulation component provides benefit beyond standard imaginal exposure. Component analyses have yielded mixed results, and some researchers argue that the exposure and cognitive restructuring elements, rather than the bilateral stimulation, account for EMDR's efficacy.

anchors.text: TF-CBT (Cohen, Mannarino, & Deblinger) is the treatment of choice for children and adolescents (ages 3-18) with PTSD. The components are summarized by the acronym PRACTICE:
Psychoeducation — about trauma reactions and the treatment process
Parenting skills — teaching caregivers effective behavior management
Relaxation — progressive muscle relaxation, focused breathing, mindfulness
Affective modulation — identifying and regulating emotions
Cognitive coping and processing — connecting thoughts, feelings, and behaviors
Trauma narrative — gradual exposure through creating a narrative of the trauma experience
In vivo mastery — real-world exposure to trauma reminders that are objectively safe
Conjoint sessions — sharing the trauma narrative with the caregiver
Enhancing safety — safety planning and healthy relationship skills

TF-CBT includes parallel child and caregiver sessions throughout treatment and culminates in the creation and sharing of the trauma narrative. The caregiver component is considered essential — it addresses caregiver distress, teaches supportive responses, and prepares the caregiver for the conjoint narrative sharing session.

PE, CPT, and EMDR are all recommended as first-line treatments for PTSD by the APA Clinical Practice Guideline and the VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guideline. PE is particularly strong for avoidance-dominated presentations, while CPT may be preferred when cognitive distortions (guilt, self-blame) are prominent. For children and adolescents, TF-CBT is the first-line recommendation. Written exposure therapy (WET) is an emerging brief intervention (5 sessions) showing promise as an efficient trauma-focused treatment.

section_title: Specific Phobia Treatment and Pharmacological Considerations

anchors.text: One-session treatment (OST) is a single prolonged session (typically 2-3 hours) of participant modeling and in vivo exposure for specific phobias. The therapist models approach behavior, provides graduated exposure, and uses guided participation. OST has demonstrated large effect sizes for various specific phobias including animal phobias, blood-injection-injury phobia, and claustrophobia. This intensive format achieves comparable outcomes to multi-session exposure therapy.

BII phobia is unique among phobias because it involves a diphasic physiological response — an initial sympathetic activation (increased heart rate) followed by a strong parasympathetic response (vasovagal syncope — sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure leading to fainting). For this reason, standard exposure alone may be insufficient; applied tension (Ost & Sterner) — tensing the large muscles of the body during exposure to maintain blood pressure — is the treatment of choice. This is the only phobia where relaxation training is contraindicated, as relaxation would lower blood pressure further.

section_title: Specific Phobia Treatment and Pharmacological Considerations

anchors.text: SSRIs — Sertraline, fluoxetine, paroxetine, escitalopram — GAD, SAD, panic, OCD, PTSD — Increase serotonin availability
SNRIs — Venlafaxine, duloxetine — GAD, SAD — Increase serotonin and norepinephrine
Benzodiazepines — Alprazolam, clonazepam, lorazepam — Acute anxiety, panic (short-term) — Enhance GABA-A activity
Buspirone — Buspirone — GAD (chronic) — 5-HT1A partial agonist; no sedation/dependence
Beta-blockers — Propranolol — Performance anxiety — Block peripheral sympathetic symptoms
D-cycloserine — DCS (augmentation) — Exposure therapy enhancement — NMDA partial agonist; enhances extinction learning

Concurrent benzodiazepine use during exposure therapy is generally discouraged because it may interfere with new learning. State-dependent learning theory suggests that fear extinction learned in a benzodiazepine-modulated state may not transfer to the drug-free state. Research suggests that D-cycloserine (DCS), an NMDA receptor partial agonist, may enhance extinction learning when administered shortly before exposure sessions, though results are mixed and the effect appears strongest in early sessions.

section_title: ACT and Third-Wave Approaches for Anxiety

anchors.text: Applied relaxation is a structured behavioral treatment primarily for GAD that progresses through several stages: progressive muscle relaxation, release-only relaxation, cue-controlled relaxation (pairing relaxation with a cue word), differential relaxation (relaxing in non-demanding situations), rapid relaxation (achieving relaxation in 20-30 seconds), and application training (using the skill in naturally anxiety-provoking situations). It is considered an empirically supported treatment for GAD and panic disorder.

Example: Treatment for Generalized Anxiety Disorder typically combines cognitive restructuring of worry-related beliefs (e.g., "worrying helps me prepare"), behavioral experiments to test catastrophic predictions, and worry exposure (deliberately imagining the worst-case scenario without engaging avoidance). Borkovec's model emphasizes that worry serves as cognitive avoidance of emotional processing — the verbal-linguistic nature of worry dampens emotional imagery and prevents full emotional processing of feared outcomes. Intolerance of uncertainty is a key cognitive target in Dugas's model of GAD treatment.

anchors.text: Identifying automatic thoughts: Catching the spontaneous, evaluative thoughts that arise in response to situations and are often accepted as true without examination
Cognitive restructuring: Examining evidence for and against automatic thoughts, generating alternative interpretations, and testing distorted cognitions through behavioral experiments
Behavioral activation: Scheduling and engaging in pleasurable and mastery activities to counteract withdrawal, inactivity, and loss of reinforcement

Identifying cognitive distortions: Recognizing systematic thinking errors such as all-or-nothing thinking, overgeneralization, mental filtering, catastrophizing, personalization, and "should" statements

Common distortions include: All-or-nothing thinking (seeing things in black-and-white categories), overgeneralization (viewing a single negative event as a never-ending pattern), mental filter (dwelling on negatives while ignoring positives), magnification/minimization (exaggerating negatives and shrinking positives), emotional reasoning ("I feel it, therefore it must be true"), and personalization (assuming responsibility for negative events outside one's control).

topic_name: Structure of Beck's CBT for Depression

anchors.text: Beck's CBT is a structured, time-limited (typically 12-20 sessions) treatment that follows a predictable session format: mood check, bridge from previous session, agenda setting, review of homework, discussion of agenda items, assignment of new homework, and summary/feedback. The treatment progresses through three phases:
Early sessions (1-4): Establishing the therapeutic relationship, psychoeducation about the cognitive model, introducing activity monitoring and scheduling, identifying automatic thoughts
Middle sessions (5-12): Cognitive restructuring using thought records, behavioral experiments to test predictions, identifying and challenging intermediate beliefs (rules, attitudes, assumptions)
Late sessions (13-20): Identifying and modifying core beliefs (schemas), relapse prevention, spacing sessions, consolidating gains

Beck distinguished three levels of cognition: (1) Automatic thoughts — spontaneous, situation-specific thoughts that are closest to conscious awareness; (2) Intermediate beliefs — conditional rules and attitudes ("If I'm not perfect, I'm a failure"); and (3) Core beliefs/schemas — deep, unconditional beliefs about self, others, and the world ("I am worthless"). CBT for depression addresses all three levels, progressing from automatic thoughts early in treatment to deeper schema-level work in later sessions.

anchors.text: The EPPP expects knowledge of how psychotherapy compares with and combines with pharmacotherapy for depression. Key findings include:
For mild to moderate depression, CBT and pharmacotherapy are approximately equally effective. Psychotherapy alone is a reasonable first-line treatment.
For severe depression, combined CBT + medication tends to outperform either alone. BA may be as effective as medication for severe depression.
Long-term outcomes: CBT has an enduring effect that persists after treatment ends, whereas pharmacotherapy benefits typically disappear when medication is discontinued.
Relapse prevention: Both MBCT and maintenance antidepressant medication reduce relapse; MBCT may be equivalent to maintenance medication for patients with 3+ prior episodes.

anchors.text: Behavioral Activation emerged from a component analysis (known as the "component analysis study") showing that the behavioral component of CBT was as effective as the full cognitive-behavioral package for depression. This finding was replicated in the landmark NIMH Treatment of Depression Collaborative Research Program and the Dimidjian et al. trial. BA is based on the theory that depression results from a decrease in response-contingent positive reinforcement — when life circumstances reduce access to reinforcing activities, withdrawal and inactivity follow, which further decreases reinforcement in a self-perpetuating cycle.

Treatment focuses on: (1) monitoring daily activities and mood to identify the activity-mood connection, (2) scheduling and engaging in valued activities (even when motivation is low), (3) reducing avoidance behaviors and withdrawal, (4) addressing rumination as a form of avoidance (TRAP: Trigger-Response-Avoidance Pattern; TRAC: Trigger-Response-Alternative Coping), and (5) problem-solving environmental barriers to activation. BA is simpler to deliver than full CBT and has been shown to be equally effective, even for severe depression.

Example: A depressed client who has stopped exercising, socializing, and pursuing hobbies begins BA by tracking daily activities and rating each for pleasure (0-10) and mastery (0-10). The therapist and client then identify a graded hierarchy of activities to re-engage with, starting with low-effort, high-reward behaviors (e.g., a brief walk) and gradually building toward more demanding activities (e.g., attending a social event). The key principle is that action precedes motivation — the client acts first, and mood improvement follows.

anchors.text: Mindfulness: Core skill — observing, describing, and participating in experiences with non-judgmental awareness (the "what" skills) and doing so one-mindfully and effectively (the "how" skills)
Distress Tolerance: Crisis survival strategies (TIPP, ACCEPTS, IMPROVE) and radical acceptance — tolerating painful emotions without making them worse

Emotion Regulation: Understanding and naming emotions, reducing vulnerability to negative emotions (PLEASE skills: treat Physical illness, balanced Eating, avoid mood-Altering substances, balanced Sleep, get Exercise), increasing positive emotional events, and opposite action (acting opposite to the emotion's action urge when the emotion does not fit the facts)

Interpersonal Effectiveness: DEAR MAN (Describe, Express, Assert, Reinforce, stay Mindful, Appear confident, Negotiate) for asking for what one needs; GIVE (be Gentle, act Interested, Validate, use Easy manner) for maintaining relationships; FAST (be Fair, no Apologies, Stick to values, be Truthful) for maintaining self-respect
Standard DBT involves four modes of treatment delivered simultaneously:

Individual therapy — Weekly (1 hour) — Addresses treatment targets using hierarchy: life-threatening behaviors > therapy-interfering behaviors > quality-of-life-interfering behaviors > skills acquisition
Skills training group — Weekly (2.5 hours) — Teaches the four skills modules; structured psychoeducational format; NOT process-oriented group therapy
Phone coaching — As needed — Helps generalize skills to everyday life; brief coaching during crises; NOT therapy between sessions
Therapist consultation team — Weekly — Supports therapist motivation and competence; prevents burnout; "therapy for the therapist"

The dialectical philosophy is central to DBT — it balances acceptance strategies (validation, mindfulness) and change strategies (behavior analysis, skills training, contingency management) throughout treatment. The fundamental dialectic is between acceptance and change: the therapist simultaneously communicates "you are doing the best you can AND you need to do better."

Diary cards are used to track daily emotions, urges (e.g., self-harm, substance use), target behaviors, and skills used. They are reviewed at the beginning of each individual session to set the agenda according to the treatment hierarchy. Chain analysis (also called behavioral analysis) is a core DBT technique in which the therapist and client examine a problem behavior in minute detail — identifying the prompting event, vulnerability factors, links in the chain (thoughts, emotions, behaviors, body sensations), consequences, and potential points for intervention.

[002] Distress Tolerance: Crisis survival strategies (TIPP, ACCEPTS, IMPROVE) and radical acceptance — tolerating painful emotions without making them worse
[003] Emotion Regulation: Understanding and naming emotions, reducing vulnerability to negative emotions (PLEASE skills: treat Physical illness, balanced Eating, avoid mood-Altering substances, balanced Sleep, get Exercise), increasing positive emotional events, and opposite action (acting opposite to the emotion's action urge when the emotion does not fit the facts)
[004] Interpersonal Effectiveness: DEAR MAN (Describe, Express, Assert, Reinforce, stay Mindful, Appear confident, Negotiate) for asking for what one needs; GIVE (be Gentle, act Interested, Validate, use Easy manner) for maintaining relationships; FAST (be Fair, no Apologies, Stick to values, be Truthful) for maintaining self-respect
[005] Standard DBT involves four modes of treatment delivered simultaneously:
[006] Individual therapy — Weekly (1 hour) — Addresses treatment targets using hierarchy: life-threatening behaviors > therapy-interfering behaviors > quality-of-life-interfering behaviors > skills acquisition
[007] Skills training group — Weekly (2.5 hours) — Teaches the four skills modules; structured psychoeducational format; NOT process-oriented group therapy
[008] Phone coaching — As needed — Helps generalize skills to everyday life; brief coaching during crises; NOT therapy between sessions
[009] Therapist consultation team — Weekly — Supports therapist motivation and competence; prevents burnout; "therapy for the therapist"
[010] The dialectical philosophy is central to DBT — it balances acceptance strategies (validation, mindfulness) and change strategies (behavior analysis, skills training, contingency management) throughout treatment. The fundamental dialectic is between acceptance and change: the therapist simultaneously communicates "you are doing the best you can AND you need to do better."
[011] Diary cards are used to track daily emotions, urges (e.g., self-harm, substance use), target behaviors, and skills used. They are reviewed at the beginning of each individual session to set the agenda according to the treatment hierarchy. Chain analysis (also called behavioral analysis) is a core DBT technique in which the therapist and client examine a problem behavior in minute detail — identifying the prompting event, vulnerability factors, links in the chain (thoughts, emotions, behaviors, body sensations), consequences, and potential points for intervention.

anchors.text: Schema Therapy identifies and modifies early maladaptive schemas (EMS) — broad, pervasive themes regarding oneself and one's relationships that develop during childhood and are elaborated throughout life. For BPD, schema therapy focuses on four maladaptive schema modes: the Detached Protector, the Punitive Parent, the Abandoned/Abused Child, and the Angry Child. Treatment aims to strengthen the Healthy Adult mode. Schema therapy uses cognitive, experiential (empty chair, imagery rescripting), behavioral, and relational strategies.

Example: All four BPD treatments (DBT, MBT, TFP, Schema Therapy) have RCT support. DBT has the largest evidence base and is the most widely available. The APA Practice Guideline for BPD notes that different treatments may be preferred based on the predominant features: DBT when self-harm and emotional dysregulation are primary; MBT when mentalization deficits are prominent; TFP when identity disturbance and splitting are central; and Schema Therapy when rigid patterns of avoidance and early maladaptive schemas dominate the presentation.

topic_name: CBT-E for Bulimia and Binge Eating

anchors.text: CBT-Enhanced (CBT-E) is the leading evidence-based treatment for bulimia nervosa and binge eating disorder. The transdiagnostic model proposes that all eating disorders share a core psychopathology: the overevaluation of eating, shape, and weight and their control. The cognitive-behavioral model of bulimia nervosa identifies a self-perpetuating cycle: low self-esteem and overvaluation of shape/weight lead to extreme dietary restriction, which leads to binge eating (as restriction eventually breaks down), which triggers compensatory behaviors (purging) and intensifies feelings of failure and low self-esteem.

CBT-E has two forms: a focused form (20 sessions) that targets the core eating disorder psychopathology, and a broad form that additionally addresses maintaining processes including clinical perfectionism, core low self-esteem, mood intolerance, and interpersonal difficulties. Key treatment components include:
Self-monitoring: Real-time recording of eating, purging, and associated thoughts/feelings
Regular eating pattern: Establishing three planned meals and two to three planned snacks per day
Cognitive restructuring: Challenging overvaluation of shape/weight and dietary rules
Exposure to avoided foods: Gradually reintroducing forbidden foods
Relapse prevention: Developing a personalized maintenance plan

CBT-E produces remission rates of approximately 40-50% for bulimia nervosa and higher rates for binge eating disorder. It is superior to pharmacotherapy alone for bulimia nervosa, and gains are well-maintained at follow-up. The transdiagnostic framework allows CBT-E to be applied across eating disorder diagnoses, including atypical presentations.

anchors.text: Family-Based Treatment (FBT), also known as the Maudsley approach (Lock & Le Grange), is the first-line treatment for adolescent anorexia nervosa. FBT proceeds in three phases:

Phase 1 (Weight Restoration): Parents take full charge of refeeding their child. The therapist empowers the parents as the experts on feeding their child, while externalizing the eating disorder as separate from the adolescent. A family meal is conducted in session 2, during which the therapist coaches parents to encourage the adolescent to eat one more bite than they feel comfortable with.
Phase 2 (Return of Control): Once weight is largely restored and the eating disorder symptoms have decreased, control of eating is gradually returned to the adolescent in an age-appropriate manner.
Phase 3 (Adolescent Identity): Focus shifts to establishing a healthy adolescent identity, addressing general developmental issues, and termination of treatment.

FBT is agnostic about the cause of the eating disorder and explicitly exonerates parents from blame. This represents a significant departure from earlier family therapy approaches that implicated family dynamics in the development of anorexia. FBT typically involves 15-20 sessions over 6-12 months.

IPT has been shown to be as effective as CBT for bulimia nervosa in the long term, though CBT produces faster symptom improvement. IPT for eating disorders focuses on the same four interpersonal problem areas (grief, role disputes, role transitions, interpersonal deficits) and does not directly target eating behaviors — yet eating symptoms improve as interpersonal functioning improves.

topic_name: Treatment of Anorexia Nervosa in Adults

anchors.text: Unlike bulimia nervosa and binge eating disorder, no single psychotherapy has demonstrated clear superiority for adult anorexia nervosa. Evidence supports CBT-E (adapted for underweight patients), the Maudsley Model of Anorexia Nervosa Treatment for Adults (MANTRA), and Specialist Supportive Clinical Management (SSCM). Medical monitoring and nutritional rehabilitation are essential across all treatment approaches. Inpatient or residential treatment may be necessary when BMI is dangerously low or medical complications are present. The mortality rate for anorexia nervosa is the highest of any psychiatric disorder.

Example: SSRIs (particularly fluoxetine at 60 mg) are FDA-approved for bulimia nervosa and can reduce binge/purge frequency. For binge eating disorder, lisdexamfetamine (a stimulant) is FDA-approved. Pharmacotherapy has limited efficacy for anorexia nervosa — no medication has been shown to produce weight gain in acutely underweight patients. Olanzapine (an atypical antipsychotic) has shown modest weight gain benefits in some studies. Pharmacotherapy is generally recommended as an adjunct to psychotherapy, not as a standalone treatment for eating disorders.

anchors.text: MI is defined by its underlying spirit — the stance and mindset of the clinician:
Collaboration (Partnership): MI is done "with" the client, not "to" or "for" them. The clinician is an equal partner in exploring change.
Evocation: The motivation for change already exists within the client. The clinician's role is to evoke and amplify it, not impose it.
Autonomy (Acceptance): The client's right to make their own choices is respected. The clinician does not coerce or prescribe.
Compassion: The clinician prioritizes the client's welfare and well-being.

anchors_text:
[001] MI is defined by its underlying spirit — the stance and mindset of the clinician:
[002] Collaboration (Partnership): MI is done "with" the client, not "to" or "for" them. The clinician is an equal partner in exploring change.
[003] Evocation: The motivation for change already exists within the client. The clinician's role is to evoke and amplify it, not impose it.
[004] Autonomy (Acceptance): The client's right to make their own choices is respected. The clinician does not coerce or prescribe.
[005] Compassion: The clinician prioritizes the client's welfare and well-being.

anchors.text: MI is closely associated with Prochaska and DiClemente's Transtheoretical Model (TTM) of change, which identifies five stages:
Precontemplation — Not considering change; unaware or in denial — Raise awareness; explore pros of status quo and cons of change
Contemplation — Ambivalent; weighing pros and cons — Explore ambivalence; develop discrepancy; elicit change talk
Preparation — Planning to change; committed but not yet acting — Support planning; explore options; strengthen commitment
Action — Actively making changes — Support self-efficacy; problem-solve barriers; reinforce efforts
Maintenance — Sustaining change over time — Prevent relapse; reinforce gains; address ongoing challenges

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > EBT: Substance Use & Developmental Disorders > Motivational Interviewing (MI) > Stages of Change (Transtheoretical Model)
anchors_text:
[001] MI is closely associated with Prochaska and DiClemente's Transtheoretical Model (TTM) of change, which identifies five stages:
[002] Precontemplation — Not considering change; unaware or in denial — Raise awareness; explore pros of status quo and cons of change
[003] Contemplation — Ambivalent; weighing pros and cons — Explore ambivalence; develop discrepancy; elicit change talk
[004] Preparation — Planning to change; committed but not yet acting — Support planning; explore options; strengthen commitment
[005] Action — Actively making changes — Support self-efficacy; problem-solve barriers; reinforce efforts
[006] Maintenance — Sustaining change over time — Prevent relapse; reinforce gains; address ongoing challenges

anchors.text: In MI, the clinician listens for and strategically reinforces change talk — client statements favoring change — while softening sustain talk — statements favoring the status quo. Change talk can be categorized using the DARN-CAT framework:
Preparatory change talk (DARN): Desire ("I want to..."), Ability ("I could..."), Reasons ("Because..."), Need ("I have to...")
Mobilizing change talk (CAT): Commitment ("I will..."), Activation ("I'm ready to..."), Taking steps ("I already started...")

Research shows that higher frequency of change talk relative to sustain talk predicts actual behavior change. The clinician uses strategic reflections and questions to differentially evoke and reinforce change talk.

When a client expresses ambivalence (e.g., "I know drinking is hurting my liver, but it's the only way I relax"), the MI-consistent response is a double-sided reflection that acknowledges both sides of the ambivalence while subtly emphasizing the change side: "On one hand, alcohol has been your go-to way to unwind, and on the other hand, you're concerned about the real damage it's doing to your health." This respects autonomy while developing discrepancy.

section_title: Relapse Prevention and Behavioral Treatments for SUDs

anchors.text: Relapse prevention (RP) is a cognitive-behavioral approach that conceptualizes relapse as a predictable process with identifiable precursors. Key concepts include:
High-risk situations: Circumstances that increase vulnerability to substance use (e.g., negative emotions, interpersonal conflict, social pressure, cue exposure)

Seemingly irrelevant decisions (SIDs): Apparently minor choices that progressively move the person closer to a high-risk situation (e.g., an individual in recovery who decides to take "the scenic route home" that passes their former dealer's neighborhood)

Abstinence violation effect (AVE): The cognitive-emotional reaction to a lapse, characterized by internal attribution ("I'm weak") and a sense of loss of control, which increases the probability that the lapse will escalate to a full relapse. Challenging the AVE is a core RP strategy.

Example: A client in recovery identifies that negative affect after arguments with their spouse is their primary high-risk situation. In RP, they develop coping strategies for managing anger (e.g., calling a sponsor, using relaxation techniques), identify early warning signs of the relapse chain, recognize SIDs (e.g., agreeing to attend a party where alcohol will be present after a fight), and plan responses to any lapses to prevent the AVE from triggering full relapse.

In RP, they develop coping strategies for managing anger (e.g., calling a sponsor, using relaxation techniques), identify early warning signs of the relapse chain, recognize SIDs (e.g., agreeing to attend a party where alcohol will be present after a fight), and plan responses to any lapses to prevent the AVE from triggering full relapse.

section_title: Relapse Prevention and Behavioral Treatments for SUDs

anchors.text: Contingency management applies operant conditioning principles by providing tangible reinforcers (typically vouchers redeemable for goods and services) for objectively verified drug-free urine samples or treatment attendance. The voucher value typically increases with consecutive drug-free samples and resets to the initial value after a positive sample. CM has among the highest effect sizes of any substance use treatment, particularly for stimulant use disorders.

CM is grounded in the operant principle that behaviors followed by reinforcement are more likely to recur. Two major CM approaches include: (1) Voucher-Based Reinforcement Therapy (VBRT) — vouchers increase in value with consecutive negative samples (escalating reinforcement schedule) and reset after a positive sample, and (2) Prize-Based CM (fishbowl method) — clients earn draws from a fishbowl containing slips for prizes of varying value. The prize-based approach is more cost-effective as most draws yield low-value prizes or encouraging messages, yet the intermittent reinforcement schedule maintains motivation. CM is particularly effective for stimulant use disorders where no pharmacotherapy exists.

section_title: Relapse Prevention and Behavioral Treatments for SUDs

anchors.text: CBT for substance use disorders teaches clients to identify and modify maladaptive thoughts and behaviors associated with substance use. Key components include:
Functional analysis: Identifying the antecedents (triggers), behaviors (substance use), and consequences that maintain the addiction cycle
Coping skills training: Developing alternative responses to high-risk situations, including drink/drug refusal skills, managing cravings (urge surfing), anger management, and assertiveness training
Cognitive restructuring: Challenging permission-giving thoughts (e.g., "I deserve a drink after this week") and seemingly irrelevant decisions

Example: Urge surfing is a mindfulness-based technique from relapse prevention in which clients learn to observe cravings without acting on them. Rather than fighting or suppressing the urge, the client is taught to "ride the wave" — noticing the craving rise, peak, and naturally subside. This technique is based on the principle that cravings are time-limited and will pass if not reinforced by substance use.

section_title: Relapse Prevention and Behavioral Treatments for SUDs

anchors.text: TSF is a manualized, therapist-delivered intervention designed to facilitate engagement with Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) and other 12-step programs. Based on findings from Project MATCH — the largest psychotherapy trial for alcohol use disorders — TSF was as effective as CBT and MET (Motivational Enhancement Therapy). TSF works primarily by increasing AA attendance and involvement, which mediates outcomes. Key mechanisms include acceptance of the disease model, surrender to a higher power, and active participation in the fellowship community.

The landmark Project MATCH study compared TSF, CBT, and MET for alcohol use disorder and found that all three treatments produced significant and roughly equivalent reductions in drinking. The primary patient-treatment matching hypothesis was largely unsupported — few significant matching effects were found. The main finding that matching did not substantially improve outcomes challenged assumptions about treatment-patient matching and supported the value of multiple evidence-based approaches.

section_title: Relapse Prevention and Behavioral Treatments for SUDs

anchors.text: SBIRT (Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment) is an evidence-based framework for delivering early intervention for individuals with risky substance use in non-specialty settings such as primary care, emergency departments, and college health centers. The brief intervention component typically lasts 5-15 minutes and uses MI principles to provide personalized feedback about substance use risks, increase motivation for change, and develop a plan. SBIRT is most effective for reducing hazardous alcohol use in adults who have not yet developed dependence.

Common screening tools include: CAGE (4 yes/no questions: Cut down, Annoyed, Guilty, Eye-opener — 2+ positive answers suggest problem drinking), AUDIT (Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test — 10 items, WHO-developed, distinguishes hazardous from harmful drinking), and DAST (Drug Abuse Screening Test — 28 items assessing consequences of drug use). These are screening tools, not diagnostic instruments.

section_title: Relapse Prevention and Behavioral Treatments for SUDs

anchors.text: Naltrexone — Opioid antagonist; blocks euphoric effects — Alcohol and opioid use disorders
Buprenorphine — Partial opioid agonist; reduces cravings/withdrawal — Opioid use disorder
Methadone — Full opioid agonist; prevents withdrawal, reduces craving — Opioid use disorder (dispensed in clinics)
Disulfiram (Antabuse) — Aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor; causes nausea if alcohol consumed — Alcohol use disorder (aversive conditioning)
Acamprosate — NMDA/GABA modulation; reduces craving in abstinent patients — Alcohol use disorder (maintaining abstinence)

topic_name: Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) for Autism Spectrum Disorder

anchors.text: ABA is the most well-established intervention for autism spectrum disorder (ASD), particularly when delivered as Early Intensive Behavioral Intervention (EIBI) (25-40 hours per week, starting before age 4). ABA is grounded in learning theory and uses systematic application of reinforcement, prompting, shaping, chaining, and generalization to build adaptive skills and reduce problem behaviors.

Discrete Trial Training (DTT): Structured, therapist-led teaching using a three-term contingency (discriminative stimulus, response, consequence). Tasks are broken into small, measurable components taught in a controlled setting.

Natural Environment Teaching (NET): Uses the child's interests and natural interactions as learning opportunities, promoting generalization. Follows the child's lead and uses naturally occurring reinforcers.

Functional Behavior Assessment (FBA): Identifies the function (antecedents and consequences) maintaining problem behaviors to develop function-based interventions. The four functions of behavior are: attention, escape/avoidance, access to tangibles, and automatic/sensory reinforcement.

FBA systematically identifies the antecedent-behavior-consequence (A-B-C) chain to determine WHY a behavior occurs. Methods include direct observation, structured interviews, and functional analysis (systematic manipulation of environmental variables). Interventions are then designed to address the function: if a child hits to escape demands, the intervention teaches an appropriate escape request (functional communication training).

ABA is grounded in learning theory and uses systematic application of reinforcement, prompting, shaping, chaining, and generalization to build adaptive skills and reduce problem behaviors.
[002] Discrete Trial Training (DTT): Structured, therapist-led teaching using a three-term contingency (discriminative stimulus, response, consequence). Tasks are broken into small, measurable components taught in a controlled setting.
[003] Natural Environment Teaching (NET): Uses the child's interests and natural interactions as learning opportunities, promoting generalization. Follows the child's lead and uses naturally occurring reinforcers.
[004] Functional Behavior Assessment (FBA): Identifies the function (antecedents and consequences) maintaining problem behaviors to develop function-based interventions. The four functions of behavior are: attention, escape/avoidance, access to tangibles, and automatic/sensory reinforcement.
[005] FBA systematically identifies the antecedent-behavior-consequence (A-B-C) chain to determine WHY a behavior occurs. Methods include direct observation, structured interviews, and functional analysis (systematic manipulation of environmental variables). Interventions are then designed to address the function: if a child hits to escape demands, the intervention teaches an appropriate escape request (functional communication training).

anchors.text: MI/MET — Alcohol, mixed substance use — Resolving ambivalence, developing discrepancy
CBT/RP — Alcohol, cocaine, cannabis — Coping skills, cognitive restructuring, AVE prevention
CM — Cocaine, methamphetamine, opioids — Positive reinforcement for verified abstinence
TSF — Alcohol — 12-step engagement and fellowship
CRA + Vouchers — Cocaine — Environmental restructuring + reinforcement

Both are parent-focused behavioral interventions for child conduct problems, but PCIT involves live coaching of parent-child interactions (in-session observation and feedback), while PMT typically involves teaching parenting skills through discussion, modeling, and role-play without live observation of parent-child interaction. PCIT has the unique feature of the therapist coaching the parent in real-time via an earpiece.

anchors.text: Beyond ABA, evidence-based approaches for social skills in autism spectrum disorder include:
Social Stories (Carol Gray): Short, individualized stories describing social situations, expected behaviors, and perspectives of others to teach social understanding
Video Modeling: Uses video demonstrations of target behaviors for the child to observe and imitate, capitalizing on visual learning strengths common in ASD

PEERS (Program for the Education and Enrichment of Relational Skills): Manualized social skills intervention for adolescents and young adults with ASD targeting conversational skills, electronic communication, choosing friends, and handling conflict

anchors.text: Stimulants (first-line) — Methylphenidate (Ritalin), Amphetamine (Adderall) — Increase dopamine and norepinephrine — 70-80% response rate; MTA study showed medication superior to behavioral for core ADHD symptoms
Non-stimulants — Atomoxetine (Strattera) — Selective NE reuptake inhibitor — Alternative when stimulants contraindicated; lower abuse potential; slower onset (2-4 weeks)
Alpha-2 agonists — Guanfacine (Intuniv), Clonidine (Kapvay) — Noradrenergic modulation — Often used adjunctively; help with hyperactivity and impulsivity; useful for comorbid tics

The landmark MTA study compared four conditions for childhood ADHD: medication management alone, intensive behavioral treatment alone, combined medication + behavioral treatment, and community care (control). Results showed that medication management was superior to behavioral treatment alone for core ADHD symptoms (inattention, hyperactivity-impulsivity). The combined condition showed advantages over medication alone for comorbid symptoms (anxiety, oppositional behavior, social skills) and parent-child relations.
