DIF analysis statistically identifies such items for review and possible removal.
[002] Predictive Bias (Differential Prediction): A test shows predictive bias if the regression equation relating the test score to the criterion differs across groups. If a test overpredicts or underpredicts criterion performance for a particular group, the test is said to show predictive bias for that group. Research has generally shown that standardized cognitive tests slightly overpredict the academic performance of minority groups rather than underpredict it.
[003] Construct Bias: A test measures different constructs in different groups. For example, a verbal reasoning test may primarily measure verbal ability for native English speakers but may additionally measure English language proficiency for non-native speakers.
[004] Item Bias (DIF) — Group differences in item performance at equal trait levels — DIF analysis (Mantel-Haenszel, IRT methods)
[005] Predictive Bias — Different regression lines for different groups — Moderated regression analysis
[006] Construct Bias — Test measures different constructs across groups — Measurement invariance, factor analysis

anchors.text: Measurement invariance (measurement equivalence) is the psychometric property that a test measures the same construct in the same way across different groups. Without measurement invariance, group comparisons on test scores are not meaningful. Testing for measurement invariance typically proceeds through increasingly restrictive levels:
Configural invariance: The same factor structure holds across groups
Metric invariance: Factor loadings are equal across groups
Scalar invariance: Item intercepts are equal across groups (required for meaningful mean comparisons)
Strict invariance: Residual variances are equal across groups

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Assessment Ethics: Test Fairness & Security > Test Bias and Fairness > Measurement Invariance
anchors_text:
[001] Measurement invariance (measurement equivalence) is the psychometric property that a test measures the same construct in the same way across different groups. Without measurement invariance, group comparisons on test scores are not meaningful. Testing for measurement invariance typically proceeds through increasingly restrictive levels:
[002] Configural invariance: The same factor structure holds across groups
[003] Metric invariance: Factor loadings are equal across groups
[004] Scalar invariance: Item intercepts are equal across groups (required for meaningful mean comparisons)
[005] Strict invariance: Residual variances are equal across groups

anchors.text: Several models of test fairness have been proposed, and these are not always compatible with each other:
Unqualified individualism: The same test and cutoff should be used for all examinees regardless of group membership
Quotas: Selection proportions should match the proportions of applicants from each group

Qualified individualism (regression model): A test is fair if it has equal regression slopes and intercepts across groups (Cleary's definition — the most widely accepted psychometric definition of fairness)
Equal probability model: A test is fair if examinees with equal probability of success on the criterion have equal probability of being selected regardless of group membership

[002] Unqualified individualism: The same test and cutoff should be used for all examinees regardless of group membership
[003] Quotas: Selection proportions should match the proportions of applicants from each group
[004] Qualified individualism (regression model): A test is fair if it has equal regression slopes and intercepts across groups (Cleary's definition — the most widely accepted psychometric definition of fairness)
[005] Equal probability model: A test is fair if examinees with equal probability of success on the criterion have equal probability of being selected regardless of group membership

section_title: Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing

anchors.text: Psychologists have an ethical obligation to maintain test security (Standard 9.11) by protecting test items, protocols, and scoring algorithms from unauthorized disclosure. Threats to test security include:
Internet disclosure: Posting test items online compromises validity for all future examinees
Unauthorized coaching: Providing examinees with specific test content prior to evaluation invalidates results
Inappropriate release: Releasing test materials (as opposed to test data) to unqualified individuals
Inadequate storage: Failing to secure physical and electronic test materials

When faced with conflicting demands (e.g., a court order to release test materials), psychologists should attempt to resolve the conflict by educating the court about test security concerns, requesting in camera (private) review, or requesting that access be limited to qualified professionals.

[004] Inappropriate release: Releasing test materials (as opposed to test data) to unqualified individuals
[005] Inadequate storage: Failing to secure physical and electronic test materials
[006] When faced with conflicting demands (e.g., a court order to release test materials), psychologists should attempt to resolve the conflict by educating the court about test security concerns, requesting in camera (private) review, or requesting that access be limited to qualified professionals.

section_title: Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing

anchors.text: Culturally competent assessment requires attention to multiple factors that may affect test validity across cultural groups:
Language considerations: Testing should generally be conducted in the examinee's dominant language. Use of interpreters introduces additional error variance and should be documented.
Acculturation level: The degree to which an individual has adopted the values, behaviors, and norms of the dominant culture affects the applicability of normative data.
Culturally appropriate instruments: Some tests have been developed or adapted for specific cultural groups (e.g., TEMAS for Hispanic and Black youth — a multicultural apperception test).
Norm applicability: Clinicians must consider whether the normative sample adequately represents the examinee's demographic group.

Example: A psychologist evaluates a recently immigrated 8-year-old child whose family speaks primarily Spanish at home. The child is referred for possible intellectual disability. Using the WISC-V English version alone would be inappropriate, as the VCI would likely underestimate the child's verbal abilities due to language barriers. The psychologist should consider: (1) administering a nonverbal measure such as the Universal Nonverbal Intelligence Test (UNIT-2) or Leiter-3, (2) using the Spanish-language WISC-V if appropriate, (3) supplementing with adaptive behavior assessment, and (4) carefully documenting the linguistic context and its potential impact on results.

[006] Example: A psychologist evaluates a recently immigrated 8-year-old child whose family speaks primarily Spanish at home. The child is referred for possible intellectual disability. Using the WISC-V English version alone would be inappropriate, as the VCI would likely underestimate the child's verbal abilities due to language barriers. The psychologist should consider: (1) administering a nonverbal measure such as the Universal Nonverbal Intelligence Test (UNIT-2) or Leiter-3, (2) using the Spanish-language WISC-V if appropriate, (3) supplementing with adaptive behavior assessment, and (4) carefully documenting the linguistic context and its potential impact on results.

anchors.text: The APA's Specialty Guidelines for Forensic Psychology supplement the Ethics Code for psychologists working in forensic contexts. Key principles include:
Forensic practitioners should have competence in both psychology and the legal system
The forensic role should be clearly distinguished from the therapeutic role
Multiple relationships between forensic and therapeutic roles with the same individual should be avoided when possible
Forensic opinions should be based on sufficient examination or clearly state the basis for and limitations of opinions offered without personal examination
Reports should present findings in a balanced manner, including data that do not support the referral source's preferred conclusion

[004] Multiple relationships between forensic and therapeutic roles with the same individual should be avoided when possible
[005] Forensic opinions should be based on sufficient examination or clearly state the basis for and limitations of opinions offered without personal examination
[006] Reports should present findings in a balanced manner, including data that do not support the referral source's preferred conclusion

anchors.text: When a third party (employer, attorney, insurer) requests the evaluation, the psychologist must clarify the nature of the relationship with all parties at the outset, including who the client is, what services will be provided, who will have access to results, and the limits of confidentiality.

Example: A defense attorney requests a psychological evaluation of their client for a competency hearing. The psychologist must inform the client (the defendant) that: (a) the psychologist was retained by the attorney, (b) the evaluation results will be shared with the attorney, (c) the results may or may not be presented in court depending on the attorney's strategy, (d) the evaluation is not a therapeutic relationship, and (e) the usual limits of confidentiality may not apply in a forensic context.

[002] Example: A defense attorney requests a psychological evaluation of their client for a competency hearing. The psychologist must inform the client (the defendant) that: (a) the psychologist was retained by the attorney, (b) the evaluation results will be shared with the attorney, (c) the results may or may not be presented in court depending on the attorney's strategy, (d) the evaluation is not a therapeutic relationship, and (e) the usual limits of confidentiality may not apply in a forensic context.

anchors.text: Edward Bordin proposed a pantheoretical model of the working alliance comprising three interdependent components:
Tasks: Agreement between therapist and client on the in-session activities and behaviors that constitute the therapy process
Goals: Mutual agreement on the targets or outcomes of therapy
Bond: The quality of the interpersonal attachment between therapist and client, including mutual trust, respect, acceptance, and confidence

Research consistently demonstrates that the alliance accounts for approximately 5-8% of outcome variance, making it a modest but robust and reliable predictor. Importantly, the client's perception of the alliance is a stronger predictor of outcome than the therapist's perception.

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Therapeutic Relationships & Boundaries > The Therapeutic Alliance > Bordin's Working Alliance Model
anchors_text:
[001] Edward Bordin proposed a pantheoretical model of the working alliance comprising three interdependent components:
[002] Tasks: Agreement between therapist and client on the in-session activities and behaviors that constitute the therapy process
[003] Goals: Mutual agreement on the targets or outcomes of therapy
[004] Bond: The quality of the interpersonal attachment between therapist and client, including mutual trust, respect, acceptance, and confidence
[005] Research consistently demonstrates that the alliance accounts for approximately 5-8% of outcome variance, making it a modest but robust and reliable predictor. Importantly, the client's perception of the alliance is a stronger predictor of outcome than the therapist's perception.

anchors.text: Several validated instruments are used to assess the therapeutic alliance:
Working Alliance Inventory (WAI): Based on Bordin's model; client, therapist, and observer versions available. Most widely used alliance measure in psychotherapy research.
Session Rating Scale (SRS): Ultra-brief (4-item) visual analog measure designed for session-by-session alliance monitoring as part of routine outcome monitoring (ROM).
Helping Alliance Questionnaire (HAq): Luborsky's measure assessing the client's perception of the therapist as supportive and the sense of working together.

Routine outcome monitoring systems such as the OQ-45 (Outcome Questionnaire) and PCOMS (Partners for Change Outcome Management System) combine alliance measurement with outcome tracking to provide real-time feedback to therapists, reducing deterioration rates and improving outcomes.

Alliance ruptures are breakdowns in the collaborative relationship, manifested as disagreements about tasks or goals, or strains in the bond. Ruptures can be withdrawal (client disengages, becomes compliant but not invested) or confrontation (client expresses dissatisfaction or hostility). Successful repair of ruptures is associated with improved outcomes and may be a key mechanism of therapeutic change, particularly for clients with interpersonal difficulties.

anchors.text: Michael Lambert's research identified four common factors that contribute to therapeutic outcome:
Extratherapeutic Factors — ~40% — Client variables, spontaneous remission, life events, social support
Therapeutic Relationship — ~30% — Empathy, warmth, acceptance, alliance quality
Expectancy/Placebo — ~15% — Hope, credibility of the treatment rationale
Technique — ~15% — Specific interventions and procedures unique to each approach

While these percentages are approximate and debated, they underscore that relationship factors contribute more to outcome than specific techniques alone. This finding supports the common factors perspective and has implications for training and supervision.

section_title: Boundaries, Dual Relationships, and Sexual Ethics

anchors.text: Standard 3.05 states that a psychologist refrains from entering into a multiple (dual) relationship if the relationship could reasonably be expected to impair objectivity, competence, or effectiveness, or could risk exploitation or harm. Multiple relationships that would not reasonably be expected to cause impairment or risk exploitation are not unethical. The standard recognizes that some multiple relationships are unavoidable, particularly in rural, military, and small community settings.

Example: A psychologist in a small rural town discovers that the only dentist in the area is also a current therapy client. Avoiding dental care entirely would be impractical. The Ethics Code does not prohibit this incidental contact but requires the psychologist to be mindful of how the dual relationship might affect the therapeutic relationship and to take steps to minimize potential harm, such as discussing the situation openly in therapy.

The standard recognizes that some multiple relationships are unavoidable, particularly in rural, military, and small community settings.
[002] Example: A psychologist in a small rural town discovers that the only dentist in the area is also a current therapy client. Avoiding dental care entirely would be impractical. The Ethics Code does not prohibit this incidental contact but requires the psychologist to be mindful of how the dual relationship might affect the therapeutic relationship and to take steps to minimize potential harm, such as discussing the situation openly in therapy.

section_title: Boundaries, Dual Relationships, and Sexual Ethics

anchors.text: Standard 10.05: Psychologists do NOT engage in sexual intimacies with current therapy clients/patients.
Standard 10.06: Psychologists do NOT accept as therapy clients/patients persons with whom they have engaged in sexual intimacies.
Standard 10.07: Psychologists do NOT engage in sexual intimacies with individuals they know to be close relatives, guardians, or significant others of current clients/patients.

Standard 10.08 (Two-Year Rule): Psychologists do NOT engage in sexual intimacies with former clients/patients for at least two years after cessation or termination of therapy. Even after two years, the psychologist must demonstrate that the relationship is not exploitative, considering factors such as time elapsed, the nature and duration of therapy, circumstances of termination, the client's personal history, and current mental status. The burden of proof rests entirely on the psychologist.

The two-year rule in Standard 10.08 creates a mandatory minimum waiting period, NOT a safe harbor. After two years, sexual contact with a former client is permissible ONLY if the psychologist can demonstrate it is not exploitative across multiple factors. In most clinical scenarios on the EPPP, the answer is that the psychologist should NOT pursue the relationship even after two years, because the power differential and potential for exploitation persist.

anchors.text: Gift exchange between therapist and client is a common boundary issue. Important considerations include:

Client gifts to therapist: Small, culturally appropriate gifts (e.g., a holiday card) are generally acceptable. Expensive or frequent gifts may indicate transference dynamics and should be explored therapeutically.

Therapist gifts to client: Generally discouraged as they can blur boundaries, create obligation, or introduce the therapist's personal values. Exceptions may include small gestures at termination of long-term treatment.
Cultural context: In some cultures, gift-giving is an important social norm and refusing a gift may be experienced as a rejection. Cultural sensitivity must guide the response.

[003] Therapist gifts to client: Generally discouraged as they can blur boundaries, create obligation, or introduce the therapist's personal values. Exceptions may include small gestures at termination of long-term treatment.
[004] Cultural context: In some cultures, gift-giving is an important social norm and refusing a gift may be experienced as a rejection. Cultural sensitivity must guide the response.

anchors.text: Therapist self-disclosure — sharing personal information or experiences with clients — is viewed differently across theoretical orientations. Psychodynamic approaches traditionally minimize self-disclosure to maintain the "blank screen" necessary for transference analysis. Humanistic and relational approaches view judicious self-disclosure as potentially beneficial for the therapeutic relationship. Research suggests that self-disclosure is most beneficial when it is:
Infrequent and brief
Focused on normalizing the client's experience or building the alliance
Not used to meet the therapist's own emotional needs
Relevant to the client's therapeutic issues

anchors.text: John Norcross's APA Division 29 task force identified specific relationship elements that are demonstrably effective, probably effective, or promising based on meta-analytic evidence:
Demonstrably Effective — Alliance, empathy, goal consensus/collaboration, positive regard/affirmation, congruence/genuineness
Probably Effective — Collecting client feedback, repairing alliance ruptures, managing countertransference, promoting treatment credibility
Promising — Self-disclosure, immediacy, emotional expression
This research supports the integration of both relationship and technique factors in effective psychotherapy rather than an either/or approach.

anchors.text: Research demonstrates that therapist variables contribute significantly to outcome variability. Key therapist factors include:

Empathic attunement: Rogers identified empathy, unconditional positive regard, and genuineness/congruence as the necessary and sufficient conditions for therapeutic change. While the "sufficient" claim is debated, these conditions are consistently associated with positive outcomes.

Cultural humility: An ongoing process of self-reflection and self-critique regarding one's own cultural assumptions. Unlike cultural competence (which implies an achievable endpoint), cultural humility emphasizes the lifelong nature of learning about others' cultural identities and experiences.

Therapist effects: Research shows that approximately 5-9% of outcome variance is attributable to the individual therapist, independent of treatment modality. Some therapists are consistently more effective than others across different clients and presenting problems.

[003] Cultural humility: An ongoing process of self-reflection and self-critique regarding one's own cultural assumptions. Unlike cultural competence (which implies an achievable endpoint), cultural humility emphasizes the lifelong nature of learning about others' cultural identities and experiences.
[004] Therapist effects: Research shows that approximately 5-9% of outcome variance is attributable to the individual therapist, independent of treatment modality. Some therapists are consistently more effective than others across different clients and presenting problems.

anchors.text: Psychologists terminate therapy when it becomes reasonably clear that the client no longer needs the service, is not benefiting from it, or is being harmed by continued treatment. Prior to termination, the psychologist provides pretermination counseling and suggests alternative service providers when appropriate.
Psychologists may terminate for many reasons, but ethical termination requires:
Adequate notice to the client
Discussion of the client's current needs and progress
Appropriate referrals when continued treatment is needed
Documentation of the termination process

Abandonment occurs when a psychologist terminates treatment without reasonable notice or appropriate referral when the client still needs services. Non-payment alone is typically insufficient grounds for immediate termination without providing referral options.

[005] Appropriate referrals when continued treatment is needed

anchors.text: Sell v. United States established criteria for involuntary medication of incompetent defendants solely for the purpose of competency restoration. The government must demonstrate: (1) an important governmental interest is at stake, (2) medication is substantially likely to render the defendant competent, (3) medication is substantially unlikely to have side effects that interfere with the defendant's ability to assist counsel, and (4) no less intrusive alternative exists. This ruling balances the government's interest in prosecution against the defendant's liberty interest in refusing medication.

Research indicates that approximately 70-80% of defendants referred for competency restoration are successfully restored, most within 6 months. Factors associated with failure to restore include intellectual disability, chronic psychotic disorders with medication resistance, and neurocognitive disorders such as dementia. For defendants who cannot be restored, civil commitment proceedings may be initiated under Jackson v. Indiana standards.

section_title: Duty to Warn/Protect and Privileged Communication
topic_name: Tarasoff v. Regents of the University of California

anchors.text: The Tarasoff case established the precedent for mental health professionals' duty to protect identifiable potential victims of client violence.
Tarasoff I: Established a duty to warn — the therapist must warn the identified potential victim

Tarasoff II: Broadened to a duty to protect — the therapist must take reasonable steps to protect the potential victim, which may include warning but also hospitalization, notification of police, or other interventions

The duty to protect applies when the therapist determines (or should have determined) that the client poses a serious threat of violence to a reasonably identifiable victim. States vary considerably in their implementation of Tarasoff principles — some have codified the duty by statute, others apply it through case law, and a few have explicitly rejected it.

Example: A client tells their therapist, "If my ex-wife brings her new boyfriend to my daughter's recital next week, I'm going to kill him." The therapist must assess whether this represents a serious, imminent threat to a reasonably identifiable victim. Factors to consider include: the specificity of the threat (identified person, time, and place), the client's history of violence, access to means, and current mental state. If the therapist concludes the threat is credible, the duty to protect may require warning the identified potential victim, notifying law enforcement, adjusting treatment (e.g., voluntary or involuntary hospitalization), or a combination of these interventions.

[004] The duty to protect applies when the therapist determines (or should have determined) that the client poses a serious threat of violence to a reasonably identifiable victim. States vary considerably in their implementation of Tarasoff principles — some have codified the duty by statute, others apply it through case law, and a few have explicitly rejected it.
[005] Example: A client tells their therapist, "If my ex-wife brings her new boyfriend to my daughter's recital next week, I'm going to kill him." The therapist must assess whether this represents a serious, imminent threat to a reasonably identifiable victim. Factors to consider include: the specificity of the threat (identified person, time, and place), the client's history of violence, access to means, and current mental state. If the therapist concludes the threat is credible, the duty to protect may require warning the identified potential victim, notifying law enforcement, adjusting treatment (e.g., voluntary or involuntary hospitalization), or a combination of these interventions.

section_title: Duty to Warn/Protect and Privileged Communication

anchors.text: Jaffee v. Redmond established psychotherapist-patient privilege in federal courts. The Supreme Court recognized that confidential communications between a licensed psychotherapist (including licensed social workers) and their patients are protected from compelled disclosure in federal proceedings. The privilege belongs to the client, not the therapist, and can be waived only by the client.

Confidentiality is a broader ethical obligation to protect client information from disclosure. Privilege is a narrower legal right that protects against compelled disclosure in judicial proceedings. A communication can be confidential but not privileged (e.g., a therapist could be legally compelled to testify), or both confidential and privileged. Privilege is established by statute or case law and varies by jurisdiction.

The Supreme Court recognized that confidential communications between a licensed psychotherapist (including licensed social workers) and their patients are protected from compelled disclosure in federal proceedings. The privilege belongs to the client, not the therapist, and can be waived only by the client.
[002] Confidentiality is a broader ethical obligation to protect client information from disclosure. Privilege is a narrower legal right that protects against compelled disclosure in judicial proceedings. A communication can be confidential but not privileged (e.g., a therapist could be legally compelled to testify), or both confidential and privileged. Privilege is established by statute or case law and varies by jurisdiction.

section_title: Duty to Warn/Protect and Privileged Communication

anchors.text: Psychotherapist-patient privilege is not absolute. Common exceptions include:
Danger to self or others: When the client poses imminent risk of harm (consistent with Tarasoff duties)
Child abuse reporting: All states have mandatory reporting laws for suspected child abuse or neglect that override privilege
Court-ordered evaluations: When the evaluation is ordered by the court, privilege typically does not apply because the relationship is not therapeutic

Client raises mental health as an issue: If the client puts their mental health at issue in litigation (e.g., suing for emotional damages), they may waive privilege regarding relevant treatment records
Malpractice claims: If the client sues the therapist, the therapist may disclose relevant information in self-defense

anchors.text: The Daubert standard is the federal standard for admissibility of expert testimony. The trial judge serves as "gatekeeper" and evaluates whether the expert's testimony is based on:
Testability: Can the theory or technique be (and has it been) tested?
Peer review and publication: Has the theory or technique been subjected to peer review?
Known error rate: Is the error rate of the technique known and acceptable?
General acceptance: Is the theory or technique generally accepted in the relevant scientific community?
Additionally, the testimony must be relevant (helpful to the trier of fact) and reliable (based on sufficient facts/data and reliable principles/methods).

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Legal & Forensic Psychology > Standards for Expert Testimony > Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals
anchors_text:
[001] The Daubert standard is the federal standard for admissibility of expert testimony. The trial judge serves as "gatekeeper" and evaluates whether the expert's testimony is based on:
[002] Testability: Can the theory or technique be (and has it been) tested?
[003] Peer review and publication: Has the theory or technique been subjected to peer review?
[004] Known error rate: Is the error rate of the technique known and acceptable?
[005] General acceptance: Is the theory or technique generally accepted in the relevant scientific community?
[006] Additionally, the testimony must be relevant (helpful to the trier of fact) and reliable (based on sufficient facts/data and reliable principles/methods).

anchors.text: The older Frye standard ("general acceptance test") required only that the scientific theory or technique had gained general acceptance in the relevant scientific community. Frye is still used in some state courts but has been largely superseded by Daubert in federal courts and many state jurisdictions.

Whether forensic psychologists should offer opinions on the ultimate legal issue (e.g., "Was the defendant insane?") is debated. Federal Rule of Evidence 704(b) prohibits expert witnesses from stating an opinion about whether a criminal defendant had the mental state required for the offense (the ultimate issue). Many forensic psychology guidelines recommend that experts limit testimony to clinical findings and opinions while leaving the ultimate legal determination to the trier of fact (judge or jury). This approach respects the boundary between clinical expertise and legal decision-making.
Jurisdiction — Federal courts (and many states) — Some state courts
Gatekeeper — Trial judge — Scientific community
Criteria — Testability, peer review, error rate, general acceptance — General acceptance only
Flexibility — Multi-factor; more flexible — Single factor; more restrictive for novel science

Federal Rule of Evidence 704(b) prohibits expert witnesses from stating an opinion about whether a criminal defendant had the mental state required for the offense (the ultimate issue). Many forensic psychology guidelines recommend that experts limit testimony to clinical findings and opinions while leaving the ultimate legal determination to the trier of fact (judge or jury). anchors.text: O'Connor v. Donaldson — 1975 — A non-dangerous, mentally ill person who can survive safely in freedom cannot be involuntarily confined. Mental illness alone is insufficient.

Addington v. Texas — 1979 — The standard of proof for civil commitment must be at least "clear and convincing evidence" — higher than civil "preponderance of evidence" but lower than criminal "beyond a reasonable doubt."
Wyatt v. Stickney — 1971 — Established the right to treatment in the least restrictive environment for involuntarily committed individuals.
Youngberg v. Romeo — 1982 — Involuntarily committed individuals have constitutional rights to safety, freedom from unnecessary restraint, and minimally adequate training/habilitation.

[003] Wyatt v. Stickney — 1971 — Established the right to treatment in the least restrictive environment for involuntarily committed individuals.
[004] Youngberg v. Romeo — 1982 — Involuntarily committed individuals have constitutional rights to safety, freedom from unnecessary restraint, and minimally adequate training/habilitation.

anchors.text: The IDM is the most widely known developmental model of supervision. It proposes that supervisees progress through predictable developmental levels across eight specific domains of clinical practice (intervention skills competence, assessment techniques, interpersonal assessment, client conceptualization, individual differences, theoretical orientation, treatment plans and goals, and professional ethics). Each level is characterized by distinct patterns of motivation, autonomy, and self-and-other awareness:
Level 1 — High (anxious enthusiasm) — Low (dependent on supervisor) — Self-focused, limited awareness — Structured, directive, supportive; skill-building focus
Level 2 — Fluctuating (confusion, frustration) — Vacillating (dependency-autonomy conflict) — Oscillating focus between self and client — Less structure, more autonomy; process exploration
Level 3 — Stable, realistic — Conditional dependency (consults when needed) — Balanced, empathic, self-aware — Collegial, consultative; minimal structure
Level 3i — Integrated — Master practitioner — Integrated personal and professional identity — Peer consultation; self-supervision

The IDM predicts that Level 2 supervisees experience the most difficulty — they have enough experience to recognize the complexity of clinical work but not yet enough competence to manage it confidently. This level is characterized by a "trial-and-tribulation" phase with fluctuating motivation and the emergence of a dependency-autonomy conflict. Supervisors must resist the urge to become overly directive and instead support the supervisee through this transitional period.

anchors.text: The Discrimination Model identifies three supervisor roles and three focus areas, creating a flexible 3 x 3 matrix:

Supervisor Roles: Teacher (instructing, providing information), Counselor (exploring supervisee's personal reactions and blind spots), Consultant (encouraging supervisee's own problem-solving and professional judgment)

Focus Areas: Intervention skills (what the supervisee does in session), Conceptualization skills (how the supervisee understands the client), Personalization skills (how the supervisee's personal characteristics affect clinical work)

The supervisor selects the appropriate role and focus based on the supervisee's needs in each moment. For example, a supervisor might take the teacher role to address intervention skills but shift to the counselor role when exploring personalization issues. The model emphasizes flexibility — the supervisor should avoid becoming "stuck" in any one role and should be responsive to the supervisee's shifting needs within and across sessions.
Intervention — Instruct on techniques — Explore personal reactions to techniques — Brainstorm approach options
Conceptualization — Teach case formulation models — Explore blind spots in understanding — Encourage independent formulation
Personalization — Normalize personal reactions — Process countertransference — Encourage self-reflection

anchors.text: Competency-based supervision represents a paradigm shift from process-oriented supervision to outcome-oriented supervision. It is grounded in the identification of specific, measurable competency benchmarks that supervisees must achieve at each training level. The APA Competency Benchmarks framework identifies foundational competencies (professionalism, reflective practice, scientific knowledge, relationships, diversity, ethics) and functional competencies (assessment, intervention, consultation, research, supervision, teaching, management).

Supervision is oriented toward documenting progress toward these benchmarks through ongoing formative and summative evaluation and feedback. This approach aligns with the broader culture of competence movement in professional psychology and is consistent with accreditation requirements. Competency-based supervision requires the use of direct observation methods (live observation, video review, co-therapy) rather than relying solely on supervisee self-report.

Example: Research consistently shows that supervisors who rely solely on supervisee self-report have limited and potentially distorted access to the supervisee's actual clinical performance. Best practices include: live observation (through one-way mirror or sitting in), video recording review, audio recording review, co-therapy (supervisor and supervisee work together with the client), and live supervision (real-time guidance via bug-in-ear, phone-in, or monitor). Direct observation is considered essential for competency-based evaluation.

anchors.text: Just as the therapeutic alliance predicts therapy outcomes, the supervisory working alliance predicts supervision outcomes including supervisee satisfaction, skill development, and professional growth. Bordin's alliance model identifies three components: agreement on tasks (the specific activities that take place in supervision), agreement on goals (the desired outcomes of supervision), and the emotional bond (mutual trust, respect, and liking between supervisor and supervisee).

Ruptures in the supervisory alliance require the same attentive repair as therapeutic alliance ruptures. However, the power differential in supervision makes alliance repair more complex — supervisees may be reluctant to express dissatisfaction for fear of negative evaluation. Supervisors must actively create conditions that allow supervisees to provide honest feedback about the supervisory process. Research shows that unresolved supervisory alliance ruptures are associated with nondisclosure by supervisees, reduced learning, and negative supervisory outcomes.

anchors.text: Gatekeeping is the supervisor's ethical responsibility to protect the public by ensuring that only competent trainees advance in the profession. This includes identifying and addressing supervisee impairment or problems of professional competence (PPC) — performance deficits that are not merely developmental but represent significant departures from expected competence levels. PPCs are distinguished from normal developmental struggles by their severity, chronicity, resistance to remediation, and impact on professional functioning.

When PPCs are identified, the supervisor should implement a formal remediation plan that includes: (1) clear description of the competence concern; (2) specific, measurable benchmarks for remediation; (3) a timeline for achieving benchmarks; (4) additional support and resources to be provided; (5) consequences if benchmarks are not met; and (6) procedures for monitoring progress. If remediation fails, the supervisor must pursue more significant actions, which may include probation, additional training requirements, leave of absence, or dismissal from the training program.

Ethical gatekeeping requires adherence to due process: (1) clear communication of evaluation criteria and expectations at the outset of supervision; (2) timely notification when concerns arise; (3) opportunity for the supervisee to respond to concerns; (4) documented remediation efforts; (5) appeal procedures; and (6) institutional support for the supervisor's gatekeeping decisions. Failure to follow due process can expose the supervisor and institution to legal action by the dismissed supervisee.

[002] When PPCs are identified, the supervisor should implement a formal remediation plan that includes: (1) clear description of the competence concern; (2) specific, measurable benchmarks for remediation; (3) a timeline for achieving benchmarks; (4) additional support and resources to be provided; (5) consequences if benchmarks are not met; and (6) procedures for monitoring progress. If remediation fails, the supervisor must pursue more significant actions, which may include probation, additional training requirements, leave of absence, or dismissal from the training program.

Failure to follow due process can expose the supervisor and institution to legal action by the dismissed supervisee.

anchors.text: Effective supervision requires attention to cultural dynamics within the supervisory relationship and the supervisee's clinical work. Supervisors must model multicultural competence, create a safe space for discussing cultural issues, explore how cultural identities (race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, religion, disability) affect the supervisory and therapeutic relationships, and address cultural blind spots in case conceptualization.

Key multicultural supervision tasks include: (1) initiating discussions about cultural factors rather than waiting for the supervisee to raise them; (2) exploring the cultural identities of supervisor, supervisee, and client and how these intersect; (3) examining power dynamics related to cultural identity within supervision; (4) addressing supervisee's cultural assumptions and biases in case conceptualization; and (5) helping supervisees develop culturally adapted interventions. Research indicates that supervisors who avoid cultural discussions create supervision environments perceived as less safe and less effective.

anchors.text: Supervision necessarily involves an evaluative component that distinguishes it from consultation or personal therapy. Effective evaluation includes:
Formative evaluation: Ongoing feedback during supervision aimed at guiding the supervisee's development; occurs throughout the supervisory relationship
Summative evaluation: Formal assessment of the supervisee's competence at specified intervals (e.g., end of rotation, end of training year); used for grading, advancement, or certification decisions
Clear criteria: Evaluation criteria should be communicated at the outset of supervision as part of informed consent
Documentation: Supervisors should maintain written records of supervision sessions, including topics discussed, recommendations made, and any concerns about supervisee competence

Supervision involves a formal evaluative relationship with authority and gatekeeping responsibilities; the supervisor is legally responsible for the supervisee's clients. Consultation is a voluntary, non-evaluative relationship between professional peers; the consultee retains full responsibility for the client. Personal therapy focuses on the clinician's personal issues; it should never be combined with supervision due to conflicting role demands. These distinctions are frequently tested on the EPPP.

anchors.text: Triadic supervision involves one supervisor with two supervisees simultaneously. This format combines elements of individual and group supervision — each supervisee receives individual attention while also benefiting from observing the other's supervision process. Triadic supervision is increasingly used in training programs as a cost-effective alternative to purely individual supervision.
Individual — Intensive, personalized, safe for personal exploration — Limited perspectives, resource-intensive
Group — Multiple perspectives, vicarious learning, cost-effective — Less individual attention, potential for conformity pressure
Triadic — Blends individual and group benefits, moderately efficient — Requires balancing attention between two supervisees
Peer — Non-hierarchical, ongoing professional development — No formal authority, does not count toward licensure
Live — Real-time intervention, direct observation — May be intrusive, logistically complex

Supervisors themselves need supervision of their supervisory practice, particularly when first learning to supervise. The APA Guidelines for Clinical Supervision in Health Service Psychology recommend that supervisors receive training in supervision methods, multicultural competence in supervision, evaluation practices, and the ethical and legal dimensions of the supervisory role. Many states now require specific training in supervision for those who provide it.

section_title: Legal and Ethical Issues in Supervision

anchors.text: Under the legal doctrine of respondeat superior ("let the master answer"), supervisors can be held legally liable for the actions of their supervisees. This vicarious liability applies because the supervisor has the authority to direct the supervisee's work and a duty to ensure competent care. Supervisors can also be held liable under direct liability for their own negligent supervisory acts, such as failing to provide adequate oversight, failing to obtain informed consent from clients regarding the supervisory arrangement, or failing to act on knowledge of the supervisee's incompetence.

To manage liability, supervisors should: maintain clear documentation of supervision sessions (including topics discussed, directives given, and supervisee progress); provide regular and timely oversight; ensure clients are informed that the clinician is a trainee under supervision; review high-risk cases (suicidal, homicidal, child abuse) promptly; and take corrective action when competence problems are identified.

Example: A supervisee fails to assess suicide risk in a client who subsequently makes a suicide attempt. The supervisor, who did not review the case or inquire about risk assessment, may be held vicariously liable because the supervisor had a duty to oversee the supervisee's clinical work and failed to do so. This underscores the importance of regular, documented case review in supervision.

section_title: Legal and Ethical Issues in Supervision

anchors.text: Both the supervisee and the supervisee's clients must provide informed consent. Client informed consent must include: (1) that their clinician is a trainee under supervision, (2) the name and credentials of the supervisor, (3) how the supervisor will access case material (e.g., audio/video recordings, case notes, live observation), (4) any implications for confidentiality (e.g., the supervisor will have access to clinical information), and (5) how to contact the supervisor if needed.

Supervisee informed consent must include: (1) goals and methods of supervision, (2) frequency and duration of supervision sessions, (3) evaluation criteria and procedures, (4) expectations for the supervisory relationship, (5) limits of confidentiality within supervision, (6) policies regarding emergency situations, and (7) procedures for addressing concerns or disputes.

[002] Supervisee informed consent must include: (1) goals and methods of supervision, (2) frequency and duration of supervision sessions, (3) evaluation criteria and procedures, (4) expectations for the supervisory relationship, (5) limits of confidentiality within supervision, (6) policies regarding emergency situations, and (7) procedures for addressing concerns or disputes.

section_title: Legal and Ethical Issues in Supervision

anchors.text: The inherent power differential in supervision makes dual relationships particularly concerning. Sexual relationships between supervisors and current supervisees are never ethical — this represents one of the clearest ethical prohibitions in the field. Other problematic dual relationships include: supervisor serving as the supervisee's personal therapist (creates conflicting evaluative and therapeutic roles), supervisor having a business relationship with the supervisee, supervisor being the supervisee's close friend or family member, and social relationships that compromise objectivity.

When unavoidable dual relationships exist (e.g., in rural or small community settings), the supervisor must take steps to manage potential harm: openly discuss the dual relationship, document its management, seek consultation, and prioritize the supervisee's welfare and the quality of client care.

anchors.text: Psychology licensure in the United States is regulated at the state level, with each state establishing its own requirements for education, supervised experience, and examination. Common requirements include: a doctoral degree from an APA-accredited program, completion of a predoctoral internship (typically APPIC-matched), a specified number of postdoctoral supervised hours (typically 1,500-2,000), and passing the Examination for Professional Practice in Psychology (EPPP). Some states also require a jurisprudence exam on state-specific laws and regulations.

The Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards (ASPPB) administers the EPPP and maintains the Psychology Interjurisdictional Compact (PSYPACT), which allows qualified psychologists to practice telepsychology across state borders without obtaining separate licensure in each state. Board certification through the American Board of Professional Psychology (ABPP) represents an advanced credential beyond licensure, available in specialty areas such as clinical, counseling, neuropsychology, forensic, and health psychology.

Common requirements include: a doctoral degree from an APA-accredited program, completion of a predoctoral internship (typically APPIC-matched), a specified number of postdoctoral supervised hours (typically 1,500-2,000), and passing the Examination for Professional Practice in Psychology (EPPP). Some states also require a jurisprudence exam on state-specific laws and regulations.
[002] The Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards (ASPPB) administers the EPPP and maintains the Psychology Interjurisdictional Compact (PSYPACT), which allows qualified psychologists to practice telepsychology across state borders without obtaining separate licensure in each state. Board certification through the American Board of Professional Psychology (ABPP) represents an advanced credential beyond licensure, available in specialty areas such as clinical, counseling, neuropsychology, forensic, and health psychology.

anchors.text: Burnout is an occupational syndrome characterized by three dimensions: emotional exhaustion (depleted emotional resources from the demands of work), depersonalization (cynicism, detachment, and negative attitudes toward clients), and reduced personal accomplishment (diminished feelings of competence and achievement). Burnout develops gradually in response to chronic workplace stressors including excessive caseloads, organizational demands, lack of autonomy, and insufficient support.

Compassion fatigue (also called secondary traumatic stress or vicarious traumatization) is a related but distinct concept referring to the emotional toll of working with traumatized populations. Unlike burnout, which develops gradually from workplace conditions, compassion fatigue can develop rapidly from exposure to clients' traumatic material. Vicarious traumatization (Pearlman & Saakvitne) refers to cumulative changes in the therapist's inner experience resulting from empathic engagement with clients' traumatic material, potentially affecting the therapist's sense of safety, trust, esteem, intimacy, and control.

Psychologists have an ethical obligation to monitor their own functioning and to seek appropriate help when personal problems may interfere with professional competence (Standard 2.06). Self-care strategies include maintaining work-life balance, seeking peer support and consultation, engaging in personal therapy when needed, practicing stress management techniques, maintaining clear professional boundaries, and engaging in regular self-assessment.

When psychologists become aware of personal problems that may interfere with their professional duties, they take appropriate measures such as obtaining professional consultation or assistance, and determine whether they should limit, suspend, or terminate their work-related duties. This standard creates an affirmative obligation to self-monitor and act proactively. Failure to address personal problems that impair professional functioning is itself an ethical violation.

Burnout develops gradually in response to chronic workplace stressors including excessive caseloads, organizational demands, lack of autonomy, and insufficient support.
[002] Compassion fatigue (also called secondary traumatic stress or vicarious traumatization) is a related but distinct concept referring to the emotional toll of working with traumatized populations. Unlike burnout, which develops gradually from workplace conditions, compassion fatigue can develop rapidly from exposure to clients' traumatic material. Vicarious traumatization (Pearlman & Saakvitne) refers to cumulative changes in the therapist's inner experience resulting from empathic engagement with clients' traumatic material, potentially affecting the therapist's sense of safety, trust, esteem, intimacy, and control.
[003] Psychologists have an ethical obligation to monitor their own functioning and to seek appropriate help when personal problems may interfere with professional competence (Standard 2.06). Self-care strategies include maintaining work-life balance, seeking peer support and consultation, engaging in personal therapy when needed, practicing stress management techniques, maintaining clear professional boundaries, and engaging in regular self-assessment.
[004] When psychologists become aware of personal problems that may interfere with their professional duties, they take appropriate measures such as obtaining professional consultation or assistance, and determine whether they should limit, suspend, or terminate their work-related duties. This standard creates an affirmative obligation to self-monitor and act proactively. Failure to address personal problems that impair professional functioning is itself an ethical violation.

anchors.text: Impairment refers to a decline in professional functioning that compromises the quality of care provided to clients. Common sources of impairment include substance abuse, mental health disorders, personal crises (divorce, bereavement), burnout, and age-related cognitive decline. Most state licensing boards have impaired practitioner programs that provide confidential assessment, treatment, and monitoring as an alternative to disciplinary action, provided the psychologist voluntarily seeks help.

Colleagues who become aware of another psychologist's impairment face an ethical obligation under Standard 1.04 (Informal Resolution of Ethical Violations) and Standard 1.05 (Reporting Ethical Violations). The preferred approach is to first attempt informal resolution by bringing the concern directly to the psychologist's attention. If informal resolution is inappropriate or unsuccessful, a report to the state licensing board or relevant ethics committee may be necessary.
Burnout — Emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, reduced accomplishment from chronic workplace stress — Develops gradually; related to organizational factors
Compassion Fatigue — Emotional toll from working with traumatized clients — Can develop rapidly; related to trauma exposure
Vicarious Traumatization — Changes in therapist's cognitive schemas from empathic engagement with trauma — Cumulative; affects worldview (safety, trust, control)
Countertransference — Therapist's emotional reactions to the client — Specific to individual client; can be informative if managed
Impairment — Decline in functioning that compromises client care — Triggers ethical and legal obligations; may require reporting

anchors.text: The original version presents 9 geometric designs one at a time; the examinee copies each design onto blank paper
The Bender-Gestalt II updated the instrument with 16 designs, modern norms (ages 4-85+), and supplemental tests (motor and perception tests)
Administration takes approximately 5-10 minutes for the copy phase

section_title: Cognitive Screening Instruments: MMSE and MoCA

anchors.text: The MMSE was developed by Folstein, Folstein, and McHugh as a brief screening measure for cognitive impairment, particularly dementia. Key features:
Total score range: 0-30 points
Assesses orientation (time and place), registration, attention and calculation, recall, and language
Traditional cutoff: score of 23/24 suggests possible cognitive impairment
Administration time: approximately 5-10 minutes

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Clinical & Neuropsych Tests > Cognitive Screening Instruments: MMSE and MoCA > Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
anchors_text:
[001] The MMSE was developed by Folstein, Folstein, and McHugh as a brief screening measure for cognitive impairment, particularly dementia. Key features:
[002] Total score range: 0-30 points
[003] Assesses orientation (time and place), registration, attention and calculation, recall, and language
[004] Traditional cutoff: score of 23/24 suggests possible cognitive impairment
[005] Administration time: approximately 5-10 minutes

section_title: Cognitive Screening Instruments: MMSE and MoCA

anchors.text: The MoCA was developed to address the MMSE's limitations in detecting mild cognitive impairment (MCI). It is more sensitive to early cognitive decline than the MMSE.
Total score range: 0-30 points (cutoff of 26 for normal cognition)
Assesses visuospatial/executive, naming, memory, attention, language, abstraction, delayed recall, and orientation
Includes executive function tasks (Trail Making B adaptation, clock drawing) that the MMSE lacks
Better ceiling effect performance: more sensitive to MCI because the MMSE shows ceiling effects in educated individuals

[001] The MoCA was developed to address the MMSE's limitations in detecting mild cognitive impairment (MCI). It is more sensitive to early cognitive decline than the MMSE.
[002] Total score range: 0-30 points (cutoff of 26 for normal cognition)
[003] Assesses visuospatial/executive, naming, memory, attention, language, abstraction, delayed recall, and orientation
[004] Includes executive function tasks (Trail Making B adaptation, clock drawing) that the MMSE lacks
[005] Better ceiling effect performance: more sensitive to MCI because the MMSE shows ceiling effects in educated individuals

anchors.text: The examinee sorts cards according to an unknown rule (color, form, or number)
After each sort, the examiner indicates "right" or "wrong" -- the examinee must infer the sorting rule from feedback
After 10 consecutive correct sorts, the rule changes without warning, and the examinee must shift to the new rule
The test continues until 6 categories are completed or all 128 cards are used

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Clinical & Neuropsych Tests > Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) > Administration
anchors_text:
[001] The examinee sorts cards according to an unknown rule (color, form, or number)
[002] After each sort, the examiner indicates "right" or "wrong" -- the examinee must infer the sorting rule from feedback
[003] After 10 consecutive correct sorts, the rule changes without warning, and the examinee must shift to the new rule
[004] The test continues until 6 categories are completed or all 128 cards are used

anchors.text: Categories completed: Number of sorting categories successfully identified (max = 6)
Perseverative errors: Continuing to sort by a previously correct but now incorrect rule -- the most clinically significant score, sensitive to frontal lobe dysfunction
Perseverative responses: Total responses matching a previously reinforced category
Failure to maintain set: Making an error after 5+ consecutive correct sorts within a category (suggests attentional lapses)

anchors.text: The examinee draws a line connecting numbered circles (1-2-3-4...25) in sequential order as quickly as possible
Primarily measures processing speed, visual scanning, and simple sequencing
Score = time to completion in seconds

Score = time to completion in seconds
Much more sensitive to executive dysfunction than Part A

anchors.text: Category Test: Measures abstract reasoning and concept formation -- the examinee identifies a common principle underlying groups of stimuli (208 stimuli, 7 subtests). Most sensitive test in the battery to brain damage.

Tactual Performance Test (TPT): Blindfolded examinee places blocks into a form board using dominant hand, non-dominant hand, then both hands; followed by memory and localization drawings. Measures tactile perception, psychomotor speed, spatial memory.
Speech Sounds Perception Test: Examinee matches spoken nonsense syllables to printed options. Measures auditory-verbal perception and sustained attention.
Seashore Rhythm Test: Examinee identifies whether pairs of rhythmic patterns are the same or different. Measures nonverbal auditory perception and attention.
Finger Oscillation Test (Finger Tapping): Measures motor speed for each hand separately.
Trail Making Test (Parts A and B): Often considered part of the HRB battery.

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Clinical & Neuropsych Tests > Halstead-Reitan Neuropsychological Battery (HRB) > Core Tests
anchors_text:
[001] Category Test: Measures abstract reasoning and concept formation -- the examinee identifies a common principle underlying groups of stimuli (208 stimuli, 7 subtests). Most sensitive test in the battery to brain damage.
[002] Tactual Performance Test (TPT): Blindfolded examinee places blocks into a form board using dominant hand, non-dominant hand, then both hands; followed by memory and localization drawings. Measures tactile perception, psychomotor speed, spatial memory.
[003] Speech Sounds Perception Test: Examinee matches spoken nonsense syllables to printed options. Measures auditory-verbal perception and sustained attention.
[004] Seashore Rhythm Test: Examinee identifies whether pairs of rhythmic patterns are the same or different. Measures nonverbal auditory perception and attention.
[005] Finger Oscillation Test (Finger Tapping): Measures motor speed for each hand separately.
[006] Trail Making Test (Parts A and B): Often considered part of the HRB battery.

anchors.text: Level of performance: Comparing scores to normative cutoffs
Pattern of performance: Examining the profile of strengths and weaknesses across tests
Right-left comparisons: Comparing performance between the two sides of the body (lateralization)
Pathognomonic signs: Specific indicators (e.g., dysnomia, sensory suppression) that are strongly associated with brain dysfunction

anchors.text: 269 items organized into 11 clinical scales and 3 summary scales
Clinical scales: Motor, Rhythm, Tactile, Visual, Receptive Speech, Expressive Speech, Writing, Reading, Arithmetic, Memory, Intellectual Processes
Summary scales: Pathognomonic (items most sensitive to brain damage), Left Hemisphere, Right Hemisphere
Administration time: approximately 1.5-2.5 hours (shorter than the Halstead-Reitan)

anchors.text: Copy trial: The examinee copies the complex figure while looking at it (no time limit)
Immediate recall: After a brief delay (approximately 3 minutes), the examinee draws the figure from memory
Delayed recall: After approximately 30 minutes, the examinee draws the figure again from memory
Optional: a recognition trial may also be administered

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Clinical & Neuropsych Tests > Rey Complex Figure Test (RCFT) > Administration
anchors_text:
[001] Copy trial: The examinee copies the complex figure while looking at it (no time limit)
[002] Immediate recall: After a brief delay (approximately 3 minutes), the examinee draws the figure from memory
[003] Delayed recall: After approximately 30 minutes, the examinee draws the figure again from memory
[004] Optional: a recognition trial may also be administered

anchors.text: The figure is divided into 18 scorable elements
Each element is scored 0-2 based on accuracy and placement
Maximum score = 36 for each trial
Clinicians also assess the organizational strategy (e.g., does the examinee begin with the overall structure or with details?)

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Clinical & Neuropsych Tests > Rey Complex Figure Test (RCFT) > Scoring
anchors_text:

anchors.text: Copy performance: Impaired copy suggests visuospatial constructional deficits (right hemisphere, parietal lobe dysfunction)
Memory performance: Impaired recall with intact copy suggests visual memory deficits (right temporal or hippocampal dysfunction)
Organizational approach: A piecemeal or fragmented approach to copying (focusing on details rather than the global structure) is associated with executive dysfunction and may also predict poor recall

section_title: Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children, Second Edition (KABC-II)

anchors.text: The KABC-II can be interpreted using either of two frameworks:

Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) model: The default interpretive framework; yields a Fluid-Crystallized Index (FCI) as the global score. Includes five CHC broad abilities: Gc (Crystallized), Gf (Fluid), Gsm (Short-Term Memory), Gv (Visual Processing), Glr (Long-Term Storage and Retrieval).

Luria model: Based on Luria's neuropsychological theory; yields a Mental Processing Index (MPI) that deliberately excludes measures of acquired knowledge (crystallized ability). The Luria model includes Sequential Processing, Simultaneous Processing, Learning, and Planning.

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Other Cognitive Measures > Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children, Second Edition (KABC-II) > Dual Theoretical Model
anchors_text:
[001] The KABC-II can be interpreted using either of two frameworks:
[002] Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) model: The default interpretive framework; yields a Fluid-Crystallized Index (FCI) as the global score. Includes five CHC broad abilities: Gc (Crystallized), Gf (Fluid), Gsm (Short-Term Memory), Gv (Visual Processing), Glr (Long-Term Storage and Retrieval).
[003] Luria model: Based on Luria's neuropsychological theory; yields a Mental Processing Index (MPI) that deliberately excludes measures of acquired knowledge (crystallized ability). The Luria model includes Sequential Processing, Simultaneous Processing, Learning, and Planning.

section_title: Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children, Second Edition (KABC-II)
topic_name: When to Use the Luria Model

anchors.text: The Luria/MPI model is recommended when the examiner wants to minimize the influence of language and crystallized knowledge on the global score. This is particularly appropriate for:
Children from non-mainstream cultural or linguistic backgrounds
English Language Learners (ELLs)
Children whose educational opportunities have been limited
Any situation where acquired knowledge may not represent the child's cognitive potential

section_title: Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children, Second Edition (KABC-II)
topic_name: Kaufman Brief Intelligence Test, Second Edition (KBIT-2)

anchors.text: The KBIT-2 is a brief screening measure of verbal and nonverbal intelligence for ages 4-90. It yields three scores:
Verbal Score (Riddles and Verbal Knowledge subtests)
Nonverbal Score (Matrices subtest)
IQ Composite (M = 100, SD = 15)
The KBIT-2 takes approximately 15-30 minutes and is used for screening purposes. It is not a substitute for a comprehensive intelligence test.

anchors.text: Standard Progressive Matrices (SPM): 60 items in 5 sets (A through E) of increasing difficulty. For ages 6 to adult. Most widely used version.
Coloured Progressive Matrices (CPM): Easier version for children ages 5-11 and individuals with cognitive impairment. Uses colored backgrounds to maintain attention.
Advanced Progressive Matrices (APM): More difficult version for above-average adults and adolescents.

[003] Advanced Progressive Matrices (APM): More difficult version for above-average adults and adolescents.

anchors.text: Strengths: Minimal verbal demands; can be administered to non-English speakers; strong measure of Gf and g; widely researched cross-culturally; brief administration

Limitations: Measures only one narrow facet of intelligence (nonverbal reasoning); no verbal, memory, or processing speed components; not a substitute for comprehensive cognitive assessment; still shows cultural effects despite being "nonverbal"

Profile level (A = above average, B = average, etc.)

Profiles are used to suggest differentiated instructional strategies

anchors.text: Culture-fair tests (sometimes called "culture-reduced" tests) attempt to minimize cultural bias without claiming to eliminate it entirely. Strategies include:
Using nonverbal stimuli and response formats
Reducing language demands in both instructions and responses
Using abstract geometric or figural content rather than content tied to specific cultural knowledge
Providing practice items to ensure the examinee understands the task format
Developing norms that include representative samples of diverse populations

[005] Providing practice items to ensure the examinee understands the task format

anchors.text: Best available research evidence -- includes meta-analyses, RCTs, effectiveness studies, single-case designs, qualitative research, and clinical observation. The hierarchy typically places systematic reviews and RCTs at the top, but all levels of evidence contribute.

Clinical expertise -- refers to the competencies acquired through education, training, and experience, including assessment skill, diagnostic acumen, case formulation, treatment planning, therapeutic relationship management, and self-reflection.

Patient characteristics, culture, and preferences -- encompasses the client's values, goals, religious beliefs, worldview, cultural identity, socioeconomic context, readiness for change, social support, and treatment preferences.

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Evidence-Based Treatments > The Evidence-Based Practice Model > The Three Components
anchors_text:
[001] Best available research evidence -- includes meta-analyses, RCTs, effectiveness studies, single-case designs, qualitative research, and clinical observation. The hierarchy typically places systematic reviews and RCTs at the top, but all levels of evidence contribute.
[002] Clinical expertise -- refers to the competencies acquired through education, training, and experience, including assessment skill, diagnostic acumen, case formulation, treatment planning, therapeutic relationship management, and self-reflection.
[003] Patient characteristics, culture, and preferences -- encompasses the client's values, goals, religious beliefs, worldview, cultural identity, socioeconomic context, readiness for change, social support, and treatment preferences.

anchors.text: A case formulation is a hypothesis about the causes, precipitants, and maintaining factors of an individual's psychological problems. It goes beyond diagnosis to provide a conceptual framework for treatment. Components typically include:
Presenting problems and their functional impact
Predisposing factors (e.g., developmental history, genetics, early learning)
Precipitating factors (e.g., recent stressors, life transitions)
Perpetuating factors (e.g., avoidance patterns, cognitive distortions, environmental reinforcement)
Protective factors and strengths

[003] Predisposing factors (e.g., developmental history, genetics, early learning)
[004] Precipitating factors (e.g., recent stressors, life transitions)
[005] Perpetuating factors (e.g., avoidance patterns, cognitive distortions, environmental reinforcement)
[006] Protective factors and strengths

anchors.text: Beutler and colleagues developed the Systematic Treatment Selection (STS) model, which identifies patient dimensions that predict differential response to specific treatment characteristics:
Problem complexity / chronicity: More complex or chronic problems may require longer-term, insight-oriented approaches
Coping style: Internalizers (high self-blame) respond better to insight-oriented treatments; externalizers respond better to symptom-focused, skill-building approaches
Resistance level / reactance: Highly resistant clients respond better to nondirective approaches; low-resistance clients respond well to directive approaches
Subjective distress: Moderate distress levels optimize treatment engagement; very low or very high distress may impede progress

[004] Resistance level / reactance: Highly resistant clients respond better to nondirective approaches; low-resistance clients respond well to directive approaches
[005] Subjective distress: Moderate distress levels optimize treatment engagement; very low or very high distress may impede progress

anchors.text: The Transtheoretical Model suggests that interventions should match the client's readiness for change:
Precontemplation: Consciousness-raising, motivational interviewing
Contemplation: Decisional balance, exploring ambivalence
Preparation: Goal setting, commitment enhancement
Action: Behavioral strategies, skill building, contingency management
Maintenance: Relapse prevention, stimulus control, social support

section_title: Common Factors and the Therapeutic Alliance

anchors.text: Bordin's pantheoretical model defines the alliance as consisting of three components:
Agreement on goals: Therapist and client share an understanding of the targets of treatment
Agreement on tasks: Both parties agree on the activities and methods used in therapy
The relational bond: Mutual trust, respect, liking, and attachment between therapist and client

section_title: Common Factors and the Therapeutic Alliance

anchors.text: Empathy: The therapist's ability to understand the client's experience (r = .28 with outcome)
Positive regard / warmth: Unconditional acceptance of the client
Congruence / genuineness: The therapist's authenticity in the relationship
Client expectations (placebo/hope): The client's belief that therapy will help

GAD-7: 7-item measure of generalized anxiety severity

anchors.text: Howard et al. proposed the dose-effect model, which suggests a log-linear relationship between the number of therapy sessions and improvement. Key findings:
Approximately 50% of clients show clinically significant improvement by session 8
Approximately 75% improve by session 26
There are diminishing returns with additional sessions, though some clients require longer treatment
The rate of improvement is fastest in the earliest sessions (negatively accelerating curve)

anchors.text: Congruence: People are most satisfied and productive when their personality type matches their work environment (e.g., an Artistic person in an Artistic job)

Consistency: Some type combinations are more related to each other (adjacent on the hexagon, e.g., RI or SE) than others (opposite, e.g., RA or SC). Consistent profiles are more stable and predictable.

Differentiation: A person who strongly resembles one type and little resembles others is well-differentiated. A flat profile (similar scores across all types) is undifferentiated and harder to interpret.
Identity: The clarity and stability of a person's goals, interests, and talents
Calculus: The hexagonal arrangement reflects the relationships among the types -- adjacent types are most similar; opposite types are most different

[002] Consistency: Some type combinations are more related to each other (adjacent on the hexagon, e.g., RI or SE) than others (opposite, e.g., RA or SC). Consistent profiles are more stable and predictable.
[003] Differentiation: A person who strongly resembles one type and little resembles others is well-differentiated. A flat profile (similar scores across all types) is undifferentiated and harder to interpret.
[004] Identity: The clarity and stability of a person's goals, interests, and talents
[005] Calculus: The hexagonal arrangement reflects the relationships among the types -- adjacent types are most similar; opposite types are most different

anchors.text: The six GOTs correspond directly to Holland's RIASEC types. They provide the broadest level of information about an individual's interests.
Scores are reported as standard scores with a mean of 50 and SD of 10
Scores are compared to a combined-gender or same-gender reference group
The GOT profile provides the Holland code (e.g., ISA, SEC) used to identify congruent occupations

The 30 Basic Interest Scales provide more specific information within each GOT. For example, within the Investigative theme, separate BIS scores are provided for Science, Mathematics, and Medical Science.
BIS scores help differentiate within a broad interest area
Also reported as standard scores (M = 50, SD = 10)
Useful for identifying specific activity clusters within a general theme

The 260 Occupational Scales are the most specific level. Each scale was developed using the criterion keying (empirical method) approach -- comparing the item responses of individuals employed in a specific occupation with those of a general reference sample.
A high score on an occupational scale indicates that the examinee's pattern of interests is similar to that of satisfied workers in that occupation
Scores are reported as standard scores (M = 50, SD = 10) for each occupation
Separate male and female norms are available for each occupational scale

Learning Environment (prefers academic/practical learning)

Risk Taking (prefers adventure and risk vs. caution and safety)
Team Orientation (prefers working as part of a team vs. independently)

anchors.text: The SDS consists of four sections: Activities (liked/disliked), Competencies (can/cannot do), Occupations (appealing/not), and Self-Estimates (self-rated abilities)
Each section yields scores for all six RIASEC types
The three highest scores form the individual's three-letter Holland code (called the Summary Code)
The code is then used with the Occupations Finder or Dictionary of Holland Occupational Codes to identify matching occupations

anchors.text: Strengths: Self-administered and quick (20-30 minutes); cost-effective for group use; strong theoretical foundation; well-validated
Limitations: Less detailed than the Strong; self-scoring can lead to errors; relies heavily on self-estimates that may be biased; less useful for individuals with undifferentiated profiles

anchors.text: Each item presents three activities, and the examinee selects the most preferred and least preferred
This forced-choice format reduces the tendency toward acquiescence (saying "like" to everything) or social desirability
Scores are ipsative (within-person comparisons) rather than normative (compared to a reference group)

Nature (aligns with Realistic)
Science/Technical (aligns with Investigative)
Art/Communication (aligns with Artistic)
Social/Personal Services (aligns with Social)
Influence/Sales (aligns with Enterprising)
Organization/Management (aligns with Conventional)

anchors.text: Concurrent validity: Individuals in a given occupation tend to score highest on the corresponding scale
Predictive validity: Interest scores measured in adolescence or young adulthood predict occupational choice years later at moderate levels (r ~ .30-.40)
Hit rates: The Strong correctly predicts occupational group membership in approximately 50% of cases over long follow-up periods
