anchors.text: Interest inventories are most useful when combined with other sources of information in a comprehensive career counseling process:

Interests + abilities: High interest without corresponding aptitude may lead to frustration; high aptitude without interest may lead to dissatisfaction. Comprehensive career assessment evaluates both.

Interests + values: Work values (e.g., autonomy, financial security, altruism) add a dimension beyond what interest inventories measure. Instruments like the Work Values Inventory can supplement interest results.
Interests + personality: Personality measures (e.g., NEO-PI-R, MBTI) can help explain why certain interests exist and how they might manifest in different work environments.
Interests + developmental context: Consider the client's age, life stage, career development stage (Super's Life-Span model), and prior work experiences when interpreting interest profiles.

[004] Interests + personality: Personality measures (e.g., NEO-PI-R, MBTI) can help explain why certain interests exist and how they might manifest in different work environments.
[005] Interests + developmental context: Consider the client's age, life stage, career development stage (Super's Life-Span model), and prior work experiences when interpreting interest profiles.

anchors.text: Original MMPI: Hathaway and McKinley developed the instrument at the University of Minnesota using empirical criterion keying -- items were selected based on their ability to discriminate between clinical groups and normals, not based on item content

MMPI-2: Butcher, Dahlstrom, Graham, Tellegen, and Kaemmer restandardized the instrument with a more representative normative sample (N = 2,600). Item content was updated but the clinical scales were preserved. Uniform T-scores were introduced.

MMPI-2-RF: Ben-Porath and Tellegen restructured the instrument using factor analysis, creating 51 scales organized hierarchically. The 10 clinical scales were replaced by Restructured Clinical (RC) scales.
MMPI-3: Ben-Porath and Tellegen further revised the RF, with updated norms, revised items, and modernized content. 335 items, 52 scales.

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > MMPI-2/MMPI-3 > Overview of the MMPI Family > Historical Development
anchors_text:
[001] Original MMPI: Hathaway and McKinley developed the instrument at the University of Minnesota using empirical criterion keying -- items were selected based on their ability to discriminate between clinical groups and normals, not based on item content
[002] MMPI-2: Butcher, Dahlstrom, Graham, Tellegen, and Kaemmer restandardized the instrument with a more representative normative sample (N = 2,600). Item content was updated but the clinical scales were preserved. Uniform T-scores were introduced.
[003] MMPI-2-RF: Ben-Porath and Tellegen restructured the instrument using factor analysis, creating 51 scales organized hierarchically. The 10 clinical scales were replaced by Restructured Clinical (RC) scales.
[004] MMPI-3: Ben-Porath and Tellegen further revised the RF, with updated norms, revised items, and modernized content. 335 items, 52 scales.

anchors.text: The validity scales assess the test-taking attitude and response style of the examinee. They must be evaluated before interpreting the clinical scales.
? (CNS) — Cannot Say — Number of items left unanswered. More than 30 unanswered items invalidates the profile.
L — Lie — Naive, unsophisticated attempts to present oneself in a favorable light. Denying common human faults. Elevated L = "faking good" or rigid/moralistic personality.
F — Infrequency — Items endorsed by fewer than 10% of the normative sample. Elevated F = "faking bad," exaggeration, random responding, severe psychopathology, or a "cry for help."
K — Defensiveness — More sophisticated defensiveness than L. Moderate K = healthy self-presentation; very high K = denial/defensiveness; very low K = excessive openness or self-criticism.
Fb — Back F — Infrequency items from the second half of the test. Detects changes in response style partway through administration.
VRIN — Variable Response Inconsistency — Pairs of items with similar or opposite content; inconsistent responding suggests random or careless responding.
TRIN — True Response Inconsistency — Pairs of items where answering both True or both False is contradictory. Detects acquiescence (yea-saying) or nay-saying bias.

Fp — Infrequency-Psychopathology — Items infrequently endorsed even by psychiatric inpatients. Helps distinguish genuine severe psychopathology (F elevated, Fp normal) from overreporting (both elevated).
S — Superlative Self-Presentation — Items reflecting an extremely positive self-view; supplement to L and K for detecting underreporting.

[004] F — Infrequency — Items endorsed by fewer than 10% of the normative sample. Elevated F = "faking bad," exaggeration, random responding, severe psychopathology, or a "cry for help."
[005] K — Defensiveness — More sophisticated defensiveness than L. Moderate K = healthy self-presentation; very high K = denial/defensiveness; very low K = excessive openness or self-criticism.
[006] Fb — Back F — Infrequency items from the second half of the test. Detects changes in response style partway through administration.
[007] VRIN — Variable Response Inconsistency — Pairs of items with similar or opposite content; inconsistent responding suggests random or careless responding.
[008] TRIN — True Response Inconsistency — Pairs of items where answering both True or both False is contradictory. Detects acquiescence (yea-saying) or nay-saying bias.
[009] Fp — Infrequency-Psychopathology — Items infrequently endorsed even by psychiatric inpatients. Helps distinguish genuine severe psychopathology (F elevated, Fp normal) from overreporting (both elevated).
[010] S — Superlative Self-Presentation — Items reflecting an extremely positive self-view; supplement to L and K for detecting underreporting.

anchors.text: 1 — Hypochondriasis — Hs — Excessive somatic concern, vague physical complaints, pessimism, demanding
2 — Depression — D — Depressed mood, psychomotor retardation, hopelessness, social withdrawal
3 — Hysteria — Hy — Somatic complaints with denial of psychological problems, need for attention, naive/superficial
4 — Psychopathic Deviate — Pd — Antisocial behavior, rebelliousness, family conflict, impulsivity, authority problems
5 — Masculinity-Femininity — Mf — Interests differing from traditional gender roles; interpretation depends on gender and context
6 — Paranoia — Pa — Suspiciousness, sensitivity, hostility, rigidity, paranoid ideation, persecutory beliefs
7 — Psychasthenia — Pt — Anxiety, obsessive-compulsive features, guilt, self-doubt, indecisiveness, rumination
8 — Schizophrenia — Sc — Bizarre thinking, social alienation, unusual perceptions, poor reality testing, confusion
9 — Hypomania — Ma — Elevated mood, grandiosity, hyperactivity, impulsivity, flight of ideas, irritability
0 — Social Introversion — Si — Social withdrawal, shyness, discomfort in social situations; low scores = extroversion

anchors.text: Clinical scales use Uniform T-scores (developed by Auke Tellegen) to ensure comparable percentile rankings across scales
T-score of 65 or above is considered clinically significant (93rd percentile)
T-scores between 60-64 are marginally elevated
Scales 5 (Mf) and 0 (Si) use linear T-scores rather than uniform T-scores because their distributions are close to normal

4-6 / 6-4 (Pd-Pa) — Hostile, blaming, passive-aggressive; interpersonal conflict; projects responsibility onto others
8-9 / 9-8 (Sc-Ma) — Severe disturbance; possible mania with psychotic features; agitation, grandiosity, disorganization

anchors.text: Validity Scales (9): CNS, VRIN-r, TRIN-r, F-r, Fp-r, Fs, FBS-r, L-r, K-r
Higher-Order (H-O) Scales (3): Emotional/Internalizing Dysfunction (EID), Thought Dysfunction (THD), Behavioral/Externalizing Dysfunction (BXD)

Restructured Clinical (RC) Scales (9): The core interpretive scales RCd: Demoralization (general unhappiness/distress) RC1: Somatic Complaints RC2: Low Positive Emotions RC3: Cynicism RC4: Antisocial Behavior RC6: Ideas of Persecution RC7: Dysfunctional Negative Emotions RC8: Aberrant Experiences RC9: Hypomanic Activation
Specific Problems (SP) Scales (23): Provide detailed information within domains (e.g., Head Pain Complaints, Stress/Worry, Juvenile Conduct Problems)
Interest Scales (2): Aesthetic-Literary Interests, Mechanical-Physical Interests

Personality Psychopathology Five (PSY-5) Scales (5): Aggressiveness-Revised, Psychoticism-Revised, Disconstraint-Revised, Negative Emotionality/Neuroticism-Revised, Introversion/Low Positive Emotionality-Revised

anchors.text: Evaluate validity scales: Determine whether the profile is valid and interpretable. Check CNS, VRIN, TRIN, F, L, K, Fb, Fp, S
Examine overall profile elevation: Look at how many scales are elevated above 65T
Identify code type: Determine the two or three highest clinical scales and look up the corresponding code type interpretation
Examine individual scale elevations: Consider the meaning of each elevated scale
Review Harris-Lingoes subscales: Clarify what content is driving clinical scale elevations
Examine content and supplementary scales: Use additional scales (e.g., Anxiety, Depression, Addiction Acknowledgment) to refine interpretation
Integrate with clinical data: Combine MMPI results with interview, history, behavioral observation, and other test data

Scores are reported as sten scores (standard ten scores, M = 5.5, SD = 2, range 1-10)

Validity indices: Invalidity, Inconsistency, Disclosure, Desirability, Debasement

anchors.text: Uses Base Rate (BR) scores rather than T-scores
BR scores are anchored to the prevalence (base rate) of each disorder in clinical populations
BR score of 75 = presence of the trait/syndrome; BR score of 85 = prominence (clinically significant)
This approach accounts for the fact that different disorders have different base rates in clinical settings

anchors.text: The Comprehensive System standardized Rorschach administration, scoring, and interpretation by integrating elements from earlier systems (Beck, Klopfer, Hertz, Piotrowski, Rapaport).
Administration: Two phases -- Response Phase (free association to each card) and Inquiry Phase (examiner clarifies what and where the examinee saw each percept)

Scoring categories: Location (W = whole, D = common detail, Dd = unusual detail), Determinants (form, color, shading, movement), Content (human, animal, anatomy, etc.), Popular responses, Organizational Activity (Z-scores)
Structural Summary: A quantitative compilation of all coded scores, including ratios, percentages, and derived indices
Erlebnistypus (EB): Ratio of human movement (M) to weighted color responses (WSumC) -- reflects whether the individual is introverted (M > WSumC), extraverted (WSumC > M), or ambitent
Lambda (L): Ratio of pure form responses to all other responses -- high Lambda suggests avoidant, simplistic approach to complexity
X-% and X+%: Measures of perceptual accuracy (reality testing). X+% = conventional form quality; X-% = distorted form quality. Elevated X-% suggests impaired reality testing.
SCZI / PTI (Perceptual-Thinking Index): Identifies thought disorder and perceptual distortion associated with psychotic processes
DEPI (Depression Index): Identifies features associated with affective disturbance
S-CON (Suicide Constellation): Risk index for suicidal behavior (one of the best-validated indices)

anchors.text: The R-PAS was developed to address psychometric criticisms of the CS. Key improvements include:
Standardized response process: Prompts examinees to give 2-3 responses per card (reduces variability in number of responses)
International normative reference data (more diverse than CS norms)
Evidence-based variable selection (retained variables with the strongest empirical support; dropped poorly validated ones)
Standard score profiles (similar to MMPI profiles) for easier interpretation
Updated scoring guidelines and reduced complexity

anchors_text:

[002] Standardized response process: Prompts examinees to give 2-3 responses per card (reduces variability in number of responses)
[003] International normative reference data (more diverse than CS norms)
[004] Evidence-based variable selection (retained variables with the strongest empirical support; dropped poorly validated ones)
[005] Standard score profiles (similar to MMPI profiles) for easier interpretation
[006] Updated scoring guidelines and reduced complexity

anchors.text: The TAT is based on Murray's need-press theory. Responses are interpreted in terms of:
Needs: Internal drives and motives of the protagonist (who is assumed to represent the examinee)
Press: Environmental forces acting on the protagonist (reflecting the examinee's perceived environment)
Thema: The interaction between needs and press -- the story's central conflict and resolution

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Personality Measures > Thematic Apperception Test (TAT) > Theoretical Basis
anchors_text:

[002] Needs: Internal drives and motives of the protagonist (who is assumed to represent the examinee)
[003] Press: Environmental forces acting on the protagonist (reflecting the examinee's perceived environment)
[004] Thema: The interaction between needs and press -- the story's central conflict and resolution

anchors.text: The TAT lacks a universally accepted scoring system, which is a major psychometric limitation
Notable systems include: Murray's need-press analysis, Bellak's system, McClelland's need for achievement (nAch) scoring, Westen's SCORS (Social Cognition and Object Relations Scale)

SCORS (Westen): The best-validated TAT scoring system; assesses complexity of representations of people, affective quality of relationships, emotional investment in relationships, and understanding of social causality

anchors.text: Rotter Incomplete Sentences Blank (RISB): 40 stems scored on a 7-point scale from positive adjustment (0-1) to maladjustment (4-6). Yields a total adjustment score. Has adequate psychometric support.

anchors.text: Linear T-scores: Direct transformation of raw scores (preserves original distribution shape). Used on MMPI-2 Scales 5 and 0.
Normalized T-scores: Raw scores are first transformed to percentile ranks, then converted to T-scores based on the normal distribution. This forces the distribution into a normal shape.

Uniform T-scores: Used on most MMPI-2 clinical scales. A method developed by Tellegen that ensures the percentile value of a given T-score is the same across all scales, even though the raw score distributions differ.

[002] Normalized T-scores: Raw scores are first transformed to percentile ranks, then converted to T-scores based on the normal distribution. This forces the distribution into a normal shape.
[003] Uniform T-scores: Used on most MMPI-2 clinical scales. A method developed by Tellegen that ensures the percentile value of a given T-score is the same across all scales, even though the raw score distributions differ.

Percentile ranks are ordinal, not interval -- equal differences in percentiles do NOT represent equal differences in ability
Percentile ranks are compressed near the mean (where most scores cluster) and stretched at the extremes

anchors.text: Used to evaluate whether therapeutic interventions produced meaningful change
Used in neuropsychological re-evaluation to determine whether cognitive decline is beyond what measurement error would predict
Provides an objective criterion for "reliable" change rather than relying on arbitrary cutoffs

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Score Interpretation > Reliable Change Index (RCI) > Clinical Application
anchors_text:
[001] Used to evaluate whether therapeutic interventions produced meaningful change
[002] Used in neuropsychological re-evaluation to determine whether cognitive decline is beyond what measurement error would predict
[003] Provides an objective criterion for "reliable" change rather than relying on arbitrary cutoffs

anchors.text: A student who scores very high on a test is likely to score somewhat lower on retest (and vice versa) -- not because their ability changed, but because the extreme score was partly due to random error in the favorable direction
Regression to the mean is more pronounced when reliability is lower (more error variance) and when the initial score is more extreme
This effect must be considered when evaluating treatment outcomes: improvement from an extremely low baseline may partly reflect regression to the mean rather than true treatment effects

The estimated true score = M + rxx(X - M), where M = population mean, rxx = reliability, and X = observed score. This formula shows that the estimated true score is always closer to the mean than the observed score (regressed toward the mean by a factor of the reliability coefficient)

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Score Interpretation > Regression to the Mean > Key Implications
anchors_text:
[001] A student who scores very high on a test is likely to score somewhat lower on retest (and vice versa) -- not because their ability changed, but because the extreme score was partly due to random error in the favorable direction
[002] Regression to the mean is more pronounced when reliability is lower (more error variance) and when the initial score is more extreme
[003] This effect must be considered when evaluating treatment outcomes: improvement from an extremely low baseline may partly reflect regression to the mean rather than true treatment effects
[004] The estimated true score = M + rxx(X - M), where M = population mean, rxx = reliability, and X = observed score. This formula shows that the estimated true score is always closer to the mean than the observed score (regressed toward the mean by a factor of the reliability coefficient)

anchors.text: Age equivalent: The age at which the individual's raw score is the average performance. A 7-year-old with an age equivalent of 9:6 performs like the average 9-year-6-month-old.
Grade equivalent: The grade level at which the individual's raw score is the average. A 4th grader with a grade equivalent of 6.2 performs like the average student in the 2nd month of 6th grade.
Both are ordinal scales and are widely criticized because they are often misinterpreted (e.g., a 2nd grader with a grade equivalent of 5.0 in math does not necessarily know 5th-grade math content)
Age and grade equivalents should not be used for comparison across different tests or subtests

section_title: Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale - Fourth Edition (WAIS-IV)

anchors.text: Similarities: How are two words alike? Measures verbal abstract reasoning and concept formation
Vocabulary: Define words. Measures word knowledge, verbal expression, and crystallized ability
Information: General knowledge questions. Measures breadth of acquired knowledge and long-term memory
Comprehension (supplemental): Social judgment questions. Measures practical reasoning and social knowledge

Block Design: Replicate patterns using red-and-white blocks within time limits. Measures visual-spatial analysis, construction, and nonverbal problem-solving. Often considered the best single nonverbal measure of g.
Matrix Reasoning: Select the missing element from a visual pattern. Measures fluid reasoning with minimal motor demands
Visual Puzzles: Identify pieces that combine to form a target design. Measures visual-spatial reasoning
Figure Weights (supplemental): Quantitative fluid reasoning using visual balance scale
Digit Span: Three conditions -- Forward (attention, short-term memory), Backward (working memory, mental manipulation), and Sequencing (working memory, cognitive flexibility)
Arithmetic: Mental math problems. Measures working memory, attention, and numerical reasoning
Symbol Search: Visual scanning task -- does the target symbol match any in the row? Measures processing speed and visual discrimination
Coding: Transcribe symbol-number pairs using a key. Measures processing speed, visual-motor coordination, and incidental learning

anchors.text: The GAI is composed of VCI + PRI subtests only, excluding WMI and PSI. It provides an estimate of general intellectual ability that is less influenced by processing speed and working memory. The GAI is useful when:
WMI or PSI scores are significantly lower than VCI/PRI (e.g., in ADHD, TBI, or processing disorders)
The clinician wants to estimate cognitive ability without the confound of processing speed deficits

anchors.text: The SB5 uses a unique routing procedure to establish the appropriate starting point for each subtest. Two routing subtests are administered first:
Nonverbal Fluid Reasoning (first nonverbal routing subtest)
Vocabulary (first verbal routing subtest)

These routing subtests determine the functional level (starting item set) for the remaining subtests, ensuring that the examinee is tested at an appropriate difficulty level and reducing floor/ceiling effects.

[002] Nonverbal Fluid Reasoning (first nonverbal routing subtest)
[003] Vocabulary (first verbal routing subtest)
[004] These routing subtests determine the functional level (starting item set) for the remaining subtests, ensuring that the examinee is tested at an appropriate difficulty level and reducing floor/ceiling effects.

anchors.text: The SB5 has a broader age range (2-85+) than any single Wechsler scale
The SB5 measures each factor in both verbal and nonverbal domains (the Wechsler scales do not systematically do this)
The SB5 uses a routing procedure; the Wechsler scales use age-based starting points
The SB5 has a wider score range (extended IQ from 40 to 160), which is useful at the extremes
The Wechsler scales generally have more subtests and offer more detailed clinical information within each domain

anchors.text: Fluid Intelligence (Gf): The ability to reason, solve novel problems, and identify patterns without relying on previously acquired knowledge. Largely biologically determined. Peaks in young adulthood and declines with age.

Crystallized Intelligence (Gc): Accumulated knowledge, vocabulary, and skills acquired through education and experience. Largely culturally and educationally influenced. Continues to grow throughout the lifespan (or at least remains stable into late life).

full_path: Domain 8: Clinical Assessment & Interpretation > Wechsler & Stanford-Binet > Factor Structure and CHC Theory > Gf vs. Gc
anchors_text:
[001] Fluid Intelligence (Gf): The ability to reason, solve novel problems, and identify patterns without relying on previously acquired knowledge. Largely biologically determined. Peaks in young adulthood and declines with age.
[002] Crystallized Intelligence (Gc): Accumulated knowledge, vocabulary, and skills acquired through education and experience. Largely culturally and educationally influenced. Continues to grow throughout the lifespan (or at least remains stable into late life).

section_title: Standard 5: Advertising and Other Public Statements
topic_name: 5.01: Avoidance of False or Deceptive Statements

anchors.text: Psychologists do not knowingly make public statements that are false, deceptive, or fraudulent concerning their research, practice, or other work activities. This prohibition applies to:
Training, experience, or competence
Academic degrees and credentials
Institutional or association affiliations
Services offered and their scientific or clinical basis
Publications or research findings

Psychologists do not make false, deceptive, or fraudulent statements concerning the degree of success of their services, and they claim only degrees as credentials that were earned from regionally accredited educational institutions or that are the basis for psychology licensure.

Example: A psychologist advertises a "95% success rate" for treating anxiety disorders without any empirical basis for this claim. This violates Standard 5.01 because it is a deceptive statement about the degree of success of services. Vague or unsubstantiated claims of effectiveness are prohibited.

[002] Training, experience, or competence

[004] Institutional or association affiliations
[005] Services offered and their scientific or clinical basis
[006] Publications or research findings
[007] Psychologists do not make false, deceptive, or fraudulent statements concerning the degree of success of their services, and they claim only degrees as credentials that were earned from regionally accredited educational institutions or that are the basis for psychology licensure.
[008] Example: A psychologist advertises a "95% success rate" for treating anxiety disorders without any empirical basis for this claim. This violates Standard 5.01 because it is a deceptive statement about the degree of success of services. Vague or unsubstantiated claims of effectiveness are prohibited.

section_title: Standard 5: Advertising and Other Public Statements

anchors.text: Psychologists who engage others to create or place public statements that promote their professional practice retain professional responsibility for such statements. If psychologists learn of deceptive statements about their work made by others, they make reasonable efforts to correct such statements.
Psychologists do not compensate employees of press, radio, television, or other communication media in return for publicity in a news item.
A paid advertisement must be identified as such.

section_title: Standard 5: Advertising and Other Public Statements
topic_name: 5.03: Descriptions of Workshops and Non-Degree-Granting Educational Programs

anchors.text: Psychologists responsible for workshops, seminars, and other non-degree programs ensure that descriptions are accurate regarding:
The target audience
Educational objectives
The presenters and their qualifications
Fees and any prerequisites

anchors.text: When psychologists provide public advice or comment via print, internet, mail, television, radio, or other electronic media, they take precautions to ensure that statements are:
Based on appropriate psychological literature and practice
Consistent with the Ethics Code
Not indicative of a professional relationship with the recipient

section_title: Standard 5: Advertising and Other Public Statements

anchors.text: Psychologists do not solicit testimonials from current therapy clients or other persons who, because of their particular circumstances, are vulnerable to undue influence. This reflects the power differential in the therapy relationship and the potential for coercion, even if unintentional.

The prohibition on soliciting testimonials applies to current therapy clients and others vulnerable to undue influence. The standard does not explicitly prohibit testimonials from former clients, but careful ethical analysis is warranted because former clients may remain vulnerable to the influence of their former therapist.

[002] The prohibition on soliciting testimonials applies to current therapy clients and others vulnerable to undue influence. The standard does not explicitly prohibit testimonials from former clients, but careful ethical analysis is warranted because former clients may remain vulnerable to the influence of their former therapist.

section_title: Standard 5: Advertising and Other Public Statements

anchors.text: Psychologists do not engage, directly or through agents, in uninvited in-person solicitation of business from actual or potential therapy clients or other persons who, because of their particular circumstances, are vulnerable to undue influence. This does not prohibit:
General marketing or advertising that is not targeted at vulnerable individuals
Providing disaster relief or community outreach services
Responding to individuals who initiate contact seeking services

anchors.text: Fluoxetine — Prozac — Longest half-life (~2-6 days; active metabolite norfluoxetine ~4-16 days); approved for children/adolescents with depression; less risk of discontinuation syndrome
Sertraline — Zoloft — Mild dopamine reuptake inhibition; commonly prescribed for PTSD; considered safe in cardiac patients
Paroxetine — Paxil — Most anticholinergic of the SSRIs; short half-life leading to higher discontinuation risk; associated with weight gain; NOT recommended in pregnancy (Category D)
Citalopram — Celexa — Most selective SSRI; dose-dependent QT prolongation risk; FDA max dose 40 mg/day
Escitalopram — Lexapro — S-enantiomer of citalopram; may have fewer drug interactions; commonly used for generalized anxiety disorder
Fluvoxamine — Luvox — Primarily used for OCD; significant drug-drug interactions via CYP enzymes

anchors.text: Sexual dysfunction (decreased libido, anorgasmia, erectile dysfunction) -- most common reason for discontinuation
Gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, diarrhea)
Headache, insomnia, or drowsiness
Weight gain (especially paroxetine) or weight loss
Increased anxiety initially (may worsen before improving)
Discontinuation syndrome with abrupt cessation (dizziness, nausea, "brain zaps," irritability)

anchors.text: Venlafaxine — Effexor — At low doses, primarily serotonergic; norepinephrine effects emerge at higher doses; may increase blood pressure; significant discontinuation syndrome
Duloxetine — Cymbalta — FDA-approved for MDD, GAD, fibromyalgia, diabetic neuropathic pain, and chronic musculoskeletal pain; hepatotoxicity risk (avoid in liver disease)
Desvenlafaxine — Pristiq — Active metabolite of venlafaxine; fewer drug interactions; simpler dosing
Levomilnacipran — Fetzima — Greater selectivity for norepinephrine than serotonin; may be more activating

anchors.text: Amitriptyline — Elavil — Highly sedating; used for chronic pain and migraine prophylaxis; most anticholinergic TCA
Imipramine — Tofranil — First TCA discovered; used for enuresis in children; panic disorder
Nortriptyline — Pamelor — Active metabolite of amitriptyline; less sedating; therapeutic window for blood levels

[002] Imipramine — Tofranil — First TCA discovered; used for enuresis in children; panic disorder
[003] Nortriptyline — Pamelor — Active metabolite of amitriptyline; less sedating; therapeutic window for blood levels
[004] Clomipramine — Anafranil — Most serotonergic TCA; first-line pharmacotherapy for OCD
[005] Desipramine — Norpramin — Most noradrenergic TCA; least sedating; less anticholinergic

anchors.text: Anticholinergic effects (dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, blurred vision, tachycardia) -- remember "can't see, can't pee, can't spit, can't sh*t"
Sedation (due to histamine blockade)
Orthostatic hypotension (due to alpha-1 blockade)
Cardiac toxicity -- fatal in overdose due to cardiac arrhythmias (QT prolongation, heart block). This is why TCAs are dangerous in suicidal patients.
Lowered seizure threshold

TCAs are lethal in overdose due to cardiac arrhythmias. This is a critical clinical consideration and a frequently tested EPPP fact. For this reason, TCAs are prescribed cautiously (if at all) to patients with suicidal ideation. A one-week supply of TCAs can be lethal in overdose.

anchors.text: MAOIs inhibit the enzyme monoamine oxidase, which normally breaks down serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine. By inhibiting this enzyme, MAOIs increase the availability of all three monoamines.
MAO-A preferentially metabolizes serotonin and norepinephrine
MAO-B preferentially metabolizes dopamine (selegiline, used in Parkinson's disease, is selective for MAO-B at low doses)

anchors.text: Patients taking MAOIs must follow strict dietary restrictions to avoid tyramine-containing foods. Tyramine is normally broken down by MAO in the gut. When MAO is inhibited, tyramine accumulates and causes the release of large amounts of norepinephrine, leading to a potentially fatal hypertensive crisis (severe headache, rapid heart rate, stiff neck, nausea, stroke, death).
Foods to avoid while taking MAOIs include:
Aged cheeses (cheddar, Swiss, parmesan, blue cheese)
Cured or smoked meats (salami, pepperoni, smoked fish)
Fermented foods (sauerkraut, kimchi, soy sauce)
Draft beer, red wine
Broad (fava) beans
Certain dietary supplements and over-the-counter cold medications containing pseudoephedrine or phenylephrine

anchors.text: Mechanism: Norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI); does NOT affect serotonin
Uses: Depression, smoking cessation (marketed as Zyban), ADHD (off-label)
Advantages: No sexual dysfunction (may actually improve libido); no weight gain (may cause weight loss); activating rather than sedating
Risks: Lowers seizure threshold (contraindicated in patients with seizure disorders, eating disorders, or those undergoing abrupt alcohol withdrawal); may increase anxiety

anchors.text: Mechanism: Noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA); blocks alpha-2 autoreceptors (increasing NE and 5-HT release) and 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors; potent H1 antagonist
Uses: Depression, especially with insomnia, poor appetite, or weight loss
Side effects: Significant sedation and weight gain (due to H1 blockade); increased appetite; useful when these "side effects" are actually therapeutic goals
Advantages: Minimal sexual dysfunction; helpful for nausea (5-HT3 blockade)

anchors.text: Mechanism: Serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor (SARI)
Uses: Primarily used as a sleep aid at low doses; antidepressant at higher doses (rarely used this way due to sedation)
Side effects: Sedation, orthostatic hypotension, priapism (rare but serious -- prolonged painful erection requiring emergency treatment)

anchors.text: Cognitive/behavioral changes: Agitation, confusion, hypomania, restlessness
Autonomic instability: Hyperthermia, tachycardia, diaphoresis (sweating), diarrhea, fluctuating blood pressure
Neuromuscular abnormalities: Tremor, myoclonus (muscle jerking), hyperreflexia, rigidity, clonus
Treatment: Discontinue all serotonergic agents; supportive care; cyproheptadine (a serotonin antagonist) may be used in severe cases; benzodiazepines for agitation.

anchors.text: Fever (hyperthermia, often >40C/104F)
Encephalopathy (altered mental status, confusion, delirium)
Vitals unstable (autonomic instability: tachycardia, labile blood pressure, diaphoresis)
Elevated enzymes (elevated creatine phosphokinase/CPK from muscle breakdown)
Rigidity (severe "lead pipe" muscle rigidity)

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Antipsychotics > Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) > Clinical Features of NMS (mnemonic: FEVER)
anchors_text:
[001] Fever (hyperthermia, often >40C/104F)
[002] Encephalopathy (altered mental status, confusion, delirium)
[003] Vitals unstable (autonomic instability: tachycardia, labile blood pressure, diaphoresis)
[004] Elevated enzymes (elevated creatine phosphokinase/CPK from muscle breakdown)
[005] Rigidity (severe "lead pipe" muscle rigidity)

anchors.text: Immediate discontinuation of the antipsychotic
Supportive care (cooling, IV fluids, cardiac monitoring)
Dantrolene (muscle relaxant) for rigidity
Bromocriptine (dopamine agonist) to restore dopaminergic activity
Benzodiazepines may be used adjunctively

Example: Both involve hyperthermia and altered mental status, but NMS features lead-pipe rigidity and develops over days, while serotonin syndrome features hyperreflexia, clonus, and myoclonus and develops within hours. NMS is caused by dopamine blockade; serotonin syndrome by serotonin excess.

anchors.text: Clozapine — Clozaril — Gold standard for treatment-resistant schizophrenia; lowest EPS risk; most effective for refractory positive and negative symptoms; also reduces suicidality in schizophrenia. SERIOUS RISK: agranulocytosis (1-2%) requiring mandatory blood monitoring (weekly for 6 months, then biweekly, then monthly)
Risperidone — Risperdal — Higher EPS risk than other atypicals at higher doses (dose-dependent D2 blockade); significant prolactin elevation; available as long-acting injectable (Risperdal Consta)
Olanzapine — Zyprexa — Highest risk of weight gain and metabolic syndrome; structurally similar to clozapine; effective but metabolic concerns limit use
Quetiapine — Seroquel — Very sedating at lower doses; used off-label for insomnia and anxiety; lower EPS risk; less prolactin elevation
Ziprasidone — Geodon — Weight-neutral; lowest metabolic risk among atypicals; QT prolongation concern; should be taken with food for absorption
Aripiprazole — Abilify — Partial dopamine agonist (D2 partial agonist); stabilizes dopamine activity; low EPS, low metabolic risk, low sedation; may cause akathisia
Lurasidone — Latuda — Must be taken with food (350+ calories); lower metabolic risk; approved for bipolar depression

Key facts to know: Clozapine = treatment-resistant schizophrenia + agranulocytosis risk + mandatory blood monitoring. Olanzapine = worst metabolic side effects. Aripiprazole = unique partial D2 agonist mechanism. Risperidone = highest prolactin elevation among atypicals.

anchors.text: Diazepam — Valium — Long-acting — Rapid onset; used for anxiety, seizures, muscle spasms, alcohol withdrawal; active metabolites prolong effects
Lorazepam — Ativan — Intermediate — No active metabolites; safe in liver impairment; commonly used in acute agitation; IM administration well-absorbed
Alprazolam — Xanax — Short-acting — Most commonly prescribed benzodiazepine; high abuse potential; significant rebound anxiety; commonly used for panic disorder
Clonazepam — Klonopin — Long-acting — Used for panic disorder, seizures, social anxiety; longer duration reduces interdose rebound
Chlordiazepoxide — Librium — Long-acting — Historically used for alcohol withdrawal protocols; first benzodiazepine synthesized
Triazolam — Halcion — Ultra-short — Used as a hypnotic (sleep aid); risk of anterograde amnesia; very short half-life

[006] Triazolam — Halcion — Ultra-short — Used as a hypnotic (sleep aid); risk of anterograde amnesia; very short half-life

anchors.text: Rapid onset of action (minutes to hours), unlike antidepressants which take weeks
Tolerance and dependence develop with chronic use; benzodiazepines should generally be prescribed for short-term use
Withdrawal can be medically dangerous (seizures, delirium); must be tapered gradually, never stopped abruptly
Cross-tolerance exists with alcohol and barbiturates (all act on GABA receptors)
Benzodiazepines are respiratory depressants; combined with opioids or alcohol, the risk of fatal respiratory depression increases significantly
Older adults are at increased risk for falls, cognitive impairment, and paradoxical reactions (agitation, disinhibition)

Flumazenil is the specific benzodiazepine antagonist used to reverse benzodiazepine overdose. It competitively blocks the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor. Caution: it can precipitate seizures in patients with benzodiazepine dependence.

anchors.text: These drugs inhibit the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which breaks down acetylcholine, thereby increasing acetylcholine availability in the brain. They are used for mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease.
Donepezil — Aricept — Most commonly prescribed; once-daily dosing; approved for all stages of Alzheimer's; relatively well-tolerated
Rivastigmine — Exelon — Available as a transdermal patch (reduces GI side effects); also inhibits butyrylcholinesterase; approved for Parkinson's disease dementia
Galantamine — Razadyne — Also modulates nicotinic acetylcholine receptors
Common side effects: Nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, decreased appetite, dizziness, bradycardia (all related to increased cholinergic activity).

anchors.text: Mechanism: NMDA receptor antagonist; blocks excessive glutamate activity (thought to protect against excitotoxicity)
Uses: Moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease; often used in combination with a cholinesterase inhibitor
Side effects: Generally well-tolerated; dizziness, headache, constipation, confusion

Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) work by increasing acetylcholine and are used for mild to moderate Alzheimer's. Memantine is an NMDA antagonist used for moderate to severe Alzheimer's. These drugs slow symptom progression but do NOT cure or reverse the disease.

anchors.text: Psychologists provide opinions only after they have conducted an examination of the individual adequate to support their statements or conclusions. When a personal examination is not practical, psychologists document the efforts they made and the results of those efforts, clarify the probable impact of their limited information on the reliability and validity of their opinions, and appropriately limit the nature and extent of their conclusions or recommendations.

A frequent EPPP scenario: A psychologist is asked to provide a diagnosis or custody recommendation based solely on record review (without examining the individual). Standard 9.01 does not prohibit this, but requires the psychologist to clearly state the limitations and restrict conclusions accordingly. When a personal examination is not practical, the psychologist must document this and qualify their opinions.

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Assessment (Std 9) > Standard 9.01: Bases for Assessments > 9.01(a) -- Sufficient Information
anchors_text:
[001] Psychologists provide opinions only after they have conducted an examination of the individual adequate to support their statements or conclusions. When a personal examination is not practical, psychologists document the efforts they made and the results of those efforts, clarify the probable impact of their limited information on the reliability and validity of their opinions, and appropriately limit the nature and extent of their conclusions or recommendations.
[002] A frequent EPPP scenario: A psychologist is asked to provide a diagnosis or custody recommendation based solely on record review (without examining the individual). Standard 9.01 does not prohibit this, but requires the psychologist to clearly state the limitations and restrict conclusions accordingly. When a personal examination is not practical, the psychologist must document this and qualify their opinions.

anchors.text: Psychologists use assessment instruments whose validity and reliability have been established for the specific purpose and population. When assessing individuals from populations not represented in the normative sample, psychologists must consider cultural, linguistic, and individual factors that may affect interpretation and clearly note these limitations in reports.

Example: A psychologist administers an intelligence test normed on English-speaking Americans to a recent immigrant whose first language is Spanish. The psychologist must note the cultural and linguistic limitations of the assessment, consider using instruments validated for Spanish speakers, and avoid drawing definitive conclusions about intellectual ability based on the potentially biased results.

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Assessment (Std 9) > Standard 9.02: Use of Assessments > 9.02(b) -- Outdated Norms and Cultural Factors
anchors_text:

When assessing individuals from populations not represented in the normative sample, psychologists must consider cultural, linguistic, and individual factors that may affect interpretation and clearly note these limitations in reports.
[002] Example: A psychologist administers an intelligence test normed on English-speaking Americans to a recent immigrant whose first language is Spanish. The psychologist must note the cultural and linguistic limitations of the assessment, consider using instruments validated for Spanish speakers, and avoid drawing definitive conclusions about intellectual ability based on the potentially biased results.

anchors.text: When services are court ordered or otherwise mandated, psychologists inform the individual of the nature of the anticipated services, including whether the services are court ordered or mandated and any limits of confidentiality, before proceeding.

Court-ordered assessments still require notification -- the psychologist must tell the individual about the nature of services and limits of confidentiality, even though the person cannot refuse the assessment. Informed consent is modified but not eliminated in mandated evaluations.

[002] Court-ordered assessments still require notification -- the psychologist must tell the individual about the nature of services and limits of confidentiality, even though the person cannot refuse the assessment. Informed consent is modified but not eliminated in mandated evaluations.

anchors.text: In the absence of a client release, psychologists provide test data only as required by law or court order.

Test data (9.04) = the client's responses, scores, and behavioral observations -- generally released to the client upon request. Test materials (9.11) = the test itself (questions, stimuli, manuals, scoring keys) -- protected from release to maintain test security. This distinction is frequently tested on the EPPP.

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Assessment (Std 9) > Standard 9.04: Release of Test Data > 9.04(b) -- Absent Client Release
anchors_text:

[002] Test data (9.04) = the client's responses, scores, and behavioral observations -- generally released to the client upon request. Test materials (9.11) = the test itself (questions, stimuli, manuals, scoring keys) -- protected from release to maintain test security. This distinction is frequently tested on the EPPP.

section_title: Standard 9.08: Obsolete Tests and Outdated Test Results

anchors.text: Psychologists do not base decisions or recommendations on tests and measures that are obsolete and not useful for the current purpose.

Example: A psychologist continuing to use the WISC-III for a cognitive evaluation when the WISC-V is available would potentially violate Standard 9.08, as the older version has outdated norms that may not accurately represent current population characteristics. There may be exceptions (e.g., research comparing results across versions), but for clinical purposes the most current edition should be used.

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Assessment (Std 9) > Standard 9.08: Obsolete Tests and Outdated Test Results > 9.08(b) -- Outdated Instruments
anchors_text:
[001] Psychologists do not base decisions or recommendations on tests and measures that are obsolete and not useful for the current purpose.
[002] Example: A psychologist continuing to use the WISC-III for a cognitive evaluation when the WISC-V is available would potentially violate Standard 9.08, as the older version has outdated norms that may not accurately represent current population characteristics. There may be exceptions (e.g., research comparing results across versions), but for clinical purposes the most current edition should be used.

anchors.text: Test security concerns must be balanced against clients' rights to access their own data (9.04). The distinction between test data (which can be released to clients) and test materials (which should be protected) is critical. For example:
A client may receive their scores and responses (test data)
A client should not receive the test manual, scoring key, or stimulus materials (test materials)
When test data are intertwined with test materials (e.g., a response booklet that includes test questions), the psychologist must use professional judgment to balance client rights with test security

anchors_text:

[002] A client may receive their scores and responses (test data)
[003] A client should not receive the test manual, scoring key, or stimulus materials (test materials)
[004] When test data are intertwined with test materials (e.g., a response booklet that includes test questions), the psychologist must use professional judgment to balance client rights with test security

anchors.text: Psychologists provide services in areas in which they have established competence through education, training, supervised experience, consultation, study, or professional experience. Competence is typically demonstrated through:
Graduate coursework in the specific area
Supervised clinical or research experience
Postdoctoral training or specialty fellowships
Continuing education in the specific domain
Peer consultation and supervision

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Competence (Std 2) > Standard 2.01: Boundaries of Competence > 2.01(a) -- Education, Training, and Experience

[001] Psychologists provide services in areas in which they have established competence through education, training, supervised experience, consultation, study, or professional experience. Competence is typically demonstrated through:
[002] Graduate coursework in the specific area
[003] Supervised clinical or research experience
[004] Postdoctoral training or specialty fellowships
[005] Continuing education in the specific domain
[006] Peer consultation and supervision

anchors.text: When psychologists wish to provide services in areas where recognized professional standards do not yet exist, they take reasonable steps to ensure the competence of their work and to protect clients, students, and others from harm. This provision acknowledges that psychology is an evolving field.

Example: A psychologist trained in cognitive-behavioral therapy wants to begin providing telepsychology services. Under 2.01(b), the psychologist should obtain training in telehealth best practices, learn the relevant technology, understand the legal requirements of interstate practice, and seek consultation from colleagues experienced in telepsychology before beginning.

Ethical and legal standards — Research and evaluation
Individual and cultural diversity — Supervision and teaching
Interdisciplinary systems — Management and administration

anchors.text: When psychologists become aware of personal problems that may interfere with their performing work-related duties adequately, they take appropriate measures such as:
Obtaining professional consultation or assistance
Determining whether they should limit, suspend, or terminate work-related duties
Seeking personal therapy
Taking a leave of absence if necessary

EPPP questions about impaired psychologists test whether you know that the ethical response involves the psychologist taking responsibility for their own impairment. The first step is self-awareness; the second is taking appropriate corrective action (consultation, therapy, limiting practice). Colleagues who become aware of an impaired psychologist should attempt informal resolution (Standard 1.04) by speaking to the psychologist directly.

anchors.text: These are related but distinct concepts:
Defined by the Ethics Code and professional standards — Defined by state statutes and licensing regulations
Based on individual training, education, and experience — Based on the profession's legally permitted activities
Self-assessed and regulated by professional norms — Externally imposed by law and regulation
Can be narrower than scope of practice — Sets the outer boundary of permitted practice

Example: A state's scope of practice for psychologists may include neuropsychological assessment. However, a psychologist trained only in clinical therapy has not established individual competence in neuropsychological assessment, even though it falls within the profession's legal scope of practice. The psychologist should not perform neuropsychological assessments without obtaining appropriate training.

anchors.text: Psychologists do not require students to disclose personal information in course- or program-related activities regarding:
History of abuse and neglect
Psychological treatment
Relationships with parents, peers, and spouses or significant others

Exception: Such disclosure may be required if (a) the program clearly identified this requirement in its admissions materials, or (b) the information is necessary to evaluate or obtain assistance for students whose personal problems could reasonably be judged to be preventing them from performing competently or posing a threat to others.

anchors.text: When a program requires individual or group therapy as part of its training, students are permitted to select the therapist from practitioners unaffiliated with the program. Faculty who are or are likely to be responsible for evaluating students' academic performance do not themselves provide that therapy.

Standard 7.05 is often tested: If a program mandates personal therapy, students must be able to choose their own therapist from outside the program. A faculty member who evaluates the student should NEVER be that student's therapist, as this creates an impermissible dual relationship.

anchors.text: The five General Principles guide psychologists toward ethical ideals. For the EPPP, memorize each principle and know that they are aspirational, not enforceable.

A: Beneficence and Nonmaleficence — Do good; do no harm — Psychologists strive to benefit those with whom they work and guard against factors that might lead to misuse of influence. They manage personal, financial, social, organizational, or political factors that could lead to harm.

B: Fidelity and Responsibility — Trust, professional responsibility — Psychologists establish relationships of trust, are aware of their responsibilities to society and the communities they serve, and consult with colleagues to prevent unethical conduct. They donate a portion of professional time for little or no compensation (pro bono).

C: Integrity — Honesty, truthfulness — Psychologists seek to promote accuracy, honesty, and truthfulness. They do not steal, cheat, or engage in fraud, subterfuge, or intentional misrepresentation of fact. They keep promises and avoid unwise or unclear commitments.

D: Justice — Fairness, equal access — Psychologists recognize that fairness and justice entitle all persons to access the contributions of psychology and to equal quality in processes, procedures, and services. They exercise reasonable judgment and take precautions to ensure bias does not lead to unjust practices.

E: Respect for People's Rights and Dignity — Autonomy, privacy, diversity — Psychologists respect the dignity and worth of all people and the rights of individuals to privacy, confidentiality, and self-determination. They are aware of cultural, individual, and role differences including those based on age, gender, race, ethnicity, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, disability, language, and socioeconomic status.

A common EPPP question format presents a scenario and asks which General Principle applies. Remember: Principle B (Fidelity and Responsibility) is the one that mentions pro bono work and concern for colleagues' ethical behavior. Principle D (Justice) specifically addresses fairness and bias.

anchors.text: The Canadian Psychological Association's four-principle model ranks ethical principles hierarchically when they conflict:
Respect for the Dignity of Persons (highest priority)
Responsible Caring
Integrity in Relationships
Responsibility to Society (lowest priority)

Unlike the APA Ethics Code (which does not rank its General Principles), the Canadian Code explicitly prioritizes principles so that when two principles conflict, the higher-ranked principle takes precedence.

anchors.text: A psychologist refrains from entering into a multiple relationship if the relationship could reasonably be expected to:
Impair the psychologist's objectivity, competence, or effectiveness, or
Risk exploitation of or harm to the person with whom the professional relationship exists

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Human Relations (Std 3) > Standard 3.05: Multiple Relationships > When Multiple Relationships Are Prohibited
anchors_text:
[001] A psychologist refrains from entering into a multiple relationship if the relationship could reasonably be expected to:
[002] Impair the psychologist's objectivity, competence, or effectiveness, or
[003] Risk exploitation of or harm to the person with whom the professional relationship exists

anchors.text: The Ethics Code acknowledges that multiple relationships that would not reasonably be expected to cause impairment or risk exploitation or harm are not unethical. This is an important nuance for the EPPP.

A boundary crossing is a deviation from standard clinical practice that is not harmful and may even be therapeutic (e.g., attending a client's graduation, brief self-disclosure, accepting a small culturally appropriate gift). A boundary violation is a deviation that exploits or harms the client (e.g., entering a sexual relationship, engaging in a business partnership). Not all boundary crossings become violations.

[002] A boundary crossing is a deviation from standard clinical practice that is not harmful and may even be therapeutic (e.g., attending a client's graduation, brief self-disclosure, accepting a small culturally appropriate gift). A boundary violation is a deviation that exploits or harms the client (e.g., entering a sexual relationship, engaging in a business partnership). Not all boundary crossings become violations.

anchors.text: If a potentially harmful multiple relationship has arisen due to unforeseen factors, the psychologist takes reasonable steps to resolve it with due regard for the best interests of the affected person and maximal compliance with the Ethics Code. Strategies include:
Documenting the situation and the steps taken to address it
Consulting with colleagues
Discussing the situation openly with the client (when appropriate)
Referring the client to another provider if the relationship cannot be managed ethically
Increasing supervision or oversight

Example: A psychologist in a rural community discovers that a new therapy client is the parent of a child on the psychologist's daughter's sports team. This creates a social-professional overlap. Because the psychologist is the only provider within 100 miles, referral may not be practical. The ethical response is to carefully manage the boundaries, document the decision-making process, and consult with a colleague about how to minimize potential conflicts.

anchors.text: Lithium remains the gold standard treatment for bipolar disorder, particularly for classic (euphoric) mania. It is also the only mood stabilizer with strong evidence for reducing suicidality.
Mechanism: Not fully understood; may affect second messenger systems (inositol phosphate pathway), modulate neurotransmitter release, and influence gene expression
Therapeutic level: 0.6-1.2 mEq/L (narrow therapeutic index -- levels must be monitored regularly)
Toxicity: Levels above 1.5 mEq/L can be dangerous; above 2.0 mEq/L is a medical emergency
Mild (1.5-2.0): Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, tremor, drowsiness, muscle weakness
Moderate (2.0-2.5): Confusion, ataxia, coarse tremor, fasciculations, dysarthria
Severe (>2.5): Seizures, renal failure, coma, death
Renal: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (polyuria, polydipsia); long-term kidney damage possible
Thyroid: Hypothyroidism (20-30% of patients); monitor TSH regularly
Cardiac: Benign T-wave flattening; rare cardiac conduction issues
Tremor: Fine hand tremor (common); managed with beta-blockers
Teratogenicity: Ebstein's anomaly (cardiac malformation in the fetus); contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy
Dehydration, NSAIDs, and low-sodium diets can increase lithium levels to toxic ranges

Baseline labs before starting lithium include: renal function (BUN, creatinine), thyroid function (TSH), CBC, EKG, and pregnancy test. Lithium levels are drawn 12 hours after the last dose (trough level). Regular monitoring of renal and thyroid function is required throughout treatment.

anchors.text: Mechanism: Increases GABA levels; blocks voltage-gated sodium channels
Uses: Bipolar disorder (especially mixed episodes and rapid cycling), seizure disorders, migraine prophylaxis
Side effects: GI disturbances, weight gain, tremor, hair loss (alopecia), sedation
Serious risks: Hepatotoxicity (liver failure, especially in children under 2); pancreatitis; neural tube defects in pregnancy (spina bifida -- Category X, contraindicated in pregnancy)
Monitoring: Liver function tests, CBC (thrombocytopenia risk), valproate levels

anchors.text: Mechanism: Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels
Uses: Bipolar disorder, seizure disorders, trigeminal neuralgia
Side effects: Dizziness, drowsiness, ataxia, diplopia, nausea
Serious risks: Aplastic anemia and agranulocytosis (requires CBC monitoring); Stevens-Johnson syndrome (severe skin reaction); hepatotoxicity; neural tube defects in pregnancy
Drug interactions: Potent inducer of CYP3A4 enzymes; reduces effectiveness of oral contraceptives and many other medications; also induces its own metabolism (autoinduction)

anchors.text: Mechanism: Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels; modulates glutamate release
Uses: Bipolar disorder maintenance (especially effective for preventing bipolar depression); seizure disorders
Advantages: Does not cause weight gain; may improve cognition; effective for bipolar depression
Serious risk: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (potentially fatal skin reaction); risk is minimized by very slow dose titration; risk increases with rapid titration or concurrent valproate use

Key associations: Lithium = thyroid and kidney monitoring + Ebstein's anomaly. Valproate = hepatotoxicity + neural tube defects + contraindicated in pregnancy. Carbamazepine = aplastic anemia + Stevens-Johnson syndrome + enzyme induction. Lamotrigine = Stevens-Johnson syndrome + slow titration required + best for bipolar depression prevention.

anchors.text: Absorption is the process by which a drug enters the bloodstream from its site of administration. For oral medications (the most common route for psychotropics), the drug must dissolve in the GI tract, cross the intestinal epithelium, and enter the portal circulation.

Oral bioavailability -- the fraction of an orally administered drug that reaches systemic circulation in unchanged form. This is always less than 100% for oral drugs due to incomplete absorption and first-pass metabolism.

First-pass metabolism -- after oral absorption, drugs pass through the liver via the portal vein before reaching systemic circulation. The liver may metabolize a significant portion of the drug on this "first pass," substantially reducing the amount of active drug that reaches the brain. Example: some drugs (e.g., buspirone) have very low oral bioavailability due to extensive first-pass metabolism.
Factors affecting absorption include: drug formulation, gastric pH, food in the stomach, GI motility, and drug-drug interactions at the gut level.

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Pharmacological Foundations & Neurotransmitter Systems > Pharmacokinetics (ADME) > Absorption
anchors_text:
[001] Absorption is the process by which a drug enters the bloodstream from its site of administration. For oral medications (the most common route for psychotropics), the drug must dissolve in the GI tract, cross the intestinal epithelium, and enter the portal circulation.
[002] Oral bioavailability -- the fraction of an orally administered drug that reaches systemic circulation in unchanged form. This is always less than 100% for oral drugs due to incomplete absorption and first-pass metabolism.
[003] First-pass metabolism -- after oral absorption, drugs pass through the liver via the portal vein before reaching systemic circulation. The liver may metabolize a significant portion of the drug on this "first pass," substantially reducing the amount of active drug that reaches the brain. Example: some drugs (e.g., buspirone) have very low oral bioavailability due to extensive first-pass metabolism.
[004] Factors affecting absorption include: drug formulation, gastric pH, food in the stomach, GI motility, and drug-drug interactions at the gut level.

anchors.text: Once absorbed, the drug is distributed throughout the body via the bloodstream. Several factors determine where the drug goes and how much reaches the brain:

Protein binding -- many drugs bind to plasma proteins (primarily albumin). Only the unbound (free) fraction is pharmacologically active, able to cross membranes, and available for metabolism. Drugs with high protein binding (e.g., >95%) may be displaced by other protein-bound drugs, leading to transient increases in the free fraction and potentially toxic effects.

Blood-brain barrier (BBB) -- a selective, semi-permeable barrier formed by tight junctions between brain capillary endothelial cells. Psychotropic medications must cross the BBB to exert their CNS effects. Lipophilic (fat-soluble), small, and uncharged molecules cross more readily. The BBB is the primary reason that many peripherally active drugs do not cause CNS side effects.

Volume of distribution (Vd) -- a theoretical measure of the total body space available to a drug. A large Vd indicates the drug distributes extensively into tissues (e.g., is highly lipophilic); a small Vd indicates it stays mostly in the plasma. Highly lipophilic psychotropics (e.g., diazepam) have large volumes of distribution and may accumulate in adipose tissue.

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Pharmacological Foundations & Neurotransmitter Systems > Pharmacokinetics (ADME) > Distribution
anchors_text:

[002] Protein binding -- many drugs bind to plasma proteins (primarily albumin). Only the unbound (free) fraction is pharmacologically active, able to cross membranes, and available for metabolism. Drugs with high protein binding (e.g., >95%) may be displaced by other protein-bound drugs, leading to transient increases in the free fraction and potentially toxic effects.
[003] Blood-brain barrier (BBB) -- a selective, semi-permeable barrier formed by tight junctions between brain capillary endothelial cells. Psychotropic medications must cross the BBB to exert their CNS effects. Lipophilic (fat-soluble), small, and uncharged molecules cross more readily. The BBB is the primary reason that many peripherally active drugs do not cause CNS side effects.
[004] Volume of distribution (Vd) -- a theoretical measure of the total body space available to a drug. A large Vd indicates the drug distributes extensively into tissues (e.g., is highly lipophilic); a small Vd indicates it stays mostly in the plasma. Highly lipophilic psychotropics (e.g., diazepam) have large volumes of distribution and may accumulate in adipose tissue.

anchors.text: Drug metabolism, primarily occurring in the liver, converts drugs into more water-soluble compounds that can be excreted. Metabolism occurs in two phases:

Phase I reactions -- oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis reactions that introduce or expose a functional group on the drug molecule. The most important Phase I enzymes are the cytochrome P450 (CYP450) family. Phase I reactions may produce active metabolites (e.g., fluoxetine is metabolized to the active metabolite norfluoxetine).

Phase II reactions -- conjugation reactions (glucuronidation, sulfation, acetylation) that attach a large polar group to the drug or its Phase I metabolite, making it highly water-soluble and readily excreted. Phase II metabolites are almost always pharmacologically inactive.

Some drugs (called prodrugs) are inactive when administered and must be metabolized to their active form. Others produce active metabolites that extend the drug's duration of action (e.g., fluoxetine's metabolite norfluoxetine has a half-life of 4-16 days). The distinction between Phase I and Phase II metabolism is commonly tested.

[002] Phase I reactions -- oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis reactions that introduce or expose a functional group on the drug molecule. The most important Phase I enzymes are the cytochrome P450 (CYP450) family. Phase I reactions may produce active metabolites (e.g., fluoxetine is metabolized to the active metabolite norfluoxetine).
[003] Phase II reactions -- conjugation reactions (glucuronidation, sulfation, acetylation) that attach a large polar group to the drug or its Phase I metabolite, making it highly water-soluble and readily excreted. Phase II metabolites are almost always pharmacologically inactive.
[004] Some drugs (called prodrugs) are inactive when administered and must be metabolized to their active form. Others produce active metabolites that extend the drug's duration of action (e.g., fluoxetine's metabolite norfluoxetine has a half-life of 4-16 days). The distinction between Phase I and Phase II metabolism is commonly tested.

anchors.text: Excretion is the removal of drugs and their metabolites from the body. The two primary routes are:

Renal excretion -- the kidneys filter water-soluble metabolites into the urine. This is the primary route for most drug metabolites. Impaired renal function can lead to drug accumulation and toxicity. Lithium, which is not metabolized but excreted entirely by the kidneys, is a critical example -- renal impairment, dehydration, or sodium depletion can cause dangerous lithium accumulation.

Hepatic (biliary) excretion -- some drugs are excreted into bile and eliminated in the feces. Some undergo enterohepatic recirculation, where the drug is reabsorbed from the intestines, effectively prolonging its duration of action.

[002] Renal excretion -- the kidneys filter water-soluble metabolites into the urine. This is the primary route for most drug metabolites. Impaired renal function can lead to drug accumulation and toxicity. Lithium, which is not metabolized but excreted entirely by the kidneys, is a critical example -- renal impairment, dehydration, or sodium depletion can cause dangerous lithium accumulation.
[003] Hepatic (biliary) excretion -- some drugs are excreted into bile and eliminated in the feces. Some undergo enterohepatic recirculation, where the drug is reabsorbed from the intestines, effectively prolonging its duration of action.

anchors.text: Steady state is reached after approximately 5 half-lives of continuous dosing. At steady state, the amount of drug being administered equals the amount being eliminated, and plasma levels plateau.
Similarly, after discontinuation, it takes approximately 5 half-lives for a drug to be essentially eliminated from the body (~97% eliminated).

Half-life determines dosing frequency: drugs with short half-lives (e.g., venlafaxine, ~5 hours) often need twice-daily or extended-release dosing, while drugs with long half-lives (e.g., fluoxetine, ~2-6 days) may be given once daily.

Washout period -- the time needed for a drug to be cleared from the body before starting a new medication (to avoid interactions). This is directly related to half-life. Example: the 5-week washout required when switching from fluoxetine to an MAOI reflects fluoxetine's extremely long half-life (plus its active metabolite norfluoxetine).

anchors.text: Fluoxetine — 2-6 days (metabolite: 4-16 days) — Longest SSRI half-life; lowest risk of discontinuation syndrome; 5-week washout before MAOI
Paroxetine — ~21 hours — Shortest SSRI half-life; highest risk of discontinuation syndrome
Venlafaxine — ~5 hours — Very short; severe discontinuation if missed doses; requires extended-release formulation
Diazepam — 20-100 hours (active metabolite: up to 200 hours) — Long-acting benzo; accumulates with repeated dosing, especially in elderly
Alprazolam — ~11 hours — Short-acting benzo; higher abuse potential; rebound anxiety between doses
Lithium — ~24 hours — Narrow therapeutic index; steady state in ~5 days; blood levels must be monitored

anchors.text: CYP2D6 — Many antidepressants (fluoxetine, paroxetine, venlafaxine), antipsychotics (haloperidol, risperidone), codeine, tamoxifen — Fluoxetine, paroxetine, bupropion, duloxetine — No clinically significant inducers known

CYP3A4 — Benzodiazepines (alprazolam, midazolam), buspirone, carbamazepine, quetiapine, many other drugs (~50% of all medications) — Fluvoxamine, ketoconazole, grapefruit juice, erythromycin — Carbamazepine, phenytoin, St. John's Wort, rifampin
CYP1A2 — Clozapine, olanzapine, duloxetine, theophylline, caffeine — Fluvoxamine, ciprofloxacin — Smoking (tobacco), charbroiled foods, omeprazole
CYP2C19 — Citalopram, escitalopram, diazepam, some TCAs — Fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, omeprazole — Carbamazepine, St. John's Wort

When a CYP450 inhibitor is co-administered with a substrate of that enzyme, the substrate's metabolism is slowed, leading to increased plasma levels and potentially toxicity. When an inducer is added, the substrate is metabolized faster, leading to decreased plasma levels and potentially therapeutic failure. Example: adding fluoxetine (CYP2D6 inhibitor) to a patient on haloperidol (CYP2D6 substrate) will raise haloperidol levels, increasing the risk of EPS and other side effects.

[002] CYP3A4 — Benzodiazepines (alprazolam, midazolam), buspirone, carbamazepine, quetiapine, many other drugs (~50% of all medications) — Fluvoxamine, ketoconazole, grapefruit juice, erythromycin — Carbamazepine, phenytoin, St. John's Wort, rifampin

When an inducer is added, the substrate is metabolized faster, leading to decreased plasma levels and potentially therapeutic failure. anchors.text: Genetic polymorphisms in CYP450 enzymes result in significant variability in how individuals metabolize drugs. This field is known as pharmacogenomics.

Poor metabolizers (PMs) -- have reduced or absent enzyme activity. Drugs metabolized by that enzyme accumulate to higher levels, increasing the risk of side effects and toxicity at standard doses. Example: CYP2D6 poor metabolizers may experience toxic effects from standard doses of codeine (though paradoxically, they may get less analgesic effect from codeine, since codeine requires CYP2D6 conversion to morphine).
Extensive metabolizers (EMs) -- have normal enzyme activity and respond predictably to standard doses.

Ultrarapid metabolizers (UMs) -- have excess enzyme activity due to gene duplication. They metabolize drugs too quickly, resulting in subtherapeutic levels at standard doses. Ultrarapid CYP2D6 metabolizers may convert codeine to morphine too rapidly, leading to opioid toxicity.

Example: The FDA has recommended pharmacogenomic testing for certain drug-gene pairs. For example, CYP2D6 genotyping is recommended before prescribing codeine (risk of ultra-rapid metabolism causing morphine toxicity) and CYP2C19 testing can guide citalopram dosing (poor metabolizers require lower doses).

full_path: Domain 9: Psychopharmacology & Ethics > Pharmacological Foundations & Neurotransmitter Systems > The CYP450 Enzyme System > Pharmacogenomics: Poor vs. Extensive Metabolizers
anchors_text:
[001] Genetic polymorphisms in CYP450 enzymes result in significant variability in how individuals metabolize drugs. This field is known as pharmacogenomics.
[002] Poor metabolizers (PMs) -- have reduced or absent enzyme activity. Drugs metabolized by that enzyme accumulate to higher levels, increasing the risk of side effects and toxicity at standard doses. Example: CYP2D6 poor metabolizers may experience toxic effects from standard doses of codeine (though paradoxically, they may get less analgesic effect from codeine, since codeine requires CYP2D6 conversion to morphine).
[003] Extensive metabolizers (EMs) -- have normal enzyme activity and respond predictably to standard doses.
[004] Ultrarapid metabolizers (UMs) -- have excess enzyme activity due to gene duplication. They metabolize drugs too quickly, resulting in subtherapeutic levels at standard doses. Ultrarapid CYP2D6 metabolizers may convert codeine to morphine too rapidly, leading to opioid toxicity.
[005] Example: The FDA has recommended pharmacogenomic testing for certain drug-gene pairs. For example, CYP2D6 genotyping is recommended before prescribing codeine (risk of ultra-rapid metabolism causing morphine toxicity) and CYP2C19 testing can guide citalopram dosing (poor metabolizers require lower doses).

anchors.text: Most psychotropic medications exert their effects by binding to specific receptors -- protein molecules on cell surfaces or within cells that normally respond to endogenous neurotransmitters or hormones. Key concepts include:

Agonist -- a drug that binds to a receptor and activates it, producing a biological response. It mimics the effect of the endogenous neurotransmitter. Example: benzodiazepines are agonists at the GABA-A receptor (they enhance GABA's effect at the receptor).

Antagonist -- a drug that binds to a receptor and blocks it, preventing activation by the endogenous neurotransmitter. It has affinity for the receptor but no intrinsic activity (efficacy). Example: haloperidol is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist.

Partial agonist -- a drug that binds to and activates a receptor but produces only a submaximal response, even at full receptor occupancy. Partial agonists can act as functional agonists in low-neurotransmitter states and as functional antagonists in high-neurotransmitter states, providing a "stabilizing" effect. Example: aripiprazole is a partial agonist at the D2 receptor; buspirone is a partial agonist at 5-HT1A.

Inverse agonist -- a drug that binds to a receptor and produces an effect opposite to that of an agonist. This is distinct from an antagonist, which simply blocks receptor activation. Some researchers consider certain beta-carbolines to be inverse agonists at the benzodiazepine site on GABA-A receptors (they reduce GABA activity below baseline).

[002] Agonist -- a drug that binds to a receptor and activates it, producing a biological response. It mimics the effect of the endogenous neurotransmitter. Example: benzodiazepines are agonists at the GABA-A receptor (they enhance GABA's effect at the receptor).
[003] Antagonist -- a drug that binds to a receptor and blocks it, preventing activation by the endogenous neurotransmitter. It has affinity for the receptor but no intrinsic activity (efficacy). Example: haloperidol is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist.
[004] Partial agonist -- a drug that binds to and activates a receptor but produces only a submaximal response, even at full receptor occupancy. Partial agonists can act as functional agonists in low-neurotransmitter states and as functional antagonists in high-neurotransmitter states, providing a "stabilizing" effect. Example: aripiprazole is a partial agonist at the D2 receptor; buspirone is a partial agonist at 5-HT1A.
[005] Inverse agonist -- a drug that binds to a receptor and produces an effect opposite to that of an agonist. This is distinct from an antagonist, which simply blocks receptor activation. Some researchers consider certain beta-carbolines to be inverse agonists at the benzodiazepine site on GABA-A receptors (they reduce GABA activity below baseline).

anchors.text: Affinity -- how strongly a drug binds to its receptor. High affinity means the drug binds tightly and at low concentrations. Both agonists and antagonists have affinity.

Efficacy (intrinsic activity) -- the ability of a drug to activate the receptor once bound. Full agonists have high efficacy; partial agonists have intermediate efficacy; antagonists have zero efficacy.
